DOC.HEAD: Election Results Indicate Cesar Gaviria Leads in Presidential Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Gaviria well ahead with 43 percent of vote tallied, details. Picks up 10th graf, `Gaviria acknowledged...'
DOC.TEXT: Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, who wants to eliminate drug trafficking, end government corruption and help the poor, was easily leading in the presidential primary of the governing Liberal Party, according to election results late Monday. Besides the presidential primary, Colombians also chose a congress, mayors, city councilmen and state assemblies in Sunday's elections. Presidential elections take place May 26. With 43 percent of the total vote counted, the National Elections Office said Gaviria had 1,310,000 votes, or 48 percent of the total cast for all six Liberal Party presidential candidates. In second place was former Bogota Mayor Hernando Duran with 636,593 votes, or 23 percent; third was Sen. Ernesto Samper with 488,297 votes, or 18 percent. Vote tallying was delayed because the computer system broke down, and counting proceeded by hand in this South American country of 30 million people. The major radio networks RCN and Caracol said exit polls indicated two former guerrillas won mayoral contests in small towns. Gaviria was campaign manager of Sen. Luis Carlos Galan, a popular presidential candidate who was slain in Bogota last Aug. 18 by drug traffickers. With the only other major contender, the Conservative Party, weakened by infighting and represented by Rodrigo Lloreda, 47, who has failed two previous attempts to be president, there is little doubt Gaviria will be elected. At 43, Gaviria would be Colombia's youngest president ever. The choice of the Liberal Party's presidential candidate was the most important part of the elections as Colombia faces threats from drug traffickers, leftist guerrillas and right wing death squads. Samper and the other Liberal Party contenders for the presidential nomination had indicated they wanted to negotiate with drug traffickers and end the 6-month-old war between drug barons and government security forces. One Liberal Party presidential aspirant, Alberto Santofimio, who took the most vigorous anti-U.S. position, called for an end to the war against traffickers. Gaviria acknowledged late Sunday that his probable victory stemmed from Galan's popularity. He promised to follow Galan's program of attempting to wipe out drug trafficking. However, he suggested he may prefer to try drug traffickers in Colombia rather than send them to the United States for trials, something the traffickers fear greatly. Gaviria also promised to follow Galan's programs for a more equitable justice system, which usually favors the wealthy and influential, and to try to create more schools, jobs, housing, and better living conditions for the poor. Previous Colombian presidents have not given much importance to solving problems of the poor. Failure to face those problems has resulted in rapid growth of leftist guerrilla insurrection. It was the first time the Liberal Party leaders did not choose the presidential candidate. Usually the choice is based upon reports from local powerbrokers who show they can deliver votes. According to exit polls by networks, the Liberal Party appeared to have won 60 percent of the seats in the 313-member congress. The Conservative Party appeared headed for 37 percent of the seats, while leftist parties are expected to win 3 percent, RCN and Caracol said. Currently, congressional seats have a breakdown of 57 percent Liberal and 37 percent Conservative, with the balance held by leftists. Former leftist guerrillas of the April 19 Movement appeared to have won two of the 1,005 mayoral races, RCN and Caracol said. The group, known as the M19, surrendered its weapons last week in an impressive ceremony that marked the first time a guerrilla organization voluntarily ended its violence in Colombia's three decades of armed insurrection. There are five other guerrilla groups, none of which reached peace terms with the government. Juan Caicedo, a Liberal, was elected mayor in the capital Bogota, a city of 6 million people, according to the radio reports. President Virgilio Barco ends his four-year term Aug. 7. By law, he is ineligible to run for a second consecutive term.

DOC.HEAD: Caperton Reports Progress in Meeting With Teachers Unions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with governor saying some progress had been made. Picks up 5th graf pvs, ```It is...'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Gaston Caperton made some progress with union officials Monday in a bid to end West Virginia's first teacher strike, a spokesman said. Earlier in the day, about 1,000 teachers and their supporters rallied at the Capitol, and one county threatened to fire teachers who don't return to work. Caperton met with Kayetta Meadows, president of the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Association, and Bob Brown, president of the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers, behind closed doors for about seven hours. The meeting ended at 11 p.m. Caperton spokesman G.C. Morse said no agreement had been reached to end the strike, but the two sides were closer to a settlement than they have been in the past few days. Morse declined to elaborate on the talks. He said discussions would resume at 7 a.m. Tuesday. Brown would not comment after the meeting, and Meadows said only that she was tired but willing to continue talks. ``It is my hope and desire that we can put aside the harsh words and miscommunications of the past weekend and move on to the resolution of the present predicament,'' Caperton said in a news release issued before the meeting. ``I hope that this discussion will be framed in realistic and practical terms.'' As the meeting continued inside the Capitol, hundreds of teachers clad in red as a sign of solidarity gathered outside under a huge banner reading, ``Governor, Lead Us. Don't Fight Us.'' ``This isn't fun, but it is necessary,'' said Keith Geiger, president of the 2 million-member National Education Association, with which the WVEA is affiliated. ``You must stick together until a resolution is there.'' Teachers went on strike last Wednesday after the governor failed to provide educators with a raise in his 1990-91 proposed budget. By Monday, the strike had spread to 46 of the state's 55 counties, forcing officials in 29 counties to cancel classes for nearly 150,000 of the state's 328,445 pupils. The meeting came after talks between the two sides broke down over the weekend. Leaders of the education association said they had been ready to call off the walkout Saturday, but urged members to remain on strike, accusing the governor of reneging on the terms of a settlement. The teachers said they won't go back to work until the governor promises to call a special legislative session to consider pay raises. The governor said he won't call a special session until the teachers go back to work. Assocation members voted Saturday on a proposal to return to work for 30 days, during which time Caperton would call a special session. But Caperton termed ``a total lie'' any claim that he promised to call such a session. Meadows said the governor gave teachers no choice but to stay on strike. In Greenbrier County in the southeastern section of the state, the Board of Education told striking teachers Monday they would be fired if they didn't return to work by Wednesday. State Attorney General Roger Tompkins said last week the teachers strike is illegal and teachers could be fired or otherwise disciplined. In Jefferson County in the northeast, Circuit Judge Thomas Steptoe issued an injunction ordering county teachers to return to classrooms by Thursday, The county Board of Education asked for the injunction after teachers there voted to go on strike last Thursday. Steptoe said teachers could be fined and held in contempt of court if they didn't return by the deadline. Carolyn Spangler, a spokeswoman for the state board of education, said she knew of no similar action at county or state levels. In Ohio County in the northern panhandle, classes were canceled when officials found most of the district's 47 school buses had flat tires, said Superintendent H. Lawrence Jones. Jones said it was unclear who was responsible. In classrooms and on picket lines, teachers blasted Caperton and the news media, saying a failure to communicate has been a major problem in settling the strike. At Charleston's Capitol High School, only about 400 of the school's 1,300 students showed up for classes. ``I don't like it because we've been wasting our time,'' said Shawna Adkins, a sophomore at Capitol. ``All we do is watch movies, and we can do that at home.''

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Permanent Members Meet on Cambodia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 6 `Hun Sen' to CORRECT Nguyen to Viet foreign minister, sted Cambodian. Picks up `The Khmer...'
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council met privately Monday in their third round of discussions since January on a formula to end the 11-year-old Cambodian civil war. The diplomats from France, the United States, Soviet Union, China and Britain were expected to focus on the failure of a meeting of the four warring factions two weeks ago. In January, the five Security Council members supported large parts of an Australian plan to put Cambodia under U.N. administration until free elections were held. They met again in New York last month. Analysts believe the Australian plan offers the best chance in years of ending the conflict, but the meeting of the combatants in Jakarta, Indonesia, produced no agreement on major issues. Factions involved are the government of Premier Hun Sen, installed by Vietnam, and the resistance coalition of three parties _ the Khmer Rouge, a Communist group that is the strongest guerrilla organization, and non-Communist insurgent forces led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former ruler, and Son Sann, a former premier. Hun Sen and Vietnam's foreign minister, Nguyen Co Thach, said one reason the Jakarta talks failed was the opposition of Khieu Samphan, a Khmer Rouge leader and vice president of the guerrilla coalition, to using the word ``genocide'' to describe Khmer Rouge rule of Cambodia in 1975-78. The Khmer Rouge government led by Pol Pot, killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodia's 8 million people in the process of trying to create a new agrarian society. A Vietnamese invasion in December 1978 overthrew the Pol Pot regime. Australia's plan also is intended to break a deadlock at the 19-nation Paris talks in August, which foundered largely on the question of how power could be shared until election. The Australians suggested sidestepping the question by putting the country under an interim U.N. administration, with peacekeeping forces to police a cease-fire. All factions appear to accept some U.N. role, including election supervision, but there is disagreement over how Cambodia should be governed until the elections are held. Hun Sen and his Vietnamese backers say dismantling his government might open the way for the Khmer Rouge to seize power again. Sihanouk and Son Sann have welcomed the Australian proposal. Khmer Rouge spokesmen have expressed reservations about it, but have not taken a formal position. Under the Australian plan, the former French colony's U.N. seat would be declared vacant until a new government was formed in Phnom Penh after elections. The plan would cost an estimated $987 million for a year and involve 12,190 peacekeepers and outside officials. Attending the Paris talks are Richard Solomon, U.S. undersecretary of state; David Gillmore, undersecretary in the British Foreign Office; Claude Martin, France's director of Asian affairs; Igor Rogachev of the Soviet Union and Xu Dunxin of China, vice ministers of foreign affairs; and Rafeeuden Ahmed, a U.N. assistant secretary-general.

DOC.HEAD: School Teacher Kills Three Family Members, Then Himself
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT man's age to 33, sted 34.
DOC.TEXT: A high school art teacher shot his wife and daughters to death as they slept Monday, then killed himself, authorities said. Grade school principal Dean Collins asked the sheriff's office to check on the family when Joe Pianalto, 33, didn't report for work and his daughters, Annie, 8, and Jennifer, 6, didn't report to school. Sheriff Don Panzer said he found Shirley Pianalto, 35, dead in her bed with a gunshot wound to the back of the head. The children were in their bed, also dead of head wounds. Pianalto's body was behind the girl's bed, a hunting rifle at his side, Panzer said. The teacher's wound appeared to be self-inflicted, the sheriff said. The county coroner, Dr. Leo Meduna, estimated that the deaths occurred between 3 a.m. and 4 a.m. Monday. ``Everybody is just absolutely horrified about what has taken place here,'' Panzer said. ``What we're trying to find out is what possibly could have triggered him to do such a thing.'' The family moved to this north-central Kansas town about 35 miles northwest of Salina three or four years ago. The last homicide in this rural community of about 1,600 people occurred in 1977, when a Missouri fugitive held a couple and their teen-age son hostage for several hours before shooting them and killing himself, Panzer said.

DOC.HEAD: Former CIA Director Raborn Dies
DOC.TEXT: Former CIA Director Francis Raborn Jr., who led development of the Polaris missile as a Navy officer, has died of cardiac arrest at 84. Raborn, a retired Navy vice admiral, was appointed by President Johnson to head the Central Intelligence Agency in 1965. He was succeed by Richard Helms, his deputy, the following year. An aviator, Raborn served aboard aircraft carriers in World War II and commanded the carrier Bennington after the war. In 1955, he was chosen to head Navy missile development and brought in the nuclear-tipped Polaris missile on time and on budget. It was the first solid-fuel long-range missile launchable from a submerged submarine. Raborn died March 6 at Sibley Hospital, according to obituaries published Tuesday. He is survived by his wife, two children and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Haitian Exiles Cheer U.S.-Aided Change, Jeer Avril
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `Area Haitians ...' to CORRECT paper to Sun-Sentinel of Fort Lauderdale.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Deposed Haitian leader Prosper Avril stopped at a U.S. Air Force base Monday before flying to an unknown destination as Haitian exiles cautiously celebrated his ouster and called for his execution. Avril, a lieutenant general, and his family arrived aboard a U.S. C-141 transport plane at Homestead Air Force Base 25 miles south of Miami at 8:20 a.m., and left at 3:30 p.m. Avril departed in ``personally arranged transportation,'' said Maj. Bob Barca, a Homestead spokesman. He declined to comment further. A U.S. government official, speaking on condition he not be identified, said Avril left Florida. Asked if he was flown out, the official responded: ``That would be correct.'' Lt. Col. Darrell Hayes, an Air Force spokesman in Washington, said earlier that Avril was going to be driven to Boca Raton and left ``on his own'' after reaching the affluent Palm Beach County city. But city officials said they were assured by federal officials that Avril wasn't coming there. Area Haitians said Avril's son attended college in Miami until recently and moved to a home west of Boca Raton, the Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale reported Tuesday. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said earlier that Avril indicated he planned to stay in the Miami area ``a few days,'' and that his future was still under discussion. A group of Haitian exiles demonstrated briefly outside the U.S. attorney's office in Miami to call for Avril's indictment. Dozens more gathered outside the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami's Little Haiti neighborhood, listening to radio reporters and speakers. ``Avril Pa Mourin (Avril Isn't Dead!),'' some chanted in Haitian Creole, the French-African language spoken by most Haitians. Most speakers called for Avril's capture, trial in Haiti and execution for allegedly ordering the slayings of civilians and opposition leaders. The crowd became larger and livelier as nightfall neared, but the overall mood seemed more anxious than boisterous after four years of instability and dashed hopes in their Caribbean homeland. The mood contrasted with near-riotous celebrations that broke out on Feb. 7, 1986, when Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled Haiti, ending his family's 29-year rule. ``Everybody is happy, but we are still watching,'' said Pierre Joseph, 30, who said he's been in Florida 10 years. ``Nothing changed yet. Maybe if we have elections, then it will change.'' A dozen Haitians stood vigil outside the Homestead base gates when word began circulating that Avril was on his way. ``We're here to tell him he's not welcome in this society, in this country,'' said exile Jean-Pierre Louis. ``We want him to be tried and imprisoned and even executed like Ceaucescu in Romania.'' Louis said U.S. hospitality for Avril was unwelcome. But the Rev. Gerard Jean-Juste, a longtime, fiery leader in the south Florida exile community that numbers at least 150,000, urged ``cool heads.'' Leading the demonstration outside the U.S. attorney's office, he said Avril should be indicted and jailed on drug charges as was deposed Panama leader Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in federal custody near here since his own arrival at Homestead on Jan. 4. The Haitian military has been linked to shipments of South American cocaine to Florida, but there has been no indication that U.S. authorities might charge Avril. ``As far as any charges are concerned, this office will attempt to bring an indictment if there is sufficient evidence and information to justify it,'' said Diane Cossin, executive assistant to U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen. She suggested anyone with such information turn it over to the Drug Enforcement Administration. Jean-Juste twice this year led demonstrations at Miami International Airport when Avril was in transit during an official visit to Taiwan. The exiles there were ordered by police to disperse after threatening to grab Avril and take him to Little Haiti for a people's trial. ``I am very optimistic this time. I think there are new factors in the equation,'' Jean-Juste said. He said he was most encouraged by the apparent role the U.S. ambassador, State Department and White House played in easing Avril out. Many Haitian exiles have expressed bitterness about U.S. policy toward Haiti and Haitian immigration, which is to consider most Haitians attempting to leave their impoverished nation to be economic refugees and subject to deportation. ``This is a miracle for us to see many of the U.S. officials helping get the rights of the Haitian people,'' Jean-Juste said. He said Haitians were trying to learn more about Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, the Supreme Court judge designated by the opposition coalition to head a provisional civilian government. She had ties to the Duvalier regime, Jean-Juste said, but added, ``If the Haitian people accept her, we will accept her. We will be very cautious.'' He doubted there would be a mass reverse exodus to Haiti if democracy comes. He said Haiti doesn't have the infrastructure to support a surge of returning exiles, most of whom send U.S. dollars home. Jean-Juste said he would encourage exiles to go back temporarily to help, and to take goods not available in Haiti.

DOC.HEAD: Expert Says Toxicologist Can't Tell if Hazelwood Was Drunk
DOC.TEXT: Was Joseph Hazelwood drunk or sober when the Exxon Valdez ran aground? A defense witness said a toxicologist for the prosecution probably can't tell because ``there are too many unknown variables.'' Thomas Burr, an alcohol and drug testing consultant from Minneapolis, noted Monday that Hazelwood underwent only one blood test 10{ hours after the grounding and it is not known whether he drank after the grounding. Burr, called by the defense, criticized conclusions reached by Richard Prouty, an Oklahoma toxicologist who testified Hazelwood probably was drunk when his tanker rammed a jagged reef in the nation's worst oil spill. Prouty used a method known as ``retrograde extrapolation,'' which seeks to determine a person's drunkenness at an earlier hour through backward calculations based on blood tests. But Burr said he's never heard of anyone counting backwards 10{ hours with only one blood test. ``It's very dubious when it's based on a single chemical test,'' he said. ``In my opinion, it's not a valid thing to do forensically especially not for such a long period of time. ... There are too many unknown variables.'' Burr said the method is controversial in the scientific community. Taking Prouty's calculations to their extreme, Burr said they could have shown that Hazelwood had a .30 blood alcohol reading when he boarded the ship, making him unable to walk straight. ``At levels of .30, 100 percent of people are visibly and noticeably intoxicated,'' Burr said. He faced cross-examination today. Witnesses have said Hazelwood was steady on his feet and except for liquor on his breath showed no signs of intoxication after a day ashore in Valdez. There is a conflict in testimony on how much he drank while in town. Earlier Monday, another defense expert witness, Shiras Walker, testified under cross-examination that the grounding of the massive tanker would not have occurred if Hazelwood had stayed on the bridge. But Walker, a former tanker captain, said the skipper's departure to his quarters was not unusual and did not cause the disaster. Walker said if he had things to do below and had an able third mate, he wouldn't hesitate to leave, either. ``I walked several thousand miles in Captain Hazelwood's shoes,'' the experienced seaman said. Ultimately, Walker blamed third mate Gregory Cousins for the wreck. He suggested it was Cousins' job to see that Hazelwood's orders were followed by the helmsman, who failed to carry out the ordered 10-degree right rudder turn. ``Probably anybody above the age of 5 could have carried that out,'' the witness said. If there were problems, Walker said, the third mate had a telephone to call Hazelwood in his cabin. ``All he had to say was, `Captain, come to the bridge,' and this whole thing would have been avoided,'' he testified. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., was the only crew member of the Exxon Valdez charged in the wreck, which spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil. He is accused of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he could receive up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. ``Isn't it true that if Captain Hazelwood was on the bridge where he was supposed to be, this wouldn't have happened?'' Assistant District Attorney Mary Anne Henry asked during cross-examination. ``I might disagree with that `supposed to be' part,'' said Walker. ``But if Captain Hazelwood was on the bridge during those maneuvers, this accident wouldn't have happened.'' But when defense attorney Michael Chalos asked whether he felt Hazelwood's absence from the bridge contributed to the disaster in any way, the witness responded, ``None at all.'' The former captain told jurors the only regulation he knows of requiring a captain to be on the bridge is during passage through the Panama Canal.

DOC.HEAD: White House Endorses Higher-Cost Project
DOC.TEXT: The White House has agreed an $8 billion super collider is ``well worth'' building but taxpayers, not foreign countries, will probably pick up most of the extra $2 billion cost, Deputy Energy Secretary W. Henson Moore said Monday. Moore said the Energy Department does not expect Texas to contribute beyond the $1 billion it has pledged toward building the particle accelerator south of Dallas, and is also not counting on much more foreign help than was expected when the collider's price was $5.9 billion. The department said last year that it expected to finance one-third of the then-$5.9 billion project, which would be the world's largest scientific instrument, through non-federal sources _ $1 billion from Texas and close to another $1 billion from foreign countries. Design changes have since forced the price up as high as $8 billion, Moore said, although the Energy Department won't have a firm figure until July or August. The collider is a 53-miles around tunnel that will whirl beams of protons into each other to test exotic theories on the origin of matter. At a meeting Friday at the White House with Moore, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins and three presidential advisers, it was determined that ``we did not think it was possible to gain more (non-federal money) than what we had contemplated,'' Moore said. ``And so we concluded to that meeting at the White House the increase will be soley borne by the federal government, and there was little chance, if any, of that increase would come from any place else,'' Moore told a news conference. The three advisers at the meeting were John Sununu, White House chief of staff, Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Allan Bromley, assistant to the president for science and technology.

DOC.HEAD: Covenant House Struggles with a Troubled Life _ Its Own
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two years after Covenant House started sheltering children from the streets, the nation's largest program for young runaways is struggling with another troubled life: its own. Torn by allegations of sexual impropriety that forced the resignation of its charismatic founder, the $87 million-a-year operation has postponed some expansion plans and steeled itself for a drop in donations. The scrutiny also has revealed criticism from a new source: social welfare professionals who question its style of service. Critics agree Covenant House helps fill the urgent need of sheltering homeless youths; each night, about 2,000 runaways sleep in its centers in six U.S. cities, Latin America and Canada. But some say Covenant House's main thrust _ short-term stays in institutional settings _ represents triage rather than treatment. Others complain that its Roman Catholic philosophy precludes sex education that could help stem the spread of AIDS. Some critics accuse its counselors of harassing homosexual youths, and others charge the organization with institutional arrogance, saying it virtually ignores other privately operated programs. ``They fill the hallways and then call the press in and say, `There's kids on the floor, we need more money,''' said Marion Reidel, clinical director at the Emergency Shelter, a much smaller program for runaways in New York. ``They're notorious for not networking with the other programs in town.'' Since December, a series of former clients has stepped forward to accuse Covenant House's 62-year-old founder, the Rev. Bruce Ritter, of sexual misconduct. One youth claimed to have received money and gifts from Ritter, and Covenant House has conceded trying to start him off in a new life by giving him the identity of a dead 10-year-old boy, without asking the dead boy's parents. Ritter has denied wrongdoing, but Franciscan officials ordered him to take a leave of absence while they investigated. On Feb. 27, he resigned. The next day, prosecutors said they had found ``questionable financial transactions'' at Covenant House, but none meriting prosecution. Covenant House gets 95 percent of its funds from private donations, relying on appeals written by Ritter and mailed monthly to 800,000 past or potential supporters. Donations fell, recovered and fell again as the allegations surfaced and subsided. Now Covenant House officials are uncertain _ and deeply worried _ about the effect of Ritter's departure. ``There's a real question as to whether Covenant House will be able to grow and expand as it has, or whether Covenant House will be put into a period of retrenchment for some time,'' said Frank Macchiarola, who served briefly as acting president before resigning, also on Feb. 27, because of friction with the organization's board. Covenant House operates large shelters in New York; New Orleans; Houston; Los Angeles; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Anchorage, Alaska; and Toronto, and orphanage-style shelters in Mexico, Honduras, Guatemala and Panama. Plans to establish a shelter in Washington are on hold, but expansions in Los Angeles and New Orleans are proceeding and a counseling center in Dallas just opened. Despite the organization's longstanding practice of spending almost all of each year's income, Covenant House officials said its finances are basically sound and no cutbacks are envisioned. But the criticism of its programs appears likely to continue. ``We have this kind of mixed feeling toward the Covenant House,'' said Fred Griesbach, head of the Coalition for the Homeless. While the rate of AIDS is ``astronomical'' among runaways, Greisbach said, Covenant House does not encourage using condoms to stem the disease's spread but instead counsels abstinence. ``They're not going to deal with it in what I think is a rational way,'' he said. ``We think it's counterproductive. You need to talk about condoms, about abortion, about birth control that goes beyond abstinence.'' Macchiarola said Covenant House's handling of birth control and sex education is guided by principle. ``The policy we follow is church policy,'' he said. ``We have to proceed off what we think is right.'' Covenant House's main purpose is to provide emergency shelter for a few days or weeks to runaways who often return to the street. But critics say smaller, more intensive programs have more success helping youngsters find a new life. ``Young people are supposed to be in a family-type environment,'' Reidel said. ``They're not supposed to be institutionalized. They don't belong in large buildings.'' Covenant House's Manhattan shelter, in tawdry Times Square, fails to remove youngsters from the dangers and temptations of street life and is too big for effective individual counseling, she said. The Manhattan shelter was designed for 250 youths but often sleeps more than 300, some on roll-out pads in lounges. Macchiarola said Covenant House's reluctance to refer youths elsewhere reflects its open-door policy. ``The moment our people think they should refer kids elsewhere is the moment we've taken a different attitude,'' he said. After a brief stay, two-thirds of the shelter's visitors return to the street, where some meet an early death from drugs, disease or violence. The others return to families, find their own place to live or enter long-term residential programs. Covenant House also operates a 150-bed long-term residence in New York, and other organizations run similar, smaller programs. ``And there are advantages to that smallness,'' said Susan Mullgrav, special projects director at the city Department of Youth Services. ``It's more personalized. It's more individualized.'' Yet given the scope of the problem _ with an estimated 100,000 to 300,000 homeless runaway youths nationwide _ Mullgrav and others concede large shelters do fill the most urgent needs: A bed, a meal and someone to talk to. ``Covenant House has been necessary, in spite of their programmatic problems, because they're one of the few agencies that has that number of beds,'' said Reidel. ``It is better than sleeping on the streets.''

DOC.HEAD: Contras Want More Credit for Nicaraguan Transformation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: They fought and suffered. They saw their comrades killed and wounded and their own lives crippled by bullets or bombs. Now they feel their sacrifice and achievement are going unrecognized. ``Dona Violeta talks about everyone but us,'' complained Commandante ``Wilmer,'' a regional chief of the Contra insurgency based in the hills here on the border with Nicaragua. Nicaraguan President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, along with President Daniel Ortega, has called for the Contras to disband. But the Contras want more. They want credit. ``We're the ones who created the conditions for dialogue among the Central American presidents,'' Wilmer said of last year's regional summit meetings. The talks produced Sandinista concessions on early elections and international scrutiny. Wilmer, like other Contras, argues that the Sandinistas made concessions only because they wanted to get rid of the pressure of the Contra resistance. Although U.S.-supported, the current Contra leadership maintains it is a homegrown insurgency that grew out of conditions created by the Sandinistas inside Nicaragua. Mrs. Chamorro, leading a 14-party alliance, trounced Ortega in the Feb. 25 vote that grew out of the peace process. She is to take office April 25. ``We have to be paid the respect due men who have spilled our blood. Each combatant has to know his effort has not been for nothing,'' said Wilmer, who uses only his nom-de-guerre. The Contras were defeated militarily but now feel they deserve credit for what turned out to be a political victory. ``We'll return to Nicaragua when we're respected as combatants, as part of the victory,'' said ``Jackson,'' another young ``commandante.'' Asked what kind of appreciation the Contras want to see from Mrs. Chamorro, Wilmer said they would like to praised in a speech. ``But it can't be limited to just words. The words should be backed up with deeds.'' He said the combatants, most of whom are peasant farmers, are not looking for government positions or handouts. But they will need financial help to rebuild their lives back home. Wilmer, 27 years old and a veteran of nine years of counterrevolution, is a prime example of the new breed of Contra chief. The movement's leadership was overhauled last year at the insistence of men like him, who spent years in the mountains fighting a war that killed an estimated 30,000 people. The business-suited Contra honchos who spent most of their time lobbying in Washington, Miami and Tegucigalpa were pushed out. The field commanders viewed those leaders _ the ones the U.S. public saw posing with Ronald Reagan or testifying in Congress _ for the most part as venal politicians insensitive to the needs and objectives of the fighting man. Wilmer and the members of the revamped command spend most of their time at this sprawling camp, home for the past two years to about 10,000 fighters and 42,000 dependents. A few thousand Contra combatants operate inside Nicaragua, where Wilmer spent several months prior to his return to Yamales in late February. About 3,000 rebel soldiers gathered on a parade ground Thursday to hear an address from Commander ``Ruben,'' the top Contra after chief of staff Israel Galeano, known as ``Franklin.'' Ruben told the troops that in the not-too-distant future, they would parade into Managua to the cheers of a thankful throng. But just when or how the Contras will demobilize, and what will become of them after they do, has emerged as the major stumbling block to a peaceful transition in Nicaragua. The Sandinistas insist the rebel army must disarm and disband before inauguration day. The Contras want none of that. They say they will remain armed and ready to make sure the leftist regime hands over power _ the army and the police forces _ as well as the presidential sash. They also want their safety inside Nicaragua guaranteed. But Honduras wants them out. The United States agrees they must demobilize. And Mrs. Chamorro has limited her contact to an envoy, who in the sleepy Honduran capital of Tegucigalpa declared the president-elect's ``recognition'' of their contribution. It was eminently low profile. ``We are a cancer nobody wants,'' said Galeano early this month. ``There's no confetti and no medals,'' said a U.S. official close to the Contras. ``They sought a military satisfaction and weren't prepared for a political satisfaction, which is more problematical as relates to them.'' The official said Contra leaders complain they are as unappreciated as Vietnam veterans were after that war ended. ``When they say that I always tell them: `But there's a big difference. In this case, your side won.'''

DOC.HEAD: Hussein's Kingdom Moves Quietly Toward Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A year ago, Islamic fundamentalist Ahmed Kofahi had been dismissed as a university teacher and was in prison for criticizing the government. Now he's a member of Parliament. Kofahi is heard regularly in state radio broadcasts of parliamentary debates, excoriating assorted government officials. His progress from prisoner to legislator illustrates the quiet changes Jordan has undergone the past year. ``The atmosphere's different now,'' Kofahi said in an interview. ``We have more freedom, but it's not enough.'' Islamic fundamentalists and leftists who won seats in the November elections are pressing for tough investigations of government corruption, greater social justice and curbs on security agencies. Human rights ``are born before the human is born,'' Kofahi said. ``It's not a gift from a leader or a party or an authority, and not to have these rights is equivalent to death.'' Jordan is bordered to the north and east by Syria and Iraq, whose ruling parties brook little opposition. Kuwait, the most liberal state on the Arabian Peninsula to the south, suspended its parliament in 1987. ``I'm sure the countries surrounding us are not happy about what's going on here,'' said Taher Masri, who resigned from the Cabinet to make a successful run for Parliament. Reform in this kingdom of 3.1 million people, whose western neighbor is Israel, is more orderly and less sweeping than the change revolutionizing Eastern Europe. As in Eastern Europe, however, popular revolt is behind it. Four days of riots last April caused by price increases and other grievances cost 10 lives and shocked King Hussein into action. Hussein, who has ruled since 1953, is relinquishing many powers, but retains firm control and is personally popular. In November, he oversaw Jordan's first general elections since 1967, which were among the freest ever held in the Arab world. The fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood won the largest bloc of seats in the 80-member Parliament. Kofahi, running on the Brotherhood ticket, got more votes than any of the other 650 candidates. Mudar Badran, Hussein's choice for prime minister, underwent an extraordinary grilling by legislators about his personal finances and professional record before winning a vote of confidence. Since last April, the government has freed all prisoners held without charge and dozens convicted of political related crimes. Radicals who once took up arms against Hussein have been allowed to return home, and the pervasive General Intelligence Department has been stripped of its powers to withhold passports and bar people from travel or employment. The government has promised to make officials accountable for corruption. A former undersecretary of the Supply Ministry was arrested last month in a graft investigation. Badran has promised to end martial law, imposed 23 years ago because of the 1967 Middle East war, and appointed lawyers to determine which of the decrees issued during that time should be abolished. He also promised to repeal a 1935 defense law inherited from the British mandate that allows officials to ignore many civil rights. The law now is used more widely in Israel than in Jordan. Although the 33-year-old ban on political parties remains in force, it was ignored during the election campaign. The government says it will legalize parties after a new ``national charter'' of principles is submitted to a referendum, probably this year. Police have not interfered with street demonstrations, which have been few and small. A 1988 decree nationalizing newspapers was canceled and they were returned to their former managers, but government institutions retain majority ownership. ``The government is not involved in any way in restricting the press,'' Information Minister Ibrahim Izzeddine said. All the changes have not been liberal. The victory of Islamic fundamentalists set back campaigns for Western-style women's rights and encouraged censorship on moral grounds. Masri, the former government minister, said he is convinced Hussein ``will not retreat'' from reforms. Jordan has had parliaments since the 1920s. Most were weak, and any that showed signs of independence were suspended. Since 1948, however, Jordan has gone from a land of peasants and nomads with one high school to a nation that nearly equals Sweden in the percentage of young people going to college or technical school. With such an educated population, Masri said: ``You can't hide anything anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Moonshine Giveaway: Old Tradition Dies Hard in N.C. Mountains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The sheriff of this mountain county says he's stopped the old custom of giving away seized moonshine for home remedies since his arrest, even though a grand jury has refused to indict him. ``I ain't done nothing nobody else had done,'' said Madison County Sheriff Dedrick Brown, who was arrested after giving friends six half-gallon jars of ``white lightning'' in front of a state investigator. His supporters, including Republican Gov. Jim Martin, say the practice dates back a century or more and his arrest was politically motivated. The arrest was made by agents of the State Bureau of Investigation, which is headed by a Democrat. Not everyone in Madison County agrees, however, with the grand jury's decision not to indict Brown on charges of destroying criminal evidence. ``If he's crooked enough to give moonshine away in front of somebody, what else is he doing?'' said Eddie Lemin. ``He's in a respected position and he shouldn't be dealing with that stuff. They ought to can him.'' Ann Briggs doesn't like that the sheriff of a dry county was caught giving away alcohol. ``Moonshine is dangerous,'' she said. ``I can't see giving it out for medicinal purposes.'' Brown, 49, says since he took office in 1986 his moonshine recipients have included three Superior Court judges. He would not elaborate. ``As far as I'm concerned, I won't be reopening that tradition,'' said the sheriff, who was arrested on Feb. 9, a month after he seized 25 jugs of corn whiskey in a raid on a still. Brown, an imposing 6-foot-6 with a graying beard, was fingerprinted in his own jail and released. Sam Googe, retired sheriff of nearby Mitchell County, says he gave away moonshine after breaking illegal stills during a 20-year career that began in 1946. ``It's been around as long as I can remember,'' he said. ``The people thought it helped. I hope it did.'' An old-timer in Marshall verified the giveaway custom. ``They've done that ever since I was a boy,'' said 82-year-old Isaac Gunter. ``A spoonful of liquor is the best blood builder there is.'' The governor, who agreed that the arrest smacks of dirty politics, said confiscated whiskey routinely was given to Charlotte hospitals when he was a county commissioner and Davidson College chemistry professor in the 1960s. ``About once every six months, they'd have an accumulated supply of whiskey,'' said Martin. ``They'd check it to see there was no wood alcohol in it _ methanol, which blinds you. And we'd vote to give it to the hospitals, so they could use it for medicinal purposes. Seriously.'' Brown, born and raised in Marshall, which is about 20 miles northwest of Asheville, remembers being given a concoction of honey and corn whiskey when he was sick as a young boy. ``A couple of teaspoons of whiskey every couple of hours helps keep the fever from dropping too fast,'' said Brown, who was fighting a stubborn cold with white-whiskey tea during a recent interview. The sheriff, a Republican who upset longtime Democratic Sheriff E.Y. Ponder in 1986, is up for re-election in November. While he has no GOP opposition in the May primary, three Democrats are running. Brown said the arrest may help him in a county where Democrats outnumber Republicans more than 2-1. ``It was all done to weaken me so they could beat me,'' Brown said. ``Instead, it has given me strength.'' Ponder, 80, the county's Democratic Party leader, denies Brown's allegation that he, too, gave away moonshine during his 34 years as sheriff. ``I never on Earth gave away evidence, or whiskey either,'' Ponder said. And he denies having a role in Brown's arrest: ``If he says or implies that I had anything to do with it, he's either badly misinformed or willfully lying.'' Brown arrested Ponder last year after Ponder shot a man in the back with a shotgun. Ponder, who said the shooting occurred during a scuffle, was not indicted. ``The SBI had evidence that they were nine to 12 feet apart,'' Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Dowdy Bonn Worries About Talk Of Moving Capital To Glamorous Berlin
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Poor Bonn. For 41 years this sleepy city on the banks of the Rhine has been trying to live down its image as one of Europe's least exciting capitals. Now, West Germany's leaders are talking about making Berlin the capital of a united Germany and Bonn residents are worried about the future. ``My customers are politicians and the whole periphery around them _ chauffeurs, secretaries and tourist groups who come to see the government area,'' said Juergen Rausch, whose family has run a newspaper kiosk across from Parliament since West Germany's creation in 1949. Among Rausch's better-known customers are Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. ``The main source of my income would disappear if Bonn were no longer the capital,'' said Rausch. Bonn, birthplace of Beethoven, has many qualities. Farm tractors occasionally clank along major streets in Bonn's suburbs. Barges ply the Rhine and people stroll on pathways along the easy-moving river. It's a homey place in many ways. There's the Maternus restaurant, for example, whose owner drags out photo albums to show customers pictures of some of her famous guests, including Ronald Reagan, Kohl and Genscher. A stone statue of Beethoven broods over Muensterplatz, the city's quiet cobblestoned main square, just a couple blocks away from the colorful daily farmers' market. Bonn University, a former 18th-century palace with majestic onion-shaped domes, is widely respected in the fields of science, political science, history and law. Wolfgang Paul, who shared the Nobel Prize for physics with two others last year, teaches and studies atoms at the university. But it's not fun city. Bonn has never been able to cast off its image as a provincial capital. On Saturday nights, as many say, the nightlife is a 20-minute autobahn drive away in Cologne. ``Bonn is half the size of a Chicago cemetery, and twice as dead,'' goes one old joke. Bonn's image isn't helped much by uninspired government buildings that lack the grandeur of structures in London or Paris. Bonn has 290,000 residents counting politicians, government workers, bureaucrats and diplomats, who live in the city because it is the capital. Berlin, Germany's seat of government from 1871 until 1945, is a vibrant, cosmopolitan city of 1.8 million. Berlin became a key Hanseatic League trading center in the 14th century, and later the seat of powerful Prussian kings. It emerged as a center of German national feeling after the Napoleonic wars and rose to become one of the world's great cities before the 1933 Nazi takeover. Unlike Bonn, Berlin has many famous monuments and architectural treasures, like the former Reichstag building and Brandenburg Gate. Bonn has been a stand-in capital since 1949, with the idea that when German unification occurs Berlin would regain the capital crown it lost as a result of the Third Reich's defeat and Germany's postwar separation. Now, with heady talk of reunification, West Germany's leaders have been saying the capital of a united Germany rightfully belongs in Berlin. ``Berlin is the city in which the heart _ and for which the heart _ of the Germans beats,'' says Genscher. ``The indivisible German nation must also have its heart in the right place _ that is Berlin,'' he recently told the Welt am Sonntag newspaper. A recent poll indicated nearly three-fourths of all West Germans favor installing the capital of a united Germany in Berlin. There have been no similar polls for people in East Germany, whose capital is already East Berlin. Despite the popular support for Berlin as capital, some opposition politicians have said Bonn should retain the title _ partly because of Berlin's past as the center of Hitler's Third Reich. ``For 12 years Berlin was the capital of the brutal Hitler dictatorship,'' says Freimut Duve, federal lawmaker with the opposition Social Democrats. No one has yet formally proposed making Berlin a united Germany's capital. And with all the complications of unification, and Berlin technically still under the control of four foreign powers _ the United States, Britain and France _ making Berlin the capital could take some time. Government officials say billions of dollars of construction and remodeling work already begun in Bonn's government quarter will be completed, but have left open whether plans for further projects will ever get off the ground. Kohl has said he would like to see Berlin the capital again, but hints that Bonn could keep some crucial federal government responsibilities. ``I am for Berlin, but Bonn must keep important functions,'' he was quoted as saying by the Bild newspaper last month. That kind of talk is worrying Bonn boosters. A group of Bonn merchants, self-employed workers and scholars has already launched a ``Yes To Bonn'' lobbying campaign to keep their city as a united Germany's capital. They have been saying that while Berlin is tainted by the Nazi years, West Germany's 41 years of democracy have bloomed in Bonn. West German news media say Bonn could lose nearly half its residents if the capital is moved to Berlin, and real estate prices in Bonn have already begun to slip. Bonn city officials seem to be putting their hopes on hints by Kohl and others that their city won't be completely forsaken. ``We are just at the beginning of the capital city question,'' says Mayor Hans J. Daniels.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Priest Is A 20-Year Kabul Resident _ And Survivor
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Angelo Panigati stood directly under a crucifix when a bomb landed nearby, gutting the Italian Embassy and sending the Roman Catholic priest scurrying for cover. Following his two dogs through a broken pane of glass into his chapel, Panigati took refuge with his pups in a corner. More bombs came, shaking the embassy grounds. On his first Sunday since last week's bloody coup attempt, the 65-year-old ruddy-faced Italian prayed for the afghan people. He appeared to give no thought to his own brush with death. ``I don't believe in miracles,'' said Panigati, who's been in Afghanistan since he was 40. ``But I'm about to.'' His congregation, a gathering of 12, laughed. On Sunday, services were moved to Panigati's living room while the bomb-damaged chapel underwent repairs. The Italian Embassy and surrounding buildings were just several of scores of structures around kabul destroyed by bombs dropped by renegade fighter pilots. At least 95 civilians were killed and 197 injured in the failed coup. No military casualties have been released. No one was in the embassy at the time of the attack. Western missions left Afghanistan a little more than a year ago as Soviet troops withdrew after a 10-year intervention, wrongly expecting the swift collapse of President Najib's government at the hands of Moslem guerrillas. Kabul now has just 21 functioning foreign embassies. The coup appears to have put on hold plans by some Western countries to return. Planned low-level diplomatic visits from Italy, Austria, France and Britain have been postponed, diplomats say. At the Italian compound, the bomb blew out windows in the embassy, bending the reinforced steel on the windows like rubber. Windows were knocked out in the chapel 300 feet away and in Pangati's house next door. A crater 10 feet deep and 20 feet wide yawned opposite the embassy. The father's beloved greenhouse was also gutted. ``I'll just have to start it all over again,'' he said as he surveyed the damage, dressed in an Afghan sweater and an apron decorated with blue ducks. It won't be the first time. Since the civil war began in the late 1970s, Panigati has suffered rocket attacks and raining flares, which Soviet planes drop to confuse heat-seeking missiles as they circle Kabul. Everything seems to hit the greenhouse. ``Flares are the fruit of Kabul'' he said with a chuckle. ``Instead of cherries or apples we get these.'' The priest opened a drawer in his living room revealing a collection of hundreds of spent flares. Panigati belongs to the Barnabites, a Catholic order founded in 1533. The Barnabites opened their mission in Afghanistan on Jan. 1, 1933 following an agreement between the Italian dictator Benito Mussolini, the Vatican and the Afghan government. Fascist Italy was the second government after the Soviet Union to recognize King Amanullah Khan, so the Afghan government welcomed Italian priests. Panigati's mission has been limited to serving the foreign community. No missionary work is allowed. But the priest, who speaks 10 languages, has been allowed to teach. All of Kabul's secondary schools are closed now _ the war _ so he has private students. Panigati said his close call with the bomb didn't frighten him. ``I've been through all of this before,'' he said. During World War II, a German soldier was shot in Panigati's town and Germans decided to take revenge by killing some civilians. Panigati was one of those chosen to die. ``They put me against the wall to shoot me but them bombings began and I ran off.'' Later, he was on his way to the Dachau concentration camp when another bombing attack derailed the train. Panigati said he escaped into a corn field. On Thursday, after the fighting ended, Panigati said he awoke to a ``beautiful symphony.'' ``It was a symphony of sweeping glass,'' he said. ``Everywhere around me, I heard the sound and I thought, `Lord, how good it is for us to be here.'''

DOC.HEAD: New Spy-Catching Weapons Weighed In Closed-Door Intelligence Review
DOC.TEXT: New weapons to catch spies _ including rewards for reporting turncoat relatives and greater FBI access to tax records _ are being studied by a panel of private citizens working behind closed doors for the leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee. Many of the ideas under discussion revolve around money _ now the most common motivation for those who deliver U.S. secrets to foreign governments. Without any public announcement, nine men usually at the beck and call of presidents were recruited last spring by Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., and William Cohen, R-Maine, chairman and vice chairman of the Intelligence Committee, for a unique effort to respond to ``the decade of the spy.'' Most of the nine are former White House, CIA, State or Justice officials who, Cohen said, not only are trusted by the nation's intelligence officers but also can rally political support if controversial new laws seem needed. In an interview, Cohen said he and Boren want ``to enhance security measures without turning into a Stalinist paranoid state.'' During the 1980s, the United States caught and convicted more spies than during the entire post-World War II era, but many already had worked inside the U.S. government for decades undetected. Members of the panel have visited the CIA, FBI, Justice and Defense Departments, National Security Agency and other intelligence agencies over the past nine months. Cohen said they're looking for ``common elements of these cases'' and new defenses. That sort of work normally would be done by the president's National Security Council staff, but President Bush's administration has no counterespionage proposals on the table. The advisers are: former deputy CIA Director and National Security Agency chief Bobby Ray Inman; former CIA Director Richard Helms; former Carter White House counsel Lloyd Cutler; and former Reagan White House counsel Arthur B. Culvahouse Jr. Also, former ambassador and senior State Department official Seymour Weiss; former ambassador and Xerox executive Sol Linowitz; former Deputy Attorney General and former Deputy Secretary of State Warren Christopher; and Boren's friend Eli Jacobs, a venture capitalist who owns the Baltimore Orioles baseball team and has served on defense advisory panels. Columbia University law professor Harold Edgar is helping draft legislative proposals, which Cohen expects in about two months. While refusing to discuss the panel's deliberations, Inman said his personal observation is that in 90 percent of the spy cases since 1975, ``Americans made the initial approach'' to spy for foreign powers. ``Back in the 1930s and 1940s, almost every case of espionage had one of two factors, either ideological sympathy or blackmail,'' Inman said. The ideological sympathy evaporated among spies even before the wane of communism around the world during the last year. And ``it's pretty hard to blackmail people for lifestyle these days,'' Inman said. But ``look at the number of people who have taken money.'' Cohen agreed. ``One of the weaknesses has been that we have not had laws on updating financial status,'' he said. ``If a guy goes from a Vega to a Jaguar in a year's time, something's wrong.'' For example, Navy spies John Walker and Jerry Whitworth, who enabled the Soviets to read a million coded messages, were paid hundreds of thousands of dollars. Ronald Pelton sold NSA secrets after he nearly went broke. An administration source said one idea floated to the panel is a long-sought FBI goal _ easier access to tax records and consumer credit data. When hunting a foreign agent, FBI agents can get bank records in secret without having enough evidence for a criminal search warrant, but they need such a warrant to obtain tax and credit data. Inman suggested that a computer list of officials with access to top secrets could be used by the IRS to ``tell you if there was any significant change, either a bankruptcy or a large gain.'' Inman also said stiffer penalties could be imposed on officials who falsify financial disclosure reports. Noting that John Walker's wife, Barbara, concealed his spying for 16 years before turning him in, Inman asked, ``Do you set up an awards system? We do with whistle blowers.'' The espionage review was planned before State Department official Felix Bloch came under suspicion last year. But, as one intelligence community source said, ``like everything else, it's been driven by some front-burner events'' including the Bloch affair, in which investigators have almost given up hope of filing criminal charges. Inman said one of the biggest difficulties in espionage cases is proving intent to harm the United States. He suggested spies might be charged with crimes other than espionage, such as theft of government property. Meeting a foreign agent without reporting it, as Bloch allegedly did, also could be made a crime, he said. But one executive branch source, dubious about the outside advisers' usefulness, said courts accept the delivery of even one piece of classified information to a foreign power as proof of intent to harm, because the government warns employees who see secrets about the danger of exposing them. ``They're focusing on several problems that have been solved since they left the government,'' this source said. ``Our big counterintelligence problem is not new legislation, but new values in society so people won't be so willing to sell out their country.'' But an intelligence community source said the need to identify a specific secret passed _ the missing element in the Bloch investigation _ ``means you literally have to catch them red-handed.'' ``This problem doesn't come up very often,'' the intelligence official said. ``When it does, it presents a big hurdle.''

DOC.HEAD: High Tides Solve Traffic Problems In Lagoon City
DOC.TEXT: High tides over the weekend filled the Venetian canals, lifelines of this lagoon city, which had sunk to dangerously low levels last week. The rising waters also helped the arrival of guests for Sunday's launching of the Moro di Venezia, the yacht belonging to Italian tycoon Raul Gardini, which will be Italy's challenger in the 1992 America's Cup. ``Traffic is back to normal through all canals, but the problem of accumulated mud is something which must be solved soon,'' said an official of the city waterworks, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Traffic on scores of small canals had come to a halt last week due to accumulated mud and prolonged low tides. The Grand Canal and other major waterways remained open to gondolas and motorboats. ``Certainly last week's low tide was very unusual in this period of the year and was probably due to a long dry spell,'' said Antonio Manfrin, a Venetian motorboat driver. ``Water was about 60 centimeters (24 inches) below the normal levels. It's ironic in a city where we always had problems from flood tides,'' he added. The canals have not been dredged in 40 years. The mud and low tides combined to cause a number of problems _ including the transportation of sick people to hospitals. City officials claimed on Saturday that cleaning of canals has been delayed by red tape and by the inability of regional authorities to find a place to store the mud.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Timothy Busfield says he draws on his own personality in playing Elliott Weston, the yuppie jerk, in ABC's ``thirtysomething.'' ``That's who I am,'' Busfield said in an interview in the March 17 edition of TV Guide. ``I'm a jerk, first and foremost. I don't know the answers. I'm an idiot. I make mistakes. I stick my foot in my mouth. I'm insensitive when I don't want to be.'' But Busfield said he has more than an emotional identification to Elliot. Elliot has a failed business behind him and two small children he struggles to know. He chases other women and at one point separated from his wife. When the role was offered to him, Busfield was in the throes of his own failed marriage, had trouble connecting with his own young son and had watched his children's theater project go under. This season, Elliot has reconciled with his wife, is back working with his old partner and has reached an understanding with his children. And Busfield has remarried, has a second son and his children's theater company is thriving. He said he people he meets recognize him as Elliot. He gets Bibles in the mail from those offended by the character's philandering, and one time a woman walked up to him in a supermarket, said ``Oh, it's you!'' and slapped him. People are ``emotionally disturbed by Elliot, yet they're completely enthralled by the character,'' Busfield said. ``He gets under their skin.''

Rob Lowe says he's worried about how moviegoers will react to his first appearance on the big screen since a videotape of his sexual escapades was splashed across TV screens. ``There's no way that you can know how embarrassing it was,'' Lowe says in the March 19 issue of People. ``No matter what adjective I choose, it would be trivializing it.'' Lowe says he went underground to escape the publicity surrounding an X-rated videotape of himself and two other women _ one of whom was a minor _ made in an Atlanta hotel room in 1988. He doesn't dispute that he videotaped his guests and says they knew they were being recorded. He denies, however, having sex with the 16-year-old. A lawsuit is pending in that case. The district attorney in Atlanta chose not to prosecute Lowe. In exchange, Lowe agreed to do 20 hours of community service. With the release of his new movie, ``Bad Influence,'' Lowe says he is hoping the public will forgive and forget. ``I'm real nervous,'' said Lowe, who turns 26 today.

Christy Ficthner-Alhadef, Miss USA 1986, says she was exploited during her yearlong reign, making her the second former beauty queen to criticize the pageant operation. ``No one is pushed that hard, not Miss Universe, not the chaperones, just Miss USA,'' she told The Wichita Eagle in a recent interview. Miss USA 1989, Gretchen Polhemus, also complained about her treatment when she wore the crown. Pageant management was changed in 1988, but many of the complaints were similar, centering on long hours and few days off. The day after the new Miss USA, Carole Gist, was crowned March 2 in a televised show from Wichita, Polhemus, 24, aired her gripes. ``She was the first one to be honest and say something negative about the pageant,'' Fichtner-Alhadef, 27, said from her Dallas home last week. ``You get trained and conditioned to say the right thing. I don't care anymore.'' Pageant officials said they tell the contestants the work is hectic and thee are long hours, but improvements have been made to make the reign more enjoyable.

Miss America Debbye Turner met with a group of troubled girls and discovered that ``our dreams and expectations are not all that different.'' ``What I found out was we had more in common than we thought we did,'' said Ms. Turner, 24, crowned Miss America 1990 in September. Ms. Turner had one-on-one interviews Sunday with seven girls ages 14 to 18 at the Females in Transition Center. The program, run by the state Department of Corrections, helps girls from broken homes or with criminal records get back into the mainstream. ``Every one of these girls recognizes that at some level they made a mistake,'' said Ms. Turner. ``They are determined and committed to making their life what they want it to be.'' She said she made plans with each of the girls to write to one another so they could chart each other's progress.

Howard Rollins, co-star of NBC's ``In the Heat of the Night,'' said his addictions to drugs and alcohol drove him to consider suicide three days before Christmas. The actor, who portrays detective Virgil Tibbs, said an inner voice was telling him: ``Just go ahead and kill me. I'm sick of it. I'll never straighten out my life, I'll never have the career I want. ``How can I talk about a career when I can't even stop using drugs? Why can't I just take a gun to my head and be out of this misery?'' In an interview in the March 17 issue of TV Guide, Rollins said he took his last drug on Dec. 28. Then he packed up his drug paraphernalia and stomped it to pieces. ``I have a thing inside, a needing or craving, that I am constantly dealing with,'' he said. Rollins said he was only an occasional user when he landed the Tibbs role in 1987 but was addicted within six months.

DOC.HEAD: Don't Fall On Your Sword Till You See Brad Waller
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Brad Waller teaches Shakespearean sword fighters how to take the ``ouch'' out of touche. A certified expert in stage combat, Waller can turn an amateur swashbuckler into a Douglas Fairbanks or Errol Flynn in 15 weeks of strenuous Monday night sessions at Washington's Folger Shakespeare Theater. For a $350 fee, Waller trains actors in the art of dueling with such deadly weapons as rapier and dagger, broadsword and quarterstaff without committing mayhem on the stage _ but convincing theatergoers they're seeing the real thing. His rapier's slashing attacks stop perilously close to a student's arms, legs or abdomen. Before each parry and thrust, he gives broad visual clues to make his next move as obvious as possible. His bucklers, the shield between a sword's blade and handle, are fashioned from hubcaps and silver-plated candy dishes. Waller's deft movements are patterned after the highly refined techniques of Camillo Agrippa, Achille Marozzo and other 16th century fencing masters, whose books he has studied in the archives of the Folger Shakespeare Library. ``Those techniques can be very dangerous,'' Waller said. ``In a way, they were meant to kill. So stage combat can never be historically accurate, or you'd kill the actors. I try to teach safety first, and the skills to make the actor really look good.'' The ebullient, red-haired Waller, 34, a Wisconsin-born actor who grew up in Minneapolis, learned his craft under Paddy Crean, dean of the Society of American Fight Directors. It was Crean who taught Errol Flynn how to handle his rapier with wit. ``Paddy always said that stage combat is 75 percent drama, 15 percent historical accuracy and 100 percent safety,'' said Waller, one of only five students to receive the society's demanding teaching certificate in 1988. Box-office stars who have been coached by society professionals in ``fight choreography,'' which includes fisticuffs as well as swordplay, include Christopher Walken, William Hurt, Jon Voigt, Henry Winkler, Kathleen Turner and Amy Irving. When he's not working with actors, teaching in local schools or performing onstage, Waller hits the road with ``Shakespeare Lunatics and Lovers,'' an Elizabethan theatrical troupe that stages battles and love scenes from the Bard of Avon's plays before high school audiences. People no longer settle feuds in a fencing duel, but Waller says there will be a big demand for classical actors trained in swordplay as long as Shakespeare's plays are performed. Shakespeare's works are full of bloody sword fights and suicides, in keeping with the Elizabethan tradition of pleasing audiences not only with plays but competitive bouts of swordplay. Waller said some of Shakespeare's stage roles, including clowns and fools, were written for fencing masters of the day. In ``Romeo and Juliet,'' the hotheaded Tybalt who ``tilts with piercing steel at bold Mercutio's breast'' took his name from Girard Thibault, who wrote a manual in 1628 describing the quick, precise cutting motions of the Spanish style of fencing. Before he was slain at Tybalt's hand, Mercutio called his adversary ``the very butcher of a silk button.'' Waller said that referred to an Italian fencing master in London, probably known to Shakespeare, who ``could take the silk buttons off any Englishman'' with his rapier. The English language, in fact, is rich with words and phrases that originated in fencing, Waller said. ``When you say you crossed someone or gave him the slip, you are using old fencing terms for maneuvers designed to thwart an opponent,'' he said. ``If you say, `Come to the point,' you are really challenging someone to a duel.''

DOC.HEAD: Census Workers Will Try to Count the Homeless
DOC.TEXT: The Tompkins Square Park band shell is filled each night with piles of ragged blankets. A passerby might hear sneezes and snores and realize there are people underneath, but certainly wouldn't know how many, or their sex, race or age. That is what census workers are being asked to find out _ without waking anyone up _ from 2 a.m. to 4 a.m. March 21 at parks and other outdoor sites where the homeless congregate. The survey is part of an unprecedented nationwide count in shelters, parks, subways, vacant buildings, doorways and bank-machine vestibules. The plan's critics call it poorly designed and doomed to undercount the homeless, estimated by the Coalition for the Homeless to number 70,000 to 90,000 in New York City alone. The Census Bureau already has issued a disclaimer. ``We are deliberately staying away from defining this as a census of the homeless,'' said Kenneth Meyer, assistant regional census manager. ``Nor are we saying that we expect to get 100 percent count of the homeless. It's going to give us some idea of the characteristics of this group but not necessarily the true size of it.'' Still, advocates for the homeless and city officials fear a low count will be used to justify social service budget cuts. Some homeless advocates have refused to cooperate with the Census Bureau plan; others believe they must participate to legitimize any objections afterward. ``Hopefully this exercise, fraught with problems before it starts, is not going to be used to justify yet another estimate from the government that is tragically low on how many homeless there are in the nation,'' said Peter Smith, president of the Partnership for the Homeless. ``If it is, we will just have to say: We told you so.'' City officials and advocates for the homeless have a long list of complaints about the count's timing, organization, the data to be collected and the recruitment of people to do the counting. From 6 p.m. to about midnight March 20, census workers will visit shelters and hotels used by the homeless. The 2 a.m.-to-4 a.m. outdoor count will be followed by a 4 a.m.-to-6:30 a.m. count of those leaving abandoned buildings. For safety's sake, enumerators will not be sent inside. Critics want the counters to stay later. ``Homeless people, like everyone else, sleep at night,'' said Kristin Morse, assistant director at the Coalition for the Homeless. In shelters, enumerators will help homeless people fill out the same forms everyone else gets in the mail. But enumerators counting homeless people in places like streets and parks need only record age, sex, race, marital status and whether the person is of Hispanic origin. If the homeless person is sleeping, the counter must guess. In places like Tompkins Square on Manhattan's Lower East Side, where the homeless wrap themselves in piles of blankets, this will be hard. Yet, said Meyer, ``We don't want them pulling a blanket off someone and find they are staring at a knife or pistol.'' Enumerators are forbidden to ask people whether they are homeless, and may miss people as a result. ``Part of surviving on the street is being able to hide or being able to look like they're not homeless,'' said Morse. Even if asked, many homeless people would not admit they have no place to live, Meyer said. In New York, city officials, homeless advocates, transit police and others compiled a list of 2,167 sites where homeless people congregate. But for safety reasons, some of those places, such as train tunnels, will not be surveyed. ``I understand why they're not doing it,'' said Morse. ``The tunnels can be very dangerous. But they are going to miss a lot of people.'' Estimates of the number of homeless nationwide have ranged from 250,000 to 3 million in recent years. A decade ago census takers went to shelters but did not try to count people living in alleys, under bridges and in similar locations. The Census Bureau is trying to include the homeless and people who work with them as counters. The $7- to $10-an-hour jobs have been advertised in New York City in Street News, a non-profit newspaper sold by the homeless, eliciting hundreds of inquiries from homeless people. Critics say the application process poses many hurdles. Applicants must fill out a four-page form, produce two pieces of identification, provide a social security number, an address and phone number, and are asked to have five years of job experience and no criminal record. Meyer says the Census Bureau can overlook convictions for trespassing or other non-violent offenses, will help the homeless obtain Social Security numbers, and is flexible about an uneven work history. The Census Bureau also is funding an assessment of the survey in five cities by independent researchers. The assessment will be used to refine any future count of ``elusive populations,'' said Kim Hopper, the primary researcher in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Two Agents Charged in Beating Death of Prisoner
DOC.TEXT: A court has indicted two agents of Israel's Shin Bet security service in the beating death of a Palestinian prisoner in a jail in the occupied Gaza Strip, the Justice Ministry announced. The names of the two defendants and details of the case were banned from publication until an initial closed-door hearing is held, Sunday's announcement said. It said the defendants' lawyers had agreed to what could be published about the case. It is unusual for charges to be brought against Shin Bet agents, and the closed-door treatment of the case was in keeping with traditional secrecy about the agency responsible for Israel's internal security. The name of the agency's chief, for example, is an official secret. The charge of manslaughter was brought in the death of Khaled Kamel Al Sheikh Ali, 27, who died Dec. 19 after being arrested on suspicion of belonging to the Moslem fundamentalist Jihad Islami organization and of illegal possession of weapons. After his death, Israeli newspapers quoted authorities as attributing his death to a heart attack, but an independent autopsy performed at the request of his family on Dec. 24 found he died of internal bleeding. The Justice Ministry announcement said the two defendants questioned the prisoner and ``during the interrogation...the accused dealt blows to Sheikh Ali, and as a result Sheikh Ali suffered internal bleeding that led to his death.'' The indictment was handed down Thursday in Jerusalem District Court but not made public until the ministry's announcement. The state prosecutor's office had requested that details be withheld and the hearing be secret, the announcement said. According to an Israeli human rights group, there are nine other cases in which Palestinians died in custody since the Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation began in December 1987. Those cases involve either prison or Shin Bet personnel. The Israeli Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories did not list prosecutions in any of the cases. Also during the uprising, four Israeli soldiers were tried in the beating death of a Palestinian in the Gaza Strip in August 1988. They were acquitted of manslaughter but convicted of brutality. In September, a Shin Bet agent was acquitted of negligence in the death of a Palestinian who died in custody in July 1987, before the uprising started. The agent's name was not made public. The most publicized case in the past involving Shin Bet agents was the beating deaths of two Palestinian guerrillas while in custody after the guerrillas took hostages aboard a hijacked Israeli bus in April 1984. The Shin Bet chief Avraham Shalom resigned amid accusations that evidence had been faked to frame an army officer. President Chaim Herzog pardoned four top Shin Bet officials accused of either ordering the killings or withholding information on them. Israel's Supreme Court upheld the pardons and rejected an appeal for a full investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Cheered by Supporters at Houston Church
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,000 displaced Nicaraguans cheered Violeta Barrios de Chamorro after the Nicaraguan president-elect's return to Houston to get a brace removed from her knee. Chanting `Viva Dona Violeta!'' and ``Viva Nicaragua!'' the supporters joined Mrs. Chamorro in singing Nicaragua's national anthem Sunday night. Mrs. Chamorro, who is using a wheelchair while recovering from knee surgery, greeted several supporters with kisses and handshakes. She addressed the crowd after a Mass at St. Thomas More Catholic Church. She pledged anew to end the draft and grant amnesty to countrymen in exile. But her words were drowned out by cheers. ``We want to show her our support,'' said Doraldina Arguello Schiene. ``As American Nicaraguans, we want to show her we support her in her victory and that we trust her to do the job. I feel very confident that 99 percent of the Nicaraguans who were here today were here to show her their support.'' Mrs. Chamorro fell and broke her kneecap on New Year's Eve and underwent surgery in Houston Jan. 4. She returned to Nicaragua on Jan. 16 and campaigned on crutches as the opposition candidate against Sandinista President Daniel Ortega.
