Mrs. Chamorro defeated Ortega in an upset in the Feb. 25 election. She takes office April 25. She returned to Houston on Thursday and orthopedic surgeon Dr. Malcolm W. Granberry removed her brace Friday. Contra leader Adolfo Calero flew in from Miami to join the supporters. ``All Nicaraguans are very happy and enthusiastic about Violeta Chamorro's triumph,'' Calero said. ``All I hear is the people saying, `We'll see you in Nicaragua. We'll see you in Nicaragua.' I think a lot of people will be returning. I know I will.'' Calero joined Mrs. Chamorro in calling for disbanding of both Contra forces and the Sandinista military. Calero said all the Nicaraguans in exile will be watching the country in the next month, hoping to see concrete signs that they can return to their country in safety. ``They want to see that there is peace _ that's the most important thing _ peace,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Another New Levy Looms, Despite No-New-Taxes Pledge
DOC.TEXT: Get ready, America. Your ``no tax increase'' federal government is about to start collecting another new tax. As taxes go, this one isn't much. Most of the impact will be on businesses, at least at first. It could raise the price of a telephone by a dime but add $25 or so to the cost of recharging an automobile air conditioner. On April 1, the government will begin collecting this new tax, which is aimed at limiting use of chemicals _ chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs _ that are deemed to damage the ozone layer protecting the Earth. It has the dual task of raising about $4.3 billion for deficit reduction over the next five years. The CFC tax is only the latest move by Congress and the Reagan and Bush administrations to reduce the budget deficit without raising income-tax rates. President Reagan signed 13 tax increases during his eight years in office; President Bush signed a package of miscellaneous increases in December and proposed another round this year. ``There is considerable feeling that the government will continue to look this way in the future as long as such sources can produce revenue,'' says Thomas P. Ochsenschlager of the Grant Thornton accounting firm in Washington. If Bush gets his way this year, for example, the 8 percent federal tax on airline tickets will rise to 10 percent; the 3 percent levy on telephone service, scheduled to expire Dec. 31, will be made permanent; and about 3.8 million state and local government workers who are not covered by a retirement plan will have to start paying Social Security taxes. In the same message that proposed those tax increases, Bush proclaimed his continued opposition to tax increases, just as Reagan did for eight years and just as many members of Congress do, even after voting for those higher taxes. The trick is that nobody is raising income-tax rates. Excise taxes have been raised. Income-tax deductions have been reduced and repealed. But the president and Congress have held fast against any increase in income-tax rates. That leaves the government in constant pursuit of ``cats and dogs,'' as detractors call the miscellaneous tax increases, to find the revenue needed for deficit reduction. It all started in 1982, when Congress had second thoughts about the huge 1981 tax cut that was the framework for Reagan's economic policy and voted to boost taxes by $296 billion over five years. Nobody's rates were raised _ but the deduction for medical expenses was diluted severely; the tax on cigarettes was doubled; the telephone tax was tripled; and tax withholding was imposed on interest and dividends. Because of public outcry, withholding was repealed a year later. In 1984, Congress passed another thick tax law designed to reduce the deficit by another $156 billion over five years. It boosted the tax on a gallon of liquor by $2; reduced the benefit of income averaging for those whose earnings fluctuate from year to year; killed a tax credit for homeowners who buy solar energy equipment and cut the value of several corporate tax deductions. Additional tax increases for deficit reduction were enacted in 1985 ($15.6 billion over five years), 1986 ($5.3 billion) and 1988 ($66 billion). The 1989 version will bring in $22 billion over five years, with one-quarter of the money coming from a Social Security tax increase on workers earning more than $50,400 a year. The CFC tax is more typical of recent increases because it is a hidden levy with little direct effect on voters. But consumers usually end up paying at least some of the taxes that are levied on business. Jack Terher Jr., a Ford dealer in Denver, said that to avoid the CFC tax, he is spending up to $7,000 on equipment to recover freon, a CFC used as a refrigerant, from auto air conditioners being repaired. That probably will force an increase of about $25 in the bill for recharging an air conditioner, Terher said. Other CFCs are widely used by electronics manufacturers to clean computer chips and circuit boards. Because of competition, however, sellers of refrigerators, computers, videocassette recorders and televisions are unlikely to raise their prices the few cents necessary to recoup the tax. ``I don't expect much impact on the consumer,'' says Steve Mixtacki, vice president of American TV and Appliance in Madison, Wis. ``But it is another big paperwork burden for business _ although the government apparently doesn't blink at that.''

DOC.HEAD: Grand Daddy Of Polls Changing, But For Better Or Worse?
DOC.TEXT: In the opinion of Gallup Poll executives, the grandfather of public surveys has changed to keep up with the times. Many top executives are gone. Interviewing operations have moved from Princeton headquarters to Lincoln, Neb. Staffs have been assembled in Moscow and Budapest, and the new owners have plans to make the now-weekly poll daily. But some former employees have a different view. They say that what the company describes as an overdue overhaul is a sacrifice of quality for profits. Since its purchase 18 months ago by Nebraska-based Selection Research Inc., the Gallup Organization has begun moving away from public opinion polls to concentrate on more lucrative market research, former executive Neil Upmeyer said. ``I believe it is their view that, because market research is more profitable, more efficient, if they de-emphasize social reseach and give additional attention to market research they would have a better bottom line,'' he said. Upmeyer, a vice president of public affairs research before his departure, now works for the Center for Analysis of Public Issues in Princeton. He said the new Gallup owners are trying to use the poll's good name to open more doors for private research on less engaging topics like toothpaste preferences. Pursuit of bigger profits, he said, ``is a perfectly legitimate thing for them to do. But from my point of view ... it negates the purpose for having built this institution for the last 50 years. It has the potential for irreparably damaging the Gallup name.'' Also departing with unflattering words for the new owners were Andrew Kohut, president of the Gallup Organization before the SRI acquisition, and Diane Colasanto, former vice president for opinion research. Jim Clifton, a former SRI executive who became chief executive officer of the Gallup Organization after the acquisition, dismissed it all as ``bitterness talking.'' He said Upmeyer had his position ``upgraded'' _ a euphemism for being fired. The old Gallup organization, he added, was badly in need of a management overhaul to ensure the profitability necessary to continue the costly stock-in-trade public opinion surveys. Like the housecleaning in executive positions, he said the move of the telephone interviewing staff to Nebraska was aimed at getting better people on board. A regional labor shortage, he said, doomed the Princeton-based interviewing headquarters to a poorly qualified staff with rapid turnover. The now-weekly public opinion polls will soon go daily, Clifton said. The quick assembly of polling teams in Moscow last year and Budapest in January, he added, are hardly signs of a diminished commitment. Also in the works is a 60-nation poll on attitudes about the environment, which Clifton bills as the largest public opinion survey ever done. ``Absolutely more time and quality are going into it. A corporation that has been there 50 years needs change. We're upgrading technology. We're upgrading management,'' Clifton said. ``The Gallup Poll is a national treasure.... (But) the reality is to have an outstanding public service company in the public opinion business you have to make a lot of profit somewhere else. ``Upgrading people doesn't really constitute change to me. There's an enormous Dr. George Gallup spirit about the place.'' Clifton gets a second from George Gallup Jr., the son of the man who founded the polling organization in 1936. The younger Gallup, a co-chairman of the company, said his father would have approved of the new owners' moves. The senior Gallup died in 1984. Whatever grand scheme might be behind them, the changes so far have not hurt the quality of the Gallup Poll, said Michael Kagay, surveys editor of The New York Times. The Times is one of about 100 newspapers that subscribe to the polls via The Los Angeles Times news syndicate. Gallup, with a rich library of public opinions accumulated in a half-century in the business, has a unique ability to measure long-term trends and provide contexts for current findings, Kagay said. ``It would be a great loss if anything happened to Gallup that would hurt its ability to provide those,'' he said. ``I certainly hope it doesn't happen.'' Upmeyer, on the other hand, thinks the abundance of polls now done by news organizations and other groups diminishes any void a Gallup withdrawal would leave. The harm, he says, is to the Gallup name. ``The work is going to continue to be done,'' he said. ``It's just that it won't be done by Gallup.''

DOC.HEAD: Special Interests Seen Favoring Status Quo on Farm Policy
DOC.TEXT: When she introduced Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter at a conference last week, analyst Susan Sechler said a lot of the current farm bill debate is being generated by special interests who want to keep the pie sliced pretty much as it is. ``Within the farm policy fraternity, it seems, the prevailing mood is defensive,'' Sechler said. ``In the aftermath of the (farm financial) disaster of the mid-1980s, and in the midst of a fragile, uneven recovery, the farm policy club is preoccupied with three things.'' She said these are: _A desire to keep government deeply involved in agriculture, including large annual costs of operating commodity programs. _Tinkering with programs in the name of ``flexibility'' so that a few million acres can shift from one crop to another. _Efforts to ``deny a seat at the farm poker table to prospective new players, notably consumer and environmental interests.'' Sechler is director of rural economic policy for the Aspen Institute, a private research organization based here. During the Carter administration, she was a senior policy analyst at the Agriculture Department. Congress has been holding hearings on a 1990 farm bill to replace the Food Security Act of 1985. Just about everyone, including the Bush administration, says the current law should be the basis of the 1990 bill and that changes should be made with tender loving care. A mainstay of the administration's proposals is flexibility to allow farmers more freedom to plant what they choose, rather than be forced into planting the same ``program'' crop year after year to protect their federal benefits. ``This term (flexibility) is consistent with the rich tradition of agricultural policy doublespeak, a tradition which in 1985 spawned a market-oriented farm bill that since has cost taxpayers $90 billion,'' Sechler said. Yeutter told his audience at the food policy conference, sponsored by Public Voice for Food and Health Policy, that consumers need to understand what is at stake in the flexibility issue on Capitol Hill. ``You ought to care, because it's going to have an impact on the cost of food, the efficiency with which we run our food production system in the United States,'' he said. Flexibility in crop plantings and rotation also would have some effect on the level of agricultural ``inputs'' such as fertilizer and pesticide used to grow food, Yeutter said. Rigid rules built into current programs ``often demand that farmers use'' chemicals to get maximum production. Yeutter also defended the administration's environmental proposals for conservation, surface and ground water quality, and the protection of wetlands. Some environmentalists say the administration should go even further than what it has proposed for the 1990 farm bill, ``but the fact is we've gone a lot farther than anybody's ever gone before in any administration,'' he said.

Land under irrigation may increase to record levels in the 1990s if the government continues to throttle back on acreage reduction programs, according to an Agriculture Department analysis. The department's Economic Research Service said its study shows a linkage between acreage reduction program (ARP) levels and the area under irrigation. From 1949 to 1978, the area irrigated in the United States doubled, reaching 50.3 million acres. But the agricultural census of 1982 showed a decline of 1.3 million acres, and the 1987 census showed a further drop of 2.6 million. Agency researchers said irrigation area dropped as the ARPs were increased. This represents land farmers must take from production in order to qualify for price support benefits. ``Since 1987, a substantial reduction in commodity stocks has allowed USDA to ease (ARP) requirements,'' the agency said in the March issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``In 1989, area diverted under annual programs was about half of the 1987 acreage reductions.'' Preliminary estimates indicate that more farmland was irrigated in 1989 than in any year since 1981. ``Beyond 1990, irrigation could rise 3-4 million acres above current levels if the area idled under the annual programs is brought back into production,'' the report said.

Imports of agricultural products rose to a record $21.5 billion last year, with most of the items competitive with domestic products, according to the Agriculture Department. Total value of competitive items imported in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30 was more than $15.24 billion, lead by $3.84 billion worth of fruits, nuts and vegetables. Beef and pork imports were next at $2.3 billion. Non-competitive imports were valued at $6.27 billion, including $2.47 billion worth of coffee and $1.05 billion worth of rubber and gums, said the department's Foreign Agricultural Service.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League Headquarters to Move to Cairo
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League has decided to move its headquarters back to Cairo from the Tunisian capital, where it was transferred in 1979 after Egypt broke ranks with Arab countries by making peace with Israel. In a dispatch from Tunis, Egypt's state-run Middle East News Agency said Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt announced the decision Sunday at a regular biannual session of the 22-member league. He said the move would come in September. ``This decision is based on the (Arab League) charter, and Egypt has been cautious to coordinate views with Tunisia because of the strong ties between the Tunisian and Egyptian leaderships,'' Abdel-Meguid said. He thanked Kuwait, Oman, Iraq and Morocco, as well as Arab League Secretary General Chedli Klibi, for their ``effort and cooperation,'' in bringing about the decision. The agency said the offices of the Arab Organization for Education, Culture and Science, and the Arab Broadcasting Union would remain in Tunis. Sunday's move followed Egyptian diplomatic efforts to return the headquarters of the Arab League to Cairo, where it was set up in 1945. The league decided 11 years ago to transfer the headquarters to Tunis as a sanction against Egypt for signing a peace treaty with Israel in 1979. All Arab states except Oman, Sudan and Somalia severed ties with Cairo in retaliation for its peace treaty with Israel. Egypt returned to the Arab fold after a league summit in 1987 allowed its members to resume ties with Cairo. All but Libya have officially restored diplomatic links with Cairo, whose suspension from the Arab League was lifted in May at a summit meeting in Casablanca, Morocco. Egypt insisted on returning the leagues offices to Cairo in accordance with the league charter, which stipulates that the Egyptian capital should be the seat of the organization.

DOC.HEAD: Opera Singer Martial Singher Dead at 85
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Singher pronounced sang-GAIR.
DOC.TEXT: Martial Singher, a French baritone whose operatic career was cut short by a heart disorder, has died at 85. Singher, who had undergone heart surgery twice, died at his home on Friday. From his Metropolitan Opera debut in ``The Tales of Hoffman,'' in 1943, Singher was hailed by critics for his elegant and precise style. A heart disorder ended his career at the Met in 1959 after performances in 200 operas there. He continued a brief concert career in recital and orchestral appearances with major philharmonics across the nation, including Boston and Los Angeles. Singher turned to teaching at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia and elsewhere before settling in Santa Barbara in 1962 to head the vocal department at the Music Academy of the West. He retired in 1981. Students of Singher's include a score of leading members of the Metropolitan, New York City, Berlin, Hamburg, Salzburg, Vienna, Munich, Bonn, Frankfurt and Paris operas. Born in the southwest of France, Singher joined the Paris Opera in 1930, where he performed for 10 years. Singher headed to the United States after Paris fell to the Nazis. He is survived by his wife, Eta; three sons, and two grandchildren. No funeral services will be held.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,368.23, down 624.89 points, or 1.84 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Irwin Schiff Spending This Tax Season Behind Bars
DOC.TEXT: As April 15 approaches, Irwin Schiff cringes at the thought of millions of obedient Americans sweating over their 1040s so they can turn over their hard-earned dollars to Uncle Sam. ``It's a sad commentary on the intelligence and the awareness of the American public,'' Schiff said _ in a telephone interview from the Morgantown, W.Va., federal prison where he is serving a second term for tax offenses. ``The government changed April Fool's Day from April 1 to April 15 _ they fooled the public into believing that they are required to pay income taxes.'' Nobody can say Schiff, author of the 1982 best seller ``How Anyone Can Stop Paying Income Taxes,'' doesn't have the courage of his convictions. Schiff landed back in prison in August when the IRS found out that a year after his parole for a 1985 conviction, he still hadn't paid back taxes and penalties for 1980, 1981 and 1982. Over the years, the tax protester has sacrificed nearly everything he owns in his crusade against the Internal Revenue Service, including an estimated $133,000 in book royalties seized to pay back taxes. He's lost his insurance and investment businesses. All this because the 62-year-old former Hamden resident stubbornly refuses to yield an inch in his position that personal income taxes are strictly voluntary and the government can't force anybody to pay. For nearly two decades, Schiff has been preaching to anybody who'll listen to his interpretation of the 16th Amendment, which gave the U.S. government authority to tax income from any source _ or so the IRS says. Schiff maintains that the amendment, adopted in 1913, gave the government power to tax goods and privileges but not wages. The amendment, by the way, was never ratified by Connecticut. He stopped paying income taxes _ at least voluntarily _ in 1974. The IRS finally got Schiff in 1980; he was sentenced to six months in prison and fined $10,000. He was arrested again in 1985, serving six months before being paroled. Since landing back in prison, Schiff, who is representing himself in this legal morass, has come up with yet another scheme to frustrate the IRS: Go ahead and fill out the IRS forms, but don't declare any taxable income _ zero. Schiff's family wishes he would relent in his battle against the IRS, but they doubt he will. ``A lot of people think he is an idiot but he is not,'' said his son, Andrew, who, unlike his father, pays his taxes. ``Like many people who are obsessed with a cause, he is only very stubborn.''

DOC.HEAD: Case Suggests Drug Taken By Women May Harm Their Granddaughters
DOC.TEXT: The parents and doctor of a 13-year-old girl who died of vaginal cancer say they suspect other children could be at risk of cancer caused by a drug their grandmothers took decades earlier. Sarah Roberts of suburban Olney, Md., whose daughter Amy died last year, said a lawyer representing the family was filing suit today against Eli Lilly and Co. of Indianapolis, which manufactured the synthetic hormone diethylstilbestrol, or DES. A Lilly spokesman did not return a telephone call seeking comment. The Food and Drug Administration banned the drug from use by pregnant women in the early 1970s after it had been used by an estimated 3 million women over three decades in the belief that it would prevent miscarriages. DES was made and sold by some 300 pharmaceutical companies from 1947 to 1971. In 1970, researchers discovered the link between DES and cancer in daughters of women who used the drug. Don McLearn, an FDA spokesman, said Amy Roberts' case was the first he had heard of a genetic defect that may be related to DES possibly being passed to a grandchild. In Amy's case, the gene would have come through her father. Mrs. Roberts said her mother-in-law, who is still living and has one other young granddaughter, took the drug in 1949 when she was pregnant with Amy's father, the Rev. J. David Roberts, a Methodist minister in Olney. She said two of her husband's sisters have had medical problems which they blame on the drug their mother took. Two grandchildren died after being born prematurely, she said. The FDA says the drug is still manufactured for some medical applications but is banned from use during pregnancy. ``Amy had no symptoms until she came home from school on a Thursday complaining of a pain in the back of her neck,'' Mrs. Roberts said in a telephone interview. A week later, she said, doctors had discovered cancer in Amy's vagina and lungs and told the Roberts their daughter had only three months to live. Amy died last June, after doctors fought for 14 months to control the rare cancer, which spread through her body, Mrs. Roberts said. ``We are hoping to alert other DES sons and daughters that there is a possibility of cancer and that maybe their daughters should be checked,'' said Mrs. Roberts. She said doctors told her Amy might have lived after surgery if the cancer had been detected earlier. A first sign of a problem may have come when Amy began menstruating at age 9, Mrs. Roberts said, but a pediatrician told her nothing was wrong. Dr. Herbert Kotz of Olney, who talked about the case only after it was reported by The Washington Post on Sunday, said he and three other doctors were preparing an article on it for submission to a medical journal. Kotz said the article will explore the possibility that the effects of DES may be passed beyond one generation. It also will note, he said, that the same cancer has been found in several young women who had no exposure to DES in their family histories and Amy's case could have occurred by chance. Kotz said the cancer usually is found among older women and has almost never been linked to DES in a woman who showed the first symptoms after age 30. A coauthor of the planned paper, Dr. Bruce Walker, has predicted from animal studies that DES effects can pass through more than one generation, Kotz said. He said the purpose of the paper is ``to alert the medical profession to the fact that we may have another generation'' at risk from the drug. The U.S. Supreme Court in October refused to hear appeals from Lilly, E.R. Squibb & Sons and Rexall Drug Co. fighting lawsuits over the effects of DES. A New York ruling had forced all manufacturers of the drug to share in paying damages for alleged DES injuries. In March 1987, a U.S. District Court jury in Milwaukee ruled Lilly was not negligent in marketing DES for use by pregnant women. The court rejected a claim by Julie Shirkey, 25, of West Bend, Wis., who said her mother's use of DES had left her with vaginal cancer which led to a radical hysterectomy and the inability to bear children.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Share Prices Plunge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with closing Nikkei, dollar. Pickup 4th graf `Currency dealers...'
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued to rise against the Japanese yen Monday, sending prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange down sharply, dealers said. The dollar closed at 152.00 yen, up 0.85 yen from Friday's close of 151.15 yen. It started trading at 151.68 yen and ranged between 151.60 and 152.18 yen during the day. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which rose 302.23 points on Friday, fell 624.89 points, or 1.84 percent, closing at 33,368.23. Currency dealers said the dollar opened higher in Tokyo after it was pushed up in the Sydney market. It was also bolstered by a strong showing in New York Friday following the announcement of a better-than-expected U.S. employment figure for February, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. Traders said the Bank of Japan, the central bank, sold dollars at around 151.85 yen in morning trading in its effort to stem the yen's fall. Japan's central bank normally does not comment on its interventionary activities. The employment statistics showed that the United States had found jobs for 372,000 more non-agricultural workers in February, compared with about 250,000 expected prior to the release. ``Although demand for the dollar remains strong, the currency is not soaring quickly because many participants are becoming concerned about the excessive rise in the dollar,'' Kanai said. On the stock market, securities dealers said the yen's continuing weakness and persistent speculation about a possible discount rate hike caused the index's fall. ``The whole market is weak across the board today mainly because people do not want to engage in trading,'' said a dealer at Nikko Securities Co., speaking on condition of anonymity. Market players have been speculating the Bank of Japan would raise its official lending rate, which now stands at 4.25 percent, by as much as 1 percent after central bank Governor Yasushi Mieno returns Thursday from a visit to Europe. The market's anxiety over the rate increase sidelined investors, the dealer said. ``I'd rather see the market get over an interest rate hike soon and get back in action again,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Events Abroad Complicating Pentagon Budget Debate
DOC.TEXT: Les Aspin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, says his plan for next year's Pentagon budget is in the back of his ``beady-eyed mind'' and he's not talking. The Wisconsin Democrat says he plans to ``hide in the weeds'' while others are wrestling with the issue of U.S. defense spending in a world where the perceived threats to the nation are changing with breathtaking speed. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the Senate Armed Services Committee chairman, is also keeping quiet. Needs more information, he says. Aspin and Nunn, as much as probably anyone in the United States, understand the changing political landscape in Eastern Europe and elsewhere. What they need more time to survey the effect those changes have had on the American public and on the playing field of Capitol Hill. The 1980s were a decade in which defense spending accelerated rapidly and then leveled off near $300 billion a year. The yearly budget battle took on a comfortable script: the Republican administration would propose a big increase, the Democrats would pare it down and a compromise would be struck. That pattern has now been shattered by the developments in the Soviet sphere. ``It's a confusing situation ... It changes the way the game is played,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the House Budget Committee. The White House proposed a small increase in Pentagon spending for fiscal 1991, less than what it would take to keep pace with inflation but enough to protect cherished programs such as the B-2 stealth bomber and the Strategic Defense Initiative. It's a comfortable position for congressional Republicans, of whom Defense Secretary Dick Cheney was one until last year. But Democratic policymakers are facing demands in their party for a ``peace dividend'' of Pentagon cutbacks to spend on domestic priorities. They now have to decide how deeply to cut from Cheney's $303 billion request, and where the cuts will be made. Panetta says the toughest decisions will be on terminating weapons programs, especially those such as the B-2 bomber where significant investments have been made and where budget savings are slow to be realized. ``What you're talking about is reversing the process which took place in the last eight years,'' where the military could launch into expensive, multi-year projects and assume the budget would grow to pay for them, he said. Reducing troop strength may also yield savings in the long term rather than soon, because of the cost of bring the soldiers home and close the bases. Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., has loosely embraced a plan to trim spending to $291 billion, $5 billion below the current year's level. The cuts over the next five years, however, would total more than 10 times that amount. Democratic leaders say their struggle is for a defense spending figure that represents a sound policy. But since sound policy is in the eye of the beholder, election-year politics will undoubtedly be a big part of the bill that passes. ``The worst thing that can happen is to simply pull a number out of the air which no one can vote for,'' said Panetta. Liberal or conservative, lawmakers are touchy about any cuts that might reverberate back home _ especially in an election year. And since the majority Democrats have brought to their districts more bacon, Republicans are trying to make it an issue. ``Whether it's an air base, or a naval base, or the manpower around it, or the defense industry, or the subcontractors,'' members of Congress are ``hooked'' on military spending in their districts, said House Republican leader Robert Michel of Illinois. Because of that, the Democrats have ``got serious problems'' in drafting a defense bill, he said. They'll have to show they understand that ``the underlying reason for having a Department of Defense and security forces are to protect the security of the country and not be a jobs program or a welfare program,'' Michel said. Defense contractors sensitive to home-district politics have played the system carefully. Projects like the B-2 have subcontractors spread all over the country. ``We're going to have to find a number that meets a lot of political questions,'' said Rep. Marvin Leath of Texas, a conservative Democrat on the Armed Services Committee. It ``ain't going to be an easy chore,'' he said. And it's not going to be quick. House Democratic leaders are still fighting with the Pentagon over its proposed changes in the current year's budget. It might take less time to unify Germany than to get Congress and the administration to agree on a defense bill this year.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Steven Komarow is a congressional reporter for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The case in federal bankruptcy court was strictly small potatoes, but it meant a lot to mechanic Norman Darish _ he won it all himself. After months of stolen hours at the library, lunch breaks spent cramming on legalese,and late-night rehearsals in front of a mirror, Darish represented himself in a case concerning several hundred dollars in unpaid bills at his family's garage. And he won. Even the attorneys were impressed. ``Check this out,'' one lawyer told another after the case was closed. ``This kid represented himself and he did all right. He did real good!'' Darish made his 10-minute argument with all the panache of Perry Mason. His suit, however, was not pinstripes but workboots and a navy blue uniform with ``Leo's Auto Repair'' embroidered over the breast pocket. Darish hadn't even removed the Phillips screwdriver, air pressure gauge and magnetic pickup tool from his hip pocket before hopping on the subway to make his lunchtime appearance. ``I didn't want to be pompous or a showboat,'' he recalled, still flying high a week after winning his case early this month. ``I just wanted to look like myself _ an average person.'' The defendant, a Boston socialite, claimed protection from creditors under a federal bankruptcy filing. But Darish found out he had been under federal bankruptcy protection almost perpetually between 1982 and 1990. ``And meanwhile the little guys he owed money to were stuck,'' said Darsish, who appealed to the federal bankruptcy judge. The judge agreed to dismiss the Chapter 13 filing.

When actors at the Guthrie Theater share the tools of their trade with lawyers, they start off with a paradoxical lesson: ``The idea is not to get them to act,'' said actress Brenda Wehle. ``The idea to get them to stop acting and be themselves.'' Since communication is a large part of the trial lawyer's job, the trial lawyers attending the class taught by Wehle and actor Richard Guthrie are urged to strip away the extraneous gestures that make the jury focus on them. ``The communication can never be how clever the attorney is,'' said Wehle. ``The communication has to be the predicament the client was in.'' The lessons are sometimes drawn through skits. In one, Grusin plays a lawyer who is making a brilliant closing argument when opposing counsel _ Wehle _ begins rattling papers behind him; in the parlance of the theater, he is being upstaged. Grusin does the only thing he can do to bring the jury's focus back on him. He walks back to Wehle's table and stands alongside her. ``She'll start seeing that I've caught her and everybody else sees it, too,'' he said. ``So what started out being a cute little ploy becomes a weapon for me.'' Grusin has taught communications skills to thousands of lawyers at the request of law schools, bar associations and law firms. He also has been hired by lawyers to sit in on trials and critique their performance. Not all reviews have been favorable. The late Leon Jaworski, the famed Watergate special prosecutor, wrote a scathing critique after attending one of Grusin's sessions. He felt the law was being obscured by technique. But Grusin, after some thought, concluded that he was not obscuring the law but clarifying it. ``Trying to be someone else is a lie that blocks effective communication,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Counterspy Review
DOC.TEXT: Here are the nine private citizens identified by Senate and administration sources as conducting a counterintelligence policy review for Sens. David Boren and William Cohen, chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the Senate Intelligence Committee: Warren Christopher _ Los Angeles lawyer with O'Melveny & Myers; has been in and out of government for 30 years, serving as a trade negotiator, deputy attorney general in the Johnson administration and deputy secretary of State in the Carter administration. He negotiated the 1981 release of U.S. Embassy hostages from Iran. Arthur B. Culvahouse Jr. _ Washington lawyer with O'Melveny & Myers; chief legislative assistant to then-Sen. Howard Baker, R-Tenn.; White House counsel late in Reagan administration. Lloyd N. Cutler _ Washington lawyer with Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering; White House counsel in the Carter administration; chair of Quadrennial Commission on federal salaries; member of President's Commission on Ethics during Bush administration. Harold Edgar _ Columbia University law professor, serving as legislative drafter for Boren-Cohen group. Coauthor of leading article on application of espionage laws to publication of government secrets. Richard Helms _ international consultant in Washington. Career CIA officer who rose to CIA director in the Johnson and Nixon administrations. Former ambassador to Iran. Bobby Ray Inman _ retired admiral; former director of naval intelligence; vice director of Defense Intelligence Agency; director of National Security Agency during Carter administration. Alerted Justice Department to Billy Carter's dealings with Libya. Deputy CIA director early in Reagan administration. The assignment comes at an opportune time for Inman. In December, he relinquished the top job at a Texas defense industry holding company, publicly pronouncing his seven years in the private sector less satisfying than his long government service. A master at manipulating the bureaucracy, Inman suddenly was more visible in Washington _ confirming a story about Gen. Manuel Noriega's spying on U.S. operations in Panama as early as the mid-1970s, then discussing counterintelligence ideas before an American Bar Association committee. At the same time, his assignment from Boren and Cohen has privately renewed his contacts throughout the intelligence community and given him an opportunity to advertise his availability for another assignment. Eli Jacobs _ New York-based venture capitalist. Owner of Baltimore Orioles baseball team. Boren's friend, Jacobs is the least likely member of the panel. He is not a member of the revolving-door society between government and the private sector in Washington. His connection to intelligence is a mystery. An Orioles spokesman says Jacobs' Army service included a tour at Fort Holabird, Md., once a chemical warfare center. An intelligence community source says, ``I've heard third-hand he might have been in counterintelligence in the Army.'' A spokesman for the Senate committee says, ``He's on an advisory board to the secretary of defense, the defense policy or Defense Science Board.'' Asked for confirmation, a secretary in his New York office says, ``I wouldn't know. I've only been here since January.'' Sol Linowitz _ lawyer and diplomat in Washington. One-time head of Xerox Corp. Named ambassador to the Organization of American States during the Johnson administration; co-negotiator of Panama Canal treaties and special Middle East negotiator during Carter administration. Seymour Weiss _ national security consultant in Washington. Served in State Department from 1955 to 1973, heading Bureau of Politico-Military Affairs in Nixon administration. Former ambassador to the Bahamas. Member of President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board and chairman of Defense Policy Board during Reagan administration.

DOC.HEAD: GM Launches Second Move into Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. has reached an agreement with East Germany's state-owned automaker to jointly build Opel cars. The agreement signed Sunday by GM's West German subsidiary, Adam Opel AG, and Automobilwerk Eisenach represents GM's second move into Eastern Europe in recent months. GM earlier agreed to a $150 million joint venture in Hungary. Opel, based in Ruesselsheim near Frankfurt, and Automobilwerk Eisenach said they hope to produce 150,000 Opels yearly at the East German company's plant in Eisenach near the West German border. The cars will be marketed in East Germany, GM spokesman Jack Harned said Sunday. ``This has a lot to do with the unification of Germany,'' Harned said. ``We have a good presence in Europe. Now we'll have more of a presence in Eastern Europe. It's a very important move for GM.'' GM, the world's biggest automaker, did not disclose size of its stake or its partner's in the venture. Details were to be released later today. GM's venture to build vehicles with RABA, Hungary's state-owned manufacturer of trucks, diesel engines and axles, made GM the first U.S. automaker to invest in Eastern Europe since its political and economic liberalization. Ford Motor Co. says it is watching the Eastern European market. Chrysler Corp. sells cars in Europe but has no independent manufacturing plants there.

DOC.HEAD: Magazine Ranks Top Graduate Schools
DOC.TEXT: Harvard has the nation's top medical school, Stanford offers the finest business training, Yale has the premium law school, and Massachusetts Institute of Technology is the best place for a graduate degree in engineering, says a survey released today. A school's reputation among educators and in the outside world was a major subjective factor, said U.S. News & World Report in releasing the results of a survey evaluating U.S. graduate education in its March 19 issue. The magazine emphasized that the institutions receiving top ranking in the survey ``do not exercise a monopoly on quality education.'' ``Nevertheless, institutional reputations matter; in some professions, they may be crucial,'' the magazine said. ``Fairly or unfairly, the value of a degree from that institution depends in part upon those perceptions.'' Four professional programs were surveyed _ business, engineering, law and medicine. Harvard and Stanford placed in the top five in three of those categories, more than any other institutions. Harvard, in addition to being tops in medicine, ranked second in business and fifth in law. Stanford ranked second in engineering and third among law schools in addition to its top rating for business. The magazine developed its rankings after interviewing faculty members and deans across the country since last fall. The survey used objective standards _ quality of students accepted, value of the degree in the job market and research spending _ along with subjective measures such as a school's reputation. The subjective survey was done by the Washington office of Market Facts Inc. The magazine says it polled ``thousands of academic and professional authorities to determine how the experts on and off campus perceive a given institution.'' Although the rankings were dominated by institutions with established reputations, the survey also identified the ``dark horse'' institutions in each field by giving them a ``best-up-and-coming'' designation. Those were Washington University in St. Louis for business; George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., for law; University of Alabama at Birmingham for medicine; and University of California at Santa Barbara for engineering. U.S. News annually ranks undergraduate colleges, but this was its first graduate-level evaluation. The top schools in each category were: Business: Stanford; Harvard; University of Pennsylvania; Northwestern; and Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Engineering: MIT; Stanford; Illinois at Champaign-Urbana; California Institute of Technology; and the University of California at Berkeley. Law: Yale; University of Chicago; Stanford; Columbia; and Harvard. Medical: Harvard; Johns Hopkins; Duke; University of California at San Francisco; and Yale.

DOC.HEAD: No-Seat Railway Cars Debut, Commuters Complain of Being Packaged
DOC.TEXT: A Tokyo train line introduced seatless cars today to reduce overcrowding during rush hours and got a mixed response from commuters, some of whom complained of being treated like packages. The new cars on the crowded Yamanote loop line have foldable seats that can be lowered or folded back into the wall automatically by pushing a button, a railroad official said. The seats will remain folded during morning rush hour to increase the capacity of the cars and allow easier movement of passengers on and off trains, he said. Regular train cars on the line have a rated capacity of 144, while the new cars can officially carry 162 people, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The cars actually carry many more passengers during rush hour, when they frequently are packed so tightly that people can hardly move. Only two trains with two seatless cars each were introduced today as an a experiment, the official said. ``We will see how it goes and will decide whether we will continue the experiment,'' he said. The reaction of passengers was divided. A middle-age commuter interviewed by Kyodo News Service said he liked the new car because it was less crowded, and that few people are able to sit anyway in cars that have seats. Other passengers said they felt they were being treated like packages and were riding in a freight train. The train official dismissed the criticism. ``We decided to introduce the seatless cars to give better service and have never thought of treating our customers as packages,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cosby and Roseanne Dominate People's Choice Awards
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cosby and ``The Cosby Show'' dominated the People's Choice Awards with three trophies, while Roseanne Barr and ``Batman'' picked up two awards each. Meryl Streep, Tom Cruise and Dustin Hoffman captured the top awards Sunday in the movie categories, while musical honors went to Paula Abdul, Bobby Brown, Kenny Rogers and Randy Travis. Arsenio Hall took the first-time category as favorite late-night talk show host for his syndicated show, beating out Johnny Carson and David Letterman. Cosby won his sixth straight trophy for favorite male TV performer. He was also named as favorite all-around male entertainer. Miss Barr captured the same two awards in the female category, beating out Phylicia Rashad of ``The Cosby Show'' for favorite all-around female TV performer. The awards, determined by a nationwide Gallup Organization poll, were announced during a two-hour broadcast on CBS. The 22 categories spanned the entertainment world, from television, film and music. Here are the winners: All-around female entertainer: Roseanne Barr. All-around male entertainer: Bill Cosby. Female TV performer: Roseanne Barr. Male TV performer: Bill Cosby. Young TV performer: Fred Savage (``The Wonder Years''). TV comedy series: ``The Cosby Show.'' TV dramatic series: ``L.A. Law.'' Male performer in a new TV series: Neil Patrick Harris (``Doogie Howser, M.D.''). Female performer in a new TV series: Jamie Lee Curtis (``Anything But Love''). New TV comedy series: ``Doogie Howser, M.D.'' New TV dramatic series: ``Rescue 911.'' Late-night talk show host: Arsenio Hall. Motion picture: ``Batman.'' Dramatic motion picture: ``Batman'' and ``Steel Magnolias.'' Motion picture actor: Tom Cruise. Motion picture actress: Meryl Streep. Male musical performer: Bobby Brown. Female musical performer: Paula Abdul. Country music performer: Kenny Rogers and Randy Travis. World motion picture actress: Meryl Streep. World motion picture actor: Dustin Hoffman. World comedy motion picture: ``Look Who's Talking.''

DOC.HEAD: Teamster Whose Testimony Sent Hoffa to Prison Dies
DOC.TEXT: Edward Grady Partin, the labor leader whose testimony sent Teamsters boss Jimmy Hoffa to prison in 1967, has died at 66. Partin, who died Sunday at a nursing home, suffered from heart disease and diabetes. A native of Woodville, Miss., Partin was business manager of Teamsters Local 5 in Baton Rouge for 30 years. Partin, a close associate of Hoffa's, helped Attorney General Robert Kennedy convict him in 1964 of jury tampering. Partin testified Hoffa offered him $20,000 to fix the jury at Hoffa's 1962 trial on charges of taking kickbacks from a trucking company. That trial ended in a hung jury. James Neal, a prosecutor in the jury-tampering trial in Chattanooga, Tenn., said that when Partin walked in the courtroom, Hoffa gasped, ``My God, it's Partin.'' The government later spent 11 years prosecuting Partin on labor corruption charges before he went to prison in 1980 for conspiracy to obstruct justice by hiding witnesses and arranging for perjured testimony. While in prison, he pleaded no contest to conspiracy, racketeering and embezzling $450,000 in union money. He was released to a halfway house in 1986. Union members at one time voted to continue paying his salary while he was in prison. He was removed from office in 1981. Funeral services were scheduled for Tuesday. Survivors include his mother, two brothers, a sister, five daughters, two sons, two brothers and several grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Archbishop Too Hasty in Seeking AIDS Vaccine Volunteers
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic archbishop of Los Angeles acted too hastily in sending letters to elderly priests and nuns seeking volunteers to test an experimental AIDS vaccine, a key researcher said. Even the prototype vaccine's developer, Dr. Jonas Salk, the 75-year-old pioneer of the polio vaccine, was unaware of the appeal by Archbishop Roger Mahony, said Dr. Alexandra Levine of the University of Southern California. ``A plan to send letters seeking volunteers from the clergy had been agreed upon,'' Levine said. ``But we had no intention of sending the letters until after all of the necessary approvals for the study had been granted.'' Mahony, in Italy for a visit to the Vatican, confirmed he sent letters to 2,500 priests and nuns in January. Mahony said he was contacted by Dr. Brian Henderson of the Norris Cancer Institute at the University of Southern California, who was working with Salk and seeking volunteers. Levine works with Henderson and Salk. ``(You're) looking for people who would want to volunteer for something that could be very risky,'' Mahony said in an interview. ``You're really looking for people who have a commitment to humankind and willingness to take risks to benefit others.'' Because the vaccine contains deactivated AIDS virus, there is a possibility that people injected with it could become infected, just as many Americans were infected with polio in the early 1950s when Salk used the same technique to develop the vaccine that eventually saved thousands from the crippling disease. The infections resulted because some traces of the virus contained in the polio vaccine hadn't been killed. The state Department of Health Services is considering the request from researchers at USC to test 10 uninfected individuals who are at very low risk of AIDS infection, Levine said. On Sunday, Cardinal John O'Connor, who heads the New York archdiocese, said he would consider trying an AIDS vaccine himself if volunteers were needed and other members of his archdiocese wanted him to participate. ``Anything that is morally licit and makes a contribution should be considered,'' said O'Connor, 70. Henderson, who was the attending physician for the late Cardinal Timothy Manning, could not be reached by telephone Sunday. Already 100 people infected with the AIDS virus have been inoculated with Salk's vaccine, and the Food and Drug Administration has approved national tests for 1,000 others, Levine said. Levine is hoping tests on healthy volunteers will stimulate their immune systems to produce large quantities of antibodies against the AIDS virus. Those antibodies, in turn, would be removed from the bloodstream, purified and injected into AIDS patients, whose immune systems cannot produce antibodies. In addition, tests on healthy people may lay the foundation for a vaccine to prevent AIDS, Levine said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Shoot Man, Watch Him Die, Witnesses Say
With PM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Police looking for the killer of an army major stopped a young man, shot him four times at close range and sat under a tree watching him die for more than an hour, witnesses said. More than a dozen police officers shot at photojournalists to keep them from helping the young man and taking pictures, the photographers said. The attack on the young man Sunday occurred a day after Haiti's military ruler, Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, relinquished of power. The news photographers said they saw policemen stop a man in his 20s wearing red shorts at 12:30 p.m. near where Army Maj. Renaud St. Bert was killed on Saturday. ``People in the area said he was an innocent passer-by,'' Associated Press photographer Scott Applewhite said. Officers threw the man against a pickup truck, said Les Stone, a New York City-based free-lance photographer. Stone said the man was then shot four times at point-blank range in the stomach, buttocks and elbow with an M-16 rifle. ``He lay there dying on the black asphalt under the noon sun, moving his head now and then, and they didn't do anything to help him,'' said Applewhite, who arrived shortly after the shooting. ``Though there were bystanders who would have helped, the police wouldn't let anybody approach,'' said Applewhite. ``Police shot at us.'' ``I am not aware of this incident,'' Maj. Jean Robert Rene, police commander of the Delmar district of Port-au-Prince where the incident occurred, said in a telephone interview. Policemen allowed a Red Cross ambulance to pick up the man two hours after he was shot, Applewhite said. He followed the man to the hospital and said he died shortly after 3 p.m. on an operating table. ``Just as they brought in three bags of blood, his arm dropped and he died with his eyes open,'' Applewhite said.

DOC.HEAD: Miami Tribe Awaits Federal Recognition to Pursue Economic Plans
DOC.TEXT: Stripped of recognition by the U.S. government in 1897, the Miami Indian tribe has pinned its hopes of prosperity on regaining its identity. Federal recognition could translate into millions in economic aid and social services, while helping to preserve the identity of the 6,000-member tribe, based for centuries in the flat woodlands of northern Indiana. Since 1980, the tribe has submitted 10 volumes of documentation, including the names of each tribe member. Proof of the tribe's longstanding existence includes the Indiana towns named after Chiefs Muncie and Kokomo. The Bureau of Indian Affairs has promised to try to decide on recognition by Friday, although officials said the decision could be delayed. ``I don't see how it could go against us because the Miamis are probably the best documented tribe east of the Mississippi,'' tribal chairman Raymond White said last week. ``The word out in Indian country and Washington is that if the Miamis don't make it, there won't be another tribe that will make it.'' Under guidelines set up in 1978, landless tribes can gain access to federal aid and other advantages once they gain official recognition. The recognition process has proved to be a bureaucratic nightmare for the more than 100 tribes that have applied, mostly small tribes from the East and West coasts. Seven have been acknowledged and 12 denied, said BIA spokesman Carl Shaw. Recognition would allow the Miami nation to set tax rates for its businesses, sell tax-free municipal bonds and become eligible for programs administered by the BIA and the Indian Health Service. White, who runs the tribe on behalf of its ailing, 75-year-old chief, Francisco Shoemaker, has ambitious plans for the Miamis. Under his guidance, the tribe in December started a joint venture with Medi-Mail Inc., a San Diego, Calif., drug distributor. The tribe finds customers among Indian clinics and hospitals around the country for Medi-Mail. Recognition could open the door to a federal loan to expand the tribe's pharmacy business. The tribe also has plans for a 50-unit, federally funded housing complex and a health clinic in Peru. The drug warehouse and other projects would create about 100 jobs for the Miamis, about 2,000 of whom are scattered among eight northern Indiana counties, White said. The tribe has no land of its own. The tribe is working with the Indiana Department of Natural Resources to build a resort on the Mississinewa River near Peru. ``In a year to 18 months there would be $60 to $100 million in development started if federal recognition comes through,'' White said. For now, said White _ who also works full-time as a machine repairman at General Motors in Anderson _ the tribe is broke. ``We don't even have a budget. We're on a shoestring,'' he said. Mayor Richard Blair said recognition for the Miamis would provide a boost to the economy of Miami County. ``The feeling is positive,'' he said. ``Our heritage goes back a long way with the Indians.'' In fact, the Miamis' heritage goes back a bit further than that of the town. Once based in what is now Wisconsin, the tribe began hunting and fishing the area around the Mississinewa River in the 1650s. In 1816, Indiana became a state, and in 1846 the government forced much of the tribe to relocate to Oklahoma. The Miamis lost their treaty rights in 1893; the Oklahoma Miamis recently won federal recognition in a separate petition.

DOC.HEAD: Burgeoning Independence Movements
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a glance at the drives for independence or greater autonomy in other Soviet republics following Lithuania's declaration of independence Sunday: ESTONIA _ The People's Front in the Baltic republic of Estonia demands independence from the Soviet Union, but is moving more slowly than Lithuania. In local elections Dec. 10, non-Communists won about half the ballots. On Sunday an informal gathering calling itself the Estonian Congress called for restoration of complete independence with U.N. help. LATVIA _ The pro-independence People's Front won more than half the votes in local elections in December, signaling that it is likely to do well when it elects a new legislature March 18. Latvia last December became the second Baltic republic, after Lithuania, to abolish the Communist Party's constitutional monopoly on power. GEORGIA _ Nationalists are demanding independence from the Soviet Union and the republic's parliament has condemned its forcible annexation to the Soviet Union in 1921. Georgians vote for a new Supreme Soviet legislature on June 17, and independence will be a key campaign issue. MOLDAVIA _ The Moldavian Popular Front, an independent political movement, is the main challenger to the Communist Party. The front initially wants political sovereignty from the Kremlin, followed eventually by full independence from the Soviet Union. UKRAINE _ A nascent nationalist movement is emerging in the Ukraine, the Soviet Union's second-largest republic. Rukh, the organization of progressive nationalists, is the most vocal of several movements demanding an independent Ukraine. Rukh and other reform groups leaders say they expect to win about 25 percent of Supreme Soviet seats in runoff elections to be held later in the month. AZERBAIJAN _ Some Azerbaijanis, a Turkic and predominantly Shiite Moslem people, want to be united with their brethren across the border with Iran. In unrest in January, some tore down border fences with Iran. Azerbaijan is engaged in a bitter dispute with neighboring Armenia over control of the Nagorno-Karabakh territory that has sapped the authority of Moscow in both republics.

DOC.HEAD: Selma Mayor: City Hall Protesters Violating Court Order
DOC.TEXT: Blacks protesting the ouster of Selma's school superintendent defied a court order today and spent the night inside City Hall and in tents on the lawn. ``We're waiting to notify the judge that they're violating the order,'' said Mayor Joe Smitherman. About half a dozen protesters were inside City Hall over the weekend and slept there this morning and in two tents pitched in front. Circuit Judge Leslie Johnson on Saturday had barred protesters from spending the night, eating and playing cards in City Hall or disrupting City Council business. Dallas County Commissioner Perry Varner, one of the protesters, said they might begin complying with the order today. But he added sarcastically: ``We just got the order and it might take us two days to read it because they've tracked us into lower levels, you know.'' One of the protesters' complaints is ``tracking,'' in which black students are supposedly placed in lower-level classes. City Hall has been in an uproar since the white-controlled school board decided Dec. 21 against renewing the $80,000-a-year contract of superintendent Norward Roussell, Selma's first black schools chief. School board meetings have turned into shouting matches, students and teachers have boycotted class and protesters have occupied City Hall. The 6,000-student system was closed for several days in February for fear of violence. Smitherman said he was unsure what action the city might ask the judge to take against the protesters at another hearing set for this week or early next week. ``He could fine them, jail them, or both,'' the mayor siad. Roussell, who has held the job 2{ years, blamed his dismissal on racism. The school board cited differences over management. A commemoration of the 1965 Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march ended Saturday with some 3,000 people at the Alabama Capitol. The march helped spur passage of the federal Voting Rights Act.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Highest In 2{ Years, Tokyo Stocks Plunge
DOC.TEXT: The dollar hit its highest level against the Japanese yen in Tokyo in more than 2{ years today, sending prices plunging on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, traders said. The dollar rose above the psychologically important 152-yen level early in the day and ended the day's trading at exactly 152.00 yen despite profit-taking and extensive central bank intervention, they said. It was the U.S. currency's highest close in Tokyo since Aug. 14, 1987, when it finished at 152.40 yen. The dollar began the day at 151.68 yen, up from last Friday's close of 151.15 yen, and ranged between 151.60 yen and 152.18 yen. Participants predicted the dollar would move into the middle of the 152-yen range this week but remained wary of central bank intervention. Low volume in Tokyo because of the end of the Japanese fiscal year this month rules out a sudden rise, they said. The yen's decline sent stocks sharply lower in slow trading, as selling late in the afternoon by arbitrageurs boosted losses in the Nikkei Stock Average, traders said. The 225-share Nikkei index, which rose 302.23 points Friday, dropped 624.89 points, or 1.84 percent, today to close at 33,368.23, due in part to program selling linked to stock-index arbitrage, in which traders profit from price differences in the spot and futures markets, dealers said. Many participants stayed on the sidelines because of the yen's decline against the dollar, dealers said. Yoshio Shimoyoma, general manager of stock trading at Nikko Securities, said the yen's weakness didn't immediately cause large amounts of selling but caused a decline in buying interest, which in turn allowed a small amount of selling and arbitrage trading to push the Nikkei down sharply. Volume on the exchange's first section was estimated at 370 million shares, down from 664 million shares Friday. Bargain hunting by individual investors, encouraged by strong advances late last week, pushed the Nikkei above 34,000 points during the first 30 minutes of trading, dealers said. But the decline of the yen quickly reversed the Nikkei's direction, they said. The dollar was bolstered by its strong showing in New York Friday following the announcement of better-than-expected U.S. employment figures for February, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. The employment statistics showed that the United States found jobs for 372,000 more non-agricultural workers last month, compared to about 250,000 expected prior to the release. Traders said the Bank of Japan, the central bank, intervened repeatedly and sizeably in the market in an effort to stem the yen's fall. The bank normally does not comment on the amount of its market interventions. The yen's weakness, combined with lower bond prices and the falling stock futures index ``reminded traders how bearish the market still is,'' said an official at Wako Securities, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Although traders enjoyed a brief bullish respite late last week, they saw bearish market sentiment quickly re-establish itself when the yen continued to fall on the foreign exchange market, he said. Yields on benchmark No. 119 10-year government bonds closed at 7.240 percent, up from 7.160 percent at the market's closing Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Three Die in Tank Explosion
DOC.TEXT: An explosion and flash fire killed three workers renovating an empty 80,000-barrel oil storage tank at a refinery. The workmen were cutting the top off the steel tank at the Kerr-McGee Refinery on Sunday when a spark ignited vapors that had built up despite a ventilation fan, said Webster Parish coroner's investigator T.C. Bloxom. ``The buildup triggered an explosion forceful enough to blow the top off the tank, and that's one of the biggest tanks on the premises,'' Bloxom said. Kerr-McGee employees extinguished the fire, but it took three hours for the tank to cool enough for rescue workers in protective clothing to be lowered in to recover the bodies, Bloxom said. The victims worked for Baker Tank, an Arp, Texas, subcontractor hired to renovate the tank. Four men were hurt, two seriously, in explosions at the Kerr-McGee plant in 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Premier To Make Historic Moscow Visit Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng will travel to Moscow in late April in the first visit by a Chinese head of government to the Soviet Union in nearly 30 years, Soviet sources say. Li's trip, scheduled to begin April 23 or 24, follows the dramatic visit to Beijing by Soviet President Michael S. Gorbachev last May that ended three decades of bad blood between the two Communist neighbors. The exchange of visits, however, has come against a background of swiftly unfolding events that largely eliminated fears or expectations that a Sino-Soviet rapprochement would transform world strategic alliances. Gorbachev's visit was overshadowed by student-led pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing that led to a violent military crackdown in June and the ascendancy of a new hard-line leadership. Li's trip comes at a time of radical political and economic changes in the Soviet Union that have again dislocated any ideological compatibility the two sides might have had. Although China has not openly criticized the Soviet Union, senior leader Deng Xiaoping in internal speeches has reportedly accused Gorbachev of ``revisionism,'' a word used by Mao Tse-tung in condemning Nikita Khrushchev in the 1950s. Disputes between Mao and Khrushchev over ideology and leadership of the Communist world led to a final break in 1960 when the Soviets withdrew all their technical advisers from China. The last Chinese premier to visit Moscow was Chou En-lai, who attended a Soviet party congress in October 1961. Chou avoided meeting Khrushchev, blasted his policy of detente with the West and scorned the Soviet leader by laying a wreath on the tomb of his discredited predecessor Stalin. Li, who studied engineering at the Moscow Power Institute from 1948 to 1954, is said to speak Russian and has long been identified with Soviet-style central planning and stress on heavy industry. In December 1985, then-Vice Premier Li made a surprise stopover in Moscow on his way home from a European tour for a meeting with Gorbachev to promote warming relations between the two countries. The 61-year-old premier has denied, however, that he is pro-Soviet, and his talks in Moscow are not expected to produce any major agreements. The two sides could reach interim accords on ongoing talks to settle border disputes or lessen military confrontation on the 4,300-mile frontier. Increasing trade will also be on the agenda, as well as such international issues as Cambodia, Afghanistan, East Europe and arms reduction.

DOC.HEAD: Estonian Congress Asks U.N. Help In Achieving Independence
With PM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Estonians have appealed to the United Nations for help in breaking away from Moscow, calling for peacekeeping forces that would monitor an end to what they called 50 years of Soviet occupation. The proclamation Sunday by the unsanctioned but popularly elected congress came the same day Baltic neighbor Lithuania declared independence from the Soviet Union and two days after the republic of Georgia condemned the Soviet annexation of its territory. Today, the Estonian congress was scheduled to discuss the republic's borders and the status of non-Estonian residents. It is to elect a 77-member council, which will be charged with negotiating independence with officials in Moscow. The 499-member congress has no formal political power. But it considers itself the highest representative body of ethnic Estonians living in the republic and abroad. The congress on Sunday appealed to the United Nations to demand that ``the Soviet Union restore the independence and sovereignty of the republic of Estonia.'' It called for the help of international peacekeeping forces during a transition period. There was no immediate comment from U.N. officials. The congress also said in its declaration that Estonia was illegally annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940 and is ``to this day still occupied by the U.S.S.R.'' The congress said it is willing to work with the Estonian Supreme Soviet legislature for independence. But delegates are expecting many Communists in the Supreme Soviet to be swept out of office in elections March 18. So far the congress has only hopes that Soviet leaders will meet with its representatives. ``It is not a question of whether we want independence or not; it's a question of what kind of independence we want,'' said delegate Tunne Kelam, who opened the congress. Kelam said Gorbachev's demand of Lithuania for $34 billion in compensation for Moscow's decades of investment was a political ploy. ``It's just propaganda. Even if Estonia gets such a bill, our bill for damages from Moscow during 50 years of occupation would be much greater,'' Kelam said in an interview. However, in contrast to Lithuania and the third Baltic republic, Latvia, Estonia is treading a careful line. Estonia has a population of only 1.6 million. ``We don't dare take the bull by the horns _ not at this point in time. We must not provoke Moscow,'' Kelam said. The delegates to the congress included leading representatives of newly established political parties opposing the ruling Communists, but no high-ranking government officials. On Friday the Georgian Supreme Soviet legislature denounced the Soviet occupation and annexation of Georgia and called for talks on restoring Georgian independence. The Red Army occupied Georgia in 1921 and subsequent treaties made Georgia part of the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Father Finds Children Playing with Human Head
DOC.TEXT: Three boys unwittingly used a wrapped-up human head as a soccer ball before the father of one of the youngsters realized what it was, police said today. The head, found in the South Bronx on Saturday, may belong to a torso discovered along in a wooded area in Manhattan on March 4, police said. The boys, ages 9, 10 and 13, apparently pulled the head wrapped in rags out of a box of trash next to a fire hydrant on a dead end street, said police spokeswoman Sgt. Mary Wrensen. ``The kids started to play soccer with the object and then threw it into a trash can containing a fire,'' she said. Ralph Rodriguez was washing his car at the hydrant, Wrensen said. After the object went into the fire, Rodriguez noticed a leg sticking out of a garbage bag in the box and realized what the ``ball'' was. He looked closer and found arms and legs, police said. Area residents call the block ``the morgue,'' because five bodies have been found there in the past two years, the Daily News reported.

DOC.HEAD: Warm Air Brings Storms to the Plains
DOC.TEXT: Warm, wet air brought flooding and thunderstorms to the Midwest this morning, while a cold front dumped heavy snow on the Rockies. Rain sprinkled coastal Oregon and California this morning, with snow in the Sierra Nevada. The cold front was bringing some of the heaviest snowfall of the year this morning to Western mountains from Montana to Arizona. A foot of snow fell Sunday night in parts of Utah and up to 12 inches more were forecast. Snow advisories were in effect for mountainous areas of Colorado, Arizona, Wyoming and Montana and the Black Hills of North Dakota. Record high temperatures were set Sunday in 40 cities from North Dakota to Maine. Thunderstorms drenched Oklahoma, Texas and parts of Nebraska, Kansas and Louisiana. Rain fell from Iowa across Missouri and into Arkansas. In Kansas, tornadoes touched down near Hurchinson, Raymond, Lyons, Geneseo and Brookville. In Alden, a twister ripped the porch off a house. Flooding was reported in Minnesota, Wisconsin, Iowa, Texas, Arkansas and Kansas. Thunderstorms with winds up to 50 mph raked parts of central Illinois. Heavier rainfall for the six-hour period ending at 7 p.m. EST Sunday included 1.34 inches at Mineral Wells, Texas, .98 inches at Alpena, Mich., and .95 at Tulsa, Okla. Heavy winds blasted the northern half of Arizona and the high deserts of Southern California on Sunday night, and a high-wind watch was posted today in the southern foothills of Colorado. It was unseasonably warm in much of the nation east of the Rockies on Sunday. Record highs included Atlanta, 82; Boston, 67; Chicago, 74; Cincinnati 78; Knoxville, Tenn., 79; Minot, N.D., 66 and Portland, Maine, 62. The high in the nation Sunday was 88 in Columbia, S.C., and Augusta, Ga. DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Chile doesn't want more violence, it doesn't want more war. This infant being born, this liberty we are reconquering, we have to take care of it.'' _ Chilean President Patricio Aylwin, upon being sworn in Sunday to end the 17-year dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

``The information coming from Lithuania is alarming, and momentous decisions are being made there that will affect both Lithuania and the Soviet Union.'' _ Soviet President Mikail Gorbachev, of Sunday's declaration of independence by the Lithuanian legislature.

``As far as I'm concerned it wasn't one of our strikers. They've been like choirboys.'' _ Bill Nicholson of the the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, after seven passengers were injured Sunday by a shot fired at a bus operated by a replacement driver near Jacksonville, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Toll Workers' Illness May Have Been Psychosomatic
DOC.TEXT: An epidemic of dizziness, chest pain and sore throats among toll takers may have been at least partly psychosomatic, officials say. Between Feb. 16 and 22, 34 workers at the Triborough Bridge suffered such symptoms. Chemical fumes were suspected, and health and environmental experts investigated many possibilities but learned nothing, officials said. Medical experts said some of the characteristics of the plague were consistent with epidemic stress syndrome, or the spread of a psychosomatic illness through a group, The New York Times reported today. Anthony M. Mauro, president of the bridge and tunnel workers' union, said, ``I think the first 20 or 25 actually experienced heavy, non-breathable fumes.'' But he acknowledged the rest may have succumbed to anxiety. Bridge officials similarly concluded that the outbreak had a psychosomatic element _ but would not say so without assurances of anonymity, the Times said. ``It's a political hot potato to go on the record and say that it's psychological. The union will go wild,'' an unidentified official told the paper. Sheila L. Kennedy, a spokeswoman for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, was asked whether some of the symptoms may have been in the workers' minds. She said, ``It's very, very, very possible, but we can't conclude that.'' ``Can we prove it? No. I don't think we want to prove it. These people work very hard, and we don't want to make little of what happens to them,'' she said. Dizziness and head, throat or chest pain are among the most common complaints in epidemic stress syndrome, the Times reported. Bridge officials checked the workers' drinking water, uniform launderers, coins, coffee grounds, heating ducts and air vents. They examined nearby factory smokestacks and the heating system of a sewage treatment plant. Thomas M. Downs, TBTA president, said nearly $1 million was spent in the search.

DOC.HEAD: Governing Party Candidate Wins Primary, Begins Quest for Presidency
DOC.TEXT: A former aide to the presidential candidate assassinated by drug bosses has won the governing party's presidential nomination, and heads into the May general election as the front-runner. Cesar Gaviria of the governing Liberal Party claimed victory in Sunday's presidential primary, the first in the country's history, after all five of his rivals conceded defeat. He is favored to win the general election in May. ``This was Luis Carlos Galan's victory,'' Gaviria said, referring to the popular candidate whose slaying in August touched off a bloody war between the government and drug barons. Speaking to reporters late Sunday at a victory celebration at his Bogota headquarters, the 43-year-old Gaviria added that the win was bittersweet because Galan had died before ``the triumph of his ideas.'' Gaviria had been Galan's campaign manager. An economist by training, Gaviria has pledged to follow Galan's political program, including his strong committment to fighting the power of the country's cocaine cartels. But the candidate has said he may try suspected drug traffickers in Colombia rather than extradite them to the United States. In the May 27 elections, Gaviria is to face 47-year-old Rodrigo Lloreda, chosen as the opposition Conservative Party candidate at a national convention in November. President Virgilio Barco is barred by the constitution from running for re-election. The presidential terms is four years. With approximately 15 percent of the precints reporting in Sunday's primary, Gaviria had received 403,611 votes or 59.7 percent of the total while his nearest opponent, Ernesto Samper, had won 123,917 or 18.3 percent. The RCN radio network compiled the figures from counts by regional voting boards. The National Voting Registry had not made its own compilation by early this morning. Elections were also held Sunday for federal, state and local offices. RCN and another radio network, Caracol, predicted that the Liberal Party would win 60 percent of the 313 seats in the country's legislature while the Conservative Party, the main opposition, would win 37 percent. The Liberals previously held 178 seats, or 57 percent, and the Conservatives 126 seats, or 40 percent. Former leftist guerrillas from the April 19 Movement, or M19, were said to have received a small but significant vote, considering that they had laid down their arms and formed a political party only 48 hours before the polls opened. M19 members were in the running in two of the 1,005 mayor's races throughout the country. The day's only fatal election violence occurred when police shot and killed a member of another guerrilla group in a confrontation in the southeastern town of Puerto Nidia, said Gen. Nelson Mejia, the commander of the country's armed forces. Political violence left six dead on Saturday, officials said. The Liberal Party recaptured the Bogota's mayor's office, but the Conservatives won the office in Cali, Colombia's third largest city and were neck and neck with Liberal candidates in Medellin and Barranquilla, RCN said. Colombians also voted for or against a non-binding resolution to call a national assembly to reform the country's constitution. The proposed reforms are aimed at increasing the public's political participation and reducing political patronage and corruption. Extradition has been Barco's main weapon in his antidrug crackdown, which began hours after Galan's death.
