The administration has sent 14 drug suspects to the United States for trial and has maintained the policy despite an offer by Medellin cartel leaders to surrender if extradition is ended. Traffickers responded with 262 terrorist attacks, mostly bombings, that killed 209 people. They called a unilateral truce in the drug war on Jan. 17 and have said they are willing to surrender their illicit business and themselves if the government scraps its extradition policy and promises to try them in Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: ANC Leader Arrives for Six-Day Visit
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela arrived today for a reunion with fellow anti-apartheid campaigner Oliver Tambo in the country that has been the major Western supporter of the struggle against apartheid. A jubilant crowd of Swedes and Africans greeted Mandela and his wife, Winnie, at Stockholm airport. Standing in the remains of an overnight snowfall, they performed the toyi'toyi foot-stamping dance made popular by South African activists. Mandela was expected later today to have a quiet and private meeting with African National Congress president Tambo, recovering in a Stockholm clinic from a stroke. The two men, once law partners, have not seen each other since Mandela was jailed in South Africa 27 years ago and Tambo went into exile. South African President F. W. de Klerk freed Mandela and legalized the ANC last month in moves intended to promote white-black negotiations. Black nationalists seek a one-man one-vote system that would end racial segregation, while the government insists that group rights must be preserved for minorities, including whites. Now deputy president of the ANC and its effective leader, Mandela had planned to cut short his weeklong Swedish stay and leave for South Africa Thursday. He was reported concerned by growing unrest in black homelands and townships, and a warning by the South African government that it might intervene with emergency powers to end the violence. But an ANC spokesman said today that Mandela will stay in Sweden until Saturday, as originally scheduled. Unofficial sources said the Swedish government, which is to give the ANC $45 million in non-military aid this year, had urged Mandela to stay on. On his first trip outside Africa since his release, Mandela came from Tanzania, where he had been examined by a doctor after complaining of fatigue. On Tuesday he is scheduled to give a news conference and address Parliament. The rest of the week is largely filled with private appointments, including an expected meeting with British Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock and further sessions with Tambo. Cyril Ramaphosa, a member of Mandela's delegation, said during a stopover in the Netherlands that Mandela is likely to travel to the United States this year, where he has been invited by President Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Rise
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose in calm trading in Europe late this morning, bolstered by a weak yen, uncertainty about the West German mark and stronger-than-expected U.S. employment figures released last week. Gold prices also rose. Investors were cautious, waiting to see if central banks would return to the market after last week's repeated interventions to curb the dollar, traders said. The dollar rose to 152 yen in Tokyo, its highest rate in more than 2{ years, and that pulled the U.S. currency up against the West German mark in Europe, dealers said. But one Milan trader said: ``There's fear that the (West German) Bundesbank is going to step in and knock the dollar lower.'' In London, the dollar rose strongly against the British pound, which was quoted at $1.6080, compared with $1.6183 late Friday. Dealers cited Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's recent decline in the opinion polls, reported jitters among Cabinet members about her leadership and last week's violent protests against the government's new local tax on individuals. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Friday: _ 1.7069 West German marks, up from 1.7040 _ 1.5130 Swiss francs, up from 1.5115 _ 5.7700 French francs, up from 5.7615 _ 1.9205 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9150 _ 1,261.00 Italian lire, up from 1,258.75 _ 1.1800 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1792 In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.85 yen to a closing 152.00 yen. That was its highest level since August 1987. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 152.25 yen. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $399.50 a troy ounce, up from $399.05 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $400.40. In Zurich, the bid price was $400.40, up from $399.50 late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 27 cents to close at a bid $401.02. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.12 a troy ounce, from Friday's $5.11.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Reported Disciplined for Letting Tape Play in Court
DOC.TEXT: The government has suspended a federal prosecutor who publicly disclosed a tape recording on which an alleged mobster boasted of bribing a local Republican leader, a published report says. The tape, recorded secretly for federal agents, was played last month during a court detention hearing and set off a political uproar. The Chicago Tribune, quoting unidentified sources, reported Saturday that Jeffrey M. Johnson, a 17-year veteran prosecutor, was suspended for two weeks without pay. The U.S. Justice Department suspended Johnson, an organized crime specialist with the U.S. attorney's office in Chicago, at the request of acting U.S. Attorney Ira Raphaelson, and the suspension began a week ago, the newspaper reported. Raphaelson refused to acknowledge the suspension, and David Runkel, a spokesman for the Justice Department in Washington, D.C., said he had no knowlege of it, the Tribune reported Saturday. Nobody answered the telephone at Johnson's office during the weekend, and attempts by The Associated Press to reach him at home by calling several people with his name in the telephone book were unsuccessful. There also was no answer at Raphaelson's office, and his home number was unlisted. Rocco Infelise, a reputed crime syndicate gambling boss, was recorded saying he made payoffs to law-enforcement officials. Infelise said he had been making $35,000 in payoffs to police and officials each month, including $10,000 a month to the sheriff's office through somebody called the Bohemian. An IRS agent said in court that an informant had identified the Bohemian as James Dvorak, a former top aide in the Cook County sheriff's office and current chairman of the Cook County GOP. Dvorak denied wrongdoing and has survived efforts by fellow Republicans to have him replaced as GOP chairman. He complained to Raphaelson that Infelise's allegations were untrue, and that releasing them to the public was unfair and seemed to lend them credence. The tape was recorded Sept. 14 by an alleged bookie-turned-government informant who was wearing a recording device. Infelise also boasted on the tape that he helped Chicago Mayor Richard M. Daley win election last year by discouraging campaign contributions to a Daley opponent. Daley dismissed the remark as a fabrication. Infelise and others who were subjects of the detention hearing were among 20 people indicted on a variety of charges, including murder conspiracy, gambling and racketeering.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS Fiorilli; PMs separates moved as a0433 for Singhair; a0454 for Partin
DOC.TEXT: Former Mayor Patrick R. Fiorilli, who organized annual dandelion and eggplant festivals in Vineland, died at his home Sunday at age 59. Fiorilli suffered from diabetes and was hospitalized for two months after the amputation of his right leg in January 1989. A bachelor whose parents and brother are deceased, Fiorilli was mayor from 1976 to 1984.
DOC.HEAD: Edward Grady Partin
DOC.TEXT: Edward Grady Partin, the labor leader whose testimony sent Teamsters boss Jimmy Hoffa to prison in 1967, died Sunday at age 66. He had suffered from heart disease and diabetes. Partin was business manager of Teamsters Local 5 in Baton Rouge for 30 years and was a close associate of Hoffa's. He testified that Hoffa offered him $20,000 to fix the jury at Hoffa's 1962 trial on charges of taking kickbacks from a trucking company. That trial ended in a hung jury, but Hoffa subsequently was imprisoned. The government later spent 11 years prosecuting Partin on labor corruption charges before he went to prison in 1980 for hiding witnesses and arranging for perjured testimony. He was released to a halfway house in 1986.
DOC.HEAD: Martial Singher
DOC.TEXT: Martial Singher, a French baritone whose operatic career was cut short by a heart disorder, died at age 85 on Friday. Born in the southwest of France, Singher joined the Paris Opera in 1930, where he performed for 10 years. Singher headed to the United States after Paris fell to the Nazis. From his Metropolitan Opera debut in ``The Tales of Hoffman,'' in 1943, Singher was hailed for his elegant and precise style. A heart disorder ended his career at the Met in 1959 after performances in 200 operas there. Singher settled in Santa Barbara in 1962 to head the vocal department at the Music Academy of the West. He retired in 1981.
DOC.HEAD: James Coldsmith
DOC.TEXT: James Wesley Coldsmith, former editor and publisher of newspapers in Alexandria, Va., died Saturday of leukemia at his home. He was 60. Coldsmith was an editor or publisher of newspapers in the northern Virginia city from the 1960s through the 1980s and ran twice for the City Council as a Republican. He expanded an advertising flyer into what became The Journal group of newspapers in the Virginia and Maryland suburbs near Washington. Coldsmith earlier had been editor and publisher of the Alexandria Port Packet and the Alexandria Gazette. Born in Parsons, Kan., Coldsmith worked for The Associated Press in Tokyo, Denver and Chicago before moving to Virginia in 1966. Earlier, he served in the Army and was news editor of Stars & Stripes in Tokyo.
DOC.HEAD: Tseng Kwong Chi
DOC.TEXT: Tseng Kwong Chi, an artist and photographer who documented the downtown Manhattan art scene, died Saturday of AIDS at age 39. Tseng, who was born in Hong Kong and studied in France and Canada, chronicled the avant-garde art scene and photographed several well known art personalities. He exhibited in New York and Paris, and his pictures appeared in Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, Artforum, Art News and Traveller magazines, and also in several European and Asian publications. Published in 1984, Tseng's book ``Art In Transit'' documented the works of subway artist Keith Haring, who died of AIDS last month at the age of 31.

DOC.HEAD: Hard-Line Cleric Calls Hostages Spies, Urges Against Release
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Iran's radical faction said some of the foreigners kidnapped in Lebanon were spies and argued against releasing any of what he called the ``mercenary U.S. hostages.'' The comment came in an editorial signed by Ali Akbar Mohtashemi that was published Saturday in Tehran's Persian-language Kayhan and made available today in Nicosia. Also today, the official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted the son of the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini as accusing the United States of falsely trying to imply that ties with Iran are improving. Mohtashemi is a former interior minister who heads the faction that opposes President Hashemi Rafsanjani's openings to the West. In the editorial he attacked those who suggest Iran should help get the hostages freed. ``The Islamic Republic of Iran cannot and should not impose its policies and views on other Moslem nations,'' he wrote. ``Furthermore, the freedom of the hostages means breaking the chains of bloodthirsty wolves.'' ``The sentence for a spy in an Islamic country is death,'' Mohtashemi wrote. The Westerners held in Lebanon are eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest held is Terry Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Mohtashemi said a recent call for the hostages' release in the Tehran Times, which is aligned with Rafsanjani, and similar comments by Lebanese Shiite Moslem spiritual leader Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah ``heightened the pressure on the Islamic revolution and the Moslems of Lebanon.'' ``Instead of putting pressure on the wronged Lebanese Moslems to release the mercenary U.S. hostages, world public opinion should look for the center of hostage-taking at the White House and among Western and American intelligence services,'' he wrote. He claimed that some of the hostages were spies for the CIA, specifically naming Terry Waite, the British envoy of the archbishop of Canterbury who disappeared in West Beirut in January 1987. The church has denied this. Mohtashemi also said Col. William Higgins was a spy for the CIA. The United States has denied that. Higgins' captors said in July 1989 they had executed him. Khomeini's son Ahmad said Washington was trying to create the impression that ``relations between Iran and the United States are so close that when a person impersonates the Iranian president and calls up the U.S. president, he easily talks to that person,'' IRNA reported. He was referring to the incident a month ago when President Bush spoke on the phone to an impostor who claimed to be President Hashemi Rafsanjani. His comment echoed editorials Sunday in two radical Tehran newspapers, Jomhuri Islami and Abrar. They wrote that the United States was trying to ``insinuate'' that relations with Tehran are improving.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Scrambling As Primary Nears
DOC.TEXT: Three Democratic candidates for governor are fighting to keep their runoff hopes alive and the Republican primary field is hoping just to keep oilman Clayton Williams from a landslide. Severe thunderstorms hampered campaign plans Sunday for the candidates vying to replace retiring Gov. Bill Clements in Tuesday's primary elections. Poll results printed in Sunday's Dallas Morning News and the Houston Chronicle dampened hopes for opponents of Williams, who is favored by 55 percent of those interviewed for the GOP primary. Williams has spent about $6 million of his own money in his first bid for public office. State Railroad Commissioner Kent Hance, initially perceived as the front-runner, trailed with 13 percent, followed by Houston businessman Jack Rains and Dallas lawyer Tom Luce with 8 percent each. On the Democratic side, State Treasurer Ann Richards had the support of 28 percent of voters, Attorney General Jim Mattox had 25 percent and former Gov. Mark White had 24 percent. White criticized Ms. Richards' campaign for distributing a flier at black churches Sunday that said White had lied about supporting minorities. ``I think that mind-altering drugs may have longer term (effects) as far as her campaign is concerned,'' White said. ``Ten years may not be long enough.'' Ms. Richards has said she hasn't been under the influence of a mind-altering chemical in 10 years, since she was treated for alcoholism. She called White's remarks ``really pathetic.'' Mattox, in southern Texas, criticized Ms. Richards for what he termed her ``gutter-style'' campaign. Richard Murray of the Public Policy Center at the University of Houston, which conducted the poll, said the Democrats appeared destined for a runoff. ``There could be a lot of movement over the weekend,'' he said, making the runoff mates impossible to predict. In the GOP race, ``the question is not `Will Williams fall under 50,' but `Will he get over 60?''' Murray said. If no candidate finishes with more than half the vote, the top two vote-getters face each other in an April 10 runoff. The policy center polled 848 people between March 4 and March 7. The poll's margin of error was plus or minus 5 percentage points for Republicans and 4.5 percentage points for Democrats, Murray said.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0504 to fix cycle designation.
Vice President Quayle, Nicaragua's Ortega Meet, Shake Hands
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs, Quayle, Ortega meeting; picks up 4th graf pvs, Asked what ...
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle shook hands and chatted today with outgoing Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega, the leftist leader long shunned by the United States. Ortega and Quayle met inside the city's municipal cathedral at a mass celebrating Sunday's inauguration of Chilean President Patricio Aylwin. It was not immediately known what they talked about; the encounter was a casual one as thousands of people arrived for the early morning service. The scene was in contrast to past diplomatic occasions when high-level U.S. officials including Quayle and President Bush shunned Ortega, who was voted out of office Feb. 25. At meeting in Costa Rica last October, Bush referred to Ortega as a ``little man'' trying to crash the party. Quayle and Ortega were to meet again today at a luncheon given by Aylwin for visiting dignitaries. Quayle said at the outset of his week-long Latin America trip last Friday that he would be willing to meet with Ortega. And Ortega, arriving in Santiago Sunday night, told reporters ``I think it will be a good opportunity to talk with Vice President Quayle.'' Asked what he would expect to cover in such a meeting, Ortega said, ``We have a vast array of subjects to discuss with the U.S.'' He declined to elaborate. Quayle's chief of staff, Bill Kristol, said later, ``I suspect they'll have a chance to talk one way or the other. We'll see what happens tomorrow.'' Ortega and his Sandinista government were treated with hostility by the Bush administration. But Quayle said last week, ``There's no reason we shouldn't talk'' because ``it's a different situation now'' since Ortega was ousted in Nicaragua's Feb. 25 election by U.S.-backed candidate Violeta Chamorro. In addition, Quayle today was meeting with Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, who won a Nobel peace prize for spearheading the regional peace process that ultimately led to the election that ousted Ortega. The vice president also scheduled a meeting with Aylwin to discuss prospects for changing the U.S. military aid and trade sanctions imposed against Chile in protest of the harsh rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who stepped down Sunday. ``We will improve relations. I look forward to a very good meeting with President Aylwin tomorrow to discuss how we can make progress,'' Quayle told reporters Sunday. Ongoing discussions over Nicaragua center on how to achieve demobilization of the U.S.-supported Contra rebels and pass the reins of government to Mrs. Violeta Chamorro. U.S. officials are pressing the idea that the Contras could return to Nicaragua and remain temporarily in enclaves under supervision of United Nations forces. Arias and Ortega did not attend Aylwin's inauguration on Sunday. They were flying from Venezuela with President Carlos Andres Perez aboard a plane provided by Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez. Ortega said they had talked during the flight about the Contra situation and bringing peace to the region. He said they agreed there should be a meeting of the Central American presidents at the end of this month to talk about demobilizing the Contras and the peace process. Ortega and Arias were among leaders who chose to miss the inauguration rather than have to pay a protocol visit to Pinochet. But Quayle said it was ``the right thing'' to make such a call, and he visited Pinochet's home on Sunday morning. Quayle was jeered by about 400 pro-Pinochet demonstrators as his limousine drove up. They complained that the United States had been unfair in its diplomatic and trade pressures on Pinochet. Pinochet, under the constitution his regime wrote, still retains power of Chile's armed forces, but Quayle said after the 35-minute meeting that the general had promised him he would respect Aylwin's authority. He said Pinochet assured him ``there would be no problems between himself and President Aylwin _ when President Aylwin gave an order that order would be complied with.'' Later, as thousands massed in the square outside the presidential palace, scattered violence broke out between political partisans. Police used tear gas that affected some Quayle aides who were readying his motorcade for him to attend an evening concert at the Municipal Theater. Quayle saw none of the violence. On the 1{-hour drive back to Santiago from the inauguration in Valparaiso, his car edged through thousands of reveling Aylwin supporters who were waiting for their new president to return to the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Two Aftershocks to Upland Quake Reported
DOC.TEXT: Two mild aftershocks to the Upland earthquake shook parts of Los Angeles and San Bernardino counties early today, but no injuries or damages were reported, seismologists said. The first aftershock at 3:26 a.m. measured 3.3 on the Richter scale, and the second, at 3:29 a.m., measured 2.8, said Robert Finn of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. Both were centered four miles northwest of Upland, he said. Upland police received about 20 telephone calls from residents who reported feeling the aftershocks, but Lt. John Cannon said no injuries or damages were reported. The Feb. 28 Upland earthquake measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and caused nearly $13 million in damages, according to a preliminary estimate by the state Office of Emergency Services. The Richter scale measures ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of magnitude 2 is the smallest normally felt by humans, while a quake of magnitude 3 can cause slight damage. A magnitude 5 quake can cause considerable damage.

DOC.HEAD: Aylwin Takes Over for Pinochet, Street Clashes Mar Celebrations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede, SUBS grafs 21-22 pvs, `Several people...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with higher number of injured, arrested; Pickup 23rd, `Aylwin's interior...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: President Patricio Aylwin called for an end to violence and hate as he took over from long-ruling Gen. Augusto Pinochet, but street disturbances marred the celebration of an end to military rule. ``Chile doesn't want more violence, it doesn't want more war,'' Aylwin declared late Sunday from the balcony of the presidential palace after his inauguration earlier in the day. Thousands below cheered the end of Pinochet's 16-year rule. ``This infant being born, this liberty we are reconquering, we have to take care of it,'' said the 71-year-old Aylwin. He said that would require ``knowing how to respect one another, never again having Chileans divided into enemies.'' Aylwin's first official act was to pardon all political prisoners. His government also restored diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, East Germany, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and Poland. Chile is the last in a series of South American countries to restore elected civilian rule in the last decade. But Pinochet, 74, who seized power in a bloody 1973 coup that toppled Marxist President Salvador Allende, plans to stay on as commander of the powerful 60,000-man army and has rejected Aylwin's requests he retire from the military. Aylwin, who won office in December with the backing of centrist and moderate leftist groups, assumed office to thunderous cheers and applause in a half-finished congressional building in the seaport of Valparaiso, 70 miles northwest of Santiago. Beside him during the ceremony was Pinochet, his dark blue military uniform bedecked with gold medals. The general shook Aylwin's hand after Aylwin, a centrist Christian Democrat, slipped on the presidential sash. Aylwin has vowed to restore respect for human rights and civil liberties and put more emphasis on social services. But he plans no major changes in Pinochet's largely successful free-market economic program. A newly elected congress, dominated by foes of Pinochet, also took power Sunday. Vice President Dan Quayle said Pinochet assured him he will obey the new civilian government. Quayle, who attended the inauguration, was jeered earlier Sunday by Pinochet supporters upon arriving for a 35-minute meeting at the general's walled residence. ``Go Away!'' they shouted. ``Son of a whore!'' and ``Pinochet, Pinochet!'' A U.S. arms embargo placed on Chile since 1976 because of human rights violations remains in effect. The embargo was proposed by Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., who also was at the inauguration. Pinochet was forced to call elections when a proposal to extend his rule to 1997 was rejected in a 1988 referendum. He entered the new congress as supporters chanted his name and detractors in the gallery shouted ``Murderer, murderer!'' Earlier, a group of demonstrators tossed tomatoes and rocks at Pinochet's open-topped convertible limosine. He was not injured in the incident, which panicked horses carrying cermonially dressed soldiers. One horse bumped hard into the car. After the ceremony, Aylwin returned to Santiago, the capital, and hundreds of thousands of people lined the route into the city to cheer as he passed in an open car. The celebrants waved red, white and blue Chilean flags and chanted anti-Pinochet slogans including ``He's fallen now, he's fallen now.'' For years, during demonstrations against military rule, the most popular chant was ``He's going to fall.'' As darkness approached, bands of leftist youths set up barricades of burning trash and threw rocks and sticks at police. Helmeted anti-riot squads responded with water cannons and harsh tear gas, which spread through downtown streets. The clashes persisted for several hours before calm returned, leaving the streets full of debris, including pulled-up street signs and overturned police barricades. Several people were seen bleeding or overcome by the gas and Santiago's central emergency hospital reported early today that 122 people were treated and four remained hospitalized with broken bones. Police said 79 officers were injured, 10 of them seriously. Police were seen hauling off several youths, some of whom wore emblems of the Communist or other leftist parties. Police sources said ``more than 100'' demonstrators were arrested, but no exact figure was immediately available. Aylwin's interior minister, Enrique Krauss, said the street violence ``soiled the dignity, the cleanliness, of this occasion.'' Krauss spoke to reporters upon arrival at an evening ball for Aylwin, his closest supporters and foreign dignitaries. Another celebration was planned this evening in Santiago's National Stadium, long a symbol of political repression and human rights abuse under Pinochet. Upon seizing power, the Pinochet regime rounded up thousands of suspected dissidents in the stadium. They were interrogated and, according to human rights groups, many were tortured and some were executed. A clause in the 1980 constitution, written by Pinochet's administration, bars any new president from replacing him as army commander before 1998. Aylwin's term ends in 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MOSCOW
Entire Mongolian Politburo Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads thruout to change attribution, UPDATE with developments. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The entire Communist Party leadership resigned today in response to opposition demands and the leader of the longtime Soviet client state said the ruling party must renew itself to head off crisis. The five-man Politburo of the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party voted to abolish the constitutional clause declaring the party the leading force in society. It also set April 10 as the date for a special party congress to elect a new Central Committee that, in the words of party General Secretary Zhambyn Batmonh, should be younger and in favor of reform. The Politburo voted to hold early elections this year for the new legislature, the Great People's Hural. An exact date was not set. The moves were obvious concessions to protesters who crowded the central square of the capital, Ulan Bator, on Friday to demand change in the party's leadership and an emergency party congress. The demonstrations, shown on Soviet television, were evidence that the winds of democratic change that swept through Eastern Europe last year have reached Asia. Mongolia is a sparsely populated nation on the Soviet-Chinese border. The Mongolian Democratic Union, an organization similar to the grassroots citizens groups that have sprung up in the Soviet Union, is demanding an end to the Communist Party's 69-year-old monopoly on power, a mutiparty system and resignation of the premier, Cabinet and legislature. It has also called for new elections and for the withdrawal of Soviet troops. Two years ago, Mongolia's leaders followed the lead of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and embarked on political and economic reforms, but critics say it has been moving too slowly. Batmonh announced the Politburo decision in a speech to the 120-member Central Committee that was broadcast live. He also said he was giving up his No. 1 job in the party, though Mongolian officials did not rule out the possibility that those who resigned might be re-elected. As chairman of the Hural's Presidium, Batmonh is also Mongolia's head of state, and that job was not affected by today's announcement. The Politburo decisions must be approved by the Central Committee but all are expected to pass. The committee, which began meeting after the Politburo session, will continue its meeting on Tuesday. Batmonh said the party's main task ``is to build human and democratic socialism on the soil of Mongolia. It is important to renew our party leadership with younger people... people who are clever and constructive and for perestroika.'' He said the party should be the leading force in society but should acquire that status ``by its work and not from a constitutional article.'' ``We also recognize the main principle of Marxism-Leninism,'' Batmonh added. ``National unity and stability are very important for perestroika.'' A Foreign Ministry official said the next step, after the Central Committee approves the Politburo measures, will be establishment of a commission to prepare for the April party congress. Batmonh said this commission could include younger, reform-minded members. One of the tasks of the new Hural, once elected, will be to approve a new constitution. Work on the draft has already started. One of the goals of the new constitution will be to separate the roles of party and government. Batmonh said the draft for new party rules already being worked on internally should be published and discussed widely. ``The Central Committee has received many letters from ordinary workers and party organizations,'' he said. ``Some scientists sent an open letter to the Central Committee and worked out a draft program for party renewal.'' He said all of these suggestions were being considered. ``The party is ready to have active cooperation and negotiations with every force that is for democracy, socialism and improving the welfare of our people,'' the Mongolian leader said. ``The Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party will fight against forces that are against the interests of the people and extremist organizations.'' Batmonh also called for renewed effort to rehabilitate people wrongly punished in past political purges. ``There was a bad tradition that those who criticized the leaders of the party were punished,'' he said. He said this tradition should be eradicated and any possibility of a cult of personality re-emerging should be ruled out.

DOC.HEAD: Tornados in Kansas, Flooding Elsewhere in Central U.S.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after lead and 2 grafs after 5th graf, `Flash flooding ..., to UPDATE with Texas flooding; INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf pvs, `Residents of ..., to UPDATE with Des Moines power outage; pick up 9th graf, `In Arkansas ...
DOC.TEXT: Utah's biggest winter storm of the season dumped more snow today, while Kansans cleaned up tornado damage and scores of people in Illinois waited for floods to subside so they could return to their homes. In Texas, a 13-year-old boy drowned in a rain-swollen creek and a fisherman was rescued from the raging Llano River. The heavy, wet snow in Utah _ at least 10 inches at Salt Lake International Airport _ delayed airline flights and clogged freeways Sunday. More snow fell this morning along the Utah-Colorado border, with as much as 12 more inches expected today in Utah's mountains. In central Kansas, at least three tornados touched down Sunday evening in Rice County, damaging some buildings. No injuries were reported. At least two tornadoes were spotted in south-central Kansas, but no damage was reported. Flash flooding was reported after about 2 inches or rain fell in Kansas. Minnesota, Wisconsin, Iowa, Texas, Arkansas and Kansas also had flooding. In Texas, 13-year-old Paul Cooley drowned Sunday night after falling into a creek in the southwest Denton County suburb of Trophy Club. Authorities said the teen apparently was playing with two other 13-year-olds when he slipped and fell into the water about 8 p.m. In Llano, police and rescue workers dragged 45-year-old Billy Carrol Ratliff to safety after he was swept into the river. Officials said Ratliff was saved because he managed to grab and cling onto a tree until help arrived. Late Sunday night, thunderstorms with winds up to 50 mph raked central Illinois. Earlier in the day more than 200 people were forced from their homes along the North Fork River after storms Saturday dumped 4 inches of rain. Rescue workers helped about a dozen people from their homes by boat when the river overflowed. ``People are telling me that the water is higher than they ever remember seeing it before,'' said Bismarck Fire Department Chaplain Jim Russell. Residents of Danville, Ill., were warned Sunday to boil their water after flooding shut down pumps at a water station on Lake Vermilion, police said. In Des Moines, Iowa, about 500 Iowa Power customers spent a fifth night without power and were waiting for repair workers early today. A spokesman said the company hoped to finish the work by tonight. In Arkansas, emergency services officials spent the weekend documenting damage from floodwaters. ``If the governor releases any disaster funds, we must have a documentation of damages. It's wise to take pictures before repairs are done,'' said Jim Burns, director of the Clark County Office of Emergency Services. Strong currents on the Arkansas River just downstream from Pine Bluff pushed three barges up against a dam. Officials from the Army Corps of Engineers awaited a drop in the river flow so the barges could be moved. Residents along the Ouachita River near Camden, Ark., braced for a crest today of 40 feet _ 14 feet above flood level. ``When they say the river is going to hit 40, people around the river know what to expect,'' said Mark Norwood, dispatcher with the Ouachita County sheriff's office. ``They put things up and move in with relatives.'' The storm in Utah was the largest of the season, but not enough to overcome a dry winter, said William Alder, meteorologist in charge of the National Weather Service in Salt Lake City. ``One storm doesn't do it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Rate of Death Higher Among Those Taking Experimental AIDS Drug
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, ``I think ..., to restore dropped word `School.'
DOC.TEXT: AIDS patients taking an experimental drug under their own doctors' supervision have been dying at more than 10 times the rate of those taking the drug in clinical tests, The New York Times reported today. Out of 8,000 patients taking the new drug in an expanded distribution program, 290 have died, the newspaper said. But in clinical trials by the drug's manufacturer, Bristol-Myers Squibb, only two of the 700 patients taking DDI, or dideoxyinosine, have died, the company said. The Food and Drug Administration set up the expanded access program last August after people with AIDS and their supporters demanded the drug be made available through private doctors even before it was fully tested. AIDS sufferers' groups said they were willing to risk taking the drug _ which previously has been linked to pancreatitis _ to fight the fatal disease. ``I think it's a painful way to learn the lesson, but maybe it's the only way they'll learn that, to my mind, they did the wrong thing,'' said Dr. Thomas C. Chalmers, associate director of the technology assessment group at the Harvard University School of Public Health. Bristol-Myers Squibb said the increased death rate needs to be kept in context. ``We're dealing with a very, very sick population,'' said Kathryn Bloom, a spokeswoman for the drug company. She said the company, thus far, attributes the deaths to AIDS, not the drug, with the possible exception of five deaths from pancreatitis. One death from pancreatitis was reported in the clinical tests.

DOC.HEAD: Thieves Steal World's Largest Elephant Tusk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to delete reference to weight. Pick up 4th graf, `The 10-foot...'
DOC.TEXT: A 10-foot long ivory tusk believed to be the world's largest has been stolen from a Zairean national park, a police source said today. The police official said there are no clues yet in the theft of the tusk, which was kept in a science center at Kahuzi-Biega National Park, near the eastern border with Rwanda. He spoke on condition of anonymity and declined to give other details. The 10-foot-long tusk came from an elephant killed in 1943 in the eastern Kivu province, police said. Elephant herds in this central African nation have been nearly destroyed by ivory hunters, who have reduced the continent's elephant population from 1.2 million to 600,000 in eight years.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia Subway Resumes Service After Crash
DOC.TEXT: The city's east-west subway line reopened this morning on a stretch of track closed since a derailment last Wednesday killed three and injured 94. The reopening meant a return to routine for the 100,000 commuters a day who normally ride the Market-Frankford elevated train that dips underground through downtown. Trains were as crowded as usual and many riders said they had no qualms about taking the subway. ``No, I wasn't nervous; didn't even think about it,'' said Albert Cavallero. ``The train seemed to be going a little slower, stopping every now and then as if they were checking things out.'' Tony Scarpa, a Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority supervisor, said the line was ``a few cars short, maybe seven or eight'' for the morning rush hour. ``We're moving a little slower, a little under par, but not much,'' said Scarpa. A motor under a subway car became dislodged Wednesday morning, hitting a switch that sent half of a six-car train onto a second set of tracks. The three cars derailed. One car split open when it hit tunnel support beams, The accident was the deadliest in the system's history. About 30 mechanics have been inspecting cotter pins that help hold the motors in place under the cars, SEPTA spokesman Dave Murdock said. National Transportation Safety Board inspectors examined 76 motors on 19 cars Friday and found 27 cotter pins incorrectly installed.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Eclipses Quayle Among Chileans
With PM-Quayle
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDs 8 grafs, new notebook item at end, bgng, Quayle often ...
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle headed the U.S. delegation to the presidential inauguration in Chile, but another entourage member clearly was the bigger celebrity here _ Sen. Edward Kennedy. From the arrival of Air Force Two on Saturday night, the Massachusetts Democrat was unmistakably the center of attention. After Quayle made brief arrival remarks at the airport and prepared to leave, the local reporters and TV crews shouted for Kennedy to say something. When the senator and Quayle stood together, camera shutters clicked nonstop. Kennedy proclaimed it ``extraordinary to breathe the free air of Chile.'' He is famous here both because of the affection the Latin people hold for his two slain brothers _ President John F. Kennedy and Sen. Robert Kennedy _ and also because of his advocacy of human rights in Chile. Kennedy crusaded against the military dictatorship of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, who transferred the presidency on Sunday to Patricio Aylwin. Kennedy was the featured speaker Saturday night at a dinner honoring human rights victims. He also met with opposition activists with whom he has established relations over the years. ``One gave me his voting card. He said it was the most precious thing he owned,'' Kennedy said during a brief morning stroll outside his hotel where a local TV crew shadowed him. A round of applause erupted among the Chilean correspondents in a press room at Aylwin's inauguration when Kennedy was shown on a TV screen.

Not everyone was happy to see Kennedy in the nation that gave Pinochet 43 percent approval vote in a 1988 plebiscite. Pro-Pinochet demonstrators who greeted Quayle's motorcade when he visited the outgoing president on Sunday morning chanted anti-American slogans, including, ``Go away.'' Asked if they wanted Quayle to leave, some told a reporter they did. But one woman interjected, ``It's not Quayle. It's Kennedy we want to go home.'' Kennedy's motorcade was pelted with rocks and eggs on his last visit, in 1986. This time, the senator was afforded his own Secret Service detail during his stay in Chile. Describing the difference in the country's mood on inauguration day, a clearly pleased Kennedy observed, ``It was just smoke and riot gear last time.''

Although they were representing the United States together in Chile, the Democratic senator couldn't resist having some political fun with Quayle on the flight down. Quayle was conducting a question-and-answer session with reporters when Kennedy burst into the cabin bearing a gift for the vice president. He handed him a red New England Patriots jersey, with Quayle's name and the number 96 on it. The reference to the 1996 presidential election was lost on no one. Quayle, who does not discuss his future election plans, laughingly took the shirt without comment. Kennedy was also mum when asked later if he was trying to say that the Democrats would like Quayle to be their Republican opponent in 1996. Quayle's public opinion ratings are as low as President Bush's are high, a fact that is not lost on Democrats looking to a post-Bush era.

En route to Sunday's inauguration ceremony, Quayle made a typical motorcade stop to greet unsuspecting bystanders. As he shook hands, he repeated, ``Democracy, democracy,'' in a refrain praising the nation's return to democratic government after 16 years of military dictatorship. One man told him, ``The American people is very good. Now we need help in the United States, economic help for help democracy.'' Quayle promised he would discuss such matters with Aylwin today. But Chile's post-election polarization was again evident as the U.S. entourage departed. ``Viva Pinochet,'' one woman in a car yelled to reporters racing by.
A bit of anti-American sentiment apparently isn't much of a challenge for Quayle. Asked how he felt about the 400 pro-Pinochet demonstrators that jeered him, he said blithely, ``I've had worse.''

Quayle often stops to buy gifts for his children on his foreign trips. A stop in a curio shop in Valparaiso resulted in a purchase, however, that was anything but PG-rated. He picked up a small wooden doll that looked like a simple native icon until its head was pulled. Then it became anatomically correct. Quayle laughed with surprise, turned his back to the watching cameras and asked the shopkeeper what it cost. `I can take this home,'' he joked, calling to his unsuspecting wife, standing nearby: ``Marilyn!'' ``Dan, you're not buying that!'' she shrieked. When he laughed, she exclaimed, ``You're sick.'' Not to be dissuaded, the vice president sent an aide in for the $4 purchase.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Says Trident II Missile Test-Fired Off Florida Coast
DOC.TEXT: A Navy Trident II test missile was fired from a submerged submarine on a demonstration and shakedown cruise off the coast of Florida, the Pentagon announced today. The announcement said the fleet ballistic missile was launched Sunday night from the USS Pennsylvania, the second Ohio class nuclear-powered submarine built specifically to carry the missile. It was the 30th flight of the missile since January 1987, and was the second to be launched during a demonstration and shakedown operation, designed to test the ability of the crew to handle, maintain and operate the weapons system. After completion of such a launch, the submarine is then certified for deployment, the Pentagon said. The announcement said additional underwater launches of Trident II test missiles are planned in the months ahead.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Atlantis Grounded by Storms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with shuttle return delayed further, CORRECTS day of landing to March 4, sted Wednesday; pick up penultimate graf, `The next ...
DOC.TEXT: Bad weather will keep Atlantis grounded here another day, delaying the shuttle's piggyback ride back to Florida atop a Boeing 747, NASA officials said today. Overcast skies in Texas prevented the aircraft from taking off today from Biggs Army Airfield, where it landed Sunday for refueling, NASA spokesman Dick Young said. The modified jet, which is carrying the shuttle, had taken off earlier in the day from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. But thunderstorms and showers across the South forced the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to keep the plane on the ground overnight. One more refueling will be needed before reaching Kennedy Space Center. That site will be chosen depending on the weather, Young said. Atlantis touched down at Edwards on March 4, completing a secret four-day military mission that included the release of a $500 million spy satellite capable of taking super-sharp photographs and eavesdropping on communications. The next shuttle flight is scheduled for April 12, when Discovery is to begin a five-day mission to deploy the $1.55 billion Hubble Space Telescope. Atlantis' next flight in space is another Pentagon mission, set for July 9.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Troop Withdrawal From Hungary Begins
Precede BUDAPEST
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with pullout starting, leads into pvs 8th graf, `The Soviet...' Minor editing thereafter.
DOC.TEXT: The first of nearly 50,000 Soviet troops stationed in Hungary left for home today, two days after Moscow and Budapest signed an agreement on the total withdrawal of Red Army soldiers by mid-1991. The withdrawal began near the town of Hajmasker, about 75 miles southwest of Budapest, with the pullout of a battalion comprised of 300 soldiers and 40 armored personnel carriers. Hungary on Saturday became the second Warsaw Pact country to negotiate a full Soviet withdrawal from its territory. Last month, Prague and Moscow agreed that the Kremlin would bring home all of its 73,500 Soviet troops stationed in Czechoslovakia. The pullout there began Feb. 26. The withdrawals from both countries are due to be completed by June 30, 1991 and a total of 123,200 Soviet troops are scheduled to be removed. Both agreements are independent of any accord reached at East-West troop reduction talks under way in Vienna. The agreement on the pullout from Hungary was signed in Moscow Saturday by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his Hungarian counterpart Gyula Horn, who traveled to the Soviet capital for the official signing. The Soviet Union currently has 49,700 troops stationed in Hungary, as well as 27,146 military vehicles, including 860 tanks and 1,500 armoured personnel carriers. It also has six airports in Hungary, according to deputy Chief of Staff Jozsef Biro, who released details of the Soviet presence for the first time two weeks ago. Hungarian radio reported Saturday that the two governments were still negotiating on the property being left behind by the Soviet troops. According to the report, two-thirds of the withdrawal of Soviet troops and equipment is to be completed by the end of this year. The start of the withdrawal comes barely two weeks before Hungarians go to the polls March 25 for their first free multiparty elections since the Communists consolidated power in 1948. Some opposition members have suggested the new government might seek to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement with Moscow to move up the completion date.

DOC.HEAD: North Questioned Again About Lies At Meeting On Contras
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 11 grafs judge rebuking North; picks up 8th graf, Poindexter is ...
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North testified today that he had general instructions from John Poindexter to conceal his activities aiding the Contras from members of the House intelligence committee. North's second day of testimony at Poindexter's trial brought rebukes from the judge, who complained that ``it's like pulling teeth'' to get North to answer fully questions from the prosecution. Prosecutor Dan Webb hammered away at North's assertion Friday that ``nobody told me to lie'' at an Aug. 6, 1986, meeting with members of Congress in the White House Situation Room. Had North been ``generally instructed'' by Poindexter ``to conceal facts from Congress?'' asked Webb. ``Yes, conceal or withhold,'' replied North, adding that he had been directed to keep such matters secret from foreign governments and others. ``From Congress?'' North was asked. ``Yes, it's inclusive in that,'' North replied after Webb confronted the former White House aide with testimony he gave to Congress on July 8, 1987, in which he acknowledged getting the instructions. ``It's like pulling teeth'' to get North to answer Webb's questions, U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said as North resumed testifying. Greene twice rebuked North, telling him at one point, ``Let's try to stick to the facts.'' ``Yes, your honor,'' North replied. At another point the judge complained to North that he ``quibbles'' with the prosecutor's characterizations at certain times while ``you embroider at others.'' Poindexter is accused of obstructing Congress by allegedly concealing North's Contra activities. He also is accused of conspiracy, another count of obstruction and two counts of making false statements in connection with a November 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran. Webb had said Friday he would open today's questioning of North by focusing on the missile shipment. But the prosecutor returned to the Aug. 6, 1986, meeting on the Contras. North had testified that he resisted going to that meeting, but that Poindexter directed him to go anyway. However, North on Friday said neither Poindexter nor anyone else directed him to lie at the meeting. Before North's testimony resumed, Webb asked for permission to elicit testimony about North's three felony convictions in the Iran-Contra affair. He was convicted of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, destroying documents relating to his Contra activities and accepting an illegal gratuity. The judge said he would rule on the question later today. Regarding the Hawk missiles, North kept Poindexter, his boss on the National Security Council staff, informed of the missile shipment at the time it occurred. Poindexter, however, told the House and Senate intelligence committees on Nov. 21, 1986, that he did not learn of the delivery until more than a month after it was completed. Poindexter says he gave incorrect information to the committees because he had simply forgotten a year later that he knew of the shipment beforehand. Iran-Contra prosecutors are unfairly bringing charges against Poindexter for ``a five-week mistake,'' defense attorney Richard Beckler said in opening arguments last week. The CIA-assisted delivery was authorized retroactively by a presidential document that Poindexter destroyed the same day he made his incorrect statements to the intelligence committees. The politically embarrassing document, known as a ``finding,'' depicted the U.S. government as being involved in a straight arms-for-hostages deal with Iran. North testified at his own trial last year that he watched Poindexter destroy the paper. ``I saw the finding torn up,'' North said then. ``I saw him tear it in two.'' The government alleges the existence of the document was Poindexter's motive for concealing from Congress U.S. involvement in the November 1985 missile. But at a pretrial hearing in Poindexter's case last December, North said he understood the destroyed document was the finding only after watching Poindexter testify about it in nationally televised congressional hearings. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene said North was ``prevaricating'' at the December hearing in an attempt avoid having to testify against his ex-boss. Poindexter was granted conditional immunity by Congress for his testimony, and no part of a prosecution may be derived from the immunized testimony of a defendant. Greene, however, said North's testimony at the December hearing was not believable and that prosecutors would be allowed to elicit North's testimony on the destruction of the document. On Friday, North reluctantly testified that Poindexter directed him ``to take care of'' congressional inquiries about whether he was assisting the Nicaraguan Contra rebels militarily. But North insisted that he himself made the decision to lie when he met with the congressmen and that neither Poindexter nor anyone else ordered him to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Congress Meets to Vote on Creation of New Powerful Presidency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd pvs, `And Gorbachev's...' to UPDATE with session closing for day without a vote. Pick up 5th pvs, `The divisions...'
DOC.TEXT: A divided Soviet Congress today debated the powerful presidency championed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev as essential for democracy, and the proposal faced possible rejection for lack of the required two-thirds majority. But one progressive deputy who has fought placing so much power in the hands of one man said he would have to cave in if Gorbachev were to stake his own leadership on the issue. And Gorbachev's vice president argued that the proposal for a new presidency ``rules out personal dictatorship.'' The session fell behind schedule and closed for the day without a vote on the presidency, despite Gorbachev's urgings to keep to a tight schedule. The divisions in the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies reflected the turmoil in Soviet politics as Gorbachev begins his sixth year as Soviet leader. The president and Communist Party chief told the 2,087 deputies present that they would be asked to amend the constitution to revoke the party's monopoly on power, create a new presidency and, if the presidency proposal is adopted, to elect the new president. ``We find ourselves in a paralysis of power,'' said Sergei Alexeyev, chairman of the congress' Constitutional Committee, who took the floor in support of Gorbachev. ``The presidency is the only way to transfer the real power from the party to the government.'' If the presidency issue is resolved positively, ``we can get down to drafting a new constitution immediately which will confirm human rights, democracy and conversion to a market economy,'' he said. The president will have the power to veto laws, appoint a Cabinet, declare a state of emergency and presidential rule. Opponents say that concentrates too much power in the hands of one person. Progressive Moscow parliamentarian Alexei Yablokov predicted a boycott of the vote on the presidency by many of the deputies from Georgia, Moldavia, Azerbaijan, Estonia and Latvia. On Friday, Georgia's parliament denounced the office as ``authoritarian presidential rule.'' Before the session began, progressive parliamentarian Sergei Stankevich said he expected about a third of the deputies to abstain from voting on the expanded presidency. Estonian deputy Igor Griazin said the Estonian delegation would abstain because prticipating in the creation of the presidency ``can be interpreted as an indirect acknowledgement of Moscow's rule.'' Estonia, although it has not gone as far as Lithuania, has moved to distance itself from the Kremlin. Lithuania declared itself independent on Sunday. As the congress session opened today Gorbachev, noting the absence of the chairman of the Lithuanian delegation, said, ``The information coming from Lithuania is alarming, and momentous decisions are being made there that will affect both Lithuania and the Soviet Union.'' Most of the Lithuanian seats at the Congress in the Kremlin were vacant. Gorbachev gave no indication he would seek to prevent Lithuania's secession, although he has opposed it. Stankevich said Gorbachev could turn the presidency issue into a vote of confidence in his own stewardship. If the Soviet leader threatened to resign, Stankevich said, then the deputies will give him what he wants. The legislator, who strongly objects to the specific powers given to the president in the draft, said that if Gorbachev threatened to resign, he would throw his support behind him. ``I will vote for Gorbachev,'' Stankevich said. Gorbachev has said the new presidency is necessary to ensure that his campaign for democratization and domestic reform do not fail. His view was overwhelmingly endorsed on Feb. 27 by the country's smaller working legislature, the Supreme Soviet, which is elected by the Congress from among its own membership. Vice President Anatoly I. Lukyanov, in his speech to the Congress on today, stressed the limits that would be placed on the new president. He said the president would be subject to recall by the Congress and that the proposal would for the first time establish a clear balance of power between the legislative and executive branches of government. Gorbachev, in his present post, holds executive authority while also presiding over the Congress of People's Deputies and the Supreme Soviet. Lukyanov also pointed out a presidential veto could be overridden by a two-thirds majority of both houses of the Supreme Soviet legislature, which is similar to the U.S. president's veto power. And while the Soviet president would have power to declare war, Lukyanov said the president would be required to ``immediately solicit the determination of the Supreme Soviet.'' The new office must be created by a constitutional amendment, which requires a two-thirds majority of all deputies _ not just those voting. A boycott by a substantial number of deputies, therefore, could torpedo the proposal. Members of the Inter-regional Group, a parliamentary opposition of some 400 Congress members, planned either to vote against the proposed constitutional amendments establishing the presidency or abstain, group leader Gavriil Popov told a news conference Sunday. Inter-regional Group members say their constituents want the right to directly elect the president from the start. However, Popov said the opposition deputies would not field a candidate to oppose Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: Second Brother Arrested in Millionaire Parents' Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of name in 2nd graf to Erik, sted Eric; pick up 3rd graf, `His brother ...
DOC.TEXT: A 19-year-old tennis pro charged with his brother in the shotgun slayings of their millionaire parents returned home from a tournament in Israel and surrendered to police waiting at the airport. Erik Menendez, 19, was arrested early Sunday after arranging the surrender through his attorney, said police Lt. Bob Curtis. Menendez was booked for investigation of murder and jailed without bail. His brother, 22-year-old Lyle Menendez, was arrested Thursday. He was held without bail for arraignment today. Curtis said he did not know when Erik Menendez would be arraigned. The brothers were charge with two counts of homicide each in the slayings of their parents, Jose Menendez, 45, and Mary Louise ``Kitty'' Menendez, 44. The couple were shot to death Aug. 20 in their $5 million Beverly Hills mansion. The sons reported finding the bodies upon returning from a night on the town. The young men are heirs to the $14 million estate of Jose Menendez, an executive of Live Entertainment Inc., a video distribution company. Erik, who decided on a tennis career after his parents' deaths, had been playing in a tournament when he received word of his brother's arrest. Police have said two killers committed the crime, then picked up shell casings from the .12-gauge shotguns they used before fleeing. The Los Angeles Times reported Saturday that a friend found a .12-gauge casing in one of Lyle's jackets. It was held as evidence. Police who served search warrants at a psychologist's office Thursday also obtained tape recordings, apparently of counseling sessions involving the sons, which are likely to be the subject of a court hearing on their admissibility.

DOC.HEAD: Defying Threat, Teachers Refuse to Call off Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with strike spreading to 46 counties, 150,000 pupils, vandalism reported; pick up 4th graf, `Leaders of ...
DOC.TEXT: Teachers across West Virginia today heeded their union's refusal to call off a growing strike despite a warning from the governor that those who didn't come back could lose their jobs. A proposed settlement of the state's first teacher walkout collapsed over the weekend. The largest teachers union says West Virginia has the second-lowest teachers' salaries in the nation. The strike over pay began Wednesday and by today had spread to 46 of the state's 55 counties. Classes were canceled in at least 27 counties for more than 150,000 pupils, about half the state's enrollment. In Ohio County, classes had to be canceled when officials found most of the district's 47 school buses had flat tires, Superintendent H. Lawrence Jones said. It was unclear who was responsible, he added. Leaders of the 16,000-member West Virginia Education Association recommended continuing the strike until Gov. Gaston Caperton promises to call a special legislative session to consider pay raises. But Caperton said he won't consider calling a special session until the teachers go back to work. Last week, Attorney General Roger Tompkins declared the strike illegal and said any teachers who walk off the job can be suspended, fired, barred from teaching for a year and charged with misdemeanors. After the proposed settlement collapsed, Caperton said he would ask county superintendents to begin disciplinary action against any teachers who continue to strike. State School Superintendent Hank Marockie met on Sunday with the 55 county superintendents but said he would wait to see how many teachers returned today before deciding what action to recommend. Teachers are employed by county school boards, and it is up to county school superintendents to take any action against striking teachers, including suspension or firing. ``County superintendents will follow those rules and make it strict and the consequences are pretty bad,'' Caperton said. ``It's very clear by law what they're to do. I've asked them to do that.'' Association members voted overwhelmingly Saturday to go back to work for 30 days if Caperton called a special legislative session. But Association President Kayetta Meadows accused the governor of reneging on a promise to call a special session, and she said late Saturday, ``We have no choice but to continue a statewide strike.'' Caperton termed Meadows' accusation ``a total lie'' _ but he did not rule out calling a special session. ``We did not commit ourselves or close the door to a special session,'' Caperton spokesman G.C. Morse said. ``This is ludicrous.'' Leaders of the other main striking union, the 3,000-member West Virginia Federation of Teachers, recommended an end to the strike but said the decision was up to teachers in each county. Another 3,000 teachers are not represented by either union. The association's former president, Tom Vogel, late Sunday urged striking members to ignore Meadows and return to work today. ``The governor assured me he will begin talking immediately upon the return of teachers to the classroom,'' said Vogel, who did not run for re-election in 1988 and was replaced by Meadows. ``We have stood proud and tall and we have made our point, but now is the time to solve the problems and the only way we really can is by working directly with the governor and the Legislature.'' Saturday's aborted settlement was the second in a week. Last Monday, the governor and legislative leaders offered teachers a 5 percent raise but withdrew the proposal 14 hours later, saying the association's refusal to lift its strike threat ruined any chance of passage in the Legislature. The association says the average West Virginia teacher salary of $21,904 ranks the state 49th in the nation. That figure does not include a 5 percent raise teachers received in February. Teachers objected when the governor provided no money in his 1990-91 budget for an additional raise.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Asks Gorbachev to Respect `Will of the Citizens'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADs with 10 grafs White House, Gorbachev comments; picks up 4th graf pvs, The United ...; edits at bottom to tighten
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration today expressed support anew for Lithuania's move toward independence, but said it will delay formal recognition of the breakaway republic until the Lithuanians are ``in control of their own destiny.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater reiterated the administration's call upon the Soviet central government to ``respect the will of the citizens'' of the Baltic state. But the administration stopped short of recognizing the government formed by a unanimous vote Sunday of the new Lithuanian parliament in Vilnius. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, opening a congress of communist party deputies today in Moscow, called Lithuania's declaration of independence ``alarming'' but gave no indication he plans any action to prevent the Baltic republic from seceding. Gorbachev has said previously that Lithuania would have to pay the Kremlin $34 billion for the factories and other infrastructure built during a half-century of Soviet rule. Lithuanians say they are owed even more for decades of Soviet repression _ including mass deportations to Siberia under Stalin. Fitzwater, asked at a briefing why the United States did not immediately recognize the new Lithuanian government, said, ``Because we would want any recognition to take into account a final government that was in control of their own destiny, and much of that has yet to be negotiated with the Soviet Union.'' He emphasized the United States has never recognized the Soviet Union's forcible annexation in 1940 of Lithuania and its two sister Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia. He said the United States wants ``to foster productive negotiations.'' ``We believe this is the right measure of support,'' Fitzwater said. ``It reflects our policy of many years of not recognizing their incorporation in the first place. It reflects the fact that they still have negotiations to carry out that we want to be successful.'' The White House, in a statement Sunday by Fitzwater, urged Gorbachev to enter ``immediate constructive negotiations'' with the Lithuanians, and said, ``We have consistently supported the Baltic peoples' inalienable right to peaceful self-determination.'' It urged ``the Soviet government to respect the will of the citizens of Lithuania as expressed through their freely elected representatives.'' The United States also ``expects the government of Lithuania to consider the rights of its minority population,'' he said. ``We hope that all parties will continue to avoid any initiation or encouragement of violence,'' Fitzwater said. A Lithuanian diplomat in Washington said Western governments are likely to wait to recognize Lithuania's declaration of independence until its leaders resolve disputes with Moscow and establish control over their country. Stasys Lozoraitis, charge d'affaires for Lithuania, said U.S. officials had told him beforehand ``they want to see the government take over effective control'' before formally recognizing it. ``All Western powers are inclined to wait,'' the Lithuanian diplomat said. But he predicted recognition could come ``after one month or two.'' The United States and other Western nations have never recognized the Soviet Union's forcible annexation of Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors while under Red Army occupation. The three states, once part of czarist Russia, had gained independence after World War I. In 1940, a year after the infamous non-aggression pact between Stalin's Soviet Union and Hitler's Germany, the Soviet Army imposed regimes that rubberstamped the three republics' incorporation into the Soviet Union. The Baltic states were overrun by Hitler's Nazi troops and subject to terror and death camps, and terrorized again by Stalin's secret police after the Red Army recaptured the lands. More than 1 million people perished in the Baltic States during World War II. Fitzwater, in a written statement, said: ``The United States believes it is in the mutual interest of Lithuania, the Soviet Union and all CSCE countries to resolve this issue peacefully. We call upon the Soviet government to address its concerns and interests through immediate constructive negotiations with the government of Lithuania.'' The CSCE is the 3-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, also known as the Helsinki process. It includes all the nations of Europe except Albania, and also the United States and Canada. The Helsinki process, which produced pan-European agreements on arms control and human rights in 1975, is now regarded as a way to help shape the new Europe in the wake of the dramatic shifts toward democracy across the East Bloc.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Lithuanian Declaration of Independence
DOC.TEXT:
Text of the Lithuanian Supreme Council's declaration of independence, approved Sunday by a vote of 124-0 with six abstentions. The English-language translation was obtained from the Sajudis political movement.
The Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania, expressing the will of the nation, resolves and solemnly proclaims that the execution of the sovereign power of the Lithuanian state, heretofore constrained by alien forces in 1940, is restored, and henceforth Lithuania is once again an independent state. The February 16, 1918 Act of Independence of the Supreme Council of Lithuania and the May 15, 1920 Constituent Assembly Resolution on the restoration of a democratic Lithuanian state have never lost their legal force and are the constitutional foundation of the Lithuanian state. The territory of Lithuania is integral and indivisible, and the constitution of any other State has no jurisdiction within it. The Lithuanian state emphasizes its adherence to universally recognized principles of international law, recognizes the principles of the inviolability of borders as formulated in Helsinki in 1975 in the Final Act of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and guarantees rights of individuals, citizens and ethnic communities. The Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania, expressing sovereign power, by this act begins to achieve the State's full sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Man Shoots Wife, Then Self Inside Church
DOC.TEXT: A man who walked into a church, shot his estranged wife and killed himself had been arrested for violating a judge's order to stay away from her, authorities say. About 50 people were at the Byng Free Will Baptist Church on Sunday when David Leon Lynch, 31, shot Tawanna Jo Lynch, 32, twice in the head before shooting himself, Pontotoc County sheriff's Deputy John Christian said. Mrs. Lynch was taken to St. Anthony's Hospital in Oklahoma City, where she was in critical condition today, a hospital spokeswoman said. She was scheduled to undergo surgery later in the day. Lynch, who was pronounced dead at the church, entered the building by a side door, walked across the back and up the side aisle and spoke to his wife, Christian said. Witnesses told investigators Lynch said something like, ``I told you I was going to get you,'' before shooting his wife, Undersheriff Jeff Glase said. The couple, who have two children, recently filed for divorce and had been separated for about a month, Christian said. He said Mrs. Lynch had received a temporary protective order, and that Lynch was arrested Feb. 22 for violating the order. Christian also said Lynch had a long criminal record, with convictions of knowingly concealing stolen property, intimidating a witness, assault and public drunkenness.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Party Gives Peres Mandate to End Coalition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Labor party giving Peres mandate to end coalition, trims. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Party today blamed Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc for undermining peace efforts and authorized party leaders to bring down the coalition government. In a nationally broadcast speech, Labor leader Shimon Peres told the 1,300 members of the center-left party's Central Committee that Shamir was stalling and would not respond to U.S. peace proposals. ``We have reached a conclusion that Shamir will try to run a policy of saying neither yes or no. He will try to avoid the decision and will pull us into the desert of indecision,'' said Peres, who is finance minister and vice premier. On Sunday, Shamir refused to allow the 12-member Inner Cabinet to vote on a U.S.-backed peace plan, which aims to set up preliminary peace talks between Palestinian and Israeli delegations in Cairo. The Labor members today approved a vaguely worded resolution, with only one member dissenting. The resolution authorized the party leadership and the 39 Labor members in the 120-seat parliament to ``determine the parliamentary moves necessitated by the situation.'' That gave Peres a mandate to join with other, smaller parties to support a no-confidence motion expected to be brought before Parliament Thursday, unless a compromise can be worked out in the meantime. A no-confidence vote would bring down the 15-month-old government. Before the Labor announcement, Religion Minister Zevulun Hammer met separately with Israel's four top political leaders _ Shamir, Peres, Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Likud and Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Labor _ to try to mediate a compromise, Israel radio said. But Shamir aide Avi Pazner said there seemed little room left for agreement. ``It looks like the two parties are going for a showdown Thursday. It would take a miracle to reach a compromise before that,'' he said. Israeli newspapers said Shamir was considering firing the Labor Cabinet ministers to prevent them from becoming part of a transitional government, which would be set up if parliament gave the government a no-confidence vote. The Labor Party would then be in a weaker position if national elections are called, the English-language Jerusalem Post said. It would also put the transitional government entirely under Shamir. Labor has backed the proposals put forward by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III to begin preliminary peace talks. Shamir and his Likud bloc have resisted the Baker plan, saying his call for participation in the talks by residents of Arab east Jerusalem could threaten Israel's declared sovereignty over the area. They also oppose allow deportees from the territories to participate, saying this could provide a back-door entry to the PLO. Israel considers the Palestine Liberation Organization a terrorist organization and refuses to deal with it. Also today, Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian youth, Jemal Muhammed Haleefa, 17, during a stone-throwing clash in the Ahbat Jaber refugee camp in Jericho, Arab hospital officials said. The army confirmed the death and said soldiers opened fired when attacked by a group of masked youths. Haleefa's death raised to 653 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the 27-month revolt against Israeli rule of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Another 195 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, and 43 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Surrealist Writer Philippe Soupault Dead at 92
DOC.TEXT: Writer and poet Philippe Soupault, one of the founders of the surrealist movement, has died at the age of 92. Soupault died Sunday night in his Paris home. No cause of death was announced. ``The Magnetic Fields,'' a poem Soupault wrote with Andre Breton, was first published in 1919 and is considered the work that gave birth to the surrealist movement. Born in the exclusive Paris suburb of Chaville and educated at the Sorbonne, Soupault was influenced by the works of Marcel Proust and his voyages to Germany and England. But the horrors of World War I proved a stronger influence, and in March 1919 he joined Breton and Louis Aragon to found the review ``Literature.'' The magazine quickly became the standard-bearer for intellectuals disillusioned with the bourgeois culture they believed caused the war. The journal published Soupault's poem ``Westwego'' and other works, but he eventually fell out with Breton and the surrealist movement, accusing it of having become politicized. Soupault continued to write poetry and novels including ``The Negro.'' He turned to journalism in the 1930s, reporting for the Petit Parisien newspaper and founding Radio Tunis in 1938. He married Renee Niemeyer in 1937. They had two daughters. After World War II, Soupault directed the overseas broadcasts of Radio Television Francaise and continued to work in broadcasting into the 1970s. He continued writing poetry, including ``Day and Night Song'' and ``Without Sentences,'' brought together in the ``Poems and Poetry'' collection in 1973. His last published work was ``Memoires of the Forgotten'' in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Foreign Minister Has `High Hopes' of China Relations
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's foreign minister stopped briefly in Beijing on Monday and expressed ``high hope'' the two countries would soon agree to diplomatic relations. Foreign Minister Choi Ho-joong did not meet any Chinese officials, but conferred with U.S. Ambassador James Lilley and Pakistan Ambassador M. Akram Zaki during his hour-long stay at Beijing airport. He left Tokyo aboard a commercial flight earlier Monday for an 11-day trip that will take him to Pakistan, India, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. In Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria, Choi is to sign protocols establishing normal diplomatic relations with those countries. Choi said he was carrying no messages for Chinese officials and that his only objective during the stopover was to meet his ``old friend'' Lilley, who formerly served as U.S. envoy to Seoul. ``We can exchange views'' on China, he said, but there will be ``no formal proposals.`` ``We always have high hope'' of normalizing relations with China, he said. ``I don't know how soon it can be realized (but) I've already offered to meet with the foreign minister when the situation is right.'' Choi is likely to meet one key Chinese official during his trip: Deng Pufang, the son of senior leader Deng Xiaoping, was on the same flight to Pakistan for a visit in his capacity as head of the China Federation of Handicapped People. Lilley, asked if the United States could serve as a go-between in bringing about relations between China and South Korea, said: ``No, we're not in the best position to do that.'' U.S. relations with China are badly strained by Washington's criticisms of Beijing's human rights record and its suppression of political dissent. Choi's predecessor, Choi Kwang-soo, also stopped at Beijing airport in August 1988 for a meeting with former U.S. Ambassador Winston Lord. Then, too, there were no contacts with Chinese officials.
