Trade between China and South Korea has grown to more than $3 billion a year, but China remains politically tied to South Korea's bitter rivals, the Communist government in North Korea. Chinese Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin is leaving for North Korea this week on his first foreign trip, and the North Koreans are certain to seek reassurances that Beijing is not leaning toward more ties with Seoul. Choi said he was ``very happy'' to visit East Europe and formalize relations with the two socialist states there. ``Our private sectors are very much enthusiastic to promote economic exchange and cooperation,'' he said. ``I think the establishment of relations will create a very good atmosphere for businessmen to move into those countries.'' South Korea already has diplomatic relations with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia and plans to start normalization talks soon with Romania and East Germany. The anti-Communist government in Seoul has also increased contacts with the Soviet Union, and Choi said he would ask Pakistan and India to act as go-betweens in helping South Korea establish formal ties with Moscow and Beijing.

DOC.HEAD: Party Leaders Suggest Stronger Ties with Masses
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party Central Committee called today for the party to strengthen ties with the people, many of whom became disillusioned with the Communists after last year's crackdown on the student pro-democracy movement. The Central Committee concluded a four-day meeting, the first since November, when it approved a three-year economic austerity program and announced senior leader Deng Xiaoping was resigning from his last party post. News of the semiannual meeting was carried by the official Xinhua News Agency. The party has been concerned about popular unrest because of the economic downturn and the harsh political climate following the military repression of dissent last June that left hundreds, perhaps thousands, dead. As a result, the party was expected to ease some austerity measures, such as loosening credit to money-starved industries. But any decisions probably will not be announced until the National People's Congress _ China's rubber-stamp legislature _ convenes next week. Instead, the Central Committee issued a communique saying the party's ties to the masses are its ``fundamental working line and also its fine tradition and political asset,'' according to Xinhua. It acknowledged that people have become disenchanted with the party because of its ``bureaucracy, subjectivism, formalism, passivism, (and) corruption.'' The communique did not specifically say how ties might be strengthened. But in recent days, the official media have reported the arrests of several officials on corruption charges in an attempt to show the party will not tolerate such activities. The Chinese also have become disillusioned with the party's economic policies, which have led to runaway inflation, the closure of thousands of factories and layoffs of millions of workers. But the document said China was on the right track with its economic reform and called on ``all party members ... to follow firmly and in an all-around way the basic line of taking economic construction as the central task.''

DOC.HEAD: A Loss of Place: Japan's Rush Hour Trains Without Seats
DOC.TEXT: Japanese commuters long accustomed to the crush of humanity and shoves and sneezes of fellow passengers began suffering another indignity Monday: rush hour trains without seats. The Yamanote line, one of Tokyo's most heavily traveled routes, introduced new cars with seats that can be lowered or folded back into the wall at the touch of a button. The seats will stay folded to ease crowding until the end of the morning rush hour at 10 a.m., creating what one Japanese TV announcer called a ``freight-train feeling'' aboard the cars. ``We're being treated like baggage,'' complained a middle-age man riding one of the four new cars, introduced on just two trains as an experiment. But another woman said the standing-room-only cars ``looked neater and less-crowded'' than regular trains, which sometimes are so packed that riders have only enough space to place one foot on the floor, and can let go of a bag without it falling to the ground. ``It's an attempt to ease the overcrowding. We'll see what the reaction is, and then make a decision on whether to expand their use,'' a railroad official said. Train officials say there are very few ways left to ease the crush of the growing crowds that press their way _ sometimes with the aid of train employees who push from behind _ onto Tokyo's rush-hour trains. Of the 32 million people who live in and around the capital, about half reportedly use mass transit for commuting. An estimated 5 million people each day ride the Yamanote line, which loops around central Tokyo, the railway official said. During rush hour, many lines in the city are at full capacity, meaning that no more trains can be squeezed into the schedule. On the Yamanote line, 10-car trains run every 2{ minutes during rush hour, while trains on slower-moving subway lines arrive every two minutes. An attempt two years ago to revise safety rules to narrow the gap between trains on the Sobu line was abandoned after one train slammed into another at a station, killing two people. ``We can't run any more trains because we've reached the maximum capacity,'' said the railroad official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``All we can do is try to ease the current situation.'' The new cars have six doors on each side, compared with the normal four, to allow passengers on and off trains more easily. They officially are supposed to carry a maximumb 162 people _ 18 more than the regular cars. During rush hour, however, many more people jam into the cars. ``I usually can't sit down anyway, so I think the new arrangement is good,'' said one young woman. A male rider expressed concern about older people who are unable to sit on the new trains. ``Our hope is to improve service for the largest number of passengers,'' another railway official said. ``We hope the public will understand.'' The Japan Broadcasting Corp. timed passengers getting on and off trains at a station Monday and found that the new design was about 10 seconds faster. But despite the seatless design, at least one of the new cars was so crowded Monday that train employees had to resort to the old technique of pushing passengers into the doors to allow the train to depart on time.

DOC.HEAD: 250 Attend Arab-Jewish Dance
DOC.TEXT: Arab and Jewish women danced while holding olive branches, and served matzo ball soup and baklava at a social gathering to promote peace in the Middle East. About 250 people attended ``Ballads, Bagels and Baklava,'' a five-hour dinner dance Sunday night sponsored by the 2-year-old group Tacoma Arabs, Jews and Others for Peace. The years of strife over a Palestinian homeland was ``on everybody's faces, in spite of all the good times'' at the festivities, said Patsy Kempthorne, a member of Temple Beth El. Arabs at the event said Israel should give up the West Bank and Gaza Strip; Jews said Israel must be assured that Palestinians will not threaten that country's security.

DOC.HEAD: Rare U.S. Sighting of Arctic Gull Draws Enthusiastic Bird Watchers
DOC.TEXT: More than 400 bird-watchers turned up at the crack of dawn at a sewage plant to get a glimpse of an apparently disoriented arctic bird rarely seen south of Canada, a Ross's gull. ``I woke up at 4:15 to come out here,'' said George Armistead, 16, of Philadelphia. ``I never thought I'd see the day when a Ross's gull would land so close I could make the drive in a little over two hours.'' At 8:35 a.m. Sunday, someone finally spotted the gull in flight. It eventually settled down to preen for a half-hour near a creek behind the Back River treatment plant in suburban Baltimore. ``What makes this Ross's gull so unique is that every other past record has been a one-day wonder,'' said birdwatcher Rick Blom. ``This Ross's gull has already been in Baltimore for more than a week.'' Blom said the gull is a long-distance migrator that has a tendency to get blown off course. The first confirmed U.S. sighting of a Ross's gull was believed to have been in 1975 in Salisbury Beach, Mass. Unconfirmed sightings have been reported as far afield as Tennessee and Colorado.

DOC.HEAD: Where Did the Escargot Go?
DOC.TEXT: Police said Monday they were investigating the theft of 153,000 snails from a farm that sells the mollusks to restaurants. Animal rights activists may have been behind the theft of the snails from Organic Delicatessen International in the northeastern town of Hebburn. Police said the snails disappeared sometime between Wednesday and Friday, and that slogans were found written on walls of the premises. ``There were some sort of animal rights slogans, but we don't know for sure,'' said a spokeswoman for Northumbrian police. ``We're investigating the matter.'' Some of the snails were found in nearby fields.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Sends Observers to U.S.-South Korea Military Exercises
DOC.TEXT: Poland has sent military officers to observe annual joint military exercises involving U.S. and South Korean troops for the first time since the Korean War ended in 1953, officials said Monday. Defense Ministry officials said two Polish army colonels would observe landing operations this week by U.S. troops before the full-scale ``Team Spirit'' field exercises across South Korea. Ministry officials said more than 20 military attaches in South Korea and Japan have been invited to observe the exercises, which will last for about two weeks and involve fewer than 200,000 U.S. and South Korean soldiers. Poland has military attaches in North Korea as a member of the U.N.-dispatched, four-nation commission overseeing the armistice agreement that ended the Korean War. The other nations are Czechoslovakia, Switzerland and Sweden. Of the four nations charged with overseeing implementation of the armistice agreement, officials said Poland and Switzerland had accepted invitations. It was the first time any socialist country has dispatched military observers to the exercises, which began in 1976. There has been no response from China or other Communist countries invited to observe what U.S. and South Korean officials termed the defensive exercise. As in the past, North Korea rejected the invitation and put its entire armed forces on alert, saying the exercises are a sign of U.S. agression. North Korea also cut off all dialogue with South Korea. South Korean officials attributed the dispatch of Polish observers to improved relations between the two countries. During their nine-day stay, the Polish officers will be allowed to visit the heavily fortified border.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Calls Lithuania's Declaration of Independence Alarming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 20, `In Washington...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with more U.S. reax. Pick up 21st pvs, `In Estonia...' Conforms quotes from decree to Sajudis translation.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today called Lithuania's declaration of independence ``alarming'' but gave no indication he plans any action to prevent the Baltic republic from breaking away. He did not, however, acknowledge the legality of the move, continuing to refer to Lithuania as a Soviet republic and not by the new name adopted by Lithuania's legislature. Another member of the ruling Communist Party Politburo told reporters that the Kremlin will deal peacefully with Lithuania. ``We will not use force,'' Yegor K. Ligachev told reporters at the Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow. ``We must resolve this by political means.'' Ligachev is believed to be one of the more conservative members of the party's ruling body. Gorbachev, opening a new session of the congress, noted that the chairman of the Lithuanian delegation was absent from his chair on the stage with other members of the Presidium. ``The information coming from Lithuania is alarming, and momentous decisions are being made there that will affect both Lithuania and the Soviet Union,'' Gorbachev told more than 2,000 deputies. The lawmakers had assembled in Moscow today to consider constitutional amendments that would create a new, extraordinarily powerful Soviet president and revoke the Communist Party's monopoly on power. Gorbachev said the Congress should study the ``decisions adopted in the Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic,'' ignoring the republic legislature's action Sunday declaring a sovereign ``Republic of Lithuania.'' Just two weeks after pro-independence candidates won a two-third majority in Lithuania's legislature, the body met in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius, and voted to restore sovereignty after 50 years of Soviet rule. Lithuanian lawmakers acknowledge, though, that true independence can only be won after long, difficult negotiations with the Kremlin. The hasty vote to secede was prompted by the convening of the Congress to consider giving a new president powers that would include the authority to dissolve republic parliaments and nullify their actions. The newly elected legislature of the Baltic republic of 3.7 million people voted 124-0 with six abstentions to secede. It also chose Vytautas Landsbergis, chairman of the nationalist Sajudis movement, as president. ``The Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania, expressing the will of the nation, resolves and solemnly proclaims that the execution of the sovereign power of the Lithuanian state, heretofore constrained by alien forces in 1940, is restored,'' the legislature decreed. ``Henceforth Lithuania is once again an independent state,'' it said. The decree proclaims that the local KGB and police, for most of five decades instruments of Soviet terror and repression, must now obey Lithuania rather than Moscow. After it was approved, legislators stood and joined hands, chanting ``Lietuva, Lietuva'' (Lithuania). Outside, a small crowd broke into wild cheers. Earlier, people tore down a metal Soviet hammer-and-sickle seal over the building's door and some stamped on it. ``That's the end of the Soviet regime,'' said a jubilant deputy looking on. By itself, the decree effects little change in the relationship between the Baltic republic and the Kremlin. But it was the first crack in the union of 15 Soviet republics and more than 100 nationalities as a result of the burgeoning demands for autonomy fostered by Gorbachev's reforms. In Washington, the Bush administration expressed support for Lithuania's move toward independence but said it will delay formal recognition until the Lithuanians are ``in control of their own destiny.'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the United States would urge the Kremlin to ``respect the will of the citizens of Lithuania.'' The United States has never recognized the forcible 1940 annexation of the three Soviet republics _ Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. In Estonia on Sunday, an unofficial congress of delegates elected by a majority of the republic's people denounced the Soviet annexation and sought U.N. assistance in achieving independence. In addition to changing their homeland's name, the Lithuanian legislators dropped the old seal that included a Soviet hammer, sickle and star, replacing it with one showing a white knight on a dark shield. Today, they were to consider a declaration touching the thousands of Soviet soldiers on Lithuanian soil. Lithuania's declaration of independence represents perhaps the biggest crisis yet for Gorbachev, who marked his fifth anniversary as Soviet leader on Sunday. The outgoing president of Lithuania's parliament, Communist Party chief Algirdas Brazauskas, said before the vote that approval of secession could have a ``contagious effect'' on other republics. Gorbachev's troubles include rumblings for independence elsewhere, serious economic problems and ethnic strife in many areas of the nation. Leaders of Sajudis, which dominates the new Lithuanian legislature, acknowledged that full independence would have to be won in long, difficult negotiations. ``How soon we can implement this law depends not only on us,'' Landsbergis told a news conference. ``We have to sit down at the table,'' he told legislators in a statement. ``We're not going to be beating our fists, but we have to start settling accounts.'' Gorbachev has said Lithuania will have to pay the Kremlin $34 billion for the factories and other infrastructure built during a half-century of Soviet rule. Lithuanians say their bill for decades of Soviet repression _ including mass deportations to Siberia under Stalin _ will be even higher. Landsbergis, a 57-year-old music professor, received 91 votes for the presidency in Sunday's vote, with 42 against. Brazauskas got 38 votes, with 95 against. Stalin absorbed Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia _ all independent between the world wars _ under a secret agreement with Germany on the eve of the Nazi attack on Poland that started World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Van Gogh Painting Vanishes From Safe
DOC.TEXT: A painting by Vincent van Gogh valued at $1.8 million has been reported stolen from a customs warehouse, police said Monday ``Wheat Field With Shocks,'' dated 1888, was to be shown to a potential buyer Friday but the safe containing it was found to be empty, police said. The safe was not damaged, and the frame was found in a nearby closet, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Cubans Are Demonstrating _ But For The Government
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrations toppled governments in Eastern Europe last year and now there are demonstrations here _ but with a big difference. Twice last week, members of the small human rights community met at differrent locales to try to advance their cause. Both times, they were rudely interrupted by hundreds of noisy, pro-government street demonstrators. According to the Communist Party newspaper Granma, neighbors became aware of a dissident meeting Thursday at the home of a well-known activist. Before long, with the help of indignant passersby, a crowd had formed outside. The protest, like a similar incident March 5, has been labeled an ``act of repudiation'' by the Communist Party media. Dissidents contend the protests are government-orchestrated; the media insists they are spontaneous. Either way, the demonstrations seem to help the government in its quest to nip potential trouble in the bud. If those who disagree gain a foothold, life for the government could become complicated. As things stand, the movement of Cubans who want more freedom is small, demoralized and fearful. Two of the best known activists, Elizardo Sanchez and Roberto Bahamonde, have been in prison since last year. Seven of their allies were taken into custody Saturday, informed sources said, but it is not clear whether charges will be filed against them. Castro says scuttling the system he has built could nullify the advances in health and education that the revolution has brought about about in three decades. But judging the number of Cubans who agree with him is almost impossible. His more fervent backers insist that support for the government exceeds 80 percent and perhaps 90 percent. Others who find the system has both virtues and flaws believe the support level is between 50 percent and 60 percent. Desperate Cubans who have fled the island recently for Miami on rafts _ the average is about 40 per month _ put the figure at closer to 10 percent. That estimate seems far lower than Castro deserves. There is little doubt he has the allegiance of a higher percentage of his people than any of the East European leaders who bowed out under public pressure last year. Still, the mood here is uncertain and nervous as Cuba suddenly finds itself almost without allies. At the international level, Cubans wonder if the United States, fresh from its ouster of Panama's Manuel Antonio Noriega, will target Cuba next. Cuba is so well-prepared for that eventuality, Castro has said, that invading U.S. soldiers would spill ``rivers of blood.'' On the economic front, Castro is openly questioning whether the Soviet Union will be able to survive the wave of nationalist uprisings. If not, Cuba could face, among other problems, the challenge of finding an alternate supply of oil. The Soviets provide Cuba with 12 million tons of oil annually at preferential rates. Castro warned his countrymen last week that massive energy-saving measures will have to be instituted if oil supplies are sharply reduced. Mules may have to replace tractors on the farm. In Havana, bus service may have to be curtailed by one-third, he said. The manufacture of clothing may be limited exclusively for children. Castro confided to a visitor recently that he hasn't had a day off in months because mf his accumulating troubles, but he also seems to relish the new challenges. He said last week that Cubans are fortunate to be part of a struggle against the ``giant counterrevolutionary tide'' that threatens to engulf the world. ``It is a privilege for our country to have to face these responsibilities,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Avril Leaves A Lawless Country On U.S. Air Force Transport Plane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to ADD White House comment; Pickup 3rd, `After Avril...'
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril left Haiti today aboard a U.S. Air Force transport plane, two days after the military ruler was driven from power by widespread unrest. The deposed leader and his family arrived this morning at Homestead Air Force Base, 25 miles south of Miami, the State Department said. An Air Force spokesman in Washington, Lt. Col. Darrell Hayes, said Avril was being driven to Boca Raton, Fla., after which he was ``on his own.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater refused comment on whether the United States had granted Avril asylum but said: ``We are hopeful for a smooth transition to democracy in Haiti and are encouraging that effort.'' After Avril left, the opposition coalition known as the Unity Assembly reportedly picked Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, the only woman on the 12-member Supreme Court, as its choice for provisional president. The army's choice is Supreme Court president Gilbert Austin, but he has been rejected by the coalition as too close to Avril. The deadline for announcing a provisional president is Tuesday, when Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, who took over from Avril, is to transfer power to a civilian. The new president will serve until an election is held. Thousands of people milled about Port-au-Prince, the capital, but the mood was more one of disbelief than celebration. ``He's gone, he's gone,'' people were heard saying. The Rev. Bertrand Aristide, a Roman Catholic priest and staunch critic of the military government, said residents should remain alert to the possibility of army reprisals. ``We can smile, but we can't laugh yet,'' Aristide said on Radio Haiti Inter after Avril's departure. At least 24 people were killed in seven days of protests and clashes that have left this Caribbean nation without a leader and in turmoil. Most of the victims have been civilians slain by soldiers or police. ``The people have shown how much they love democracy by dying for it,'' Aristide said earlier. A leading member of the Unity Assembly, Jean-Claude Roy, said Ms. Pascal-Trouillot was the coalition's choice for provisional president. Radio reports said Austin _ under the constitution next in line for the presidency _ resigned from the court to make way for Ms. Pascal-Trouillot. A widower, Ms. Pascal-Trouillot was Haiti's first woman judge and is an author. Her best-known book, written in 1973, was ``The Judicial Status of Haitian Women in Social Legislation.'' If she is chosen as provisional president she would be the first woman to hold the post in Haiti's history. Earlier, residents of the capital retreated behind shuttered windows after sundown Sunday and the streets were deserted. Soldiers in pickup trucks drove around the city and gunshots were heard occasionally. ``I'm afraid for my husband and I fear the Macoutes will come out of the walls,'' said the wife of a well-known politician, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Tonton Macoutes were the feared secret police of the Duvalier family, which ruled Haiti for 29 years. Numbering about 30,000, the Macoutes were disbanded after Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to exile in France in February 1986. Later, several hundred were integrated into the army and police as special agents. Tele-Haiti, a private television station, urged viewers to stay indoors Sunday night because ``there are gangs of marauding gunmen in the streets'' and politicians and religious leaders urged citizens to form neighborhood defense groups. The state hospital said it treated about 100 people, mostly for gunshot wounds, over the weekend. Radio reports said soldiers firing from a speeding truck killed five pedestrians on Sunday. In another incident, witnesses said police looking for the killers of Maj. Renaud St. Bert stopped a passer-by, shot him four times and sat under a tree for more than an hour watching him die. Avril was brought to power in a September 1988 revolt by soldiers who professed disdain for political killings and other abuses by the previous military ruler, Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy. Namphy had ruled the country _ among the poorest in the hemisphere _ for most of the 2{ years since the popular uprising that ousted Jeane-Claude Duvalier. This Caribbean nation of 6 million people has been ruled mainly by the military since it gained independence from France in 1804, and opposition leaders said they did not trust Avril to oversee presidential elections he promised for the fall. In a January crackdown, the government jailed and beat dozens of dissidents, exiling seven. Protests against Avril broke out one week ago after a soldier killed an 11-year-old girl, apparently by accident. Avril agreed to step down after negotiations reportedly involving the U.S. and French embassies, the Roman Catholic Church and opposition political parties. In Haiti's last attempt at elections, overseen by Namphy in November 1987, voting was canceled after thugs backed by soldiers killed at least 34 voters.

DOC.HEAD: Three Dead in Interstate Bridge Accident, Two Dozen Hurt
LaserPhoto GBR2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with authorities confirming three dead, 24 hurt, 45 vehicles involved; UPDATES reports on fire to reflect that tank truck was not involved; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A fiery, chain-reaction collision of 45 vehicles on a fog-shrouded, interstate bridge killed at least three people and hospitalized two dozen others early today, police said. ``The catalyst was a three-car accident. How that happened I don't know,'' said Deputy Chief of Traffic Robert Kreuser. ``From there it was a chain-reaction. It just piled up.'' The crash killed at least three people, said police Capt. Larry Gille, who was coordinating rescue efforts in the northbound lanes of the Tower Drive Bridge on Interstate 43, which spans the Fox River. At least 24 people were treated at the city's two hospital emergency rooms and three were admitted, officials said. ``It looks like it was exploding gas tanks from cars'' that caused the fire, Gille said. Firefighters extinguished at least one burning vehicle near near an oil company tanker trunk near the head of the pileup, witnesses said. ``It's a matter of unpiling the cars and treating the injured,'' Kreuser said. Many of the injured had to be extricated from their cars. Police, firefighters, ambulance and rescue crews _ including a crane _ were dispatched to the bridge shortly after the accident was reported at 6:45 a.m. ``Somebody said it's something you'd see in a Los Angeles pile-up. It'll take a long time to see this thing out,'' police Lt. Roy Johnson said. Minutes after the crash, dazed, bloodied drivers wandered in the roadway near the crash site. Other victims lay on the ground near the crest of the bridge, where other motorists went to help them. Twenty yards away, just east of the bridge's superstructure, both northbound lanes were blocked by wreckage, some of it on fire. Leo Terry of Green Bay, his face smeared with blood, said he was driving across the bridge when he entered a wall of fog, then slammed into a car stopped in front of him. ``You couldn't see nothing,'' he said. James Vandertie, 19, who escaped with a few fragments of glass in his hand, said the chain reaction started when a van hit an oil tanker. ``It was like boom, boom, boom, every couple of seconds,'' he said. Barbara Brandstatter of Red Banks said she was driving south across the bridge when she saw the wreckage on the opposite side. She said the crest of the bridge had fair visibility at the time of the accident, but another wall of fog was just beyond where she stopped her car and set out flares. Traffic chief Kreuser said the accident was the worst he'd seen in 28 years with the Green Bay department. ``We've never had anything of this magnitude.'' Green Bay, a city of 90,000 about 117 miles north of Milwaukee, is widely known for its National Football League team, the Green Bay Packers.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: ``Days of Thunder'' turned into a night of dancing for actor Robert Duvall, who took a break from the filming of his new movie to attend a shag dancing competition. For those who don't know, the shag is South Carolina's official state dance, a step performed to rhythm and blues that isn't as energetic as jitterbug. Duvall, in Darlington this week filming Paramount Picture's ``Days of Thunder'' starring Tom Cruise, danced during breaks and handed out awards Saturday at the contest at a local nightclub. ``He's a very good beginning shagger,'' said Barry Thigpen, contest organizer. Duvall, 58, who had several women waiting in line to dance with him, told emcee Diane Devaughn Stokes he prefers the jitterbug.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release after 6 p.m. EST, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Shirley Temple Black, who witnessed the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia and the country's 1989 ``velvet revolution,'' said both events left her impressed by the spirit of the Czechoslovak people. In April's McCall's magazine, Black, now the U.S. ambassador to Czechoslovakia, says the revolution ``will be remembered as unique among the upheavals of 1989 for its sense of purpose, its discipline and the sheer joyousness of its spirit.'' Black, 61, said she has been warmly greeted on trips through the country by crowds who remember her films. ``In 1937, there were Shirley Temple fan clubs all over Czechoslovakia,'' she said, adding that she met the founder of those clubs: ``I thought he would be an old man. But he wasn't at all. He must have been a child then, too.''

New forms and new issues may be around, but social activism still centers on human rights, says folksinger and longtime activist Mary Travers, one-third of the folk trio Peter, Paul and Mary. ``The issues today are a question of ecology, education and a new virulent racism,'' said Ms. Travers, whose voice blended with those of Peter Yarrow and Paul Stookey on ``Puff (the Magic Dragon)'' and other hits. Ms. Travers, in Nashville to address the Jewish Federation's annual fund-raising dinner, said Sunday the big difference between activism in the '60s and that of today is wealth. ``In the 1960s, the economic infrastructure was healthy and people could afford to be generous and help others get a piece of the pie if their piece of the pie was secure,'' Ms. Travers said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Oakland A's outfielder Jose Canseco was just doing what comes naturally when he picked off someone trying to steal. A thief tried to roar off with Canseco's 42-foot boat while the slugger was playing volleyball Sunday. Canseco had anchored near a beach club and swam ashore to play. After the match, he spotted someone hiding behind his boat's console. But the engine wouldn't start, giving Canseco time to call police, who responded with a helicopter and boat. The man in the boat was charged with attempted grand theft, said Miami Beach police spokesman Jim Hyde.

Tammy Faye Bakker is back in action, preaching Sunday sermons and keeping the faith for her jailed husband at a new home for their New Covenant Church, in an industrial park. The wife of former television evangelist Jim Bakker said still-faithful former supporters of their now-defunct PTL ministry are financing the newest church in a former office building. Bakker is serving a 45-year federal prison sentence for defrauding followers. Three months ago, a dispute over back rent forced the church out of a shopping plaza and into a series of temporary quarters. Church officials announced last week that they are buying the present building. Reporters were not welcomed at Sunday's service, but Mrs. Bakker told them part of her sermon concerned the poor. ``Love has no nose,'' Mrs. Bakker said, because poor people ``sometimes don't smell too good, so love can have no nose.''

DOC.HEAD: First Red Army Contingent Leaves Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops boarded trains and headed for home Monday, the first to leave Hungary as part of an agreement to remove all Red Army soldiers from the country by June 30, 1991. A military band played the Soviet and the Hungarian national anthems as the first contingent of 300 troops and 37 combat infantry vehicles pulled out. Moscow has 49,700 troops in Hungary. The withdrawal began just two weeks after the Kremlin began bringing home troops from neighboring Czechoslovakia where a similar agreement was reached last month on the removal of all 73,500 Soviet soldiers there. Moscow has committed itself to remove the last of its troops and equipment from both countries by June 30, 1991. Not many Hungarians turned out in this tiny village station to see off the Red Army soldiers. ``I am just glad to see them go,'' said Miklos Szilasi, an elderly resident. ``I saw them come and I'll really believe it only when the last one leaves.'' Soviet troops have been in Hungary since the end of World War II. They are mainly associated with the bloody crushing of the 1956 uprising for more democracy and a multiparty system. Moscow agreed to withdraw its troops in the initial days of the revolt, but instead of departing, reinforcements poured in to crush the uprising. The start of the withdrawal comes just two weeks before Hungarians go to the polls March 25 for the first free, multiparty elections since the Communists consolidated power in 1948. Some opposition leaders have said the new government might try to renegotiate the withdrawal agreement with Moscow to move forward the completion date. As the troops boarded the trains and combat vehicles were fastened to flatbed rail cars, activists from the opposition League of Young Democrats held up banners reading, ``Hurry Home! Sunny Azerbaijan Awaits You!'' _ a sarcastic reference to Kremlin's dispatching soldiers to quell ethnic strife in the Soviet Caucasus. ``They should leave as fast as they came in,'' said Zsuzsa Szelenyi. The withdrawal agreement was signed in Moscow on Saturday by Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his Hungarian counterpart, Gyula Horn. ``I think that the overwhelming majority of our people wanted to see this agreement,'' said Ferenc Somogyi, the No. 2 in the Foreign Ministry who negotiated the agreement and who came to this town 75 miles southwest of Budapest to see the first troops off. Addressing the opposition's concern that the withdrawal be accelerated, Somogyi said: ``We considered it of crucial importance to get the pullout under way without delay. I do not exclude the possibility of shortening the deadline, but we think it is a tight one.'' He noted the agreement stipulates that the withdrawal must be completed before June 30, 1991. Maj. Gen. Viktor Shilov, first deputy to the commander-in-chief of the Southern Group of Forces stationed in Hungary, said the pullouts ``will now be a daily event from various parts of Hungary. By the end of this year 70 percent of the combat forces will be withdrawn.'' Somogyi said ``the Soviet evaluation of 1956 is still to come.'' Hungary would like to see an admission by Moscow concerning its role in 1956 similar to the apology extended to Prague for the 1968 Soviet-led Warsaw Pact invasion that crushed reforms there. Shilov noted: ``It is good to be a guest, but it is even better to go home.'' ``Some guests _ 45 years!'' said an old peasant under his breath.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ordered Plane to Fly Haitian Leader to United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead to CORRECT name to Prosper Avril; picks up 2nd graf pvs, Avril and.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials helped convince Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril to yield power without a fight in Haiti and President Bush ordered an evacuation flight for the ex-ruler because he felt ``some obligation'' to the general, the White House said today. Avril and his family were airlifted by C-141 transport jet this morning to Homestead Air Force Base 25 miles outside Miami. Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said, ``We are hopeful for a smooth transition to democracy in Haiti and are encouraging that effort.'' He refused to say whether the United States has granted Avril asylum. ``He did meet with out ambassador over the weekend and did request that we provide transportation the United States. President Bush agreed and sent a C-141 to pick him up,'' said Fitzwater. Asked if the U.S. ambassador, Alvin P. Adams, had talked Avril into stepping down, Fitzwater said, ``We had discussions with him about a transition and one of the reasons we offered him transportation to the United States was a feeling of some obligation to help him leave power and facilitate a peaceful transition.'' ``We were helpful in facilitating his departure,'' said Fitzwater. An Air Force spokesman in Washington, Lt. Col. Darrell Hayes, said Avril was being driven to Boca Raton, Fla., after which he was ``on his own.'' Fitzwater said Avril ``has a temporary sanctuary here,'' but ``we don't know what his long term plans are.'' Fitzwater said Avril has indicated he wants to stay in the Miami area ``a few days. His plans beyond that are unknown. We're still talking to him about that.'' he said. ``We aren't prepared to discuss Mr. Avril's future at this point,'' said Fitzwater. The United States also provided an Air Force jet in February 1986 to evacuate Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier to France, ending 29 years of dictatorships under Duvalier and his father, Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier. The father died in 1971 after 14 years of iron fist rule. Fitzwater said the United States had not placed any ``conditions'' on the new government that is to be set up in Haiti. The Haitians are scheduled to vote in local elections in April and in presidential elections in October and November. With Avril gone, power rested in the hands of Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army chief of staff, who was to name a provisional president by Tuesday. The United States currently is providing $41.4 million in humanitarian and development assistance to Haiti through private voluntary and non-governmental agency. It cut off direct assistance to the government of Haiti following an election massacre in November 1987, but did provide $10 million in emergency food assistance last year. ``We have said in the past that any other resumption of assistance to the Haitian government will be contingent upon tangible evidence of progress and a transition to democracy and to respect for human rights,'' said Fitzwater. ``We are consulting with other interested governments in the area on the process of transition,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Press Group Lists Administration Restrictions on Information
DOC.TEXT: A reporters committee said Monday that the Bush White House is ``bent on orchestrating'' the news and listed nearly 100 instances of restrictions, such as excluding a press pool from early coverage of the Panama invasion. ``Our report illustrates the Bush administration's obsession with secrecy and leaks,'' said Jane E. Kirtley, executive director of The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press, a non-profit research and service organization. ``It chronicles the activities of a White House bent on orchestrating and controlling the presentation of news,'' she said. ``The policy clearly fails to serve the interests of the American people.'' The report, the first on the Bush administration, was released to mark Freedom of Information Day on March 16. In addition to exclusion of the Pentagon-approved 16-member news pool from early combat in Panama, the 42-page list included: _Pentagon refusal to release combat footage shot by the military. _Directives to regional offices of the Department and Housing and Urban Development and the Immigration and Naturalization Service to clear answers to reporters' questions with Washington headquarters. _A Justice Department policy change subjecting federal officials who leak information about on-going criminal investigations to possible prosecution for theft of government property. _Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's lay-off of six career spokesmen in the 10-person Justice Department press office. The actions listed were categorized as either ``disinformation,'' ``prior restraints,'' ``secret government'' and ``policing thought.'' In 1988, the committee issued its final annual report on similar actions in the Reagan administration. That list contained more than 200 entries.

DOC.HEAD: Eccentric Ex-Prime Minister Poses Challenge in Grenada Election
LaserPhoto NY22
DOC.TEXT: Sir Eric Gairy, the eccentric former prime minister deposed in a leftist coup 11 years ago, is attempting a comeback in Grenada's second general election since the U.S.-led invasion of 1983. Gairy, who dominated the tiny Caribbean island's politics for three decades before his ouster, faces competition from three moderates and one leftist in what could be a close vote Tuesday. ``We are right down to the wire, but it is not clear who is in the lead,'' said Michael Minors, president of the Grenada Chamber of Commerce. The election falls on the 11th anniversary of the leftist coup that ousted Gairy's authoritarian regime and brought the People's Revolutionary Government of the late Prime Minister Maurice Bishop to power. An ideological rift within Bishop's government led to his assassination, along with 10 other people, on Oct. 19, 1983. Six days later, U.S. troops, accompanied by a small regional force, invaded the island and ousted a Marxist junta that had seized power. Herbert Blaize, a staunch U.S. ally, won the first election after the invasion in 1984. He died in December at the age of 71. Gairy, 68, is nearly blind with glaucoma and had said that he would not contest the election unless a ``miracle'' improved his sight. But at a recent news conference, he declared that ``a source which is greater than I'' ordained that he lead Grenada once again despite his failing sight. He asserted that it was no coincidence the election was being held on the anniversary of his ouster. ``No man on Earth could have arranged this,'' he said. ``It had to be arranged cosmically by a divine force.'' Gairy, who was Grenada's first prime minister after independence from Britain in 1974, has been dogged throughout his career by allegations of corruption and repression. His interest in the occult has made him an occasional object of ridicule. He was deposed on March 13, 1979, while in New York trying to persuade the United Nations to investigate flying saucers. But Gairy maintains strong support among farm workers _ he founded Grenada's first trade union _ the urban poor and the elderly. His followers call him ``Uncle Gairy,'' and voters are largely divided between pro- and anti-Gairy forces rather than along party lines. Since the invasion, the United States has pumped more than $110 million into Grenada, a nation of 94,000 people, but a widely expected bonanza of foreign investment has never occurred. The campaign, however, has focused more on personalities than economic issues. The other main contenders for prime minister are all regarded as moderates. They are Prime Minister Ben Jones, 66, a former foreign minister appointed as Blaize's replacement pending the election; Keith Mitchell, 44, a U.S.-educated statistician who was fired by Blaize as public works minister in a personality and policy dispute; and Nicholas Brathwaite, 65, who led an interim government after the U.S. invasion. A fifth candidate, Dr. Terrence Marryshow, 37, a Cuban-trained doctor and leader of the leftist Maurice Bishop Patriotic Movement, is considered to have virtually no chance of winning. No voter opinion polls have been published, but most Grenadians expect a close election. Some believe no single party will win a majority of the 15 seats in the House of Representatives, Grenada's Parliament, which could result in a coalition government.

DOC.HEAD: Communists, Opposition Sign Elections Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communist Party and democratic oposition groups signed an agreement Monday ensuring equal terms for parties competing in multiparty elections in June, state radio reported. The agreement also guarantees a peaceful transition to democracy. The measures must be approved by the Communist-dominated parliament. Communist Party chief Alexander Lilov, who led his party's delegation to the talks for the first time, said the accords were important for the political future of Bulgaria and called for mutual respect and responsibility between parties. Petko Simeonov, a senior opposition official and director of the opposition newspaper Demokratsiya, termed the agreement ``a victory of democratic forces,'' the radio said. The inter-party talks were the first held in a month. The largest opposition group, the Union of Democratic Forces, suspended the negotiations Feb. 12, saying the Communists refused to abolish their party organizations at work places. The Communists since have promised to withdraw the organizations. The agreements came after a weekend conference of opposition parties in Plovdiv, Bulgaria's second largest city, where four small non-aligned democratic parties joined the Union of Democratic Forces, which comprises 19 different factions. Two small non-Communist opposition groups, the Political Opposition Block, and the the Alternative Socialist Party, have refused to join the main opposition alliance despite initial promises to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Subway Victim's Foot Saved by Grafting It to Arm
DOC.TEXT: Doctors on Monday claimed initial success for an operation in which a man whose foot was severed by a subway train had it grafted onto his forearm. A team of 10 doctors headed by Dr. Maurice Mimoun of the Hopital Rothschild worked more than six hours Thursday to save the 40-year-old accident victim's leg and foot. The patient, who was not identified, fell onto the subway tracks just as the train was pulling into the station. The wheels mangled his lower right leg and cleanly cut off the foot. Paramedics arrived within minutes and stabilized the victim, who was bleeding heavily and going into shock. Other rescue workers found the severed foot on the track and whisked it to the hospital along with the man. ``There I was confronted with a foot in perfect condition and a stump that needed several weeks to heal before the foot could be sewn back on,'' Mimoun said. ``I had to think of a way to preserve the foot for as long as possible,'' he said in an interview. ``But I had never thought of doing this before.'' If the legs heals properly _ it could take as little as three weeks or as long as three months _ Mimoun said he will reattach the foot to the stump. ``The patient should be able to walk normally. Without the temporary graft, amputation would have been necessary,'' he said. The leg may be a little bit shorter, he added, but there are many ways to compensate and prevent a significant limp. Mimoun said the patient was under sedation and did not know he had undergone the surgery, which was authorized by the victim's family. The results of the surgery were shown on French TV Sunday night: the swollen, blood-stained foot resting in a prayer position over the hand, which was uninjured. Mimoun said the use of ``relay grafts'' is common practice among plastic surgeons who often try to save healthy muscle or skin tissue by grafting it onto the forearm. ``The forearm is used because it has two major blood vessels, one of which can be used to vascularize whatever needs to be saved,'' Mimoun said. He said the arm would supply the grafted foot with enough blood to keep it alive. Mimoun said the relay graft was a success thus far and gave the credit to being able to assemble a trauma team in 15 minutes. He said some of the patient's swelling had already gone down and there was no sign of infection. ``It's still too early to cry victory, but I'm optimistic,'' Mimoun said.

DOC.HEAD: Monte-Carlo Restaurateur Wins Michelin Third Star
DOC.TEXT: The 1990 Michelin guide book on Monday awarded three stars to Alain Ducasse, chef at the Louis XV restaurant in Monte-Carlo's Hotel de Paris, making him the youngest person ever to be so honored. But the gourmets' bible demoted L'Oustau de Baumaniere, a famous restaurant in Les Baux in southern France, to two stars after 35 years as a three-star restaurant. Michelin's famous red guide, which goes on sale Wednesday, thus retained only 19 restaurants in the three-star category. The best-selling guidebook, which last year sold more than 750,000 copies, can make or break a restaurant's reputation. Ducasse, 33, was jubilant at his three stars. ``I think Michelin is now starting to honor the younger generation as the hope of French cuisine,'' he said in an interview. The son of a farmer in southwest France, Ducasse said, ``I grew up with the garden-grown vegetables, with rabbits and chickens, and my golden rule is to use the best of fresh ingredients.'' Ducasse learned his trade with several giants of French gastronomy, starting at age 16 as an apprentice at the Pavillon Landais in Soustons in southwestern France. He then moved on to apprentice with Michel Guerard, assisting in writing the famous low-fat cookbook, ``Cuisine Minceur,'' while at Guerard's three-star restaurant in Eugenie-les-Bains. He also worked with such gastronomic luminaries as Gaston LeNotre in his pastry ``factory'' outside Paris, Roger Verge at his three-star Moulin de Mougins near Cannes, and Alain Chapel in Mionnay near Lyons. In 1979 he returned to Mougins as chef for Verge's less expensive annex, l'Amandier, and from 1981-86 was chef at the Juana Hotel in Juan-les-Pins. In 1987, he was chosen personally by Prince Rainier of Monaco as chef for the renovated Belle Epoque-style Louis XV restaurant at the Hotel de Paris. ``The prince wanted this to be a world-class restaurant,'' Ducasse said. The Louis XV is the only hotel restaurant to garner three stars in the history of the guide, which started in 1900. Michelin also awarded a first star to the hotel's rooftop Grill Room. Under Ducasse, the Louis XV won its first star in 1987 and its second in 1988 before the 1990 accolade that made it ``worth a detour'' in the guidebook's parlance. This is a spectacular rise, as the guidebook is circumspect in its choices. Anonymous inspectors visit a restaurant several times for months or years before handing out the little ``stars'' that actually look like rosettes. Six restaurants were demoted from two stars to one, including Paris' Pre-Catalan in the Bois de Boulogne and Le Petit Bedon. And 57 restaurants fell from one star to none. These include some well-known Paris eateries such as Lamazere, Gildo, Le Bistrot de Paris and l'Aquitaine. The reason that Baumaniere lost its third star is ``mainly that it's going through a transitional period,'' according to Alain Arnaud, a spokesman for Michelin. Arnaud said the former chef, Raymond Thuilier, has handed over the reins to his grandson, and for Michelin the results are still tentative. Meanwhile, Ducasse was busy in the Monegasque kitchens, turning out his famous delicacies that include a risotto with white Italian truffles, ``little vegetables'' sauteed with fresh black truffles, warm seafood salad, and giant pasta made with parsley to look like a mosaic. ``Of course, I'm near Italy and their cuisine influences me,'' said Ducasse. ``I'm aiming to produce `flavors of the sun' in my food, a Mediterranean style based on its wonderful seafood, vegetables, olive oil.'' Just back from a tour of Japan, where he created a new menu for the Okura Hotel restaurant in Tokyo, Ducasse said he was impressed by the freshness of Japanese cuisine. ``Americans, too, have marvelous produce,'' he said. ``But the average American seems to consume too much sugar and starch, making for less healthy and more fattening cuisine than Japanese.'' Although the red guide will be snapped up for its restaurant recommendations, it is still basically a guide for drivers, giving exhaustive information about hotels, distances between towns, garages and auto dealers.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Criticize Proposed Base Closings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: David O'B. Martin in 3rd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Military personnel who helped finance the construction of bases now slated for closing will be losing the $400 million they invested in commissaries and base exchanges, two congressmen said Monday. ``In effect, military people paid 5 percent higher prices to finance construction of facilities such as PXs, commissaries and recreation buildings,'' Rep. Marvin Leath, D-Texas, said in a statement. ``They donated these facilities to the government's inventory upon completion.'' Joining Leath in the criticism was Rep. David O'B. Martin, R-N.Y. The Commission on Base Realignment and Closure recommended in December 1988 closing 86 domestic bases, partly closing five others and changing the mission of 54 other installations for an estimated savings of $694 million a year and a 20-year savings estimated at $5.6 billion. Former Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci approved the recommendations and Congress, despite some complaints, last year overwhelmingly supported the commission's decision. Earlier this year, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney recommended closing or scaling back more than 72 domestic facilities and 14 overseas installations. Members of Congress, including Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, have criticized Cheney's list as partisan. Leath and Martin said that based on their calculations closing the 86 bases as well as the domestic installations Cheney has recommended would cost U.S. personnel about $240 million. If overseas bases were included, the cost would be approximately $400 million. ``Base closures are being billed as a step to reduce costs to the taxpayer,'' Martin said in a statement. ``Military personnel are taxpayers too. They had to dig deep into their pockets to build these facilities and they should be compensated for their contributions.'' Martin gave no specific proposals on how the personnel might be compensated. Leath is the chairman and Martin the ranking Republican on the House Armed Services panel on morale, welfare and recreation.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Who Never Knew Hostage Work for Him in Hometown
LaserPhoto BF1
DOC.TEXT: A red oak tree a few miles down the road from Terry A. Anderson's hometown was just a sapling when Monica Stocum tied a yellow ribbon around it soon after he was abducted in Lebanon on March 16, 1985. Now, the tree has grown enough to burst the ribbon, engulfing parts of it in the tree's new growth. The one-time sapling will soon be big enough to shelter a picnic. ``My God, a tree grows slowly and look at how it has grown,'' Stocum said. Anderson is still a hostage, held captive longer than any other Westerner in Lebanon. But in this town of about 17,000 people, Stocum and hundreds like her are keeping his memory alive, even though they have never met him. An informal group organizes ceremonies to commemorate Anderson's birthdays and the anniversaries of his kidnapping. On Friday, the fifth anniversary of his abduction from the streets of Beirut, they will attend services and fast for 24 hours as a gesture of spirituality and support. Hometown solidarity and admiration for the efforts of Anderson's sister, Peggy Say, to free all the Western hostages in Lebanon have spurred those efforts, said Anne Zickl, a member of the group. ``Terry Anderson graduated from Batavia High School. So did my mother and father and I. So did my four kids. So you have a connection right there,'' said Mrs. Zickl. ``Plus, I think Americans don't like injustice.'' Stocum moved to nearby Le Roy 15 years after Anderson left the area, but said the hometown tie was important to her as well. ``I probably wouldn't know him if I fell over him in the street, even with the pictures,'' she said. ``It just seems like we should be more alert because he's one of us.'' Anderson left Batavia, in dairy country 40 miles east of Buffalo, in 1965 to join the Marines. He went on to a career in journalism that took him, as chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, to Lebanon. His father, Glenn R. Anderson, and brother, Glenn Richard Jr., remained here, and after Terry was kidnapped Say moved back to be with them, said Penny Anderson, a sister-in-law. The father and brother have since died. ``She was always the strong one of the family,'' Mrs. Anderson said. Since then, Say has been the most persistent and outspoken advocate of her brother's cause. Her efforts drew admiration and offers of help locally, from longtime friends like Marsha Barton and strangers such as Mrs. Zickl. They now form a support team for Say, who has moved to Kentucky but continues to travel the world to press for her brother's freedom. Working from Mrs. Zickl's dining room _ her family has not eaten there in 1{ years _ they publish newsletters, collect Valentine's Day and Christmas cards for Anderson and field inquiries from reporters from around the world. ``We just function here to give Peggy as much support as we can, because Peggy is the one who can do the most for the hostages,'' Mrs. Zickl said. There have been more than enough dashed hopes, and as they plan for the fifth anniversary of Anderson's capture, they find themselves trying to stifle excitement over Iran's recently softened stance on the hostage issue. ``My head is saying, `Now, don't get excited. We've heard all this before,''' Mrs. Anderson said. ``My heart says he's coming home. I woke up Monday morning absolutely positive he's coming home.'' Friday's fast, they hope, will give the kidnappers one more nudge toward that goal. ``I think that people in other countries find Americans very arrogant and very self-indulgent,'' Mrs. Zickl said. ``For them to know that Americans are fasting, not on their own behalf but for peace and freedom in the Middle East, I think they'll find that very moving.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Hard-liner Says Hostages Should Not Be Freed
DOC.TEXT: The Iranian mentor of Shiite Moslem kidnappers in Lebanon says some of the Western captives are spies and none of the ``mercenary U.S. hostages'' should be freed. In a signed editorial published Saturday in the Tehran newspaper Kayhan and received Monday by The Associated Press in Nicosia, Ali Akbar Mohtashemi said the sentence for espionage in an Islamic country is death. Mohtashemi attacked those who suggest Iran help free the hostages. The former interior minister leads the powerful radical faction, which opposes President Hashemi Rafsanjani's policy of improving relations with the West. ``The Islamic Republic of Iran cannot and should not impose its policies and views on other Moslem nations,'' Mohtashemi wrote in the Persian-language newspaper, an apparent reference to Lebanon and the hostage-holders. ``Furthermore, freedom for the hostages means breaking the chains of bloodthirsty wolves. The sentence for a spy in an Islamic country is death.'' Eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian are missing in Lebanon and believed to be hostages. Held longest is Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who this week will mark five years in captivity. He was abducted March 16, 1985. Mohtashemi's editorial conflicted with Rafsanjani's indications last week that the hostages might be freed. It was not carried by the official Islamic Republic News Agency, which regularly excerpts important articles from Iranian papers. Rafsanjani, who seeks Western investment and technology to revive Iran's sluggish economy, told a news conference March 7 the hostage issue was ``moving toward a solution.'' Al-Qabas, a Kuwaiti newspaper, said in a dispatch Monday from Syria, that Iranian radicals wanted guarantees Hezbollah, the umbrella group for most groups holding hostages, would not be disbanded after the captives were freed. ``The hard-line groups in Iran which possess the key card in the file of the Western hostages held in Lebanon have asked President Hashemi Rafsanjani for concrete guarantees about the future of Hezbollah party in Lebanon as one of the conditions for the release of the captives,'' the paper said. Mohtashemi said calls for hostage releases in the Tehran Times, a paper allied with Rafsanjani, and by Mohammed Hussein Fadlallah, spiritual leader of Hezbollah, had ``created a new climate inside the country and abroad'' that ``heightened the pressure on the Islamic revolution and the Moslems of Lebanon.'' ``Instead of putting pressure on the wronged Lebanese Moslems to release the mercenary U.S. hostages, world public opinion should look for the center of hostage-taking at the White House and among Western and American intelligence services,'' Mohtashemi said. He said some hostages were spies for the CIA and named Terry Waite, special envoy of the archbishop of Canterbury, who disappeared in west Beirut in January 1987 after leaving his hotel to negotiate with hostage-holders. The church has denied such charges. According to Mohtashemi, who helped found Hezbollah in 1983 while ambassador to Syria, said recent publicity in the West about the hostages ``does not mean the West and the U.S. want a solution to the hostage problem,'' but is ``a tactic to confront Islam.'' Those holding the hostages should not be condemned, he said, because ``the West and the U.S. have turned the Third World and Islamic countries, especially Lebanon and Palestine, into big prisons. When prisoners carry out reprisals and take a few of their jailers hostage for some period of time to achieve their just rights, colonialist networks raise a hue and cry.'' Mohtashemi denied Iran was involved in hostage taking. ``The Islamic Republic of Iran has not been involved in any stages of hostage taking in Lebanon and the Moslem Lebanese forces have been and are operating on their own,'' he said in the editorial. Rafsanjani excluded Mohtashemi when he formed his Cabinet in August. Four months later, the former interior minister won an important Tehran seat in the 270-member parliament, which is dominated by radicals. The Kuwait newspaper said the United States was urging Syria to crack down on Hezbollah by moving its forces into the Shiite slums of south Beirut, where most of the hostages are believed held. Syria, an ally of Iran, has 40,000 soldiers in Lebanon, but has kept them out of the Shiite slums. The soldiers are there under a peackeeping mandate issued by the Arab League in 1976, the year after Lebanon's civil war began.

DOC.HEAD: North Says Poindexter Ordered Him to Withhold Iran-Contra Details
DOC.TEXT: Oliver L. North, scolded by the judge for ``quibbling'' on the witness stand, testified Monday that John M. Poindexter instructed him to withhold from Congress key details of the Iran-Contra affair. Testifying at Poindexter's Iran-Contra coverup trial, the former National Security Council aide also said that his one-time boss approved the diversion of U.S.-Iran arms-sale profits to buy weapons for the Nicaraguan Contras. ``You got the full permission and authority to do that from Admiral Poindexter?'' prosecutor Dan Webb said of the diversion. ``Yes,'' North said. ``Before you did it, you cleared each one of these (transactions) with Admiral Poindexter before they occurred?'' Webb asked. ``Yes,'' said the retired Marine lieutenant colonel. Asked if he remembered Poindexter saying that the diversion should ``never ever be revealed,'' North replied he did not ``recall the specific direction, but I do remember the general admonition.'' Poindexter, a retired Navy rear admiral who was President Reagan's national security adviser in 1986, is accused of obstructing congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair, making false statements and destroying key documents. North looked away without replying when Webb said, ``Good Morning, Col. North.'' He was rebuked several times by U.S. District Judge Harold Greene for ``quibbles'' with the prosecutor over minor details or for repeatedly failing to remember significant ones. ``Almost every time a question is asked, he says he can't recall,'' the judge complained. ``It's like pulling teeth.'' Later, Greene directed North not to try to ``embroider'' his answer with explanations that only made his responses less clear. ``Just answer the question,'' he told North, who was declared a hostile witness at the outset of his testimony last Friday. ``Let's try to stick to the facts,'' Greene said. ``Yes, your honor,'' North replied. North conceded that when he met Aug. 6, 1986, with congressmen inquiring about news reports concerning covert assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels, he was following general instructions from Poindexter to conceal the operation. Webb pursued the line of questioning to try to dispel North's insistence on Friday that ``nobody told me to lie to Congress.'' The prosecutor asked North if he knew that Poindexter had ``generally instructed you'' to conceal both the Contra assistance operation and the diversion of profits from the still-secret U.S.-Iran arms sales. ``Yes, but it was to conceal it or withhold that information from anybody,'' North replied. ``You knew he had generally instructed you to conceal facts from Congress?'' Webb asked. ``It's inclusive in that, yes,'' North replied only after Webb produced a transcript of the former White House aide's sworn acknowledgement to Congress of receiving Poindexter's instructions. ``You knew that you were denying important facts that Congress needed to make decisions?'' Webb said. ``I didn't recall thinking about it,'' North said. The prosecutor showed North the testimony he gave Congress in 1987, when the former White House aide admitted that he had concealed important information from lawmakers. ``That's how I answered the question,'' North said. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, obstruction of Congress and making false statements to lawmakers to conceal the secret Contra resupply operation set up after Congress banned U.S. military aid to the rebels. The indictment accuses Poindexter of destroying documents and lying to hide White House knowledge of a November 1985 shipment of 18 Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran. North was convicted last year of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress as well as destruction or alteration of key Iran-Contra documents.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Denies it Plans Settlement in South Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: The Foreign Ministry on Monday denied a claim by Lebanese villagers that Israel plans to build a settlement in its self-declared security zone in south Lebanon. Villagers in south Lebanon petitioned their government Monday to prevent an American from establishing what they said would be the first Israeli settlement on Lebanese soil. But deputy Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman Baruch Bina said: ``The story is totally untrue. It is nonsense.'' A statement by the Lebanese government said the petition was made by representatives of Rashaya Foukhar, a town of 5,000 people in the security zone. It was addressed to President Elias Hrawi, Prime Minister Salim Hoss and Parliament speaker Hussein Husseni. The petition said William Robinson, who it described as a Jewish-American immigrant, moved to settle in the town's school after Israel's 1982 invasion and gradually brought in relatives and Israeli acquaintances. But an official with a fundamentalist Christian organization in Israel said Robinson was an evangelical Christian, who, with his family, has been trying to help orphans and handicapped children. The Lebanese petition said Robinson ``seized the pine forests near Rashaya Foukhar and recently brought in Israeli engineers to build houses for 100 families to live outside the town.'' It said most of these families would be Jews who emigrated to Israel from the United States and Ethiopia in the last two years. ``We appeal to you to move quickly to block the establishment of the first Zionist settlement on Lebanese territory,'' the petition added. It accused the command of a Norwegian battalion serving with the U.N. peacekeeping force in south Lebanon of ``collaborating with Robinson'' but gave no details. Timur Goksel, spokesman for the U.N. peacekeepers, described the incident as a local quarrel. He said the force's only contact with the Robinson family was that ``our soldiers during Christmas gave gifts to the five children at the school.'' Rashaya Foukhar, in the foothills of Mount Hermon, is eight miles northeast of the Israeli border and part of a 6- to 10-mile-wide buffer strip patrolled by Israeli troops and the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia. The zone was established in 1985 when Israel withdrew the bulk of its invasion force from South Lebanon ending a three-year occupation.

DOC.HEAD: Iditarod Racers Reach Strike Out for Norton Sound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with today's events; picks up 7th graf pvs: `Named for ...; a version also moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Three-time winner Susan Butcher and defending champion Joe Runyan, their dog teams well rested, gained on Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race leader Lavon Barve today as they pulled into this checkpoint on Norton Sound. Resting his dogs only 3{ hours, Barve was about four hours ahead of Butcher and Runyan when they left Kaltag, the last checkpoint on the Yukon River, for the 90-mile run to Unalakleet, the gateway to the Bering Sea. Butcher, with eight hours rest, and Runyan with five, were both less than two hours behind Barve when they hit Unalakleet, where racers were expected to rest about six hours before heading up the coast for the last 170 miles to Nome. Leaving Kaltag behind Runyan were Tim Osmar, four-time champion Rick Swenson, DeeDee Jonrowe and Robin Jackobson of Squaw Lake, Minn. Runyan said any one of the first five racers could win the race in the last 170-mile sprint to Nome. ``If you want to make a good bet, never bet on a dog race,'' he said. ``It's really shaken out which team is healthy and really fit. Looks to me like it's anybody's bet what's going on here.'' Before leaving Kaltag, Runyan said the leaders in the 18th running of the 1,158-mile race had come under the spell of what he called the ``crazy syndrome.'' ``Everybody's pushing pushing pushing,'' Runyan said. Runyan called his dogs ``little bio-mechanisms'' that have to be understood, cared for and appreciated. ``The trick is to be predictable for the dogs,'' said Runyan. Because of his habit of running behind his sled rather than riding its rails when it heads up hills, Kaltag area residents have begun calling him ``Runnin' Runyan.'' Butcher said it was wrong to assume she was leading the race from Anchorage to Nome just because she had been first to reach Kaltag. She said everybody was running their own race with different strategies. Named for an abandoned gold-mining town along the trail, the Iditarod race was started in 1973 to commemorate the 1925 emergency delivery of life-saving diphtheria serum from Anchorage to Nome by sled dog teams. Retired Col. Norman Vaughan, at 84 the oldest musher, was reported in 63rd place in McGrath, 389 miles into the race. Vaughan was a member of Admiral Byrd's Antarctic expedition and competed at the Lake Placid, N.Y. Olympics in 1932. Six mushers have scratched out of the 70 who began the race March 3.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Militants Arrested; Leader Dies in Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: Police on Monday arrested 11 Moslem militants suspected of fanning sectarian violence, and their leader was electrocuted when he jumped out a window onto power lines while fleeing authorities, an official said. In raids in El-Minya province, police also seized thousands of leaflets and weapons allegedly used in clashes there between Egypt's Moslem majority and its Coptic Christian minority, said Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa. The southern province has been the scene of recent violence against Coptics. Two churchs and a youth club were set alight and stoned, while a candy factory and several shops owned by Coptics were burned. Moussa, whose remarks were distributed by the state Middle East News Agency, did not identify the man reported to have leaped to his death in El-Minya other than as leader of the alleged militant group. But state-owned newspapers identified him as Sherif Saber Mohammed, a techncian. As police raided the man's house, he tried to flee by jumping from his second-floor apartment, Moussa said. ``He fell on power lines and was electrocuted,'' he said. The news agency alleged the man opened fire on police before jumping but did not mention police casualties. Moussa said policemen seized about 8,000 leaflets ``inciting sectarian strife and exploiting economic difficulties to instigate the masses against the government.'' Police also confiscated about 30 firebombs and an unspecified number of chains and swords, he said. The Interior Minister said the violence in El-Minya was fueled by false rumors a Copt was having an affair with a Moslem woman. Moussa said the militants arrested belonged to an organization calling itself Jihad. This was the extremist group the government blamed for the assassination of President Anwar Sadat at a military parade on Oct. 6, 1981, and for a subsequent failed attempt to overthrow the government. It is not known to be affiliated with the Lebanon-based group Islamic Jihad, thought to be holding some Western hostages. Jihad has been the target of repeated government crackdowns since the 1981 incidents. Among Egypt's 55 million people there are between 5 million and 6 million Christians, mostly Orthodox Copts, who are followers of the church established in Egypt by St. Mark.

DOC.TEXT: In a Feb. 9 story on delays in setting regulations for medical laboratory tests, the Associated Press erroneously referred to Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., as a member of the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEAD: Sponsors Hoping Warm Weather Won't Wreck Cherry Blossom Festival
DOC.TEXT: Sponsors of the annual Cherry Blossom Festival on Monday expressed optimism that unseasonably warm weather hitting the nation's capital will not cause the trees to bloom too early for the celebration. ``Even though the weather forecasts are good _ drat it _ and the cherry blossoms look like they may come out early, we're still hopeful,'' National Park Service spokesman Al Dale said. April 1 is the scheduled start of the 78th annual festival commemorating the gift of the 3,000 trees to the United States by the mayor of Tokyo in 1912. Temperatures ranging from the mid 60s to the upper 80s are expected for the rest of the week. The earliest the trees have ever blossomed was March 20. But forecasters say it could be even earlier this year. The delicate pink and white blossoms last four to five days after they peak. ``If things go according to our estimates, by April 1, the program may just be the Japanese Tree Festival, because the blossoms will have come and gone,'' National Weather Service meteorologist Jim Belleville said. About 1,300 of the trees ring the Tidal Basin between the Lincoln and Jefferson memorials, with the rest planted on nearby park land. Forecasters said there was still hope that the cooling effect of the nearby Potomac River could slow down blossom development. ``Temperatures near water are always lower than those farther away from water,'' Belleville said. But he said any slowdown caused by the Potomac waters would be short-lived. National Park Service spokesman Earle Kittleman said that if the blossoms of the Yoshino, or single-blossom trees make an early debut, all would not be lost, because there were at least 400 double-flowering, or Kwanzan, trees that would bloom later than the Yoshino trees.

DOC.HEAD: 20 Dead in Factional Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Black factional fighting and other confrontations between activists and authorities have killed 20 blacks and wounded six police, officials said Monday. Zulu leader Mangosothu Buthelezi, whose supporters have been involved in some of the worst fighting, said he favors turning South Africa into a federation of states to take into account ethnic differences. Buthelezi said in an interview that he opposes any plans to nationalize the economy. The anti-apartheid United Democractic Front said 89 activists were detained without charge last week under state of emergency regulations. Only a handful of people had been in detention until the widespread violence erupted last month. Thirteen people were killed in unrest this weekend in Buthelezi's KwaZulu homeland, in the southeast, police said. The dead included a woman and her four children who burned to death when their hut was set on fire. Police gave no additional details. Police said Monday they found the bodies of three black men who were stoned and burned in the KwaGuqa township east of Johannesburg. Also, three blacks were killed Sunday in fighting between rival factions in black townships in various parts of the country and a fourth man was killed by police gunfire. In Cape Town, about 50 people peacefully protesting rising food prices were arrested, witnesses said. The march was organized by the National Unemployed Workers Coordinating Committee. A police statement reported unrest in various areas, with police patrols using shotguns, pistols, rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse crowds to halt faction fighting. South Africa has been hit by a wave of violence seen as the most serious unrest since the mid-1980s. More than 200 people have been killed in unrest in the past four weeks in fighting over issues ranging from tribal rivalry to struggles between gangs for control of various townships. Some of the worst fighting was in the black township of Katlehong outside Johannesburg, where at least 24 people have been killed during the past week in clashes that began in a struggle between rival taxi companies. About 1,000 men went on a rampage in the area Sunday night, chasing people from their homes after a hostel was firebombed, according to the South African Press Association. Police reported several vehciles and buildings were burned and at least one man suffered serious stab wounds. Residents of some townships have called for deployment of army troops to halt factional fighing, although removal of troops from black townships has been a standing demand of anti-apartheid organizations since a national state of emergency was declared June 12, 1986. In an interview with the South African Press Association, Buthelezi said he was willing to consider the African National Congress' plan for full democracy with no racial barriers in South Africa.
