But the leader of the Zulu Inkatha political movement said he still prefers his previously stated plan for dividing the country into separate ethnic-based entities to avoid racial friction. ``One cannot ignore the multinational character of South Africa,'' he was quoted as saying. ``I believe a federation of states would accommodate all interests. However I am not locked into this idea to the extent that I am not prepared to explode the ANC's idea of a unitary state,'' he added. Inkatha is a major political movement representing South Africa's large Zulu tribe. It opposes apartheid, but is more conservative than the ANC and some other black nationalist groups. Buthelezi said he was totally opposed to any plans to end South Africa's free market economy. He said black African states that adopted socialist economic systems experienced major problems and were not switching back to free enterprise. But the ANC, which favors nationalizing key sectors of the economy, had ``studiously ignored'' the experience of other African states, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Filed by Writer Against Billy Barty
DOC.TEXT: Billy Barty is being sued by a television writer who says the diminutive actor owes him $2,000 for his help on the brief-run TV show ``Short Ribbs.'' Bill Winckler, 25, of suburban Woodland Hills, said the ``little people'' actor has ignored a contract guaranteeing him pay for each script plus a percentage of syndication profits. The show ran from September to December. Barty, 65, who has starred in such films as ``Willow'' and ``Rumpelstiltskin,'' was out of town Monday and was unavailable for comment, said his sister, Evelyn Barty, from the Billy Barty Foundation, which helps raise money for scholarships for people of small stature. The small claims case was scheduled to be heard March 19 in Van Nuys Municipal Court. Winckler said he agreed to work for $100 a script because he also was promised 10 percent of the syndication profits, which could turn a large profit for him if successful. ``I'll be bringing my copy of the contract to court, which means it should be an open and shut case,'' Winckler said. Winckler said he doesn't know why Barty refused to pay him, saying only that ``creative differences'' had caused friction between the two men.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Lithuania Bjt
Administration Walks Careful Line on Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Monday it is willing to deal with Lithuania as an independent state if it can negotiate a full transfer of power from the Soviet Union and take charge of its own destiny. Weaving a delicate balance betweeen the national aspirations of the Lithuanian people and the shaky political posture of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, administration officials stopped short of official recognition of Lithuania's new move toward independent government. ``We believe this is the right measure of support,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. ``It reflects our policy of many years of not recognizing their incorporation (into the Soviet Union) in the first place.'' Fitzwater and Margaret Tutwiler, spokeswoman for the State Department, made clear that Lithuania's declaration of independence is only a first step. There is much to be done before the Baltic state becomes independent in fact and formal U.S. ties are established, they said. Ms. Tutwiler said, however, that prompted by the unanimous declaration of independence voted Sunday by the Lithuanian parliament, the United States ``will expand the range of our contacts with freely elected representatives and officials of the Baltic States as appropriate.'' But she and Fitzwater also made clear that does not yet extend to an exchange of ambassadors or the extension of full diplomatic recognitiion. The administration's policy, Fitzwater said, ``reflects the fact that they still have negotiations to carry out that we want to be successful. ... But we aren't going to try to dictate the eventual outcome.'' Fitzwater said: ``... We would want any recognition to take into account a final government that was in control of their own destiny, and much of that has yet to be negotiated with the Soviet Union.'' The United States recognized the independence of a Lithuanian state in 1922. It has never recognized its forced incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940. Nonetheless, Ms. Tutwiler said that over the years it has been U.S. practice ``to establish formal relations with the lawful government of any state once that government is in effective control of its territory and capable of entering into and fulfilling international obligations.'' ``When we are satisfied that the Lithuanian government can meet these requirements, we will establish formal diplomatic relations with the new government,'' she said. She said such questions as the removal of some 200,000 Soviet troops from Lithuanian soil is a matter for negotiations between the Soviets and representatives of Lithuania. And Ms. Tutwiler said she would not spell out precisely what specific steps would have to be taken before the United States would recognize Lithuania's full sovereignty. Gorbachev, opening a congress of Communist Party deputies in Moscow on Monday, called Lithuania's declaration of independence ``alarming.'' But he gave no sign that action will be taken to prevent Lithuania and the other Baltic republics from seceding. Gorbachev had previously placed a $34 billion pricetag on Lithuanian independence, saying an independent Lithuania would have to pay for the factories, roads and other physical improvements made during a half-century of Soviet rule. But Lithuanians say they have a much larger bill to present for five decades of Soviet repression _ including mass deportations to Siberia under Joseph Stalin.

DOC.HEAD: Hurd: Britain's Main Concern Is NATO
DOC.TEXT: Britain's foreign secretary said Monday that protecting NATO is his main concern as German unification proceeds, but there also will be ``tough discussions'' on how to incorporate what is now East Germany into the EEC. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd made the remarks two days before the preliminary round of the ``two-plus-four'' unification talks of the two German nations and the four World War II allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain. Hurd was in Bonn for discussions with Chancellor Helmut Kohl about his game plan for unification. He also met with Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. The West German government announced, meanwhile, that Kohl would be meeting with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on March 30. Hurd said that in his talks with Kohl and Genscher, they discussed ``virtually every aspect of German unification,'' including the Polish border issue, NATO, and the European Economic Community. ``Mr. Genscher assured me it is the wish of the federal government that these external aspects should be settled _ there should be agreement on them _ before unification takes place,'' said Hurd. He praised Kohl's reversal of his earlier refusal to say unequivocally that a united Germany would have no designs on land ceded to Poland after the Third Reich's defeat in 1945. He also insisted the Poles have a right to participate in discussions about their borders. Poland is demanding it be included in the reunification talks, but West Germany has rejected that idea. ``Certainly the Poles should take part in any discussion which affects their frontiers,'' Hurd said, without specifying if he believes Poland should be a full participant in the talks. Hurd underscored that Britain supports German unification, and said London merely has been insisting that the ``external aspects'' of unification be fully discussed. He said Britain's foremost concern is protecting the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``Our main concern is with the future of the North Atlantic alliance, and the crucial importance for that alliance, and for the security of Europe, of continued German membership of NATO,'' Hurd said. The Soviet Union has insisted a united Germany cannot be a NATO member. As a compromise, Genscher has proposed keeping NATO troops off what East German territory, an idea backed by the United States but rejected by the Soviets. Hurd said he and his West German hosts talked about the problem and were ``quite close on this.'' He also said that incorporating what is now East Germany into the European Economic Community came up as well. ``I foresee a tough but technical series of discussions (within the EEC) on the Community aspect,'' he said. ``The sooner East Germany can be brought into the Community framework, into a NATO framework, the better we'll be pleased,'' he said. Four U.S. senators met with Kohl Monday. Sen. Richard G. Lugar, R-Ind., said the chancellor had ``asked for U.S. understanding'' about the accelerated pace of German unification. Lugar is head of the Senate Arms Control Observer Group.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation Begins in Tank Explosion That Killed Three
DOC.TEXT: An investigation began Monday into an explosion that killed three workers inside an empty oil storage tank. The victims were renovating the 80,000-barrel tank on Sunday when a piece of equipment apparently touched off vapors that had built up inside, causing the explosion, Webster Parish coroner's investigator T.C. Bloxom said. The blast was strong enough to blow the top off the tank, ``and that's one of the biggest tanks on the premises,'' Bloxom said. The refinery is run by the Kerr-McGee Refining and Crude Oil Hauling Corp., whose investigators were joined by federal and state inspectors Monday. Authorities said the three killed were working for a subcontractor, Baker Tank of Arp, Texas. The vapor buildup occurred in spite of a ventilating fan. Bloxom said the victims' bodies were found near the fan. The men apparently died instantly, sheriff's Deputy Charlie Horton said. He said a fourth worker had just left the tank to get tools and was not hurt. Residents near the refinery on Louisiana Highway 7 said they heard a sound like thunder, looked out and saw fire and smoke. Kerr-McGee employees had the flash fire out by the time fire crews from the nearby town of Minden arrived, but it was three hours before rescuers wearing protective clothing and breathing gear could be lowered into the tankto recover the charred bodies, Bloxom said. The victims were identified as James Christopher Doyle, 22, of Longview, Texas; Steve Gurado Vega, 24, of Tyler, Texas; and Ricky Martin, 37, of Jacksonville, Texas. The explosion was the second at the refinery in eight years. Four men were injured, two seriously, and residents were evacuated after a series of explosions in May 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Got $481 Million in U.S. Wheat Subsidy
DOC.TEXT: U.S. subsidies on wheat sold to the Soviet Union were worth $481 million over 29 months, the General Accounting Office reported. The Soviet Union got the benefit of lower prices from the largest amount that the U.S. government spent on shipments to any one country. The subsidies are collected by U.S. exporting companies, which then ship to foreign buyers at less than market prices. The object is to help sell U.S. farm products in competition with subsidies by governments of other producer countries trying to help their own farmers. The program is aimed especially at competition from the 12 countries of the European Economic Community, where France and West Germany are big exporters of wheat. Wheat is the major item under what the federal government calls its Export Enhancement Program, but subsidies are also paid on a variety of products from eggs to milk cows. Detailed figures in the report, made available recently, cover Oct. 1, 1986, through Feb. 28, 1989. During that period, the total subsidies to all exporters amounted to $2.3 billion. Total sales of U.S. products helped by the subsidies were $6.8 billion, of which $5.5 billion was for sales of wheat. Five countries were the biggest wheat buyers under the program: the Soviet Union, China, Algeria, Egypt and Morocco. Critics say the subsidized sales discourage those governments from paying better prices to their own farmers, and that the bread from the wheat is so cheap that some feed it to animals. The Agriculture Department put the total cost of the subsidies up to last week at $2.7 billion since the program began in 1985. It said later detailed figures for the Soviet Union and other individual countries were confidential. ``It's largely a pass-through operation to help U.S. farmers,'' said Rob Johnson, vice president for public affairs of Cargill Inc. ``Our commissions have averaged less than one-half of one percent of sales.'' Cargill, one of the world's biggest grain dealers, collected the largest amount in subsidies: $444.9 million. How much of that was profit is impossible to estimate, said Allen I. Mendelowitz, director of international trade and finance issues at the GAO. His report was submitted to Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Tex., chairman of the House Agriculture Commitee. Mendelowitz said Cargill's earnings come not only from commissions but also depend on the prices it paid U.S. farmers, which may have been higher than the prices it received in Moscow, as well as on the subsidies it received from the U.S. government. Those subsidies are paid in the form of surplus farm products already owned by the government. Egypt was the second biggest beneficiary under the U.S. program, which paid U.S. dealers $311.8 million in such commodities to help exports there. Egypt got frozen poultry, dairy cattle and semolina, too, but wheat and wheat flour were much the biggest items. China received some cattle, but mostly wheat. Subsidies for shipments there totaled $299.5 million. Algeria, a major wheat producer, also got mainly wheat from the United States. The bonuses on exports there were worth $206.9 million, including some for barley, semolina and vegetable oil. The GAO is Congress' watchdog agency on government spending.

DOC.HEAD: Freud Psychiatry Clinic Entitled to Quarter of Monroe's Estate
DOC.TEXT: An English psychiatric center founded by Sigmund Freud's daughter is entitled to one-fourth of Marilyn Monroe's estate, a judge ruled Monday. Miss Monroe had left the share, estimated to be worth millions of dollars, to her psychiatrist, who died in 1980. Manhattan Surrogate Marie Lambert decided that the psychiatrist, Dr. Marianne Kris, had the right to bequeath her share of Monroe's estate to the Anna Freud Centre for the Psychoanalytic Study and Treatment of Children in London. Miss Monroe, who starred in such movies as ``Bus Stop,'' ``Gentlemen Prefer Blondes,'' ``The Seven-Year Itch'' and ``Some Like It Hot,'' died in 1962 from an overdose of drugs and alcohol. In a three-page will dated Jan. 14, 1961, Miss Monroe left the rest of her estate to her acting coach, Lee Strasberg. Strasberg's widow, Anna, was appointed in July as administrator of Miss Monroe's estate after the original executor's death earlier in the year. Mrs. Strasberg challenged the psychiatric center's right to the money, saying Kris' rights to the estate ended when she died. Kris reportedly never collected any proceeds from Miss Monroe's estate. But in her own will, she left her share to the Hampstead Child Therapy Clinic, renamed for its founder, Anna Freud. Had Lambert ruled in Mrs. Strasberg's favor, Kris' share would have gone to Strasberg's estate. But Lambert noted that Mrs. Strasberg had said she would donate the disputed share to charity. Bernard Green, lawyer for the center, said it is impossible to say exactly what the estate is worth, but added, ``It's not an insubstantial amount.''

DOC.HEAD: Dole Calls for Speedup in Bailout of Savings and Loan Industry
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole on Monday warned President Bush of a political backlash from voters unless the administration speeds up work on the savings and loan bailout. ``This thing could be an albatross in 1992 ... which happens to be an election year,'' the Kansas Republican said. ``I think George Bush has some interest in staying on.'' The Resolution Trust Corp., the new agency created to dispose of failed thrifts, has sold only 50 of the more than 380 S&Ls under government control and ``is not living up to expectations,'' Dole said. He said the delay is driving up the cost of the bailout, estimated at $160 billion over 10 years. ``We've got to get this thing going... I've got a feeling this thing is going to get out of hand one of these days and the American people are going to start saying, `What are you doing about it?''' he told a meeting of the National Association of Federal Credit Unions. The Republican leader said the administration must fill vacant positions in the savings and loan bureaucracy and resolve an apparent turf battle between the Resolution Trust Corp. and a Treasury Department-led oversight board. And Congress must ``go back and take a look'' at S&L legislation ``if not this year, then early next year,'' he said. The chairmen of both the House and Senate banking committees say they oppose revising the law this year. But Dole said the S&L law contributes to what he called a sluggishness that is gripping the bureaucracy by establishing conflicting guidelines. Congress ordered the administration to dispose of property from S&Ls quickly but avoid dumping property on the market. It said the government should get the highest price for the assets but offer low-income groups the first chance to buy some of the property. As a result, ``the RTC is timid,'' Dole said. ``They're afraid of Congress. They're afraid of public hearings. They don't want to do anything innovative.'' ``We (in Congress) are trying to have it both ways,'' he said. ``... Keep this in mind because, a year from now, nobody in Congress is going to tell you we did that. They're going to blame the administration.'' Dole said he's sounded his warning in a conversation with the president, in a letter to Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and in a meeting last week with White House Chief of Staff John Sununu.

DOC.HEAD: Transit Officials Don't Like Transportation Policy, But Still Like Author
DOC.TEXT: Transit officials passed a resolution Monday condemning a federal transportation policy they said could put some of them out business, but praised its author, Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner. The American Public Transit Association, which includes transit officials and suppliers from around the country, urged a 7 cents-a-gallon federal gas tax increase for mass transit and said Skinner's policy ``fails to set clear, meaningful goals for increased transit use.'' The resolution was approved on a unanimous voice vote by about 500 participants. However, several officials said they still had faith in Skinner, whose policy was unveiled at the White House last week, and believe he will fight for their goals even though his policy doesn't. ``I've lost no confidence in Sam Skinner at all,'' said Rod Diridon, chairman of California's Santa Clara County Transportation Agency. He blamed the policy's shortcomings on changes made by the White House's Office of Management and Budget and Chief of Staff John Sununu. Dan Scannell of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority said he expected Skinner, who formerly headed the Chicago area transit system, to fight ``for the principles that should be embraced.'' William Millar, manager of Pittsburgh's transit system, said the industry trusts Skinner and the people who work for him. ``All of us have a boss,'' he said, referring to the fact that Skinner works for President Bush, who has pledged not to raise taxes. ``The boss may be saying something different from what any of us may want to do.'' Millar said, however, the policy that would shift more responsibility to local governments and decrease federal support for mass transit, could put people out of work and make it so others can't get to work. Hershel R. Payne, head of transportation for Fort Worth, Texas, said the ``increased flexibility'' the policy would give local governments would mean a reduction in federal assistance. ``It would hit every transportation system in the country, from the smallest to the largest,'' Payne said. ``Many systems may even have to close down'' and fares in others could go up 25 percent. Neil Peterson, Los Angeles County Transportation Commission director, said the proposals would restrict development of a new transit system in the county and mean even more congested freeways. He predicted the congestion would lower the average speed, which now is only 37 mph, to 17 mph in 20 years. Vicki Shaffer, who runs the 25-bus system in Huntington, W.Va., said her 50-employee operation could not have started without federal help. ``The policy says to us, `Forget it,''' she said. ``If you cannot put your money where your mouth is, don't tell me you have a policy.''

DOC.HEAD: Administration Presses Israelis For Reply On Proposal For Talks
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration pressed the Israeli government Monday to overcome its indecision about a U.S. plan for negotiations with Palestinian Arabs and to approve a formula put together by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. ``We are waiting for an answer from the Israeli government,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said. ``When the answer comes back, then we will know how to proceed.'' While Baker kept his distance, lower-level U.S. diplomats were in touch with Israeli officials. There was no immediate word on whether Baker would soften any of the terms to accommodate Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and other members of the conservative Likud coalition. ``I would hate to say anything is locked in concrete,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``We are in a negotiations.'' Shamir and his supporters objected to the inclusion in the delegation of Cairo talks Palestinians with a residence in East Jerusalem or deported from the West Bank. The provision, inserted by Baker in deference to Egypt and the Palestine Liberation Organization, appeared to challenge Israel's retention of the predominantly Arab part of Jerusalem as well as handling of a Palestinian rebellion on the West Bank and in Gaza. A statement by President Bush calling East Jerusalem and the West Bank off-limits to Jewish ``settlers'' also irritated Shamir. On Sunday, the prime minister refused to put Baker's plan to a vote before the 12-member Israeli inner cabinet. The inaction raised the prospect of a government crisis in Jerusalem and abandonment by Baker of his eight-month effort to launch negotiations. Shimon Peres, leader of the opposition Labor party, accused Shamir on Monday of leaving Israel in a ``desert of indecision.'' White House and State Department officials said the Bush administration would not give up in seeking approval of the Baker plan. ``The process is still continuing. We're still talking and we're still hopeful,'' Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said. Asked if Bush's comments on East Jerusalem had set the talks back, Fitzwater replied: ``No. The process of peace talks is a long and arduous one. There have been stops and starts, and it's still continuing and we just continue to watch the process and be supportive as we can.'' State Department spokeswoman Tutwiler said, meanwhile, the sole U.S. objective in promoting Israeli-Palestinian talks was to help Israel implement its own plan for elections on the West Bank and Gaza. ``What we are looking for is agreement on moving towards peace,'' she said. Meanwhile, Thomas A. Dine, executive director of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, accused the Bush administration in a speech Sunday night of ``a new American tilt'' that had caused the PLO to rejoice and brought unhappiness to Likud and Labor circles in Israel. Dine criticized Bush's statement on Jerusalem and testimony by Baker and John Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for the Near East, crediting PLO chairman Yasser Arafat with honoring his renunciation of terrorism. ``Settlements on the West Bank are a matter on which Israelis themselves, and our community here, are divided,'' Dine said. ``Some favor them, and others are opposed. But the right of Jews to live anywhere in Jerusalem ... has never before been questioned by any American president, certainly not publicly.''

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Hits North Pacific
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck the north Pacific on Monday, and was felt 110 miles away in the Aleutian Island town of Adak. There are no reports of damage or injury. The quake had a preliminary strength of 6.2 on the Richter scale, said Alec Medberry at the Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer. It was not strong enough to generate a tsunami, or tidal wave, he added. The quake struck at 5:41 a.m. AST and was centered about 110 miles southeast of Adak. Medberry said it was also felt in the Aleutian Island town of Atka, about 100 miles away. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-Ager Shot Dead Two Days Before 16th Birthday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9 `Police Capt. ...' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with arraignment; picks up 10th graf, `This is ...'
DOC.TEXT: A high school sophomore who would have celebrated his 16th birthday Monday died after being shot in the face by a 14-year-old friend as they were playing with guns, police said. Chad MacDonald died at Baystate Medical Center on Sunday, a day after the shooting at his home in this Springfield suburb. His parents said the boy had taken the loaded weapons _ a 9mm semiautomatic pistol and a .357-caliber Magnum revolver _ to his room without their permission because he had been frightened by an older boy. West Springfield High School Principal George F. Bauman described Chad as ``your everyday high school student.'' ``He was an average student, who didn't stand out above the rest, but at the same time had not been in any difficulty,'' Bauman said Monday. As an 8-year-old, Chad received a National Heroism Award from the Boy Scouts of America for summoning help for his mother when she suffered collapsed lungs. The principal said counselors and nurses were being made available to distraught students. ``We are trying to help the students and the family get through this crisis with as little scarring as possible,'' he said. Police Capt. Thomas Burke declined to release the name of the 14-year-old charged, because of his age. The youth was arraigned Monday in Springfield Juvenile Court on charges of delinquency by reasons of murder and of possession of a firearm with no identification, said Clerk Magistrate Marc Katsoulis. Witnesses said the youth tremble at the closed hearing as an automatic plea of innocent was entered. The case was continued to April 2 and the youth was released to his parents' custody. Burke said police also were looking into how the boys came to have the guns, which belonged to Chad's father and were licensed. ``This is a very careless, negligent, tragic act, especially with young kids,'' Burke said. ``Guns should be stored in a locked place, with ammunition kept in a separate locked place.'' Burke said the 14-year-old, who was sleeping over as the family was preparing for Chad's birthday party, told authorities he took the 9mm semiautomatic from a dresser and fired at Chad after Chad had pointed the Magnum at him and said ``bang.'' Chad's parents said their son had taken the two loaded weapons and put them in his room without their knowledge. Debra MacDonald said her son had been repeatedly harassed by an older youth, and she and her husband had filed several complaints with police. Her husband, Glenn, said the family did not harbor any ill-feelings toward the 14-year-old boy. ``He is destroyed,'' the father said. ``He has to live with this the rest of his life.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Taking ukuleles to Hawaii sounds about as misplaced as shipping coals to Newcastle. But that's what 25 Vancouver-area students, aged 9 to 19, are doing this week. ``Even though the ukulele is the key instrument in their society _ it's as Hawaiian as the grass skirt _ the school authorities over there want to learn the Canadian teaching methods we use which are so successful,'' said Peter Luongo, vice principal and music specialist at Alice Brown elementary. The school has become so skilled at teaching the four-stringed, guitarlike instrument that word has reached Hawaii. The ukulele, introduced from Portugal into the Hawaiian Islands about 1879, was first used in Canadian schools in the Maritime provinces about 20 years ago to teach music, he said. ``It came to Langley about 15 years ago and we got some really keen kids,'' he said. ``I picked up the program when I came here and developed a senior honors group.'' The students have played in concerts across Canada and will pay for most of the 10-day trip beginning Thursday. ``We will be given a lot of hospitality but we'll be going to schools that are very meager compared to ours and I think our students will learn a lot about the other side of Hawaii _ it's not all plush hotels,'' Luongo said.

Marleen Suess wanted an undergraduate degree, and knew it was just a matter of finding the time. Ms. Suess, an accounts supervisor for H.J. Heinz Co., expects to graduate from Robert Morris College in 1992, just 12 years and 29 semesters after enrolling. ``I'm on the 12-year plan,'' said Ms. Suess, 40, of Dorseyville. ``When I started, I knew I would definitely finish no matter how long it would take.'' She now has 90 credits and a 3.67 grade point average. Ms. Suess said she returned to college to advance her career. After her divorce, she said, ``I knew I had to take care of myself.'' She initially was afraid she would be unable to juggle her job, schoolwork and housework. ``Now I realize that's silly. You can always find the time,'' she said.

Two dozen students discovered that being a parent to an egg can really scramble your life. Third-grade teacher Charla Easley gave her students at Ima Dell Fitzgerald Elementary School hard-boiled eggs to name, clothe and nurture for one week as a firsthand lesson about the responsibilities of parenthood. The students were given $100 in play money with which they could pay to leave their eggs in day care _ at the back of the classroom _ if they wanted some free time. Overnight care was available at $10 a night. The ``eggs-perience'' was eye-opening, the students said. The high cost of day care forced Espie Randolph to take his ``daughter,'' Jessica, everywhere, he said. ``She really got on my nerves,'' Espie said. ``I had to take her to the park, to the mall, and even on the bus.'' ``I thought raising a kid would be a lot easier,'' said 9-year-old John Moffett. Moffett said he is glad the shell game is over and has plans for his triplets. ``I'm going to throw them in the trash compactor,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Disabled Climb Capitol Steps To Plea For Government Protection
DOC.TEXT: Using her arms to drag her small body up the Capitol steps, 8-year-old Jennifer Keelan joined some 60 disabled Americans Monday in lobbying for legislation to guarantee their civil rights. ``I'll take all night if I have to,'' Jennifer said to others crawling alongside her. She paused just past the halfway point for a sip of water on a bright and unseasonably hot March day, then resumed pulling herself along the rest of the 83 marble steps. Keelan, a blond-haired second grader from Denver, was the youngest of about 60 people with disabilities who left their wheelchairs and crawled up the West Front of the Capitol. They were making a symbolic protest to demand passage of a key bill now pending in the House that would extend civil rights to disabled persons. She and the others climbed the Capitol steps after about 1,000 people walked or rode in wheelchairs down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House to the Capitol and held a rally at the base of the Capitol steps. The were demanding passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act, which passed the Senate last year but has been bogged down in the House this year, despite widespread predictions of its ultimate passage. The measure would outlaw discrimination based on physical or mental disability in employment, access to buildings, use of the telephone system, use of public and private transportation systems, and in other areas. Although the bill has the support of the Bush administration and congressional leaders, some supporters have begun questioning the administration's commitment in recent weeks. At the White House, Bush press secretary Marlin Fitzwater denied that the support was slipping and said the administration was negotiating over the bill with key members of Congress. ``We do support the legislation,'' Fitzwater said. ``We're very supportive of their rights and their cause. President Bush has spoken out on that in the past.'' Rep. Pat Schroeder, D-Colo., a supporter of the bill, told the rally that pressure was building for the bill and that the House Energy and Commerce Committee had scheduled its vote on the measure for Tuesday as a result. The protesters wore signs demanding passage of the bill, without weakening amendments. They represented people with all sorts of disabilities _ people in wheelchairs, people speaking in sign language, people with seeing-eye dogs. Among those at the rally were James Brady, the former White House press secretary who was shot in head during the attack on President Reagan in 1981. I. King Jordan, president of Galludet University and the first deaf person to hold that position at the school for the hearing impaired, said: ``We're not asking for any favors. We're simply asking the same rights and equality any other American has.'' Jennifer Keelan and the other demonstrators began crawling up the steps to the Capitol as soon as the speeches ended. Unable to move any other way, some rolled on their side to cover the concrete spaces between the five flights of steps. As Jennifer crawled, her mother, Cynthia Keelan, stood watching in the shade. She said Jennifer suffers cerebral palsy. She said her daughter decided to crawl the steps herself, after joining the group Americans Disabled for Accessible Public Transit and becoming friends with its members, adults and children. A young friend of hers in that group, 5-year-old Kenny Perkins of Denver, died in January. ``I'm doing it for Kenny,'' Jennifer said as she reached the top.'' ``I'm proud of her,'' her mother said. ``That was hard work.''

DOC.HEAD: Independence-Minded Republics Assail Gorbachev's Presidency Plan
LaserPhotoMOSB1,3,5; LaserColor MOSB4
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan for a powerful presidency to hold the Soviet Union together ran into a wall of opposition Monday, one day after Lithuania fractured the union by declaring its independence. Parliamentarians from other independence-minded republics took the floor of the Congress of People's Deputies to assail the proposed presidency as far too strong for the loose federation of sovereign countries they envision as the future Soviet Union. ``The fact that the U.S.S.R. is a union of sovereign states is hardly taken into account,'' said Givi Gumbaridze, Communist Party chief of the southern republic of Georgia, where the parliament voted Friday to reject the presidency proposal and to demand immediate negotiations with Moscow on independence. ``This draft does not give enough consideration to the sad traditions of our state,'' he said, referring to decades of dictatorship and its terrible toll of mass murder. Lithuanians were so dismayed by Gorbachev's proposed strengthening of the presidency that they rushed to declare independence before it passed. ``Tomorrow, Mr. Gorbachev will get dictatorial powers with the right to overrun any republican parliament,'' said Algimantas Chekuolis, a Lithuanian who with his republic's declaration of independence now describes himself as a former member of the Soviet Congress, attending as an observer. As Gorbachev opened the session, he called the Lithuanian action ``alarming'' without ever mentioning the word independence. He suggested that the government study what is happening and prepare a reaction. Another member of the ruling Communist Party Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, said Moscow would not use force in Lithuania. Progressive Moscow deputy Alexei Yablokov said legislators from Georgia, Moldavia, Azerbaijan, Estonia and Latvia are expected to boycott Tuesday's vote on the constitutional amendment, which could fail for lack of the required two-thirds majority. All five of those republics are possible candidates for following the Lithuanians into secession. But throughout the day, deputies huddled with Gorbachev and each other seeking compromises. At one point, Estonian President Arnold Ruutel, Gorbachev and Gorbachev's aide Georgi Shakhnazarov pulled up chairs behind the dais and Ruutel earnestly pitched a deal to the Soviet leader. Ruutel told reporters Estonia was seeking assurances that Gorbachev would negotiate the Baltic state's future relationship with Moscow, but he refused to say if the Estonians would trade that promise for their votes on the presidency. Also on the agenda of the special session of Congress were constitutional amendments to end the Communist Party's monopoly on power and substitute a multiparty political system, and to allow individuals to own factories and lease land. Another draft amendment would ban any party or organization whose goal is violent overthrow of the constitutional structure or the socialist state. If the presidency proposal is approved Tuesday, deputies will then nominate and elect someone to the job, possibly the same day. Gorbachev is the only candidate whose name has been mentioned thus far and he is expected to win, said progressive deputy Sergei Stankevich. Gorbachev has said the new powers are needed so the Soviet Union won't fall into a ethnic and nationalist violence that could threaten his campaign for democratization and reform. The Supreme Soviet, an arm of the Congress that functions as the working legislature, voted overwhelmingly to support the proposal Feb. 27. Soviet Vice President Anatoly Lukyanov introduced the latest draft of the presidency proposal Monday by promising: ``There is no reason to believe that the institution of the presidency would lead to alleged authoritarian power.'' Lukyanov said the bill creates checks and balances between the executive and legislative branches of power. He said the Congress may recall the president for violating laws or the constitution, but only the Congress and the Supreme Soviet may pass laws. The current Constitution still allows the Presidium, headed by Gorbachev, to issue decrees. Progressive deputy Anatoly Sobchak said a tentative compromise had been reached on the most controversial point allowing the president to declare a state of emergency, suspend the parliament of a republic and take over its administration. It would require him to obtain permission from the republic or the national parliament, he said at a news conference. Gorbachev supporter Sergei Alexeyev argued the Soviet Union is ``in a paralysis of power,'' and ``the presidency is the only way to transfer the real power from the party to the government.'' If the presidency issue is resolved positively, ``we can get down to drafting a new constitution immediately which will confirm human rights, democracy and conversion to a market economy,'' Alexeyev said. But Vitaly Vorotnikov, president of the Russian Federation, alarmed deputies from the smaller republics when he said the country needed a president ``to ensure strict compliance with all the laws of the union.'' Several of the independence-oriented republics have adopted constitutional amendments allowing them to suspend Soviet laws on their territory. The constitutional amendment requires a two-thirds majority, or 1,500 of the 2,250 members of the Congress. A close vote could force Gorbachev into a difficult choice: recognize that the Lithuanians are no longer members of Congress, thus lowering the needed margin to 1,462 votes out of 2,192, or risk losing the vote. Yuri Afanasyev, a leader of a group of progressive deputies, urged the presidency be adopted only in conjunction with a new constitution, direct election of the president, real opposition parties, freedom of the press and a new union treaty. He angered many of the deputies by attacking Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin. ``The use of force and violence is our entire history. If our leader and founder laid the foundation of anything, it was the institution of mass violence and state terror,'' he said. Deputies shouted their anger. Afanasyev, a historian, said later he was proud of the statement even though it undoubtedly cost the progressives votes.

DOC.HEAD: In Newly Independent Lithuania, Quiet Hope Prevails
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, ``But Lithuania's ...'' to CORRECT spelling to Algimantas sted Algimontas; SUBS 21st graf ``Kyastutis Rimkus, ...'' to CORRECT spelling to Kestutis, sted Kyastutis.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON7
DOC.TEXT: At the doors to Lithuania's Supreme Soviet _ renamed the Supreme Council _ artist Kestutis Balikonis was touching up the paint Monday under the banner of a medieval knight that replaced the metal Soviet hammer and sickle torn down the night before. ``In concrete daily life, nothing has changed'' since Lithuania declared its independence from the Soviet Union on Sunday night, he said. But he added: ``Now we're living in the hope that something will change.'' ``We know that at the beginning, things will be harder, but no one says we shouldn't have done this, even though everyone is a little concerned,'' Balikonis said. In the blustery Lithuanian capital, there were no special signs of rejoicing Monday, no banner headlines in the newspapers and no special flags flying or bells ringing. Virtually all the signs of a half-century of Soviet control remained. Only a dozen or so stalwart activists gathered in the rain in front of the Supreme Council's concrete columns. Residents and legislators said the joy over the moves for independence was overshadowed by trepidation about the possible consequences and whether Lithuania's new government would make the right moves. In discussions Monday, the Supreme Council turned to thorny economic issues, including the question of the fate of Moscow-controlled factories on Lithuanian soil. With no direct response from Moscow, members of the 141-seat Supreme Council drafted a message to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, asking him to recognize Lithuania's statehood and begin talks with the republic on restoration of its independence. Gorbachev told the Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow that Lithuania's action was ``alarming,'' but gave no further reaction. Another member of the ruling Communist Party Politburo, Yegor K. Ligachev, said the Kremlin would not use force against Lithuania. The Soviet leader has told Lithuanian leaders that he will demand 21 billion rubles _ about $34 billion _ as compensation for a half-century of investment in Lithuania. But Lithuania independence leader Algimantas Chekuolis, also in Moscow for the Congress, said the republic's bill to Moscow for damages done during that time was 300 billion rubles _ about $500 billion. He said that figure included compensation for 300,000 Lithuanians killed, imprisoned or exiled during Soviet rule, and for Kremlin-inspired economic failures. Earlier in the day, Vytautas Landsbergis, Lithuania's new president, warned legislators to expect disappointment and unpleasantness in the near future. ``Hope and joy must dissolve into determination to work for Lithuania. We must work very hard,'' he told the Supreme Council. Despite people's fears, Sunday night's decison brought a wave of euphoria for many. Balikonis said a strange man offered him a cigarette and said, ``Can't you already breathe easier?'' Many parents told their children to ``remember this day of Lithuania's freedom,'' said council deputy Vidmante Lasukaitete. But she added that many people were upset that Algirdas Brazauskas, the popular Communist Party chief who had served as president, lost his re-election bid to Landsbergis, a music professor who led the pro-independence Sajudis movement, at Sunday's parliamentary session. ``People are happy about independence, but would have wanted a different president,'' Lasukaitete said. Kestutis Rimkus, a deputy from rural Lithuania, said his constituents were concerned that the Supreme Council had rushed its decision on independence and bringing in a provisional constitution. ``No one is thinking now, they're just living by their emotions,'' he complained.'' Balchas Saulius, a student at Vilnius Teachers Institute, said Lithuanians agreed with the traditional Communist saying: ``We have nothing to lose but our chains.'' ``It's not important what happens. We are ready for everything, even being hungry and cold,'' added philosophy professor Stase Radziuniene. They said they expected a restrained political reaction from Moscow, but also an intense supply blockade and other tough measures intended to punish Lithuania economically. They also expected harassment of 50,000 Lithuanians serving in the Soviet armed forces by their fellow soldiers, and problems from Lithuania's minorities _ the Poles, Russians, Jews and others that make up 20 percent of the republic's 3.7 million people. Russians in the port city of Klaipeda have already launched a petition drive to append their area to the Russian republic, the activists said. Gorbachev has suggested that Klaipeda, a port on the Baltic sea, may be the subject of a territorial dispute because post World War II documents do not specifically include it in Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Robbery in Nablus Raises Fear New Gang Forming
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf after 9th pvs `The shop' to UPDATE with second attack on store. Picks up 10th, `Kanaan, a...'
DOC.TEXT: The robbery of a gold merchant by armed Palestinians in the West Bank town of Nablus on Monday raised fears that a new gang of self-styled ``enforcers'' has emerged. Arab reports said two Palestinian men armed with Israeli-made Uzi submacine guns entered a shop near the Nablus central market and robbed the merchant of 11 pounds of gold. Last year, a Palestinian gang called the Black Panthers financed its campaign of assassinations against Arabs suspected of cooperating with Israel by stealing 17.6 pounds of gold from a Nablus merchant. The Black Panthers went underground in December after gang leaders were killed in a raid by Israeli troops. They are believed affiliated with Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction in the PLO. Another Nablus gang, known as the Red Eagles and aligned with the Marxist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, was smashed by the army in November. The robbers Monday were believed to be renegade Fatah members, Arab reports said. They said both men were wanted by Israeli police for activities related to the 27-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. After the theft, masked Palestinians affiliated with Fatah marched through the Nablus market and announced over loudspeakers they would pursue the robbers and try to recover the gold. Fatah leaders last fall appealed in vain to the Black Panthers and the Red Eagles to end their killings of suspected collaborators. Also in Nablus on Monday, three masked Palestinians armed with swords and clubs forced their way into a cosmetics shop owned by Palestinian businessman Saeed Kanaan and smashed some of his goods. Kanaan refused to comment on the incident. The shop was attacked for a second time that night when four masked Palestinians smashed the windows and set the store ablaze, Nablus residents said. They said the shop suffered moderate damage before firefighters arrived. Kanaan, a moderate Palestian leader who supports Fatah, was threatened by Palestinian radicals after reports were published in a Hebrew-language daily suggesting that he would be named to a delegation opening preliminary peace talks with Israel. Kanaan later took out advertisements in Arab newspapers denying the report. Also Monday, Palestinian Jamal Muhammed Khalifa, 17, died of bullet wounds suffered in a stone-throwing clash with Israeli soldiers Sunday night in the Akhbat Jaber refugee camp in Jericho, hospital officials said. The army confirmed the death and said soldiers opened fired when attacked by a group of masked youths. His death raised to 663 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis during the uprising. Another 196 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, and 43 Israelis have died.

DOC.HEAD: Dense Fog Blamed in Flaming Pileup that Kills Three
With AM-Storms Rdp
LaserPhoto GBR2
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of cars and trucks piled up and burned in a chain-reaction collision on a downtown freeway bridge in fog so thick it cut visibility to zero. Three people were killed, authorities said. ``It was just horrible, terrible. To hear the brakes squeal, the gas tanks explode, to hear the people screaming,'' said Harry Suppanz, 35, of Sturgeon Bay, a passenger in a truck that crashed and burned. At least 30 people were injured and taken to hospitals. Police Lt. Roy Johnson described the situation as ``total chaos'' after the crash on the northbound lanes of the Interstate 43 bridge over the Fox River. He said visibility was ``just about down to zero'' when the accident occurred shortly before 7 a.m. Authorities said 45 vehicles were involved. By afternoon, investigators were still trying to determine the sequence of events that started the pileup, said Police Inspector Jim Taylor. ``It is absolutely amazing. I couldn't believe it when I saw only three did die,'' said Brown County Coroner Genie Williams. ``It was amazing that many people got out.'' Police Capt. Larry Gille said a fuel tanker truck involved in the crash did not burn, but a number of vehicles did. ``It looks like it was exploding gas tanks from cars'' that caused the fire, he said. Suppanz and Dan Lauder, 31, of Sturgeon Bay said they were in a small truck on their way to work for a tree-trimming service at the time of the crash. Suppanz said his truck was jolted at least six or seven times during the chain-reaction crash, but his only injury was a bump on the head. Lauder said five or six vehicles crashed in front of his truck, and a fuel tanker truck was behind it. Two other vehicles started on fire, and the tanker driver was worried the blaze could spread to his gasoline cargo, Lauder said. ``The tanker truck driver was yelling, `Get out of here. Get out of here. The tank might blow,''' Suppanz said. ``There were cars that were smashed and burned beyond recognition. It is a miracle more people weren't killed,'' said Suppanz. ``We were lucky.'' Lauder estimated he was traveling about 30 mph when his truck first collided with another vehicle. In southern Wisconsin, fog was blamed for the collision of four tractor-trailer rigs in eastbound lanes of Interstate 94 near Lake Mills after the lead truck slowed because of low visibility. The Wisconsin State Patrol said the accident closed the eastbound lanes for more than two hours. One driver suffered a broken leg. Williams, the coroner, said the three who were killed were in separate cars and were in the middle of the pileup. Two were burned beyond recognition, she said. Of the injured, two were admitted to St. Mary's Hospital Medical Center and were in serious condition, spokeswoman Susan Fisk said. St. Vincent Hospital admitted five crash victims, spokesman Jim Reck said. Three were in serious condition and two in fair condition, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Official Predicts Increased Unemployment With Economic Reforms
With AM-Germany
DOC.TEXT: Economic reforms will leave 100,000 autoworkers without jobs, an auto industry official said Monday in the most concrete sign that East Germany's radical changes could mean widespread unemployment. Changes in the crippled economy could shock many East Germans accustomed to four decades of near full employment under the now-disgraced Communist Party. In East Berlin, the head of East Germany's Communist Party, Gregor Gysi, complained of intolerance toward party members, while the Social Democrats claimed privatization of state businesses should be slowed down. At the weeklong Leipzig International Trade Fair that opened Sunday, Dieter Voigt, the general manager of East Germany's automobile works IFA, said layoffs of between 60 percent to 70 percent were expected in the automobile industry and related production facilities. Voigt said automobile plants in East Germany employ 65,000 people, with another 150,000 people working in related electronics and other supply industries. ``Of those, the jobs of between 90,000 to 105,000 are in danger,'' Voigt said, if plants are modernized and production restructured. But he said job cuts would eventually be overcome and collaboration with West German companies would show that ``people can go to work with new motivation and hope.'' West German auto producers Volkswagen, Opel and Daimler-Benz have signed joint-venture agreements with East Germany. Volkswagen's total investment in East German automobile production is scheduled to reach $2.94 billion by 1994, Volkswagen chief Carl Hahn said. At Monday's session of talks between the Communist Party and opposition groups, Gysi said there had been evidence of intolerance toward party members. ``Already, qualified students who belong to the party are not admitted to universities,'' Gysi said. ``Let's not replace our old intolerances with new ones.'' During 40 years of hard-line rule, Communist Party members were often given preference in the pursuit of higher education and job opportunities. Gysi made his comments at the 16th and last session of weekly talks between the political groups.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Official Tapped for Labor Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Monday he will nominate Julian W. De La Rosa, a St. Louis police official and former FBI agent, to be inspector general at the Labor Department. De La Rosa, 50, would succeed James B. Hyland in the post, which requires Senate confirmation. De La Rosa is secretary to the Board of Police Commissioners in St. Louis. He spent three decades with the FBI in St. Louis, his hometown of San Antonio, Texas and in other posts.

DOC.HEAD: N.D. Lieutenant Governor, Public Service Commissioner Duke it up
DOC.TEXT: Donning boxing gloves and bemused expressions, North Dakota's lieutenant governor and a state commissioner skewered Norwegians, neighboring Montana and each other in an after-dinner feast of verbal fisticuffs. It was billed as a bout of political light-wits, and the audience of state officials was soon groaning. A judge couldn't decide whose barbs were best, so he cracked a joke and disqualified himself. They entered the mock ring in red boxing gloves. In early exchanges, Lt. Gov. Lloyd Omdahl scored with a shock one-liner _ ``I'm a runner, I'm not a fighter'' _ that had Public Service Commissioner Leo Reinbold reeling. Omdahl pressed home his advantage, aiming for Reinbold's midriff. ``He comes from Hebron, you know, a city where there's no crime,'' he said. ``Not because the people are honest but there's nothing to steal. ``He was raised on a farm. His folks had hoped for corn,'' said Omdahl, now on a roll. Reinbold leapt back, conjuring up the childhood of a champion. ``Let's fast-forward from there to March 24, 1933, western Morton County, where Leo M. Reinbold was born, in a small log cabin, on a hillside, with a picture of Abraham Lincoln on the wall ...,'' Reinbold said. ``I'll never forget, I was about 10 years old, and I was looking around at my brothers and sisters, and they were short and I was tall. I had red hair and they had dark hair. I had freckles and they didn't. I started wondering about myself. ``I went into the house, and I talked to my mother, and I said, `Mom, was I adopted?' And she said, `Well, yes, but they brought you back.''' Reinbold's chest swelled as the crowd roared. At a banquet on the eve of a biennial summit conference of state officials opening Monday at the University of North Dakota, there wasn't a dry eye in the house. Secretary of State Jim Kusler, North Dakota's boxing commissioner, had introduced the combatants in a ring complete with three hemp ropes, bright red cushions and a water bucket in each corner. Montana inevitably came in for rough treatment. ``Do you know who discovered Montana? It was the Roto-Rooter man working out of Williston,'' Reinbold said, scoring heavily. ``Only 10 percent of Montana is habitable,'' came back Omdahl. ``The people live in the rest.'' Norwegians, a common immigrant group in North Dakota, weren't spared. ``Do you know what 1066, 1776 and 1918 have in common? They were adjoining rooms at the Oslo Hilton,'' Reinbold said. Omdahl, who is chairman of a specially appointed commission looking into ways to cut costs in state government, ridiculed his own work by offering some ``suggestions'' to shave expenses. ``The secretary of state has extra 1947 code books. Please use these before new ones will be printed. I want that one for the judges. I think they're using them anyway.'' he said. The state Supreme Court justices were split. Herbert Meschke, a former Democratic senator, voted for Reinbold, a Republican. H.F. ``Sparky'' Gierke, a former vice chairman of the state GOP, thought Omdahl, a Democrat, had edged it. Gerald VandeWalle had the final word. ``Lloyd, you said something about the judges still using 1947 law books,'' the justice said. ``That's because it's our considered opinion there hasn't been anything intelligent passed since then. ``I have to disqualify myself,'' VandeWalle concluded. ``They're both impossible.''

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Panel Questions Imprisonment of Alleged IRA Bombers
DOC.TEXT: Six Irishmen convicted of the worst terrorist bombing in modern British history deserve a new trial because police beat confessions out of them and new evidence has been ignored, witnesses told a congressional panel Monday. ``On rare occasions we raise questions of human rights concerns in democratic societies,'' said Rep. Thomas Lantos, D-Calif., chairman of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus, a bipartisan group of 200 members of Congress. ``Democratic societies occasionally go wrong,'' he said. The Irishmen, known as the ``Birmingham Six,'' were convicted of planting bombs in two pubs in Birmingham, England. The bombs went off without warning, minutes apart on Nov. 21, 1974, killing 21 people and injuring 162. The attack was the most deadly in a series of bombings, many linked to the Irish Republican Army, in England that year. ``In this case, justice has yet to be done,'' said Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy II, D-Mass., who called the hearing. Witnesses said Monday that the six Irishmen arrested the night of the bombings confessed under severe police beatings and intimidation. ``We are confronted here today with a human rights abuse,'' said Anthony Gifford, a member of the British House of Lords and an attorney for two of the defendants. Seamus Mallon, a member of the British House of Commons representing Ireland, told the caucus that the IRA, not the Birmingham Six, was responsible for the bombings. ``I believe it is in the interest of peace and the interest of stability to see that justice is done,'' Mallon said. The six _ Hugh Callaghan, Patrick Hill, Gerry Hunter, Richard McIlkenny, Billy Power and Johnny Walker _ are serving life sentences for murder. A 1988 court of appeals decision upheld the life sentences. But since then, the West Midlands Serious Crimes Squad was disbanded after several of its officers were charged with corruption and fabricating evidence in later cases, according to a congressional summary. Among those under investigation are five officers who were also involved in the Birmingham Six case. British Home Secretary David Waddington is considering new evidence in the case. The home secretary is responsible for the administration of prisons and law and order, among other things. Meanwhile, human rights groups including Amnesty International have called for another look at the case and more than 130 Members of Parliament advocated a re-opening of the investigation after one member said he had interviewed people claiming responsibility for the bombings. Francis Cornish, a spokesman for the British Embassy in Washington, questioned whether the hearing could accomplish anything because the government is already considering the case. ``We're in the middle of due process on this,'' Cornish said. ``We don't see what can come out of this hearing apart from pressure for us to continue the process.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Takeshita Discuss Trade Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with White House statement on meeting. No pickup. ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and former Japanese prime minister Noboru Takeshita agreed Monday that ``extraordinary efforts on both sides of the Pacific'' are needed to ease trade tensions, the White House said. Bush and Takeshita, who is in the United States on a private visit, met for about an hour to discuss trade and other thorny issues. Takeshita told Bush that Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu ``has become increasingly aware of the urgency of the problems facing the two nations,'' according to a statement by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Kaifu and Bush met earlier this month in Palm Springs, Calif. Although Takeshita no longer is in power, he still is viewed as influential in helping to shape policy in Japan as leader of the Liberal Democatic Party. Takeshita resigned as prime minister after criticism of his role in the Recruit stock and influence-peddling scandal. ``The two leaders discussed the public pressures'' in both countries and ``the necessity for leaders in both countries to re-invigorate the relationship,'' Fitzwater's statement said. Takeshita told Bush that Kaifu had named a team to coordinate Japan's side of talks with the United States on easing trade barriers, the statement said. ``Much of the (Bush-Takeshita) discussion concerned economic issues currently existing between the two countries and the fact that their solution will require extraordinary efforts on both sides of the Pacific,'' the statement said. Takeshita declined to speak with reporters as he left the White House. He was also meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, with whom he played golf Sunday. In a picture-taking session earlier, Bush and Takeshitatalked briefly about changes on the world political scene. ``Such fascinating changes in Europe and now in this hemisphere, wonderful,'' Bush told his guest as reporters were ushered into the Oval Office. ``In the case of Brazil, the new president is just 40 years old,'' Takeshita said, speaking in Japanese. ``I will be meeting a very young person.'' Takeshita will attend Thursday's inauguration of Fernando Collor de Mello in Brazil. Fitzwater said before the meeting that Bush would ``emphasize again that the United States needs and wants access to Japanese markets, that we have strong protectionist pressures in the Congress, and any help that the former prime minister can give us in relaying that message to the people and the government of Japan would be helpful.'' Bush has sent Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher to Tokyo for further talks on the trade disputes.

DOC.HEAD: Witness Says Third Mate Was at Fault For Exxon Valdez Grounding
DOC.TEXT: An expert witness testified Monday that the Exxon Valdez disaster would not have happened if skipper Joseph Hazelwood had been on the bridge, but insisted Hazelwood didn't cause the nation's worst oil spill. Former tanker captain Shiras Walker, testifying for the defense in Hazelwood's trial, said he believes the third mate, Gregory Cousins, was responsible for the March 24 grounding of the Exxon Valdez. Walker also said he believes Hazelwood's remarks immediately after the grounding were meaningless because ``he was coming apart mentally ... He was telling them what they wanted to hear.'' For that reason, Walker said, he discounted Hazelwood's remarks that he was trying to move the grounded tanker off jagged Bligh Reef. He said he believed the skipper actually was stabilizing the vessel so it would not float off the reef with the coming high tide. Walker said his opinions were based on experience commanding similar tankers, declaring, ``I walked several thousand miles in Capt. Hazelwood's shoes.'' Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., was the only crew member of the Exxon Valdez charged criminally in the wreck, which spilled nearly 11 million gallons of oil. He is accused of criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he faces a maximum penalty of 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. ``Isn't it true that if Capt. Hazelwood was on the bridge where he was supposed to be, this wouldn't have happened?'' Assistant District Attorney Mary Anne Henry asked during cross-examination. After the judge overruled a defense objection that the question called for speculation, Walker answered: ``I might disagree with that `supposed to be' part. But if Capt. Hazelwood was on the bridge during those maneuvers, this accident wouldn't have happened.'' Under redirect questioning from the defense, Walker was asked whether he believed Hazelwood's absence from the bridge contributed to the grounding of the vessel in any way. ``None at all,'' Walker answered. The former captain told jurors that the only regulation he knows of requiring a captain to be on the bridge is during a transit of the Panama Canal. Earlier, Walker testified that the third mate had failed to properly carry out orders left behind by Hazelwood. Walker said it was the third mate's responsibility to see to it that Hazelwood's orders were carried out by the helmsman, who failed to execute the 10-degree right turn called for. Walker was the first witness in the lengthy trial to directly point a finger at Third Mate Gregory Cousins, who was placed in control of the ship while Hazelwood went below to do paperwork. Most other witnesses have blamed the helmsman, Robert Kagan. Walker, testifying on cross-examination, acknowledged that he considers a helmsman ``just another piece of the machinery,'' and indicated the third mate should have kept close watch to make sure he obeyed orders. He said the only thing the helmsman needed to know to carry out his job was knowing the difference between right and left and the ability to read the numbers 1 through 35. Asked whether any able-bodied seaman should be able to carry out an order for a 10-degree right turn, the witness replied, ``Probably anybody above the age of 5 could have carried that out.'' ``So what you are saying is that if Greg Cousins had followed Capt. Hazelwood's instructions and watched the rudder angle indicator to make sure the rudder angle order was being obeyed, the Exxon Valdez would not have hit Bligh Reef?'' the prosecutor asked. ``Yes, ma'am,'' said Walker. ``And what you're saying is that because Greg Cousins did not follow Capt. Hazelwood's order, the grounding is Cousins' fault,'' Henry added. ``Yes, ma'am,'' responded Walker. ``And Capt. Hazelwood is not at fault at all?'' Henry asked. ``No, ma'am,'' said the witness.

DOC.HEAD: FAA Inspectors Not Trained to Stop Drinking Pilots, Congressman Says
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration said Monday it would upgrade the training of its inspectors to prevent crews from flying airliners under heavy alcohol influence. An inexperienced FAA inspector in Fargo, N.D., allowed a Northwest Airlines jet to take off last Thursday despite a tip that the crew had been drinking for more than six hours. FAA Administrator James Busey told the chairman of the House aviation subcommittee Monday ``he was going to get their (inspectors) training upgraded to deal with situations like that,'' said FAA spokesperson JoAnn Sloane. ``The system could fail again the same way,'' Rep. Jim Oberstar, D-Minn., said at a news conference after meeting with Busey. ``The FAA is going to act on this quickly or we're going to burn their behind.'' Sloane said she could not provide any details of how the inspector training would be improved. The three crew members on the flight from Fargo to Minneapolis were arrested upon landing last Thursday when blood tests showed excessive alcohol levels. The FAA revoked their licenses. The Fargo inspector didn't detain the crew members because they didn't smell of alcohol and didn't appear to be impaired, said Oberstar. The inspector interviewed the men and observed them for more than an hour while they prepared for departure, Oberstar said. The FAA had said that the Fargo inspector did not have the authority to stop the plane from taking off under North Dakota law and that the tip didn't consitute evidence of intoxication. However, Oberstar said Northwest or any other airline would have voluntarily grounded the flight had it been warned of the allegations. ``You don't want to throw the book at this FAA inspector at this point ... but there clearly ought to have been training at some point to deal with these circumstances,'' he said. The FAA said Sunday that it received an anonymous tip at least three hours before the Boeing 727 with 91 passengers left Fargo. The person making the call said the cockpit crew had been drinking. Northwest Airlines received a similar tip but could not match the names it was given with its crew list, Oberstar said. Flight 650 took off from Hector International Airport in Fargo at 6:25 a.m. local time after an unexplained 25-minute delay that Northwest said is part of the company's investigation. It arrived in Minneapolis at 7:30 a.m., and the crew was placed under citizen's arrest by an FAA inspector at the airport, detained by the airport police and given a blood-alcohol test. Busey announced Friday that the test showed all three had a blood alcohol level above .04 percent, exceeding the federal limit for flight crews. The three have the right to appeal their emergency license revocations within 10 days to the National Transportation Safety Board. The Minneapolis city attorney's office said charges might be brought this week under state law. Flying while intoxicated is a misdemeanor, carrying up to 90 days jail and a $700 fine. Airport police identified the crew members as Capt. Norman Prouse, 51, of Conyers, Ga.; first officer Robert J. Kirchner, 35, of Highland Ranch, Colo., and second officer Joseph W. Balzer, 34, of Antioch, Tenn. Attempts to reach Prouse have been unsuccessful, Kirchner has not returned phone calls and Balzer referred questions to attorneys for the Air Line Pilots Association.

DOC.HEAD: Warm Over East And Central, Snow In West
DOC.TEXT: Unseasonably warm weather broke out Monday from the northern Plains to the East Coast, with records broken or tied in 16 states and the District of Columbia, and snow was scattered over parts of the West. More than 50 cities broke or tied high temperature records for the date, and some had their highest temperatures for any day in the whole month of March. The high of 67 at La Crosse, Wis., broke a record that had been on the books since 1877. Most of the record highs were in the 60s and 70s but downtown Baltimore had an astonishing record high of 92, and Richmond, Va., and Augusta, Ga., reached 88. Record highs were set or tied in Delaware, Illinois, Indianapolis, Iowa, Kentucky, Maryland, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia, Wisconsin, and the District of Columbia. ``I can't believe the weather,'' said Mary Ann Karpovich, a Dushore, Pa., grocery clerk who licked a chocolate ice cream cone while sitting on a bench at the crowded Boardwalk at Atlantic City, N.J., which had a record 82. Elsewhere in New Jersey, golfers took advantage of Monday's weather by flocking to the Princeton Country Club, said park manager Pete Palmieri. The club's usual 80-90 golfers on a March day more than doubled Monday to 195, Palmieri said. Locally heavy snow fell during the morning in north-central Wyoming, including 2 inches of snow in one hour at Buffalo. Snowfall diminished Monday after falling across northern Arizona since Sunday morning, accumulating to 7 inches at Flagstaff, 4 inches at Walnut Canyon and 3 inches at the southern rim of the Grand Canyon. At midday, snow fell across northern Montana into west-central Montana, northern Wyoming, east-central Nevada and central Arizona. Rain extended across northern North Dakota, northern Minnesota, northwestern Wisconsin, eastern Upper Michigan, north-central New York state, and from east-central New York state across southern New England. Showers and thunderstorms reached from western Kentucky across western Tennessee and northern Mississippi, and from southwestern Louisiana across the northern and central Texas Gulf Coast into central Texas. Wind gusted to 41 mph during the morning at Moline, Ill., 48 mph at Chicago's O'Hare airport and 46 mph at Clayton, N.M. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 24 degrees at Cut Bank, Mont., to 92 at Cherry Point, N.C. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was zero at McCall, Idaho.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Colonel Pleads Guilty To Distributing Classified Documents
DOC.TEXT: A retired Air Force lieutenant colonel pleaded guilty Monday to a felony conspiracy charge that, as a Grumman Corp. employee, he unlawfully obtained and distributed classified Pentagon budget documents. As part of the plea bargain, Harry Kotellos agreed to cooperate fully with the government investigation into the illegal trafficking in classified Defense Department documents. Kotellos, 53, is a West Point graduate and retired Air Force lieutenant colonel who has worked for Grumman since 1980, said his attorney, Plato Cacheris. He faces a maximum penalty of $250,000 in fines and five years imprisonment when he is sentenced May 18 for his actions from 1980 through 1985. The documents involved were those that summarize the resources the Pentagon is planning to spend in future years, said Richard Smith, assistant special agent in charge of the Defense Criminal Investigative Service's Washington field office. The case also involved Air Force budget documents, according to court papers. ``Mr. Kotellos was a significant player in the tightly knit group which acquired and distributed some very sensitive DoD information,'' said Michael J. Costello, special agent in charge of the DCIS Washington field office. ``We have attempted to reach the inner core of the network and neutralize it.'' Investigators would not say whether Grumman itself was under investigation. But Grumman spokesman Larry Hamilton said: ``Grumman is engaged in discussions with the government as to the consequences to the company of Mr. Kotellos' plea. Since this matter continues to be under review, the company cannot comment on these discussions.'' The DCIS field office has been conducting an investigation _ code-named Operation Uncover_ since the mid-1980s into illegal transfers of Pentagon documents to defense contractors. Last Friday, Hughes Aircraft Co. became the fourth major defense contractor to plead guilty to unlawfully obtaining Defense Department budget documents, and agreed to pay a total of $3.67 million in fines and restitution. Previous companies to plead guilty are: _GTE Government Systems Division, which paid about $300,000 in fines in 1985. _The Boeing Company, which paid fines and restitution of $5.2 million last November. Boeing employee Richard Lee Fowler was convicted last December of all counts of a 39-count indictment. _RCA Corp., which was ordered Feb. 5 to pay fines and restitution of $2.75 million. Former RCA employee Leonard Kampf and current RCA employee Ronald Stevens each pleaded guilty to one felony count and face sentencing April 6. The plea agreement submitted Monday to U.S. District Judge Claude Hilton is contingent on Kotellos' cooperation in the probe. The conspiracy count says Kotellos acquired classified documents from a government employee who was not authorized to release them, getting classified documents from Fowler of Boeing, sharing classified documents with other defense contractors and obtaining such documents from them, and destroying some of the documents in his fireplace at home. The government employee was not identified in court papers, and Smith declined to reveal the name or to say whether that person was under investigation. The source close to the investigation said he believed prosecutors ``may have a problem with the statute of limitations'' in the case against the government employee because of a lack of information of wrongdoing after 1984. The court papers say Kotellos got documents from the government employee ``on approximately two occasions between 1980 and December 1984.'' Said Smith: ``In a continuing conspiracy, the last overt act that an individual or corporation does in furtherance of that conspiracy can continue the life of the statute of limitations.'' The 1985 actions enabled prosecutors to go after Kotellos, Smith said. Kotellos was placed on administrative leave with pay from his job as a senior marketing analyst at the Washington operations office on Monday morning, said Grumman spokesman Larry Hamilton.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest 31 in Demonstration Against Soviet Power
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police broke up a demonstration Monday in downtown Moscow to commemorate the Russian revolution that ended czarist rule, the Tass news agency said. Thirty-one people were reported arrested. The news agency said the Democratic Union, an unofficial political party, gathered several hundred people in Moscow's Mayakovsky Square to mark the 1917 spring revolution that Communist founder Vladimir I. Lenin in turn toppled later that year. Moscow authorities had refused to permit the demonstration in the center of the city and offered to let demonstrators rally near a stadium on the south side of the capital, Tass said. ``Slogans against the Communist Party and the Soviet state and social system were chanted by some people,'' the official news agency said. It said police restored order and arrested 31 people after the crowd ignored repeated calls to disperse. There was no information on injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Wins Labor Party Approval to End Coalition
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS four grafs for 14th `Peres indicated...' to UPDATE with one Labor leader giving Shamir another chance, talks with religious parties; pickup graf 15 pvs `A confidence....' ADDS graf with background on proposed settlement
DOC.TEXT: Shimon Peres won Labor Party approval Monday to bring down the government, after accusing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of leading Israel into ``the desert of indecision'' about peace talks with Palestinians. The decision by Labor, which is in a ``national unity'' coalition with Shamir's conservative Likud bloc, set the stage for a showdown. Peres leads the Labor Party and is vice premier. Reports said Shamir might dismiss Labor ministers from the Cabinet. If the government falls, elections would be likely. The last two elections were indecisive and tenuous Likud-Labor coalitions resulted. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater was asked whether the United States was concerned about Israel's failure to accept the peace proposals of Secretary of State James A. Baker III. He replied: ``Well, the process is still continuing. We're still talking and we're still hopeful. ... The process of peace talks is a long and arduous one.''
