Peres told the 1,300 members of the center-left Labor's Central Committee the prime minister was stalling by not responding to the Baker proposals. ``The thing is not moving, very simply,'' he said in a nationally broadcast speech to the Labor leadership. ``We have reached the conclusion that Shamir will try to run a policy of saying neither yes nor no. He will try to avoid the decision and will pull us into the desert of indecision.'' Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin, speaking after Peres, said: ``The problem, the delay, the obstacle in the peace process is Likud's refusal to vote on a positive answer. Our duty is to guarantee a perpetual progress, and we shall do it in any way possible.'' At the end of an 80-minute meeting, held at Beit Berl near Tel Aviv, the Labor leadership approved a vaguely worded, two-point resolution with only one member dissenting. It said Likud prevented a Cabinet vote ``on essential issues relating to the peace process'' and threatened continuation of diplomatic efforts. The resolution authorized the Labor leadership and the party's 39 members in the 120-seat parliament to ``determine the parliamentary moves necessitated by the situation.'' That gave Peres a mandate to try to bring down the government by putting his Labor Party in league with smaller leftist and religious parties that seek a confidence vote in Parliament. Chaim Ramon, head of Labor's parliament faction, offered Shamir a last-minute escape, saying: ``We shall treat the no-confidence motions in accordance with the prime minister's behavior in the issue of peace. I hope that until then the prime minister would use the opportunity provided by us and would say yes to the peace process.'' In his speech, Peres suggested he could work out a deal with the religious parties, a key element in any narrow government. Israel TV said Labor launched intensive contacts with two ultra-Orthodox parties immediately after the central committee vote. The negotiations with Agudat Israel and Torah flag parties are expected to last until early Tuesday, the television said. A confidence vote is expected Thursday unless a compromise is worked out to save the 15-month-old government. Zevulun Hammer of the National Religious Party, religious affairs minister, said earlier Monday he was trying to find common ground. After the Labor vote, he said: ``I believe that my effort still has a chance.'' Shortly before the Labor decision, however, Shamir aide Avi Pazner said little room was left for compromise. ``It looks like the two parties are going for a showdown Thursday,'' he said. ``It would take a miracle to reach a compromise before that.'' Cabinet member Ronnie Milo of Likud said the decision clearly meant Labor had decided to end the coalition. Labor ``is not thinking of the peace process,'' he said. ``They want to break the government to advance their party's and personal interests.'' ``If you decide you cannot be partners in such a government, stand up and resign. Don't try to stay in the government while attempting to bring it down.'' Shamir was said to be considering dismissal of all 10 Labor ministers so they could not be part of a transitional government that would take over if a no-confidence motion passed. The government crisis began last month when Labor demanded the Cabinet approve the Baker proposals, which had been under consideration since October. On Sunday, Shamir refused to allow the decision-making Inner Cabinet to vote on the plan, which involves arranging preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in Cairo. The Inner Cabinet is made up of six Labor and six Likud ministers. Labor ministers walked out of the meeting on grounds the failure to vote meant a negative response. Labor supports the Baker proposals, but Likud says the provision for including residents of Arab east Jerusalem in the talks could threaten Israel's declared sovereignty over the area. Likud also opposes participation by exiled Palestinians on grounds that could provide an opening to the talks for the Palestine Liberation Organization, which Israel views as a terrorist organization. Hammer has suggested Israel give Baker a positive answer, with the question of participation by east Jerusalem Arabs to be decided by Parliament. The Israel-Palestinian talks are meant to lead to eventual elections in the Israeli-occupied territories, with their final status decided later.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Protest Handling of KGB Defector
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union lodged a ``strong protest'' with the United States on Monday over the handling of Victor I. Sheymov, a KGB defector who surfaced after nearly a decade in the United States. Sergey B. Chetverikov, minister-counselor at the Soviet Embassy, accused U.S. intelligence agencies of ``subversive action'' for smuggling Sheymov, his wife and 5-year-old daughter out of the Soviet Union in 1980. The family's exit from the Soviet Union was a ``gross violation of rules of international law, which is, in fact, an act of state terrorism,'' Chetverikov told reporters at a news conference. Chetverikov said he met with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger on Monday to complain about the Sheymov affair. Chetverikov said he was particularly concerned about allegations Sheymov made as a time of a thaw in relations between the two superpowers. ``The Soviet Embassy lodged a strong protest with the State Department,'' he said. The State Department had no immediate comment. Chetverikov confirmed that Sheymov was employed by the KGB, but the embassy official said he worked as a ``coding equipment maintenance technician.'' As such, Sheymov had ``no access to serious secret information, including documents,'' the embassy official said. Sheymov, 43, appeared at a press conference March 2, making a series of allegations. Among other things, he said that in the late 1970s the Soviet Union had two sources inside the State Department who were able to deliver secret information on U.S. policy and negotiating positions. The department refused any comment on that case at the time. Sheymov also said he was present in the Warsaw station of the KGB in 1979 when a cable arrived from Moscow ordering what he believed to be the initial stages of a plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II. The Soviet Embassy denied Sheymov's claim about the pope. ``Totally untenable and malicious from beginning to end is his assertion about the committee for state security's involvement in the affair relating to the attempt on Pope John Paul II's life,'' Chetverikov said. He said the CIA leadership knew ``very well that the KGB had not and could not have anything to do with this heinous crime.'' Allegations have long circulated about possible Soviet involvement in a plot to kill the pope after the pope was wounded by a gunman's bullet in 1981. No connection with Moscow has ever been firmly established, however. Chetverikov also said ``hints about the KGB's involvement in organizing the attempt on the late President Zia ul Haq of Pakistan can also be described as wild fiction.'' Zia was killed when a plane blew up in Pakistan in 1988. Chetverikov claimed that the CIA had put statements in Sheymov's mouth as a ``hostile action.'' Forces inside the United States, the Soviet official said, were bent on disrupting growing ties between Moscow and Washington. Sheymov has said he is looking for a publisher for his book. Despite the protest, Chetverikov said he doubted Moscow would retaliate in any way against the United States. ``I guess we are beyond that stage,'' he said. At the same time, he said Sheymov's actions had a ``very negative effect'' on perceptions in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: World Hails Lithuania Declaration of Independence _ with Caution
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Governments from Australia to Italy on Monday cheered Lithuania's declaration of independence from Soviet rule, but congratulations came mixed with caution. The Bush administration expressed support for Lithuania's move, while saying the United States will delay formal recognition of the breakaway republic until the Lithuanians are ``in control of their own destiny.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater reiterated the administration's call for the Soviet central government to ``respect the will of the citizens'' in the Baltic state. The newly elected non-Communist legislature of Lithuania on Sunday voted to declare its independence 50 years after the Soviet Union annexed the sovereign state of Lithuania on the basis of an agreement with Nazi Germany. The United States and other Western nations never recognized the Soviet Union's forcible annexation of Lithuania in 1940 and its Baltic neighbors Latvia and Estonia while under Red Army occupation. The three states, once part of czarist Russia, had gained independence after World War I. Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave said in London on Monday that Britain is ``fascinated'' by Lithuania's action, but has no immediate plans to recognize Lithuania as a country separate from the Soviet Union. ``The legal right of the Lithuanian people to seek self-determination is not in question. But when it comes to the recognition of states ... we haven't quite got to that point yet. We may well do so,'' Waldegrave said in a British Broadcasting Corp. radio interview. Waldegrave said ``a considerable negotiation'' with the Soviet Union would have to take place before Lithuanians ``know the full extent of the implications of what they are seeking.'' Fitzwater, too, remarked at a news briefing that Washington was not recognizing the new government at once ``because we would want any recognition to take into account a final government that was in control of their own destiny, and much of that has yet to be negotiated with the Soviet Union.'' Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called Lithuania's move ``alarming'' when he opened a congress of Communist Party deputies Monday in Moscow, but gave no indication he plans any action to prevent Lithuania from seceding. The Solidarity-led government in Poland expressed hope Monday that neighboring Lithuania would be able to achieve statehood in a peaceful way. ``The Polish government supports nations' self-determination, including self-determination leading to separate statehood,'' government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said in a statement on the nightly news. Earlier Monday, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa expressed his joy at the decision in a message sent to Vytautas Lansbergis, Lithuania's new president, adding that he hoped the process of separation would be peaceful. Historical links between Lithuania and Poland date to 1386, when the Lithuanian ruler Jagiello married a Polish princess. The Jagiellonian dynasty ruled until 1569, when the two nations joined in a commonwealth that lasted until Russia took over in 1795. Members of the Lithuanian community in the Polish town of Punsk, which lies near the border, put up Lithuanian and Polish flags after watching the independence declaration on television, the state news agency PAP reported. In his message, Walesa raised the issue of the fate of 260,000 Poles living in Lithuania who now are seeking greater access to their cultural heritage long denied under the republic's previous Communist leaders. Italy expressed hope that Soviet and Lithuanian authorities would be able to peacefully iron out their differences over the republic. ``The Italian government, which has never recognized the annexation of Lithuania by the Soviet Union, salutes the declaration of independence,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Giovanni Castellaneta said in a statement. Australia welcomed the Lithuanian declaration and urged Moscow to accept it without confrontation. Foreign Minister Gareth Evans said in a statement, ``The Australian government acknowledges the resolution of the freely elected Parliament of Lithuania declaring it to be an independent state. ``We welcome any development that lends reality to the Lithuanian independence which we already legally recognize.''

DOC.HEAD: Boat People Fight Each Other Again
DOC.TEXT: Twenty Vietnamese refugees in a detention center battled each other Tuesday, injuring two in the latest outbreak of violence in the crowded camps, authorities said. Police said they quickly restored order. No further details were available. Such fights have often broken out among Vietnamese boat people in Hong Kong's detention camps the past few months. Homemade weapons, including knives and iron bars, have been used. About 55,000 Vietnamese boat people now live in this British colony's squalid camps. Hong Kong considers most as illegal immigrants subject to deportation back to Vietnam, but Hanoi so far has accepted mandatory repatriation of only about 50 Vietnamese. Refugees fleeing political persecution are allowed to resettle elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: 69 People Killed, 14 Villages Destroyed in Tribal Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Arab nomads and tribal farmers clashed in western Sudan in the latest outbreak of an ancient feud, killing 69 people and burning down 14 villages, the official news agency reported Monday. The fighting between the Arabs and the Fur, a Moslem non-Arab farming tribe, took place last week at the Shattaya villages of Wadi Salih in the Darfour region, the Sudan News Agency said, without giving a specific cause for the latest unrest. It said the governor of Darfour, Maj. Gen. Abul-Gasim Ibrahim, toured the area to try to reconcile the two sides. Reporting from el-Fasher, the capital of Darfour, the agency said the governor has ordered weapons collected from the fighters. It said he also appealed to both sides to abide by a July reconciliation agreement. The accord stipulated that each tribe pay the other compensation for losses in previous clashes. Western relief workers say the age-old clashes escalated last year. They say 2,000 to 3,000 people were killed in the Darfour clashes. Every winter for hundreds of years, cattle-herding Baggara and other smaller nomadic tribes have interloped on Fur farms as they trekked toward water and grazing lands to the south. They fought brief battles, with limited deaths. Differences were resolved in traditional peace councils after the fighting. Blood money was paid for victims and compensation for destroyed farms.

DOC.HEAD: Pacts Inked in Bulgaria Ensure Equal Terms for All in Elections
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communists, the democratic opposition and other political groups signed political agreements Monday that ensure equal terms for all parties competing in June elections. The agreements also require that until the elections, all draft legislation must be first agreed at the current all-party talks before going to the Communist-dominated parliament for adoption, the state media reported. Bulgaria radio said a third agreement guarantees peaceful transition to a democratic system. The accords were adopted at negotiations that resumed Monday after having been suspended a month over disagreements on reform. The negotiators also agreed that international observers from the United States, the Soviet Union and other European countries should be invited to attend the June elections, the state BTA news agency reported. Zhelyu Zhelev, chairman of the Union of Democratic Forces, a loose coalition of 19 opposition groups, called Monday's signings a historic act, BTA said. The agreements outlined the basic aspects seen as crucial to a democratic political system, including a freely elected parliament, a multiparty system, equality of different forms of ownership and basic human rights, BTA said. Major draft legislation toward holding free elections is to be discussed at the negotiations and brought to Parliament at its next session. The negotiation parties will meet again Thursday. Zhelev reportedly credited the opposition's recent mass rallies for getting the agreements wrapped up. Communist Party chief Alexander Lilov, who for the first time headed the Communist delegation to the talks on Monday, stressed the importance of the accords for Bulgaria's political future and called for mutual respect and responsibility of all parties concerned, the radio reported. In a conciliatory gesture, Petko Simeonov, a senior official of the Union of Democratic Forces and director of the new UDF newspaper Demokratsiya, spoke of ``a victory of democratic forces, irrespective of the side of the table on which they are sitting,'' the radio reported. The Union of Democratic Forces suspended the talks Feb. 12. They complained that the Communists refused to agree to abolishing Communist Party organizations at the work place and to other points now agreed. The Communists have promised to withdraw from the work place. The agreements came after a weekend conference of opposition parties in Plovdiv, where four small, non-aligned democratic parties joined the UDF, the strongest opposition grouping. Parties of a small non-Communist coalition called the Political Opposition Bloc still refuse to join the UDF, as does the Alternative Socialist Party, a reformist group that split from the Communist Party last month.

DOC.HEAD: Comoros Island Elect President to Succeed Slain Leader
DOC.TEXT: Said Mohamed Djohar captured the presidency of this Indian Ocean republic in an election to replace his slain predecessor, final results showed Monday. However, his opponent in Sunday's runoff charged fraud and immediately challenged the outcome. The elections became necessary when President Ahmed Abdallah Abderrahmane was assassinated Nov. 26. French mercenary Bob Denard took control of the island, but he yielded to popular protests and arriving French troops by giving up power the following month. Denard, widely blamed for killing the president, has denied the accusation. Djohar said Saturday he hopes South Africa, which has granted Denard temporary refuge, will extradite him to face a trial for the slaying. No extradition treaty exists between the countries. The National Election Commission said Monday that Djohar, who was serving as interim president of the Comoro Republic, won a seven-year term with 55 percent of the vote. His opponent, Mohamed Taki, gained 45 percent. Final results gave Djohar 102,882 votes, compared with 83,250 for Taki. However, Taki claimed he was deprived of 30,000 votes by fraud at 15 polling stations. The complaints must be considered by this nation's Supreme Court. Taki, leader of the Comoran Union for Democracy, won the most votes in last week's first-round elections with 24 percent of the ballots cast. Djohar gained 23 percent. The remaining six opposition candidates had split their support between Djohar and Taki for the runoff. Taki declared less than four hours after polls opened Sunday that he would demand the results be scrapped. He said his supporters were harassed and their ballots confiscated. Beatings, incomplete voter rolls and missing ballots forced Djohar to annul the original first round of elections on Feb. 14. Voting officials said about 40 percent of the 300,000 eligible voters abstained Sunday. After independence from France in 1975, Abdallah led the islands until Denard ousted him later that year. However, Denard backed Abdallah's return to power three years later in this archipelago between Mozambique and Madagascar. The Frenchman in concert with other European mercenaries commanded the Presidential Guard, giving him effective control of the republic. The South African government said it hopes to be rid of Denard as soon as it can find a country willing to take him. In addition to any prosecution in the Comoros, the mercenary faces criminal charges in France for a failed 1977 coup in the West African country Benin. The islands' main industries are fishing and tourism, which is controlled mostly by South African interests. The average annual income for the mostly Moslem population is less than $300.

DOC.HEAD: Estonians Demand Deadline for Ending Soviet Occupation
With AM-Soviet-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A congress of ethnic Estonians on Monday demanded an ``exact deadline for ending the occupation and illegal annexation of the republic of Estonia'' as the first step toward restoring its independence. The parliament of another Soviet Baltic republic, Lithuania, declared its independence from the Soviet Union on Sunday. Estonia has no need to do that because this land of 1.6 million residents is already an independent, though occupied country, said Tunne Kelam, a leader of the movement to create the congress. Trivimi Velliste, a founder of the citizens' movement, declared, ``We want Moscow now to recognize the expression of the will of the Estonian people. Our main aim is to establish our legal position of an occupied country.'' Estonians are using different tactics from the Lithuanians to restore the statehood both enjoyed between the world wars because only 60 percent of its population is ethnic Estonian. The rest are largely Russians who have migrated to the area since it was forcibly annexed in 1940, and many of them prefer to remain part of the Soviet Union. Lithuania is still 80 percent Lithuanian and support there for independence is overwhelming. Estonian activists registered 700,000 ethnic Estonians, who last month elected 465 representatives to the new congress which convened over the weekend. Activists say this organization is the true legislature, not the Supreme Soviet parliament that will be elected Sunday by all the Soviet citizens of Estonia. The two-day session that ended Monday demanded that Moscow withdraw all Soviet troops and immediately cease KGB activity in Estonia. The group also wants Soviet military bases abolished. Velliste said the Soviet Union has 150,000 soldiers in Estonia, or about one of every 10 people. He said more are coming here as they are withdrawn from Eastern Europe. ``Some of them are situated only 50 kilometers (31 miles) east of Tallinn and forced to camp out in tents for lack of space,'' he said. Velliste said his group would be willing to negotiate on troop withdrawal. A declaration that described all state authorities of the Estonian Soviet Socialist Republic as ``only administrative organs for the occupation'' was read out to tumultuous applause. However, the congress voted to restore good neighborly relations with the Soviet Union ``on the basis of mutually beneficial cooperation and respect for each other's rights.'' Velliste said Estonians do not fear the consequences. He asked, ``What else can they do to us? We have experienced everything. We have experienced mass deportations and killings in the Stalinist regime.'' Congress delegates elected a 78-member council to conduct talks with Moscow and foreign nations for recognition of complete independence. ``The congress has the sole legitimate power now in Estonia. The Supreme Soviet will have no official position,'' said Kelam, who is expected to be elected council chairman. However, delegates said the new 105-member Supreme Soviet parliament to be elected next Sunday would play a role in cooperating with the council in the transition period. ``After we get guarantees from Moscow about the withdrawal of troops, we will hold parliamentary elections, and form the first democratically elected government of an independent Estonia,'' Velliste said in an interview. ``We shall have that government by the end of 1991, maybe even sooner.'' Volunteers guarded the congress entrance after a break-in at congress headquarters and purported attempts by members of the largely Russian group Interfront to sabotage the meeting. Forty-three non-voting members at the congress represented 35,000 non-Estonians who said they want to be citizens of independent Estonia when the new government is established.

DOC.HEAD: Researcher: Celibate Lifestyle Was One Reason For Seeking Clergy Volunteers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to fix spelling of Katharine. SUBS 18th graf, Mahony said...,' to restore first reference to Henderson.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-AIDS Vaccine
DOC.TEXT: The vow of celibacy taken by Roman Catholic priests and nuns was one reason they were sought as potential subjects for an experimental AIDS vaccine developed by Dr. Jonas Salk, a researcher said Monday. The researcher, Katharine Munson, also said it was Archbishop Roger Mahony's idea to suggest an age of 65 or older in a Jan. 25 letter to 3,500 priests and nuns telling them that volunteers were needed. Mahony, however, denied Sunday that anyone suggested to him that Catholic clergy were being sought because of their celibate lives. ``You're really looking for people who have a commitment to humankind and willingness to take risks to benefit others,'' he said. Munson, clinical director of the study at the University of Southern California's Norris Cancer Institute, said the program was in no special need of candidates and has already been contacted by hundreds of people. Salk works at the La Jolla, Calif., institute that bears his name, but the AIDS research is to be done at the Norris clinic. On Monday, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved expanded testing of the vaccine outside California. Reached at his home Monday, Salk declined to comment on the study. ``If I start giving interviews, there will be no end to it,'' said the 75-year-old physician, who in the 1950s created the first polio vaccine pronounced safe and effective. Munson said the vaccine, Salk HIV Immunogen, is being administered to 90 volunteers who have already tested positive for the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. In the next phase of testing, 10 volunteers without the virus will be given the vaccine. Munson said she didn't know whether any of those being interviewed were Roman Catholic clergy. The prototype Salk vaccine is the only one among several being developed from the whole AIDS virus. Critics say that if live strains of the virus contaminate the vaccine, volunteers could be accidentally infected. Researchers are trying to find out whether the inactivated virus used in the vaccine will cause the body to produce specific cells, called T cells, that destroy other cells infected with the virus. Munson said priests and nuns were sought as volunteers because ``in groups of people who have taken a vow of celibacy, there are likely to be fewer people who get involved in sexual activity,'' one of the ways AIDS is transmitted. In this way, researchers could be certain that if the test subjects developed the disease, it would have been caused by a faulty vaccine, she said. Munson agreed the appeal was also to ``priests and nuns who live an altruistic lifestyle, and help AIDS patients.'' ``It wasn't our decision to ask for people who are 65,'' said Munson. ``The archbishop put that in the letter. If it (the vaccine) is ineffective, someone might want to be older rather than young. ``The age is not our standard. Each person, young or old, will be screened,'' she said. Mahony said Dr. Brian E. Henderson, director of Norris, told him at their last meeting a few weeks ago that about six nuns had contacted the doctor as well as one or two priests. The study is being conducted under a California law that permits such experiments without FDA approval, as long as all the materials are made in California. Munson said the second phase of the test, injecting people who have tested negative for the virus, awaits state approval. Salk said he will inject himself with the drug when testing is approved. Volunteer candidates had been calling regularly at the rate of five to 15 a day, Munson said, adding that more calls were coming following the publicity the program received over the weekend. While Roman Catholic officials insisted there was nothing more to Mahony's letter than passing on information on behalf of Henderson, some medical ethicists wondered whether church politics was behind the move. ``The Roman Catholic church has come under a lot of criticism from the AIDS community, who have called it an obstacle to education, an obstacle to the distribution of contraceptives,'' said Arthur Caplan, a medical ethicist at the University of Minnesota. ``To see the church participating in a vaccine trial carries with it a political as well as an ethical message,'' he said. ``There are many dangerous diseases for which there are such programs. I don't think it's an accident that this letter went out about AIDS.''

DOC.HEAD: Floor Collapses at Landmark NYC Hotel; One Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with cause of collapse, next-door florist evacuated; picks up penultimate graf, `The Ansonia ...'
DOC.TEXT: A concrete ceiling collapsed onto a food shop Monday at the landmark Ansonia Hotel, killing a woman and injuring 12 others, authorities said. The collapse in the Croissant & Co. shop on the ground floor of the Upper West Side hotel on Broadway between 73rd and 74th streets occurred about 3:50 p.m. The ceiling had been perforated with holes for pipes installed by various tenants over the years, said Buildings Commissioner Charles Smith said. A suspended ceiling had been added and the combined weight apparently caused the collapse, he said. ``It's an old ceiling _ decorative molding, heavy plaster with metal leaves holding it all together. It just gave way,'' Smith said. ``We were drinking coffee. All of a sudden water started rushing above and the ceiling collapsed,'' according to one young woman who was interviewed outside. ``We felt the vibration. We thought the building was falling. First it was like a vibration, then glass breaking _ and then a big boom,'' said Elvin Rodriguez, a clerk at a nearby bookstore. When he went outside, Rodriguez said, a street vendor had already run and started pulling people out. Fire Department spokesman John Mulligan said the collapsed area measured 250 square feet and weighed about 2 tons. The woman who was killed was dressed in street clothes and apparently was not an employee, he said. As it collapsed, the ceiling dragged the sprinkler system down with it, prompting initial reports that a water leak above the shop apparently weakened the ceiling and sent it crashing onto the patrons in the shop. Eleven people were taken to hospitals, and one person declined medical aid, authorities said. Three of those taken to hospitals suffered head injuries. Construction was taking place on the second floor of the 17-story building when the collapse occurred, said Efrain Parrilla, a Fire Department spokesman. Fire crews later began tearing down the ceiling to make it safe for searchers. Dogs also were being used to search debris. A flower shop next door, the Rose Boutique, which has a similar ceiling, was ordered closed and evacuated as a precaution. The Ansonia is one of New York's architectural gems, according to the American Institute of Architects' New York guidebook. The heavily ornamented residential building was built in 1904 and was a residence hotel for Enrico Caruso, Arturo Toscanini, Lily Pons, Florenz Ziegfeld, Theodore Dreiser, Sol Hurok, Igor Stravinsky and Babe Ruth, among other celebrities. Arts figures favored the hotel because it was well soundproofed, although unintentionally. It also was featured in such movies as ``Three Days of the Condor'' and ``The Sunshine Boys.''

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Approves King Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Wyoming's Legislature approved a bill honoring slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. with a holiday after debating the issue for seven years. The Senate voted 21-9 to concur with House changes to the proposal, calling the holiday Martin Luther King Jr.-Wyoming Equality Day and celebrating it on the third Monday in January. If Gov. Mike Sullivan approves the legislation, Wyoming will become the 46th state along with the federal government to observe the holiday. Wyoming observed the federal holiday for the first time on Jan. 15, King's actual birthday. King's birthday became the 10th national holiday in 1986, eight years after he was assassinated in Memphis, Tenn. The four states that do not recognize the federal holiday are Arizona, Montana, Idaho and New Hampshire. The Legislature dropped Columbus Day, celebrated on the second Monday in October, from Wyoming's list of legal paid holidays. The House had added the amendment to prevent the state from having to pay more to state employees who got the day off.

DOC.HEAD: Chile's New President Steering Clear of Post-Repression Trials
DOC.TEXT: New President Patricio Aylwin pledged respect for human rights Monday in a speech to a huge gathering celebrating the rebirth of democracy in Chile, but indicated he will avoid holding trials for past abuses. Singing, flag-waving, sometimes weeping Chileans packed the 82,000-seat National Stadium, five miles southeast of downtown Santiago, to hear Aylwin _ a site that long served as a dark symbol of bloody political repression. Aylwin, a 71-year-old centrist Christian Democrat, became president Sunday, ending 16{ years of authoritarian rule by right-wing Gen. Augusto Pinochet. On seizing power in a violent 1973 coup, Pinochet launched a harsh anti-leftist campaign. Thousands of suspected dissidents were rounded up and brought to National Stadium where, human rights groups say, many were tortured and some were executed. Aylwin appeared on Monday to rule out vigorous prosecution and punishment of military officers for abuses committed during Pinochet's rule. He remarked at Monday's evening rally that ``in sorrowful days of blind and hateful predominance of force over reason, it (the stadium) was a place of confinement and torture for many compatriots.'' ``From this place ... we say to all Chileans and the world that is watching us: Never again. Never again violations of human dignity.'' Aylwin promised to ``clarify the truth about the disappearances of people, the horrendous crimes and other grave human rights violations that occurred during the dictatorship.'' But he called for ``tempering the virtue of justice with the virtue of prudence'' and said, ``A time for forgiveness'' would come. Chile, he said, must avoid ``becoming engulged indefinitely in inquiries, recriminations and witch-hunts.'' The issue is seen as one of the most politically sensitive to be faced by Aylwin's administration. Pinochet, 74, keeps command of the 60,000-member army and has said he will not permit the new government to prosecute military officers for past offenses. Rights organizations and leftist groups, many of which supported Aylwin's candidacy, are pressing for the trial and punishment of offenders. According to rights groups, at least 700 people disappeared during Pinochet's rule. They say thousands more were illegally imprisoned, and many of them were tortured. Aylwin appealed on Monday for patience, saying ``there will be difficulties because of obstacles and binds left behind for us by the former regime.'' Pinochet enacted last-minute laws and decrees trimming Aylwin's powers and granting the military virtual autonomy. The new government plans to eliminate or modify many of the laws, but acknowledges this will slow down its efforts to address social needs. A roar of applause greeted Aylwin as he entered the stadium wearing the red, white and blue presidential sash and accompanied by his wife, Leonor. He sat down among visiting heads of state and watched an emotionally charged folk ceremony. Relatives of people who disappeared during military rule staged a funeral dance and then marched across an open, brightly lighted soccer field in folk costumes. They held up poster-sized photographs of the victims, whose names scrolled down the electronic scoreboard. Many had last been seen in the stadium. Many people wept openly in the stands.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0668 to include pronouncer
Pascal-Trouillot Set Precedent for Women as Lawyer, Judge
With AM-Haiti, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Designated president is pronounced Earth-ah Pahs'kal True'-yoh
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, the first and only woman on Haiti's 12-member Supreme Court and on the verge of becoming Haiti's next president, has set precedents for women throughout a brilliant legal career. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, 46, will be inaugurated Tuesday morning as the first female to lead this troubled Caribbean nation since independence from France in 1804. She previously was the first woman named to the executive committee of the Haiti's Bar Association and the Appeals Court, and has campaigned for equal rights for females. After serving as an appellate judge for two years, Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot was appointed to the Supreme Court after the fall of dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier in February 1986 and has maintained a reputation for political independence. Francois Latourte, a former justice minister, said he ``highly recommended'' her to the Supreme Court after studying her record. ``She was a distinguished and competent judge, a remarkable woman,'' said Latourte. ``I did not hesitate to recommend her as the first woman justice.'' She is the author of several books about law. Her best-known work, ``The Judicial Status of Haitian Women in Social Legislation,'' was written in 1973, two years after graduation from law school. She is a member of the Association of French-Language Writers. In the 1970s, she campaigned for equal rights at a time when Haitian women were considered ``legal minors,'' a system under which a married woman could not have a bank account and could not buy property without her husband's written approval. The law has since been changed. ``She has had a meteoric career,'' said Ernst Malbranche, former president of the Haitian Bar Association. She is the widow of Ernst Trouillot, a distinguished lawyer who presided over the Port-au-Prince Bar Association until his death in 1989. The couple had one daughter. The horror of the harsh Duvalier family rule touched Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot in the late 1960s. Her brother, jazz guitarist Alix Pascal, was shot in the back in Port-au-Prince during a rehearsal. The assailant was a Tonton Macoute, the feared secret police of Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, Jean-Claude's father and predecessor. Left paralyzed, he now lives in New York City. When opposition parties nominated Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot Monday to become provisional president, she took the news in stride. ``She was shocked but she expected it. We had told her,'' said Jean-Claude Roy, a leading member of the Unity Assembly opposition coalition. With the departure Monday to a Florida exile of military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril, reaction to the appointment of a woman to replace him was favorable. ``The men in Haiti have messed up the country so much, we can only expect her to do better,'' said Pierre Louis Gaillard, 48, an unemployed mechanic.

DOC.HEAD: President Dissolves Parliament, Parties Prepare for Elections
DOC.TEXT: President Christos Sartzetakis dissolved Parliament on Monday, and Greece's political parties prepared for their third battle after two inconclusive elections since June. A presidential decree posted next to Parliament's entrance disbanded the 300-member legislature and scheduled elections for April 8. The conservative New Democracy party, with 148 seats in the last Parliament, is aiming for a majority in the elections. The socialists, with 128 seats, and the Communists, with 21, appear determined to prevent this. Three seats went to independents in November. Premier Xenophon Zolotas will lead a caretaker government until the elections. He was appointed by the conservative, socialist and Communist parties to head an all-party government after Nov. 5 elections. But on Feb. 12, that government broke up, citing policy differences. Zolotas had a mandate to tackle pressing economic problems. He was expected to take drastic action in tackling a $12-billion public-sector deficit. His government succeeded in cutting spending by about $6 billion but did not raise revenues. In June elections, New Democracy beat former Premier Andreas Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement, which had been in power eight years. New Democracy formed a coalition with the Communists and indicted Papandreou and several other senior socialists on corruption charges. No trial dates were set, and a strong showing by the socialists in November resulted in New Democracy again falling just short of a parliamentary majority. Recent opinion polls do not show any significant swing in party strengths, but New Democracy leader Constantine Mitsotakis says he will no longer cooperate with other parties. ``You can't wage a battle with three field marshals,'' he told a campaign rally on Lesbos island Sunday. However, the Communist-led Coalition of the Left and Progress, reeling after the revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe, has indicated it would form an alliance with the socialists. The Communists hinted last weekend they may field joint candidates with the socialists in the five single-seat constituencies that are traditionally the key to parliamentary power. Given present party strengths, though, a socialist-Communist alliance would hold only a slight parliamentary majority. Such a government would have trouble making unpopular decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Urged To Aid South African Blacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS throughout for clarity on references to Namibia and South Africa.
DOC.TEXT: Prominent black Americans urged Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Monday to provide up to $25 million in U.S. aid to a leading anti-apartheid group in South Africa. The idea is to help the African National Congress begin planning a new political structure for the country, Randall Robinson, executive director of Transafrica, said. He cited as precedents U.S. assistance to the Polish labor movement Solidarity and to the Nicarguan coalition headed by Violeta Chamorro before they took control of their countries. Robinson said Baker's response at a 45-minute State Department meeting was non-commital. At the same time, the Transafrica official said, Baker disagreed with ``some sharpness'' to a request to end U.S. support for Unita insurgents in Angola. The black group had asked Baker to recognize the Angolan government, now that more than half the Cuban troops have departed. Robinson said supporting Unita, headed by Jonas Savimbi, puts the United States in league with South Africa. The black visitors and Baker found themselves in accord on several other issues. For instance, Robinson said, the Bush administration will not ease economic sanctions against South Africa and it will work with the Soviet Union and other nations to try to help the hungry in Ethiopia. Unless channels for delivering food are opened quickly some 3{ million Ethiopians could starve, Robinson said. The black group proposed that President Bush ask Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cooperate in seeking a cease-fire in the African country between the Marxist government and separatist Eritrean rebels. Robinson said Israel should be asked to stop arming the government and Arab countries to stop aiding the rebels. Baker agreed to propose the plan to President Bush, Robinson said. The delegation included the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Mrs. Coretta Scott King, former Mayor Richard Hatcher of Gary, Ind., and Joseph Lowery, head of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Baker leaves Sunday to attend indepndence ceremonies in Namibia, a former South African colony. He may also meet with leaders of the South African government and black opposition groups. Robinson called the $500,000 in U.S. aid for Namibia this year ``paltry'' and suggested $15 million. Baker did not commit himself, Robinson said. For next year, the Bush administration has proposed $7.8 million for Namibia.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Expects Trial of Chilean Officers in U.S. Killing
With AM-Chile
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward Kennedy said Monday he expects the new democratic government to allow prosecution of two military officers for the 1976 bomb-slaying of a prominent Chilean dissident in Washington. The Massachusetts Democrat sponsored a 14-year-old congressional ban on military weapons sales to Chile. It can only be lifted when the 1976 assassination of Orlando Letelier is cleared up. ``I believe the overwhelming majority of the members of the Senate _ of both parties, the Republican and Democratic _ want those involved in government-sponsored terrorism brought to justice, whether here in Chile or the United States,'' Kennedy told a news conference. ``There is every expectation they will.'' Since arriving Saturday, Kennedy has met with many top officials in the new government of President Patricio Aylwin. The elected civilian took power Sunday to end 16{ years of right-wing military rule by Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Kennedy said it does not matter whether army Gen. Manuel Contreras and army Col. Pedro Espinoza, both formerly top officials in Pinochet's secret police, are tried in Chile or the United States. Contreras and Espinoza were among several former secret police implicated in the killing of Letelier. He died along with an American assistant when a remote-control bomb blew up his car as it rounded Dupont Circle on Washington's Embassy Row on Sept. 21, 1976. Chilean jurists and human rights officials say they consider it extremely unlikely Contreras or Espinoza will ever face trial in a U.S. court, despite indictments in Washington. The Chilean Supreme Court rejected a U.S. request for their extradition in 1979. Letelier was a U.S. ambassador and held several cabinet posts in the leftist government of elected President Salvador Allende, who was toppled by Pinochet in a 1973 coup.

DOC.HEAD: Fulbright Bust Placed at Kennedy Center
LaserPhoto WX25
DOC.TEXT: A bronze bust of former Sen. J. William Fulbright, D-Ark., was presented to the Kennedy Center on Monday to commemorate his little-publicized role in the creation of the national performing arts center on the banks of the Potomac River. Fulbright, 84, was accompanied by his bride of two days, the former Hariet Mayor, to a small ceremony in an Opera House lounge. ``As ugly as I am, I think it's wonderful,'' he said of the bust by sculptor Gretta Bader of Stanford, Calif. Fulbright recalled that he accompanied the Soviet ambassador to a performance of the Bolshoi Ballet in a local movie theater in 1957. The theater was such a bad locale, he said, that he introduced legislation the next day authorizing a national cultural center in Washington. After Congress approved the bill in 1958, Kennedy Center officials said, Fulbright ``provided extraordinary energy and leadership'' during a turbulent period when questions of financial support, construction site, architectural design and administration of the center were debated. Roger L. Stevens, founding chairman of the Kennedy Center who celebrated his 80th birthday Monday, said Fulbright's role had never been fully recognized. ``If it had not been for people like him, we would never have succeeded in making the Kennedy Center a reality,'' he said. Fulbright said the center represents the ``extremely important'' role that the arts play in ``humanizing our society.'' The center, which opened in 1971, is the only official national memorial to John F. Kennedy, who was assassinated in 1963. Among the reception guests were J. Carter Brown, director of the National Gallery of Art; Katharine Graham, chairman of The Washington Post Co.; James H. Billington, librarian of Congress, and Kennedy Center chairman Ralph Davidson. A partner in the Washington law firm of Hogan & Hartson, Fulbright is a former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and was a vocal opponent of U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War. His primary defeat in 1974 ended Fulbright's 30-year Senate career. Last Saturday in his Washington home, Fulbright married Hariet Mayor, 56, a longtime assistant and former executive director of the Fulbright Association of Fulbright Scholars alumni. Fulbright's first wife, Betty, died in 1985. His bride is a widow with three children and one grandson. The Fulbright bust was commissioned by the former senator's law firm and is on permanent loan to the Kennedy Center from the National Portrait Gallery. It will be displayed outside the box tier of the center's Opera House.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Asks Consideration of Completely Computerized Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version is running on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators should think about moving stock trading off exchange floors to computer screens, a report to Congress said Monday. The regulators said they weren't convinced. The General Accounting Office, the auditing and investigative agency of Congress, said the Securities and Exchange Commission should consider a proposal to repeal a New York Stock Exchange rule requiring trades of most listed stocks to be executed on the exchange floor. A rule that forbids after-hours trading of listed stocks, which tends to push after-hours trading to foreign exchanges, also should be reviewed, the report said. Trading rules were eased in 1979 to permit off-floor trading of newly listed stocks. But, a decade later, most stocks still were initially listed before 1979. Trades of 89 of the New York Stock Exchange's 100 most active shares still must be routed through the exchange floor. The GAO, noting the rapid evolution of computer and communications technology, said it is time for the commission to reconsider rules banning most off-floor trading. The commission disagreed, saying its 1979 study of off-floor trading was complex and that it would not dismantle the floor system until market participants determine a new system would be better than the old. On the New York Stock Exchange, the nation's principal exchange, brokers bring orders to a specific spot on the floor designated for trading in the stock they are buying or selling. There they must deal by ``open outcry'' with other floor brokers, if there are any. If there are none others, the broker seeking to trade may deal with a ``specialist,'' another broker charged by the exchange with standing ready to buy or sell at all times. Critics contend that the use of trading floors and specialists restricts price competition. Supporters of the current system, however, argue that a central location for trading preserves the benefits of an auction market. In trading by computer, a broker lists bids or offerings on a screen for others to accept or reject, changing prices as he or she sees fit. The SEC agreed that a review of after-hours trading was in order even though, in 1986, the commission rejected a recommendation from its staff that the agency ask the New York Stock Exchange to consider it. ``As a result ... exchange member brokers and dealers who wish to trade exchange-listed stocks when U.S. markets are closed must do so in foreign markets,'' the GAO said. The report, dated Monday, was delivered to the Senate Banking Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Is Told Western Europe Under Pressure to Cut Defense
DOC.TEXT: Western European governments are under pressure from public opinion to cut their military forces drastically, Dutch Defense Minister Aurelus ter Beek told Defense Secretary Richard Cheney Monday. ``All ministers of defense have to take the heat in this way,'' he told reporters later. ``All ministers of defense do feel pressures from public opinion on them to achieve drastic cuts.'' Ter Beek belongs to the Labor Party in the Netherlands, which like other Social Democratic groups traditionally puts less emphasis on defense than do conservative parties. He warned Cheney against too long a delay in calling a second conference on reductions in forces after the one now going on in Vienna. ``Some or several countries might be tempted or even forced to lead the way,'' he said. He noted that the U.S. government is hoping for an agreement in general terms by June. He himself would like to see a formal treaty in the second half of the year. Ter Beek said that the parties in his own coalition government have agreed to find about $1.5 billion in reductions of military spending in the next five years. He said a paper on the country's defense in the 1990s will be issued at the end of the year. He went on to say that he prefers to make cuts in the present framework of 23 governments, including the United States. ``European countries will of course be interested in the best way the American commitment to the defense of Europe can be symbolized ... after a partial withdrawal of American troops,'' he said. He said other countries have accepted the ``two plus four'' formula under which the two Germanys will negotiate unification, followed by talks with the four main victors of World War II: the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. But he called for close consultations on other subjects, such as the number of Soviet troops who will remain in eastern Europe, the value of the Warsaw Pact after free elections in its member countries, the future of foreign troops in West Germany including the present Dutch brigade, the future strategy of the alliance and the role of nuclear weapopns in it. The stationing of troops should be a decision of the North Atlantic alliance, he said. Ter Beek's message on consultations was similar to the one brought to Washington last week by Italian Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti.

DOC.HEAD: Record Warmth, Fog And Thunderstorms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with higher vehicle total in Wisconsin crash, Illinois flooding, picks up 13th graf pvs, `Heavy thunderstorms ...'
DOC.TEXT: Record warm weather surging northward caused dense fog Monday in which 52 vehicles crashed on a Wisconsin bridge, and runoff from violent weekend thunderstorms caused flooding on the southern Plains. Temperatures rose into the 60s as far north as North Dakota, and Washington, D.C., posted a high of 87, the warmest on record for any day in March. The early warmth threatened to make Washington's cherry trees bloom too early for the annual Cherry Blossom Festival, scheduled to begin April 1. In the West, northern Utah cleaned up after the heaviest snow of the season. Following a spring-like Saturday with temperatures near 60, a storm dumped 10 inches of snow on the Salt Lake Valley on Sunday, with about a foot of snow on ski resorts. ``Historically, March is a change-of-seasons month, so you have a wide variety of weather,'' said Dewey Jobe, meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Bismarck, N.D., which expected highs in the 60s in the southeast and snow during the night in the northwest. A teen-ager drowned after he fell into a raging creek in Texas, a canoeist was missing on a swollen river in Wisconsin, and three people were killed in the 52-vehicle pileup in Wisconsin. The unsettled weather on the southern Plains kept the space shuttle Atlantis grounded at Fort Bliss, Texas, delaying its piggyback flight back to Florida atop a Boeing 747, NASA officials said Monday. The twinned craft landed Sunday for refueling. Dense fog caused by the warm air flowing over snow and frozen ground was reported from North Dakota into Michigan, reducing visibility to zero in places and delaying planes at airports. Visibility was ``just about down to zero'' at the time of the accident on a bridge at Green Bay, Wis., said Police Lt. Roy Johnson. In addition to the dead, hospital officials said 30 people were treated. ``The catalyst was a three-car accident. How that happened I don't know. From there it was a chain-reaction. It just piled up,'' Deputy Chief of Traffic Robert Kreuser said. ``In my 28 years of service with the Green Bay police department, this is the worst I've ever seen.'' Elsewhere in Wisconsin, flooding was caused by a combination of rain and rapidly melting snow, and frozen ground that prevented water from soaking in. Fire department officials in the village of Plover, near Stevens Point, had to sandbag some homes Sunday to prevent flooding, and some roads remained under water Monday, said village Clerk Emma Jane Lee. Up to 2{ inches of rain plus snowmelt also flooded homes in several areas of Minnesota, including Minneapolis. Basement walls collapsed in some homes. Cars were abandoned on Interstate 94 in Minneapolis after they stalled in standing water, according to the State Patrol. In Maple Grove, Minn., a canoeist was reported helping rescue motorists stranded by high water. Authorities in the eastern Illinois city of Danville worked to restore water service to some 55,000 customers after it was halted by flooding that began Saturday. Schools and most restaurants remained closed. Bismark, Alvin and north Danville areas along the North Fork River had the most severe flooding, officials said. About 200 people had been forced from their homes and remained out Monday. Heavy thunderstorms battered parts of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas and caused flooding Sunday and Monday. Flooding continued in parts of central and northeastern Oklahoma, closing some highways, and at least a half-dozen schools called off classes, officials say. Gilford Hopkins, assistant fire chief in Skiatook, Okla., said that water from Bird Creek was ``up in and around'' about 60 homes and 10 businesses. A police dispatcher in Guthrie said water got into about a dozen businesses. In Bartlesville, about a dozen people sought shelter Sunday when water creeped up to their homes. In Arkansas, the Ouachita River pushed past 39 feet early Monday and stopped rising just in time to spare Camden from significant property damage and evacuations, officials said. Four families were evacuated. ``It was close for some of the houses. Some lacked six inches, 10 inches of getting water in their homes,'' said Niolan Spain of office of emergency services. In southwestern Fort Worth, Texas, which received about 2 inches of rain, several dozen residents were evacuated because a drainage creek overflowed. Cars were fender-deep in water and mattresses floated in flooded bedrooms at some residences. ``It happened so fast, you didn't have time to do anything,'' said Manuel Martinez, whose home was flooded. Fort Worth Meacham Airport recorded 4.55 inches of rain Sunday and sections of Cooke County recorded 4 inches.

DOC.HEAD: Key Witness in Brooklyn Racial Attack Charged With Murder
DOC.TEXT: A key prosecution witness in a racial attack that claimed the life of a black teen-ager was charged with second-degree murder Monday after refusing to cooperate with prosecutors. John Vento, who disappeared for three months but later resurfaced, was charged after he said he would not testify against friends charged with the slaying last August in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Seven other young white men from Bensonhurst have been charged in the shooting of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins. Brooklyn District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said Vento, 21, was arrested in his office and ordered held for arraignment. A spokesman for Hynes, Patrick Clark, said a grand jury would investigate the charges against Vento. Vento's lawyer, Gerald DiChiara, said Vento ``has reasons I could not argue against. ... He is very concerned for everything _ his family, himself.'' DiChiara declined to elaborate. Hynes said he still has a ``trial ready'' case without Vento. But a prosecutor who spoke on condition of anonymity called Vento's defection ``a major blow.'' ``He (Vento) was in the middle of the group, and he was going to testify,'' the prosecutor told The Associated Press. Vento, who acknowledged he was present during the attack, initially agreed to testify before a grand jury and at trial in exchange for a pledge he would not be charged in the attack. He disappeared late last year and surrendered last week to federal authorities in Dayton, Ohio. His absence forced a monthlong delay in the start of the first trials. Following Vento's arrest, Hynes said he was still willing to honor the agreement and gave Vento until Monday to say whether he would abide by the deal. Earlier in the day, Brooklyn state Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens refused to set bail for Joseph Fama, the youth accused of doing the actual shooting. He said the case would go to trial next month as scheduled. Hawkins was killed Aug. 23 when a mob of some 30 young whites _ many armed with baseball bats _ attacked him and three black friends when they went to the mainly white Bensonhurst neighborhood to look at a car that was for sale.

DOC.HEAD: Christie's Reverses Policy on Auction Guarantees
DOC.TEXT: Christie's changed a longstanding policy Monday, and guaranteed a minimum price to the sellers of Vincent van Gogh's ``Self Portrait'' and four other paintings being auctioned on May 15. The auction house said the paintings by Van Gogh, Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Amedeo Modigliani and Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec have been given a presale estimate of $40 million to $60 million, with Van Gogh's work valued at between $20 million and $30 million. The heirs of financier and art collector Robert Lehman, who are offering the paintings for sale, will be guaranteed a minimum price regardless of the bids offered, the auction house said. The minimum was not disclosed. ``The firm's concern about the possible negative impact of guaranteed sales on the art market is well-known,'' the auction house said in a statement. ``However, Christie's is aware of the guarantee's appeal to certain client segments.'' Christie's managing director, Christopher Davidge, said that during the past year ``we have in certain cases found it difficult to compete (for art sellers' business) without offering guarantees.'' ``Thus, Christie's has in this case decided to guarantee,'' he said. Davidge would not say how often Christie's planned to offer guarantees to other sellers. Christie's has long criticized rival auction house Sotheby's for making guarantees, saying the practice can artificially inflate the art market. Guarantees, particularly when they are not announced, can also give an auction house a conflict of interest.

DOC.BYLINE: Tapes of Conversations Between Brothers and Therapist ^By MICHAEL FLEEMAN
DOC.TEXT: Two brothers charged with killing their millionaire parents delayed entering pleas Monday to give their lawyers time to review the seizure of evidence from the brothers' psychologist. Attorneys for Erik and Lyle Menendez said they wanted to determine if tape recordings seized from Jerome Oziel were inadmissible in court in what appears to be a key issue developing in the case. ``The concern is that, it is my understanding, that when you talk to a therapist, that that's privileged _ as if you were talking to a lawyer _ and that privilege might be breached,'' said defense attorney Gerald Chaleff. The tapes of conversations between Oziel and the brothers were seized last Thursday, the day police arrested Lyle, 22, and launched an international search for Erik, 19, a tennis pro who surrendered over the weekend. District Attorney Ira Reiner called the tapes ``key evidence'' in the Aug. 20, 1989, shotgun slayings of Hollywood executive Jose Menendez, 45, and Mary Louise ``Kitty'' Menendez, 44. Reiner alleged that money was the motive in the killings. The brothers, who reported finding their parent's bodies in their Beverly Hills mansion, stood to inherit the $14 million estate of Jose Menendez, a successful executive of Live Entertainment Inc., a Los Angeles-based video distribution company. Defense attorneys said they wanted to read the search warrant affidavit that authorities filed before they searched Oziel's office. The affidavit, which may indicate what is on the tapes, were ordered sealed by the judge to everyone except attorneys in the case. State law allows a psychologists' patient records to be used as evidence if there is a threat of continued violence, and Deputy District Attorney Elliot Alhadeff said Oziel was threatened. Alhadeff would not elaborate and Oziel declined to return a phone message to his Beverly Hills office. Chaleff said he had no information of a threat against the psychologist or anyone else. The Menendez brothers' arraignment was rescheduled for March 26, when they will enter pleas and Municipal Court Judge Judith O. Stein will decide whether to release the affidavit. Attorneys and the prosecutor discussed the affidavit and other matters behind closed doors Monday for more than an hour before the brothers appeared in court. The brothers listened to Stein read the charges against them: two counts of murder with special circumstance allegations that could make them eligible for the death penalty if they are convicted. When asked if they understood the charges, the brothers each answered, ``Yes, your honor.'' Sitting in the courtroom were Maria Llanio, the mother of victim Jose Menendez, and Jose's sister, Teresita Baralt and her husband Carlos. The Baralts are executors of the Menendez estate. Family members declined to comment, but defense attorney Robert Shapiro said, ``Family members are united in support of both these boys.'' Reiner, in a news conference prior to the brothers' court appearance, insisted that the taped conversations were not the only evidence his office had in the case. He said there was other ``physical evidence,'' which he would not identify.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Gives Assurances on Transition, Quayle Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS graf 7: ``Two hours,'' to note Ascencion demonstration
DOC.TEXT: Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega promised Vice President Dan Quayle Monday he will peacefully relinquish power April 25, Quayle said. Ortega, confirming the commitment, said he told Quayle the best way to ensure a peaceful transfer of power was that ``the Contras cease to exist by April 25,'' and that Quayle assured him the United States would ``seek ways of supporting the idea.'' Aides to the vice president said Ortega was referring to an expected U.S. aid package that would, among other things, provide funds for resettling the rebel fighters. Ortega also assured the vice president that all cabinet ministers, including the defense minister and interior minister in charge of the Sandinista-dominated army and police, will be appointed by Violeta Chamorro, the U.S.-backed candidate who beat Ortega in the Feb. 25 election, Quayle said. Ortega sought out Quayle at a 1{-hour lunch hosted by newly inaugurated Chilean President Patricio Aylwin in the presidential palace after arranging in two brief earlier chats to talk further. Later in the day, Quayle flew to Asuncion for an 18-hour visit, the first in 32 years by a high-ranking U.S. official to Paraguay, a dictatorship until 1989. Quayle was met by an honor guard and President Gen. Andres Rodriguez under a giant red-and-white banner of welcome. Two hours after Quayle's arrival, members of a half-dozen leftist groups gathered on a downtown street to wave anti-Quayle signs and listen to speeches denouncing imperlialism. Police watched but did not intervene. Before leaving Santiago, Quayle told reporters his talk with Ortega had been ``cordial and productive'' ``He guaranteed me two things,'' Quayle said. ``One, on April 25 he will turn over his presidency to Violetta Chamorro. Two, he guaranteed to me that Violetta Chamorro will appoint all ministers, including the defense minister and the interior minister.'' Ortega also asked that the Bush administration immediately lift the economic sanctions imposed by the United States during his Sandinista regime, said other officials who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Quayle assured him the administration already was actively considering the same request made by Mrs. Chamorro, the officials said. Meanwhile, administration sources in Washington said Bush will ask Congress for a quick $300 million to support Chamorro. Sources declining to be named publicly said that Bush is expected to announce the request as early as Tuesday. The proposal would include some $30 million to help relocate the Contra rebels into their homeland, they said. Quayle's aides said that while Ortega has said repeatedly the Contras must be disbanded before power is to be transferred, he did not make that a condition to his Monday promise of peaceful transition. Quayle himself did not answer a question on whether Ortega imposed any conditions, but his aides later repeated what they said before, that Ortega had not. Ortega himself, encountering reporters in his hotel, said, ``I commited to him that the process of transfer of power was going to take place with the utmost normality. The best thing for that purpose would be that the Contras cease to exist by April 25.'' Quayle said Ortega told him, ``I want to make the transfer in Nicaragua more peaceful than the transfer in Chile,'' where a civilian government was inaugurated over the weekend to bring a 16-year military dictatorship to a peaceful end. Officials traveling with Quayle said the vice president brought up possible use of United Nations' peacekeeping troops to help prevent outbreaks of fighting between the Contra rebels and Sandinista loyqlists. Ortega indicated that would be fine ``if they are willing to take the risk,'' the aides said. They quoted Quayle as replying, ``We better take a risk for peace.'' The luncheon conversation took place after Ortega walked up and asked Costa Rican President Oscar Arias, who was seated next to Quayle, to trade places with him. Ortega later characterized the discussion as ``frank, friendly and constructive.'' He had previously made a strong point of insisting that the Contras be demobilized at once. The U.S position also favors disbanding the rebel army, but the Bush administration has insisted the rebels be given security guarantees before they lay down their arms. The occasion of the inauguration set the stage for an unprecedented faceoff _ Quayle holding official talks with the Sandinista leader the United States had shunned for a decade. Their meeting in Moneda, the official presidential palace, came as a new wave of diplomacy on Nicaragua picked up steam. Several heads of state used the inauguration to discuss how to bring a peaceful transition of power following the election Ortega lost to Mrs. Chamorro. Arias joined Ortega in announcing that a meeting of Central American presidents will be held at the end of the month to discuss ways to bring about a smooth and peaceful transition in Managua. Quayle and Ortega were joined in a 10-minute session by Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez. Perez told Quayle _ in Ortega's presence _ that Ortega had assured him he would hand over power to Mrs. Chamorro even if the Contra issue is not resolved, said a Quayle aide. The assistant briefed reporters on the condition that he not be publicly identified. This aide, however, also quoted Quayle telling Ortega: ``You can't make unilateral emobilization of the Contras a precondition for the transfer of power.'' The aide said the vice president also complained about Sandinista helicopter attacks on Contras observing a cease-fire. After first chatting at Mass, Quayle and Ortega met at a lunch hosted by Aylwin. It was the first such high-level official U.S. discussion with the Nicaraguan leftist. Arias said that Quayle concurred when Arias suggested the Contras should receive no U.S. money to repatriate until they lay down their arms. ``What I said to him was, `Unless the Contras disarm, they shouldn't get any money for their repatriation. That's a good carrot for them,''' Arias told reporters as he left a hotel where he met the vice presidents. ``He agreed with me,'' Arias said of Quayle. But Quayle's chief of staff, Bill Kristol, later said Quayle agreed only that there should be incentives for the Contras to disband _ not that they should disarm or lose repatriation money. The incentives, Kristol said, will be in the Nicaraguan aid package the administration is scheduled to announce later this week. And the chief of staff said Quayle insisted there be security guarantees for the Contras. The United States has avoided high level contacts with Ortega, holding that his government should negotiate with the Contras directly rather than with the United States. At the Venezuelan inauguration last year, Quayle stayed away from Ortega. When President Bush and Ortega were together in a multi-lateral session at last October's celebration of Costa Rican democracy, Bush also avoided any substantive talk with the Nicaraguan. He referred to him later as a ``little man'' who was trying to sidle up for a photo opportunity with the American president.

DOC.HEAD: L.A. Raiders Heading Back to Oakland?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The separate ...,' with 4 grafs to ADD that NFL approval also required, but league not expected to object, background; picks up 6th graf, `The Raiders' ... City, county votes may not take place until after 3 a.m. EST, and may be postponed. A longer version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Raiders owner Al Davis said Monday he wants to bring the National Football League team back to the city he abandoned eight years ago. Davis, breaking a long silence on the issue, called local officials to lend his support to Oakland's offer. The proposal, which guarantees Davis' Raiders $602 million over 15 years, now needs only the approval of the City Council and Alameda County supervisors. ``He's ready, and we're ready,'' said Mayor Lionel Wilson. ``This is an eventful day in history for this city.'' The separate votes were scheduled for Monday night following a hearing, but the possibility that testimony would be lengthy threatened to force a vote postponement. If Davis, the Raiders' managing general partner, had said no Monday or failed to call by a noon deadline, the deal would have been off. The NFL formally requires approval by three-fourths of team owners of any move, as well as written notification by Jan. 15 of the year of the proposed relocation. But in practice, the league poses no further obstacles if the city and county approve the offer. Davis moved the Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles without permission, and won his case in court, and Robert Irsay moved the Colts without approval from Baltimore to Indianapolis in 1984. NFL owners did approve the 1988 transfer of the Cardinals franchise from St. Louis to Phoenix. The Raiders' lease with the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum runs through the 1991 season, but it's possible Davis could seek a settlement enabling him to return to Oakland sooner. Officials in Los Angeles worked through the weekend to put together a counteroffer, but were pessimistic about their chances. ``It looks like we're going to lose the Raiders,'' said Ed Snider, lead negotiator for the Los Angeles Coliseum's private managers. ``It's a damn shame. I haven't given up, but I fear we're a day late and a dollar short.'' Oakland's offer includes a loan package totaling $121 million to the team. It proposes $53.5 million to renovate the Oakland Coliseum and the rest a ``loan'' Davis does not have to repay. Davis also would be guaranteed ticket revenues of at least $29 million a year for the life of the 15-year lease. He would receive the basic $30 ticket price from at least 57,000 seats, with the city and county taking the premium payments above that for certain categories of seats. He also would keep all television, which currently is $32 million a year. For the city and county to make money, the team must average 90 percent of capacity in a renovated Coliseum that will hold 63,500. About 37,000 seats will cost more than the $30 base ticket price; many require fans to pay $2,000 to $16,000 up front. In light of those requirements, many local officials question whether there are enough sports fan dollars in the Bay area to support another pro team. ``This deal is a gamble not worth getting into,'' said city councilman Wilson Riles Jr. ``The risks are just too high.'' If the Raiders return, they must compete with three championship professional teams _ the Oakland Athletics, San Francisco 49ers and San Francisco Giants _ and a fourth, the Warriors, that routinely sells out.

DOC.HEAD: Man Who Posed As Job-Seeker Was Actually Long-Time Radio Host
DOC.TEXT: A local radio station's program director admitted Monday his tale of hiring an unemployed draftsman who advertised his job search on a Boston billboard was a hoax. Ron Valeri, programming director for radio station WAAF, said he and others at the station lied repeatedly in a bid to outdo their local radio competitor, radio station WBCN. But Valeri said the publicity stunt, which ran on The Associated Press wire and garnered national attention, ran amok. ``We did definitely lose control. ... This thing got away from us,'' he said. Valeri and his new employee, Bill Whiteman, told interviewers from various local and national news organizations that the disc jockey was hired because of his eye-catching plea on a Boston billboard: ``Help! I Need A Job!'' The billboard ad did go up, but Valeri admitted Monday that he knew of Whiteman's prior experience as a broadcaster at radio station WRCK in Utica, N.Y., ``a couple of weeks'' before he discussed the hiring with reporters. ``Initially WAAF set up a publicity stunt in an attempt to bamboozle its competitor. We were successful in doing that,'' Valeri said. ``What we didn't count on at the time was that local media would jump on the story simultaneously.'' Calls to radio station WBCN, the local competition against which the WAAF stunt was aimed, went unanswered Monday evening.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Throw Sticks 'n Stones at Police in Anti-Tax Melee
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 7th graf `Several policemen' to UPDATE with 45 arrested. Picks up 8th, `Inside the...'
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators threw sticks and stones at police during a protest Monday night at a London borough hall over Britain's new tax, officials said. Several people were injured, including some officers, and 45 were arrested, police said. Protests have been occurring around Britain over the new tax, which will fund locally controlled spending. The uproar over the tax has contributed to a slide in the popularity of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative government. Three hundred police, some on horseback, confronted about 1,500 protesters in the northeast London borough of Islington Monday as the area council met to set the local tax rate. Police said 20 or 30 people started to snake through the crowd and push demonstrators into police lines. ``Then sticks and stones were thrown at the mounted police as (police) reinforcements went into the crowd,'' said an unidentified senior officer. ``The majority of the crowd were engaged in noisy but peaceful protest,'' said police Commander David Stevens. ``But a minority were taking part in violent protest.'' Several policemen and demonstrators were injured, authorities said. They said they arrested 45. Inside the hall, council leader Margaret Hodge told the meeting local retirees had been afraid to come express their views for fear of violence. It was a sad day for democracy, she said. Her speech, relayed outside, was continually interrupted by about 50 people in the hall's public gallery. They threw toilet paper and paper airplanes into the chamber. The new tax takes effect April 1 in England and Wales. The new per-capita levy replaces a household tax called ``the rates.'' The government calls the new tax the ``community charge.'' But the socialist opposition Labor Party and other critics have dubbed it the ``poll tax'' after a per-capita tax that set off a peasants' revolt in 1381. The government pushed through the new tax with a mind to embarrassing Labor-controlled local councils by making them more accountable for their spending. However, the move has backfired. With opposition to the tax riding high, the Conservative Party is trailing Labor by up to 19 points in opinion polls. The next general election is due by mid-1992.
