Low-income and disabled people can get rebates of up to 80 percent on the next tax. But critics say the new tax is unfair because it otherwise takes no account of an individual's ability to pay. The new tax is already in force in Scotland, with widespread protest there. Northern Ireland, a British province, has a separate system of local funding.

DOC.HEAD: Deposed Ruler Leaves Haiti, Judge Chosen First Woman President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 18th graf, `The army's ... ADDING details of how opposition prevailed. Picks up 19th, `Austin refused ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAP1,2,4
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Deposed ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril flew to Florida in exile Monday and the army caved in to civilian opposition demands that he be replaced with the first woman president in Haiti's troubled history. In a ceremony at army headquarters carried on Haitian state television, opposition leaders gave the Army High Command a letter nominating Supreme Court Justice Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, 46, as provisional president. Maj. Gen. Herard Abraham, the army chief of staff to whom Avril handed control after resigning Saturday, said he hoped to turn over power by Tuesday ``so that the people can have a government of their choice.'' ``I am very happy that the Haitian people with their army were able to achieve this,'' said Abraham, who appeared on a second-floor balcony of army headquarters with opposition leaders. He did not mention Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot by name, but clearly indicated the army accepted her nomination to lead Haiti, the Western Hemisphere's poorest country. Wild cheers broke out from the crowd, which chanted ``Liberty! Liberty!'' Excluding Avril and Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who assumed power when dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier fled to France four years ago, Haiti has had 38 presidents, nearly all military, since 1804. Haiti, the first slave nation to become independent, has also had two emperors, one king and a governor-general. The army wielded such political clout that the Duvalier dynasty created the dread secret police, the Tonton Macoutes, to offbalance the regular army. Until now, no civilian opposition has taken control of the government without the military playing a major role. Unity Assembly, the opposition coalition that put forward Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, announced on radio she would be inaugurated at the Palace of Justice at 10 a.m. Tuesday. The coalition also said a general strike it called for Monday before Avril left this impoverished Caribbean country of 5.1 million residents would end at midnight. The provisional government is to prepare Haiti, which shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic, for national elections. Avril and his family arrived aboard a U.S. C-141 transport plane at Homestead Air Force Base, 25 miles south of Miami, at 8:20 a.m. and left at 3:30 p.m. _ destination unknown. A U.S. government official speaking on condition of anonymity said Avril left Florida. Avril's departure followed a week of political turmoil that left at least 24 people dead. His military government ruled Haiti _ often harshly _ for 18 months. Thousands of people milled about this capital city of 1 million, which had been deserted before Avril's departure because of the violence. Youths danced to meringue music featuring revolutionary themes such as ``The General's Gone'' and ``Uproot the Killers.'' The mood of the city, however, appeared to be one of disbelief _ not jubilation. Radio stations reported instances of youths building flaming barricades and pillaging a government food warehouse, but the incidents were far from the bloody clashes of the previous seven days. On Monday, the Unity Assembly, an opposition coalition instrumental in Avril's downfall, submitted its choice of Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot _ the only woman on the 12-member Supreme Court _ to the Army High Command. Unity members said Abraham agreed to accept whoever they chose. The interim president is to govern along with a 19-member advisory council until elections are held, possibly in three to six months. The army's first choice had been Supreme Court Chief Justice Gilbert Austin, an Avril appointee, but the Unity Assembly rejected him, saying he was too closely tied to the deposed regime. Opposition leaders stood firm in three days of intense negotiations with the army and threatened further disruptions and strikes unless their choice for the presidency prevailed. Finally the army agreed to accept Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot. Austin was out of the picture, as was anyone else deemed to be too closely associated with Avril. Austin refused the presidency, his wife said in a radio interview. ``The people and the parties didn't want him, so to not block the country, he decided not to accept,'' she said. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the Bush administration was ``hopeful for a smooth transition to democracy in Haiti. ... We are encouraging that effort.'' He refused to say whether the United States will grant Avril asylum. Fitzwater said the Bush administration ``had discussions with Avril about the transition. ... (There) was a feeling of some obligation to help him leave and facilitate a peaceful transition.'' Sylvio Claude, a prominent Haitian politician, said it was too early to predict whether army hard-liners would resist the transfer of power to a civilian-led government. ``Last night, there were lots of threats,'' he said, referring to fears by opposition leaders that soldiers might hunt them down. Haiti has been led mostly by military governments since independence from France 186 years ago, including Avril and Namphy, who assumed power when dictator ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier fled in February 1986. The army wielded such political clout that the Duvalier dynasty created the dread secret police, the Tonton Macoutes, as a paramilitary force. When Duvalier fled into exile in France four years ago, ending the 29-year dynasty begun by his father, the late Francois ``Papa Doc,'' hopes rose for democracy, but the military held onto power. Avril took over in a September 1988 soldiers' revolt against Namphy. Under Namphy, the nation's first free general elections were aborted when thugs, protected by soldiers, killed at least 34 voters. Namphy organized army-run, fraudulent elections in January 1988 in which university professor Leslie Manigat was declared the winner. Namphy ousted Manigat five months later, before suffering the same fate that September.

DOC.HEAD: Society of Professional Journalists Marks Terry Anderson's Abduction
With AM-Anderson Hometown
DOC.TEXT: The Society of Professional Journalists on Monday condemned the captivity of journalist Terry Anderson as physical and mental torture on the eve of the fifth anniversary of his kidnapping in Lebanon. ``Journalists are outraged by Terry Anderson's continued captivity,'' Carolyn S. Carlson, president of the journalists' group, said in a statement. Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was taken hostage in Beirut on March 16, 1985. He has been held captive longer than any other Westerner in Lebanon. The group's statement noted that the anniversary ironically falls on Friday, national Freedom of Information day. ``Reporters for U.S. publications and broadcast outlets have been injured, killed or kidnapped while trying to gather information about international affairs so that their readers and their audiences can understand better what goes on outside our boundaries,'' said Ms. Carlson, an Associated Press newswoman in Atlanta. ``That such an endeavor is so dangerous should remind us all how lucky we are to have a system of government that secures the existence of a free press.''

DOC.HEAD: Aid Request Imminent, Bush Administration Sources Say
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 2nd graf to raise higher plans for follow-up request
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will ask Congress for a quick $300 million to support the newly elected government of Nicaraguan opposition leader Violeta Chamorro, administration sources said Monday. The president was said to be planning a request for a similar but smaller amount as a follow-up next year.
DOC.HEAD: Bush is, 2nd graf
Sniping Kills One, Wounds Three in Beirut
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces traded sniper fire Monday in Christian east Beirut, killing a soldier and wounding three people, police said. They said troops of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun and militiamen of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces also fired occasional rocket-propelled grenades into each other's positions in east Beirut's districts of Ashrafiyeh and Badaro. The army man was killed in the Aoun-controlled National Museum district near Beirut's Green Line, dividing the city into Christian and Moslem sectors, according to police. They said the other casualties, including a Lebanese Forces militiaman and a child, were wounded by .50-caliber heavy machine-gun fire from Aoun positions in Sin el-Fil. That raised to 755 killed and 2,097 wounded the overall toll from the fighting that broke out Jan. 30 for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Monday's skirmishes further strained a 9-day-old cease-fire.

DOC.HEAD: Harry Helmsley Hospitalized After Fall
DOC.TEXT: Real estate magnate Harry Helmsley, the husband of Leona Helmsley, fell down a flight of stairs and was hospitalized Monday, a hospital official said. ``I understand that he fell but he is in good condition,'' said Amy Weinstein, administrator at New York University-Cornell Medical Center. WNYW-TV first reported Monday night that Helmsley fell down a flight of stairs in his apartment at the Park Lane Hotel. The accident, which occurred at about 1:30 p.m., happened as he was exercising with his physical therapist. Helmsley, 81, was deemed incompetent to stand trial in federal court on charges of income tax evasion. His wife, Leona, was convicted on charges of conspiracy, tax evasion and fraud. She was ordered to pay $7.5 million in fines and to serve four years in prison. Mrs. Helmsley is free pending an appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Attorney Demands Government Release Captured Documents
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for Manuel Antonio Noriega said Monday the government should release documents captured in Panama that show the ousted dictator had helped the United States catch dozens of drug traffickers. Attorney Steven Kollin told U.S. Magistrate William Turnoff he wants to see documents from the office of the Panamanian investigative service, that country's equivalent of the FBI. The documents have been under U.S. government control since U.S. forces deposed Noriega in the December invasion of Panama. After the hearing, Kollin said the documents were important because they established that Noriega and Panama's defense forces had cooperated with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration and other law enforcement agencies ``up to the day of the invasion.'' Noriega is accused in a February 1988 federal indictment of running drugs and protecting Colombian drug shipments to the United States between 1982 and 1986. Kollin said he was sure he would win access to the documents, but may have to press harder to obtain a court order. Turnoff, who has become a referee in a dispute between the government and Noriega over the former general's personal property and papers, did not rule Monday on Kollin's request. Noriega's attorneys contend that prosecutors have been slow in producing his property for inspection, while prosecutors say they've been moving as fast as they can. The government said Monday it has completed an inventory of Noriega's holdings and turned the lists over to the defense. The court gave the defense four weeks to look over the inventory so Noriega's attorneys can determine which of his belongings are available as evidence. Prosecutors said they will be turning over some items to the Panamanian government that are not considered evidence. Kollin, however, protested, contending that international law prohibits the confiscation of private property during an invasion. ``The proper party to turn these over to is the legal representative, meaning myself,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer: Former Haitian Dictator, Wife Divorced Last October
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf after 7th `The lawyers' to UPDATE with background on wife's father, mobs ransacking his business when Duvaliers fled and SUBS penultimate graf to conform. Picks up final, `The Duvaliers...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Haiti
DOC.TEXT: Former Haitian dictator Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier and his wife Michele Bennett obtained a divorce last year in the Dominican Republic, her lawyer said Monday. The couple, who fled Haiti to exile in France after being forced out of power during a mass uprising in February 1986, were granted a divorce Oct. 24 in Samana, a tourist resort 186 miles from the Dominican capital Santo Domingo. Attorney Luz Duquela Morales, who represented Mrs. Duvalier, said the decision to divorce was ``mutual.'' The couple married in 1980. Judge Baez Barba granted custody of the couple's two children, Nicolas and Anya, to Michele Bennett and under terms of the divorce, Duvalier agreed to pay his ex-wife $3,000 in monthly child support payments and $4,500 in monthly alimony. Duvalier, the 39-year-old son of former President-for-Life Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, was represented by Dominican attorney Manuel Ramon Morel Cerda, according to the Dominican daily ``Ultima Hora,'' which reported the divorce Monday. Both lawyers said neither Duvalier or his wife were present for the divorce under a special law for foreigners in the Dominican Republic, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti. The lawyers said the couple will continue to live in France. Duvalier's wife and her father, businessmen Ernest Bennett, were resented by many Haitians who felt they lived in luxury while most islanders suffered. When the Duvaliers fled the country Feb. 6, 1986, mobs ransacked Bennett's auto dealership and his related businesses. After leaving Haiti, the ex-dictator and his wife retreated to Mougins, southern France, where he lives in opulence in Villa Mohamedia, rented from the Saudi magnate Adnan Kashoggi. The Duvaliers ruled Haiti for 29 years by force and with the help of the dreaded secret police force, the Tonton Macoutes. ``Baby Doc'' succeeded his father on his death in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: City to Seek Contempt Citations Against Black Protesters
DOC.TEXT: City officials said Monday they will ask a judge to have black protesters jailed and declared in contempt of court unless the demonstrators call off a monthlong sit-in at City Hall. Mayor Joe Smitherman said city attorneys will ask Circuit Judge Leslie Johnson at a Friday hearing to have the leaders arrested and fined unless a handful of people end their around-the-clock protest before then. Smitherman called the demonstrators ``misfits, people on welfare, people released from mental institutions.'' As he spoke in his office, four protesters sat in chairs or on the floor of the City Hall. Others were camped outside in two tents on the lawn. ``It would be useless to fine these people out here _ they haven't got anything,'' said the mayor. He said the city will seek contempt citations against leaders of protests that began in January over the dismissal of Selma's first black school superintendent. He mentioned among others, County Commissioner Perry Varner and two lawyers, Hank Sanders and his wife, Rose. Varner could not be located for comment, and neither Hank nor Rose Sanders immediately returned telephone calls. Johnson signed an order Saturday limiting the City Hall protests to business hours, although some protesters have continued to stay the night. He also said they could not interfere with government operations or City Council meetings. Several demonstrators said they were undeterred by Smitherman's threat of jail, a possibility the mayor himself said he dreads for fear of rekindling the flames of protest. Blacks have staged the protests and disrupted recent council meetings to protest the white-controlled school board's decision against renewing the contract of Superintendent Norward Roussell when it expires June 30. Roussell and his supporters blame his dismissal on racism. But the school board, which is appointed by the majority-white City Council, cited Roussell's management style. The controversy also has included boycotts by teachers. Selma's public schools were closed for nearly a week for fear of violence.

DOC.HEAD: Barve Clings to Narrow Lead as Teams Begin Run Along Bering Sea Coast
DOC.TEXT: Lavon Barve clung to the lead Monday as front-runners in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race began their run up the Bering Sea coast to Nome. Barve of Wasilla arrived at 4:02 p.m. in this windswept coastal community, the final checkpoint before mushers head across the treacherous ice of Norton Bay. ``Once they get onto the ice, they can expect sudden storms and an ample supply of wind,'' said Gail Somerville, an Iditarod spokeswoman in Anchorage. Three-time winner Susan Butcher of Manley and defending champion Joe Runyan of Nenana were trailing Barve by just a couple of hours, Somerville said. ``They haven't checked in yet, but they're not too far behind,'' she said. Tim Osmar of Clam Gulch, Dee Dee Jonrowe of Willow and Rick Swenson of Two Rivers, the Iditarod's only four-time champion, had reached Unalakleet, the largest community on the trail between Eagle River and Nome. Barve, driving 14 dogs, was first out of Unakleet at 10:05 a.m. But 50 miles earlier, at Kaltag, he rested his team only 3{ hours, compared with eight hours for Butcher and five hours for Runyan. He didn't seem to think that was much of a handicap, however. ``My dogs are getting stronger with less rest,'' Barve said. ``I think that's my advantage. My dogs always seem to recover fast.'' Butcher, whose team had dropped to 12 dogs, said she would like to be in front by the time the leaders reach White Mountain, just 77 miles from the finish of the 1,158-mile race. ``Unfortunately, that's not up to me as much as the other guys,'' Butcher said. ``I'd like to shed them early but I don't know if that's possible. ``And probably from what I know of Lavon's competitive spirit and how he can do what he wants to do with that team, I may not shed them at all.'' Runyan said any one of the first five mushers could win the race in the last 170-mile sprint to Nome. ``If you want to make a good bet, never bet on a dog race,'' he said. ``It's really shaken out to which team is healthy and really fit. Looks to me like it's anybody's bet what's going on here.'' Before leaving Kaltag, Runyan said the leaders in the 18th running of Iditarod had come under the spell of what he called the ``crazy syndrome.'' ``Everybody's pushing, pushing, pushing,'' he said. Since 70 teams left Anchorage on March 3, seven mushers have scratched and another has been disqualified because of sick dogs. The Iditarod, named for an abandoned gold-mining town along the trail, was started in 1973 to commemorate the 1925 emergency delivery of life-saving diphtheria serum from Anchorage to Nome by sled dog teams.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Role Unresolved in European Bank; New Countries Join
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's role in a new international development bank for Eastern Europe proved the major sticking point Sunday when officials from 39 countries failed to reach agreement on terms for the institution. The weekend meeting also broke up without a compromise on what currency will be used for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, where it will be located or how shareholdings will be balanced against voting rights. ``The most difficult question is the eligibility of one country in particular,'' said Jacques Attali, an aide to French President Francois Mitterrand, who proposed the bank in October. It was a reference to the Soviet Union, whose full participation in the bank has been opposed by the United States. Attali, who presided over the talks, affirmed that the Soviet Union's presence at the discussions meant it would have some future role. He said the application of any country wishing to join would be considered. Israel, Egypt, Morocco, South Korea and Lichtenstein took part in the talks for the first time, adding to the original 34 Western and Eastern European countries and the United States and Japan. ``We have opened up the teller's window,'' Attali said. ``The more countries that wish to support the revolutions in central and Eastern Europe, the better.'' At the first session in January, held to set terms for the bank, the United States ruled out Soviet participation unless Moscow made the ruble a convertible currency and began other market reforms. The United States also says the Soviet Union hasn't gone as far toward democracy as other East European countries, notably Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia. The bank would also benefit Yugoslavia, East Germany, Romania and Bulgaria. ``The U.S. is not isolated by any means at all,'' Attali said, indicating other nations also object to full Soviet participation. Attali refused to comment directly on a compromise offered by France. It would allow the Soviets to join the bank as a 6 percent shareholder and limit them to 6 percent of total lending. The issued could be resolved before the next meeting, which is set for April 9. Attali said negotiators were ``at the point of consensus'' and believed the last obstacles would soon be overcome. The participants did agree that the 12-nation European Community would provide 51 percent of the bank capital of about $12 billion, Attali said. Negotiators have also found common ground on how loans will be distributed between the private and public sectors, Attali said. But he refused to reveal the formula. Japan, Britain and the United States had insisted loans be restricted to private sector investment. Some other countries proposed allowing 40 percent be made available for public projects like roads and telephone networks. Attali predicted final terms could be set in April or May, with the bank making loans by the end of the year or in early 1991.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Nulato.
Butcher Loses Lead in Sled Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs with Butcher losing lead. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `Named for...' A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Lavon Barve was first out of this Yukon River checkpoint Sunday, taking the lead in the Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race away from three-time winner Susan Butcher and heading overland to Norton Sound. Barve of Wasilla left Kaltag at 2:28 p.m. even though Butcher had beaten him to the checkpoint by almost an hour in the latest stage of the 1,158-mile marathon race from Anchorage to Nome. The two leaders were followed into Kaltag by four-time Iditarod winner Rick Swenson at 1:26 p.m. and 1989 champion Joe Runyan at 1:33 p.m. Dee Dee Jonrowe and Tim Osmar of were next in just before 2:30 p.m. Robin Jaconson of arrived at 4:15 p.m.. By late afternoon, Barve was the only musher to have left Kaltag. Swenson said he would take an eight hour rest here. Butcher, who started the race with 17 dogs, had 12 Sunday. Race officials said some were dropped at checkpoints along the trail due to illness. When she became the first musher to reach Ruby Saturday, Butcher was rewarded with a luxurious meal of shrimp, veal, chocolate cheesecake and other delights, as well as $2,500. She said then that she intended to maintain the lead all the way to Nome. Kaltag is 42 miles along the Yukon, the biggest river in Alaska, from the last checkpoint at Nulato, which Butcher left earlier Sunday as leader. From Kaltag, where it heads overland to Unakleet on Norton Sound. With 850 people, Unakleet is the bigest community on the trail outside of Nome and Anchorage. Named for an abandoned gold-mining town along one branch of the trail, the Iditarod race was started in 1973 to commemorate the 1925 emergency delivery of life-saving diphtheria serum from Anchorage to Nome by relay dog sled teams. Joe Redington, the 73-year-old man considered the father of the Iditarod, was last reported in 32nd place after pulling out of Cripple, 510 miles from the starting line.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of March 5-12:
DOC.HEAD: Papers Need To Provide More Services, Executive Says
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers need to offer more services to compete for readers who move from town to town without developing ties to their communities, the chairman of the Knight-Ridder newspaper group said March 7. ``Transiency is bad for the country and it's also terrible for newspapers,'' said James Batten, who also serves as Knight-Ridder's chief executive officer. Batten was executive in residence for Wichita State University's Center for Entrepreneurship. He said one of the biggest challenges that newspapers must confront is that readers have _ or think they have _ less time to read than in the past. ``People are feeling the stress of time poverty _ it's tough to wedge in everything we may want to do,'' he said. Adults who say they read a newspaper every day dropped from 73 percent in 1967 to 51 percent last year, Batten said.
DOC.HEAD: Dallas Editor Contrasts U.S., Eastern Europe Attitudes
DOC.TEXT: Americans are becoming more apathetic about their communities and their governments while people in Eastern Europe are struggling to attain many of the freedoms we take for granted, an executive of a Dallas newspaper said March 5. ``We have a chance, if we don't blow it, to help reinvent freedom,'' Burl Osborne, president and editor of The Dallas Morning News, told a group at Kentucky Wesleyan College. ``We have great power to persuade; we can set the public agenda,'' said Osborne. In South Africa, where Nelson Mandela now walks free, ``the wall of apartheid has begun to crumble,'' he said. ``We need to rekindle the passion for our own freedoms, in ourselves, in our newspapers and in our communities.'' For example, newspapers should tell readers how to get involved in their community, Osborne said. Newspapers also must tell readers how problems around the world can affect them locally. ``We need to do a better job than we've done explaining that acid rain over Canada means something in Kentucky,'' he said.
DOC.HEAD: China Denies Harassment of Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The government of China denounced a U.S. Embassy investigation into the treatment of American journalists, denying charges that its security forces have stepped up surveillance of foreign reporters. Correspondents from nearly a dozen foreign news organizations say they have been followed or their Chinese sources harassed by plainclothes police in recent weeks. Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing said March 8 that such reports were groundless and that reporters who carry out normal and legitimate news coverage ``need not worry that they might run into troubles.'' An investigation into the claims ordered by the State Department was an interference in China's internal affairs, Li said. ``Should an investigation be really necessary, the justice-upholding people in the world would have every reason to ask, how many things has this superpower done in broad daylight over the years to trample upon the sovereignty and infringe upon the human rights of other nations?'' The surveillance of foreign reporters appeared to step up after martial law was lifted in Beijing on Jan. 11, with some journalists saying they have been tailed even while jogging or shopping. Journalists say Chinese security agents have also tried to photograph their meetings with Chinese sources and have interrogated their Chinese contacts.
DOC.HEAD: Post-Dispatch Offers New Contract to Employees
DOC.TEXT: The St. Louis Post-Dispatch submitted a new contract to negotiators representing about 630 newsroom employees who have been on a ``byline strike.'' Publisher Nicholas G. Penniman IV said March 9 that the latest proposal was a response to concerns among employees. Most of the newspaper's reporters and columnists have withheld their bylines from stories since March 7. ``They said, `Tell us what you need to remain competitive and give us a chance to vote,''' Penniman said. Herb Goodrick, executive secretary of The Newspaper Guild Local 47, said he would withhold comment until The Guild received a written version. About 630 newsroom employees, including reporters, some editors, photographers and advertising sales staffers, have been working without a contract since the last one expired Feb. 28. The Guild is the largest of 11 unions at the newspaper and one of six seeking a new contract. Penniman said the new proposal was for three years and included a 4 percent pay raise for each year and a $600 signing bonus. It also eliminated many demands that Guild members had objected to in the past few months. The Post-Dispatch is owned by Pulitzer Publishing Co.
DOC.HEAD: News Sues Guild Over Arbitration of Contract Deadline
DOC.TEXT: The Daily News, negotiating a new contract with the Newspaper Guild of New York and 10 other unions, filed a federal lawsuit March 7 to block an effort to extend the contract past an end-of-the-month deadline. The lawsuit, which named the Guild and its president, Barry Lipton, seeks an injunction barring the union from continuing to seek arbitration of the dispute over when the contract should expire. The lawsuit is based on correspondence between Lipton and Edward W. Gold, director of labor relations for the News. The exchange started with a letter from Lipton to Gold saying the Guild wanted to terminate its contract. Such a letter is the traditional signal opening a round of contract talks between unions and newspapers. Gold confirmed the notice of termination and said the newspaper was ready to start collective bargaining for a new contract. Gold also had said that if a new contract was not negotiated by March 30, the expiration date of the current agreement, that contract would not be renewed. The lawsuit said Lipton then asked to retract the Guild's letter requesting termination of the contract and said the union expected the terms of the old contract to continue if no agreement was reached before March 30. On Feb. 15, the Guild sent letters to the News and the American Arbitration Association asking for arbitration of the dispute, the lawsuit said. The union says it has 799 members at the News.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: New Journal of No-Apologies Liberalism to Be Launched
DOC.TEXT: The American Prospect, a quarterly journal launched March 11 by a group of writers and academics, ``marks the rebirth of no-apologies liberalism,'' its founders say. ``We're not neo-liberals, or post-liberals or any other hybrid. We're liberals,'' said co-editor Robert Kuttner. The entry of the journal coincides with the exit of the Cold War and its attending fixation on military issues, the editors said. ``A lot of the antagonisms that arose in the 1960s have died out,'' said Paul Starr, a Princeton University sociologist and one of the magazine's two editors. ``We think America's challenges today are mainly social and economic.'' The first issue, priced at $7.95, contains several meditations on the role of liberalism in the 1990s, a feature article on ``The Real Welfare Problem'' and a pollster's blueprint on how the Democratic Party can reclaim middle-class votes without moving to the right of the political spectrum. The journal's board of sponsors includes economist John Kenneth Galbraith, historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. and Marian Wright Edelman, founder of the Children's Defense fund.
DOC.HEAD: Ad-Free Ms. Magazine Plans Return _ If Enough Subscribers Sign Up
DOC.TEXT: The owners of Ms. say the magazine will return in June _ without ads _ if enough readers can be found willing to buy yearly subscriptions that cost $40 for six issues. The magazine served for more than 17 years as the chronicler of the feminist movement before suspending publication last December. Its new owner, publishing entrepreneur Dale Lang, said Ms. was losing about $150,000 a month when he acquired it in mid-October. The magazine had appeared 10 times a year for $16. Lang has said publishing the magazine without ads would enable its editorial staff to concentrate on pursuing issues important to women without concerns about advertiser backlash, which was said to be a recurring problem. The new Ms. will be a 100-page magazine with investigative reporting, profiles, interviews, fiction, poetry, regular features on health and the environment and photgraphy from all over the world.
DOC.HEAD: Public Has Heard Enough of Trump Tale, Poll Shows
DOC.TEXT: The Donald and Ivana saga may stir the hearts of reporters and editors, but most Americans have heard enough of the Trumps, according to a nationwide survey of news interests released March 8. The monthly Times Mirror News Interest Index showed a record 55 percent of the 1,226 people surveyed thought there was too much news about the Trumps' domestic battle. It was by far the largest ``over-covered'' rating ever accorded a story since the poll was begun in 1986. The survey, conducted by the Gallup Organization, found no single news story dominated public attention in the last month. The freeing of black South African leader Nelson Mandela and political changes in the Soviet Union led the index, with ``very closely followed'' ratings of 30 percent and 28 percent, respectively. The index is sponsored by the Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press. Based on the total sample of 1,226 adults, the poll has a 95 percent chance of being within 3 percentage points of the results that would be obtained if the entire adult population were interviewed.
DOC.HEAD: News Photographer Innocent in Abortion Protest Case
DOC.TEXT: A news photographer arrested while covering an anti-abortion protest was found innocent March 7 of a charge that he failed to obey a police order to move away as officers carried a demonstrator to the paddy wagon. County Judge Wilford Flowers handed down the innocent verdict for freelance photographer Gary Kanadjian, who was on assignment for The Associated Press during the December 1988 protest by Operation Rescue at the Ladies Center in Austin. Defense attorney Hugh Lowe said Kanadjian was serving the public in covering a news event that involved ``the most emotional public debate today _ abortion.'' Lowe said police had mistreated some of the protesters and didn't want that shown. ``And if the press is not there, then these sorts of wrongs never get corrected and the true nature of the debate never gets exposed to us,'' Lowe said. Before ruling, Flowers noted that police had arrested Kanadjian after they had allowed numerous other news reporters and photographers to cover the event from much closer.
DOC.HEAD: International Efforts to Save Life of Condemned Journalist
DOC.TEXT: Journalists, relatives and government leaders appealed to Iraq on March 11 to grant clemency to a London-based journalist sentenced to death on espionage charges and to a British woman accused of helping him. A delegation of European Economic Community ambassadors went to the Foreign Ministry in Baghdad to make a ``humanitarian appeal'' on behalf of Farzad Bazoft and Daphne Parish. British Ambassador Harold Walker said he made a separate trip to the ministry t deliver a personal appeal from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Bazoft, 31, was arrested in September and charged with spying for foreign powers after making an unauthorized trip to a military complex where a huge explosion had been reported. He was in Iraq on an assignment for The Observer, a London newspaper. Mrs. Parish, 52, a senior nursing administrator for an Irish-run hospital in Baghdad, was accused of helping Bazoft by driving him to the Al-Iskandaria military complex south of Baghdad. She was sentenced to 15 years in prison. No date has been set for the execution. Under Iraqi law, no court appeal is allowed against the sentences. They were imposed by a revolutionary court Saturday after a closed trial. Bazoft is an Iranian exile who has lived in Britain since 1975 and travels on British documents.
DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Slay Prominent Liberal Journalist in Turkey
DOC.TEXT: A prominent liberal journalist and outspoken critic of terrorism was shot and killed by two masked men as he left his home for work March 7. Hours later an unknown Islamic group claimed responsibility for killing Cetin Emec and his driver. Emec, 55, was a board member and columnist for Turkey's largest-circulation newspaper, Hurriyet. In his last column, published the day of the shooting, Emec expressed alarm at the resurgence of terrorism in Turkey. He accused Syria of supporting terrorist groups in the region and claimed Syrian leaders were behind the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in December 1988.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Events Planned in Washington, Elsewhere To Mark Hostage Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Family, friends, colleagues and other supporters will gather March 16 at events in Washington, Cyprus and elsewhere to mark the fifth anniversary of the kidnapping of Associated Press correspondent Terry A. Anderson, longest-held of the hostages in Lebanon. Anderson's relatives and families of other American hostages will come together at noon in Lafayette Park, across from the White House, to reaffirm their faith in the eventual release of the journalist and his fellow hostages. The scheduled speakers include U.S. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y.; AP President and General Manager Louis D. Boccardi; NBC News anchorman Tom Brokaw; CBS News anchorman Dan Rather, and broadcast personality Larry King. Other commemorations: _In Nicosia, Cyprus, the AP's Mideast hub, the multidenominational Nicosia Community Church will conduct a 40-minute prayer service. _In upstate New York, where Anderson spent his boyhood, supporters will begin a 24-hour fast at a service in Buffalo on Thursday, and ceremonially break the fast at noon Friday in an event in nearby Batavia, N.Y., Anderson's former hometown. _In Lorain, Ohio, Anderson's birthplace, supporters plan a ceremony at 11 a.m. Friday in front of city hall, and another at 7:30 p.m. at a local Veterans of Foreign Wars hall. _ In New York City, an AP-arranged Mass will be sung at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa will celebrate the 10 a.m. Mass. The 42-year-old Anderson, AP's chief Middle East correspondent, is one of eight American hostages. Ten other Westerners are also held captive by kidnappers in Lebanon.
DOC.HEAD: Inter American Press Association Hails Advances in Press Freedom
DOC.TEXT: The Inter American Press Association praised Nicaragua and Panama on March 7 for restoring press freedom, but said journalists' lives remain threatened in Colombia and elsewhere in the American hemisphere. The association, which includes 1,400 newspapers, magazines and broadcasters in the Americas, declared at its congress here that ``a free press' triumph has been most rewarding'' in Panama and Nicaragua. In Panama, independent newspapers have reopened following last December's U.S. invasion that overthrew dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Nicaraguan publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, whose newspaper La Prensa struggled to operate under the leftist Sandinista government, is now Nicaragua's president-elect after the victory of her 14-party coalition over the Sandinistas in elections Feb. 25. Mrs. Chamorro pledged total press freedom. On March 7 the Sandinista government abolished the country's media law, allowing private TV broadcasting and greater press freedom.
DOC.HEAD: Death Row Newspaper Endorses Candidate for Texas Governor
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards got an endorsement for her Democratic campaign for governor she didn't expect or necessarily want, from editors of a Texas death row newspaper. James Beathard, an assistant editor of Endeavor newspaper, said inmate support likely would hurt Ms. Richards rather than help her in the election. ``But it's us they're trying to kill, and we should have a right to comment about the people who are trying to kill us,'' said Beathard, awaiting death for a 1984 spree in which three people were slain. Ms. Richards' two Democratic opponents, Attorney General Jim Mattox and former Gov. Mark White, have run television ads in which they take credit for making Texas the nation's leader in executions. Since Texas resumed the death penalty in 1982, 33 men have been given lethal injections. Endeavor editors and other inmates were particularly upset with a White commercial in which large pictures of the executed prisoners are used as props. Beathard said Ms. Richards appeared to be concentrating on such issues as education, minorities and the budget. When she first heard of the endorsement Ms. Richards thought the question was a joke. ``I don't know what possibly could have engendered it,'' she said while campaigning for the March 13 primary. `I don't know anybody on death row.'' Ms. Richards said she believes the death penalty law should be followed. The newspaper, in existence for nearly a year, is believed to be the only one of its kind among the nation's death rows.
DOC.HEAD: Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger's Will Filed for Probate
DOC.TEXT: The controlling interest in The New York Times will pass to the four children of the late Iphigene Ochs Sulzberger, whose will was filed for probate March 5. Mrs. Sulzberger died Feb. 26 at age 97 in Stamford, Conn. She left all her stock in the Times and in the Times Printing Co. equally to three daughters and a son: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York, publisher of the Times; Marian S. Heiskell of New York; Ruth Holmberg of Chattanooga, Tenn.; and Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger of New York. Mrs. Sulzberger was the daughter of Adolph Ochs and the widow of Arthur Hays Sulzberger.
DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Against Houston Chronicle in Open Records Case
DOC.TEXT: The Texas Court of Criminal Appeals on March 7 rejected the Houston Chronicle's effort to overturn a state judge's order the newspaper said violates the First Amendment by denying it access to criminal court files. In September, State District Judge Charles Hearn ordered Harris County District Clerk Ray Hardy to refuse public access to the addresses and telephone numbers of defendants in criminal court files, until the defendants retained a lawyer or had one appointed to represent them. The action was taken to stop defense lawyers from soliciting potential clients, according to court records. But Hardy said he does not have the manpower to examine the approximately 100 criminal files he receives each day and edit out addresses and telephone numbers, according to a brief filed by the newspaper. The clerk then decided to withhold entire files, the newspaper said. ``The files in the criminal intake division ... constitute a unique and irreplaceable newsgathering resource for members of the media,'' the brief said. It also said denying names and telephone numbers to the press interferes with reporters' responsibility to check information for accuracy. The court, without writing an opinion, denied the newspaper's motion. It earlier denied a motion by Hardy seeking to set aside the judge's ruling as being in conflict with the Texas Open Records Act.
DOC.HEAD: Thomson Reporter Announces Candidacy for State Legislature
DOC.TEXT: A state capitol reporter for a newspaper company has announced his candidacy for the state House of Representatives. Albert D. Sterner, the former editor of The Evening Sun in Hanover and a Harrisburg reporter for 12 Thomson newspapers across the state, said he would run as a Republican candidate for the 193rd District. ``It's a personal goal,'' Sterner said March 4. ``I've always been interested in government and politics, and as a journalist, I'm familiar with much of what is going on with the district.'' Sterner said he would resign his job to campaign for the Legislature. Donald Dorr has held the seat since the district was created in 1971. Sterner is the fifth Republican to enter the race.
DOC.HEAD: Corning Leader to Publish Sunday Edition
DOC.TEXT: The Leader, which converted from an evening to morning daily newspaper March 5, published its first Sunday edition March 11. The initial press run for the 72-page edition was 20,000 copies, Publisher Neil Hopp said. Hopp said the paper's size went far beyond the staff's expectations. ``Our research hasn't uncovered another daily newspaper which has attempted these same feats in the same week,'' said Managing Editor Mark Sweetwood.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UPI Seeks Arbitration of Photo Dispute With Reuters
DOC.TEXT: Reuters filed court papers March 9 opposing United Press International's request for a preliminary injunction barring Reuters from backing out of a picture exchange agreement. UPI claims Reuters has deprived it of photo revenue for the past five years and is seeking damages of more than $600,000. Under an arrangement that began in 1985 and which was supposed to run for 10 years, UPI provided Reuters with pictures from the United States while Reuters supplied pictures from other countries. Reuters, which claims UPI's photo report has declined since the exchange began, has filed suit in federal court seeking to void the contract between the two news services. In the memorandum of March 9, made in response to a counterclaim made by UPI, Reuters denied allegations that it ``poached'' certain UPI clients, taken away employees and was trying to drive UPI out of business. ``It is a collection of inflammatory statements based on no authority whatever or on serious distortions of the documents at issue,'' Reuters said. UPI has filed a request for arbitration in the case, saying Reuters is obligated under agreements between the two companies to reimburse UPI for any revenue lost as a result of subscribers shifting to Reuters' photo service. Reuters spokesman Robert Crooke said there is no evidence UPI lost money because of his company's marketing activities. ``We welcome the opportunity that the arbitration provides to establish not only that Reuter activities are not the cause of UPI's losses but that those causes lie much closer to UPI's own actions,'' Crooke said. U.S. District Judge Peter K. Leisure earlier issued a temporary restraining order against Reuters, which remains in effect until he decides whether to issue the injunction. Reuters said Feb. 16 it was canceling the agreement and halted its flow of pictures to UPI for more than four hours. Reuters has alleged that UPI's photo service has declined since the exchange began.
DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Magazine Suit Settled
DOC.TEXT: A libel suit filed by two suburban police officers who claimed they were defamed by an article published in Pittsburgh Magazine was settled March 5. According to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, the Baldwin Borough officers agreed to drop their lawsuit for between $50,000 and $75,000. The suit was scheduled to go to trial the same day. Officers Warren R. Cooley and Donald Misencik said in their suit they were damaged by a May 1988 article about the unsolved disappearance of Michael Rosenblum of Pittsburgh in 1980. The lawsuit claimed that portions of the article falsely suggested the officers were somehow responsible for Rosenblum's disappearance. The suit also said writer James T. Harger made defamatory comments about the two officers during an interview with a radio station and to two Allegheny County detectives. Another suit against the magazine, its editor and Harger is pending. That suit, also related to the Rosenblum article, was filed by Aldo Gaburri, the former police chief in Baldwin.
DOC.HEAD: Auto Industry Publication Group Up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: Thomson Corp. wants to sell its Ward's Communications Inc., a group of automotive-related magazines and newsletters. Ward's employees were notified of the move March 5. Gerald D. Tenser, vice president of the Thomson subsidiary Thomson Information-Publishing Group in Stamford, Conn., said the organization hoped to make the sale within three months. Tenser declined to say how much the company was seeking or whether it had offers. He said Thomson has instituted a policy which has resulted in the divestment of several trade magazines. Ward's, whose publications are highly respected in the automotive industry, began in 1924 by publishing statistics on the industry. Thomson, a publishing conglomerate based in Toronto, acquired Ward's in 1981. Publications include two monthly magazines _ Ward's Auto World and Ward's Auto Dealer _ and newsletters including Ward's Automotive Reports and Ward's Engine Update.
DOC.HEAD: Times Mirror Subsidiary Buys Five Weeklies
DOC.TEXT: Southern Connecticut Newspapers Inc., publisher of The Advocate and Greenwich Time, has bought five weekly newspapers in southwestern Connecticut and southern New York. Terms of the agreement to buy Acorn Press Inc., which publishes The Ridgefield Press, The Wilton Bulletin, The Redding Pilot, The Bethel Home News in Connecticut and The Ledger of Lewisboro, N.Y., were not disclosed. Acorn, based in Ridgefield, has been owned and operated since 1937 by the Nash family, headed by Karl S. Nash, president and principal stockholder. The acquisition is the first for SCN, a subsidiary of Times Mirror Co. of Los Angeles. The Advocate has a circulation of 30,912 daily and 38,724 on Sundays; Greenwich Time has a circulation of 13,276 daily and 13,295 on Sundays. The five weeklies have a combined circulation of about 21,800.
DOC.HEAD: Authors, Editors Accuse Random House
DOC.TEXT: Brandishing signs and chanting slogans, about 350 authors, editors, literary agents and sympathizers staged a noisy sidewalk protest March 5 to accuse Random House of destroying one of its key subsidiaries for financial reasons. ``The bottom line is not the last word,'' read one sign displayed outside the publishing giant's midtown headquarters. The protesters said that Samuel I. Newhouse, owner of Random House, had ``effectively killed'' the subsidiary, Pantheon Books, by forcing the resignation of its longtime editorial director, Andre Schiffrin, on Feb. 28. Schiffrin reportedly had refused to cut his staff and the number of books he planned to publish. Five of Pantheon's six senior editors subsequently quit, saying Pantheon's established role as a publishing house for unconventional and otherwise little-known writers was being ruined in the name of corporate profits. Random House chairman Alberto Vitale said he was ``absolutely puzzled'' by the reaction to Schiffrin's resignation. He said Pantheon would have ``ceased to operate a long, long time ago'' without Random House's support.
DOC.HEAD: Teen-age Comic Book Buff Produces Newsletter
DOC.TEXT: A high school honors student with a love of comic books has begun his own newsletter for other buffs. ``Comics are an art form ... a literary form, too, in addition to being good entertainment,'' said Glen Lubbert, 18, publisher of The Comic Chronicle. Lubbert, who buys about 30 comic books a month and has nearly 3,000 in his collection, produces the 16-page newsletter every six weeks with the help of two other teen-agers. He sells about 150 issues at 50 cents each through mail subscriptions and newsstands. A typical issue includes interviews with cartoonists, usually done by Lubbert at the many conventions he attends, artwork and columns on comic book markets.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: State Supreme Court Overturns Sales Tax on Magazine Subscriptions
DOC.TEXT: The state Department of Revenue cannot collect sales taxes on magazine subscriptions sold in Tennessee, the state Supreme Court ruled March 5. The unanimous decision held that magazines cannot be singled out for taxation while newspapers are not. The ruling means the state Department of Revenue will have to refund sales taxes paid by Newsweek magazine, whose lawsuit challenged the taxation, and other magazines sold in the state, Revenue Commissioner Joe Huddleston said. ``We have not previously taxed newspapers, and the thrust of the decision is to tell us that we cannot tax magazines and exempt newspapers,'' Huddleston said. He estimated the state would refund $5 million in sales taxes paid by magazines. Newsweek challenged the sales tax and penalties it had paid on subscription sales in Tennessee between Jan. 1, 1982, and Dec. 31, 1984. The magazine charged that taxation violated constitutional guarantees of free speech and due process.
DOC.HEAD: New Daily Appears on Schedule But Needs Name
DOC.TEXT: A new afternoon newspaper hit Millville's streets as planned March 5, but it came out needing a name. Bridgeton Evening News Co., which publishes the Bridgeton Evening News, is calling the new paper simply the Millville for now. It asked readers to help find a permanent name. The newspaper was to have been called The Millville Daily, but that plan was changed after a threatened lawsuit by Gannett Co. Inc., which publishes the rival Daily Journal in nearby Vineland. Gannett published a newspaper known as The Millville Daily until May 1988, when it merged the Daily with The Vineland Times-Journal to form The Daily Journal. Gannett said it still owns the name The Millville Daily. ``We don't think they are right. But they could be,'' John M. Ewing, publisher of the Bridgeton Evening News and the new paper, said in a page-one story. The Millville and Bridgeton papers are owned by Hollinger Inc. of Toronto.
DOC.HEAD: BROADCAST NEWS
Directors Guild Agrees on New Pact With NBC and ABC
DOC.TEXT: The Directors Guild of America has reached tentative agreement with ABC and NBC on a three-year contract covering about 275 Guild members at the networks, say union and network officials. The new contract, to succeed one that expires June 30, still must be approved by the Guild's national board, and then submitted to Guild membership for ratification. In addition to staff members and free-lance employees at ABC and NBC, the agreement covers Guild members at facilities the networks own here and in Washington, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco. The proposed pact would boost salaries by 5 percent this July, with another 5 percent increase beginning Jan. 1, 1992, according to a statement issued March 9 by the Guild and the two networks. The Guild still is negotiating a new contract with CBS, said Chuck Warn, a Guild spokesman in Los Angeles.
DOC.HEAD: NFL Boosts TV Deals to More Than $3.6 Billion Over Four Years
DOC.TEXT: The National Football League wrapped up its new television package March 9 by agreeing to a deal with NBC that boosts its total TV revenue to more than $3.6 billion over four years, an all-sports record. The new agreement, for $752 million over four years, concludes two months of negotiations that will increase the amount of TV revenues each team now gets to $32 million from $17 million. It also will increase the number of playoff teams from 10 to 12 and eventually increase the length of the season from 16 to 18 weeks. The total NFL package is almost double what the league obtained in its last contract, when it got $1.428 billion over three years. The negotiators increased the season to 17 weeks for the next two years and 18 weeks thereafter, although teams will continue to play a 16-game schedule. They added a Sunday night cable package for the first half of season, which was sold to Turner Broadcasting, and finally added two more playoff teams, sweetening the ABC pot by giving the network its first playoff games ever. The revenue does not include the 1994 Super Bowl, which is expected to bring in an additional $40 million or more when it is bid upon at the end of the year.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: News Writers at CBS Stations Ratify Contract
DOC.TEXT: News writers for CBS radio and television stations in four cities have ratified a three-year contract giving them two 5-percent raises over the life of the pact, a spokesman said March 6. The agreement covers 325 news writers, editors, desk assistants, researchers, promotion writers and graphic artists of the Writers Guild of America, East and West, in New York, Washington, Chicago and Los Angeles. Employees will receive an immediate 5 percent wage increase and another 5 percent raise in September 1991, as well as increases in various fees for special work, said union spokesman Martin Waldman. The increases will raise the average news writer's salary to $951 by the end of the contract, Waldman said. Those covered include staff members at ``CBS Evening News With Dan Rather,'' ``CBS This Morning,'' WCBS-TV and WCBS radio in New York, WBBM-TV and WBBM radio in Chicago, and KCBS-TV and KNX radio in Los Angeles.
DOC.HEAD: Ohio TV, Radio Stations Join Anti-Drug Effort
DOC.TEXT: Most major-market Ohio television and radio stations worked together to enlist citizens in the war on drugs March 7. Two dozen television stations, 270 radio stations and several cable companies combined to broadcast locally produced anti-drug shows featuring panel discussions, interviews, live remote reports and appeals from U.S. drug czar William Bennett and Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste. The broadcasts also offered a chance to tip police to illegal drug activity. Columbus police said they recieved more than 800 tips during that city's two-hour telecast.
DOC.HEAD: Classroom TV With Commercials Goes on Air
DOC.TEXT: Students across the country got the news March 5 along with a sales pitch for candy, razors and cheese snacks when the advertiser-supported classroom program Channel One went on the air. The news show, beamed nationwide for the first time to 400 schools, is produced by Knoxville-based Whittle Communications, which loans participating schools expensive video equipment and satellite dishes to receive the program, and sells advertising to cover the cost. Despite criticism from national education groups, bans by public educators in New York and California and a lawsuit in North Carolina, 2,900 schools in 34 states have signed up for Channel One, company Chairman Christopher Whittle told reporters at the high school. He predicted 8,000 would be committed by December. ``I predict that within five years a system like this will be in 95 percent of all middle and high schools in the United States. In a sense, it will be a new institution in America's schools.'' But Timothy Dyer, executive director of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, worried that Channel One, which already has been tested in a number of schools, marked the beginning of ``the commercialization of the classroom.'' The program, produced in New York and sent by satellite to participating schools, included feature stories on a Japanese high school in Tennessee and an Army recruiting office in Kentucky. The 12-minute program was interspersed with two minutes of 30-second commercials for M&Ms, Gillette shavers and Chee-tos. The fourth ad was an anti-drug public service announcement.
DOC.HEAD: Ex-Gynecologist Sues CBS Over `West 57th' Show
DOC.TEXT: A former gynecologist accused of performing genital surgery on women without their knowledge to enhance their sexual responsiveness is suing CBS for $250 million over a ``West 57th Street'' broadcast. In the lawsuit, filed March 5 in federal court, James C. Burt alleged he was defamed by the program. CBS spokesman Tom Goodman said, ``We believe the report was entirely fair and accurate, and CBS News stands by it.'' Burt, 68, faces about 50 malpractice suits for his self-described ``love surgery,'' in which he altered the genitals of his patients, allegedly without informing them of the true purpose of the procedure. Burt, who said the surgery was designed to enhance their responsiveness, contended he has ``never operated on anybody without informed consent.'' Burt sued over a 1988 broadcast of the news show, which is no longer on the air, that contained interviews with several former patients. The ``ludicrous and horrendous'' report ``started a chain reaction of talk shows, magazine articles, media reports that have since totally destroyed my personal life, my profession as physician, loss of property, loss of income, my family,'' Burt said in a statement. Also named as defendants were two past or present CBS employees, a patient and another doctor. In 1989, Burt surrendered his medical license just days before a disciplinary hearing.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Board Upholds License Decision
DOC.TEXT: A Federal Communications Commission review board has upheld the decision to rescind the licenses of Tri-State Broadcasting Inc. for radio stations here. The board agreed with commission administrative law judge Edward Kuhlman's September 1988 decision that what he called Tri-State's 16-year record of misrepresentation and misconduct was cause to deny the license renewal for KUPD-FM and KUKQ-AM. It also agreed that Jack and Jackie Grimm and Ruth Clifford, who challenged Tri-State's renewal application in 1985, should receive a construction permit. Ed Hamlin, Tri-State vice president for operations, said March 7 the company would appeal and would continue running the stations until the full commission rules. If all appeals fail, the station would become the property of the Grimms. In Kuhlman's 1988 decision, the judge said Tri-State repeatedly had falsified reports to the FCC to conceal the names of station managers and owners and had shredded documents to the same purpose.
DOC.HEAD: News and Sing-Alongs: Investors Plan Radio Network for Children
DOC.TEXT: Investors have announced plans for a radio network of satellite-delivered programs appealing to children under 12 with music, jokes, stories, sing-alongs and the news. Orlando station WPRD-AM, which now airs big-band music, will switch to a round-the-clock format for children at the end of this month, becoming the flagship station for the Kids' Choice Broadcasting Network. Investors are seeking to raise $3 million to $4 million to launch the 24-hour network and hope to have 100 subscriber stations in the nation's top 20 markets by next year. The format, with a staff of 10, is based on children's programming at KPAL in Little Rock, Ark., which was on the air from 1985 to 1988 and won a number of national awards.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: WLAF-USA Network Reach Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The World League of American Football and the USA cable network agreed March 10 to a four-year contract for Saturday night and Monday night games starting next year. The contract also calls for a playoff game in 1991 and a playoff game and the league championship game in 1992. Next year's league championship has already been sold to ABC. The league, owned by the NFL, will begin next spring with 12 teams, six in the United States and one each in England, West Germany, Italy, Spain, Canada and Mexico. Earlier this year the league announced a two-year, $28 million deal with ABC for Sunday afternoon games.
DOC.HEAD: FCC Is Asked To Block Sale of WWL-TV
DOC.TEXT: United Communications Inc., a minority-owned investment group, has asked the Federal Communications Commission to reject the $102.85 million sale of WWL-TV. The legal challenge filed in Washington, D.C., is aimed at blocking the effort of WWL-TV manager Mike Early and his Rampart Operating Partnership, made up of WWL-TV employees, to buy the station from Loyola University. The school agreed Dec. 21 to sell WWL to the group. United Communications' petition contends that senior WWL employees broke antitrust laws and frustrated United's efforts by threatening to resign, reducing the station's value, if Loyola sold to anyone but Early. Early had no immediate comment, saying he had just received a copy of the petition and was going over it. Loyola Vice President John Eckholdt said through a spokesman that ``after a preliminary review of the challenge, it has no basis in fact.''
DOC.HEAD: KGO's Fuller To Move to KPIX
DOC.TEXT: The news director at top-rated KGO has resigned to head up the news staff at rival television station KPIX. Harry Fuller, news director at KGO for five years, begins at KPIX April 2, the San Francisco Chronicle reported March 8. Fuller will replace current KPIX news director Peter Maroney, who has been named director of cable programming for the station.
DOC.HEAD: PERSONNEL NOTES
Burleigh Elected Executive Vice President of E.W. Scripps
DOC.TEXT: William R. Burleigh has been elected executive vice president of the E.W. Scripps Co. and nominated to serve on its board of directors, the communications company said March 9. Burleigh previously was senior vice president for newspapers and publishing at Scripps. The E.W. Scripps Co. operates 19 daily newspapers, nine television stations, five radio stations and cable television systems with 558,000 basic subscribers. The company also is a worldwide syndicator and licenser of news features and comics. Burleigh, 54, was named editor and president of The Evansville (Ind.) Press in 1975 and served as editor of The Cincinnati Post from 1977 to 1983. He joined the E.W. Scripps corporate staff in 1984 as vice president and general editorial manager. In 1986, he was promoted to senior vice president. Burleigh is a member of the board of directors of The Associated Press and president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors Foundation.
DOC.HEAD: Zanotti Named Publisher For Phoenix Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: John P. Zanotti, president and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer, was named publisher of The Arizona Republic and The Phoenix Gazette on March 5. Zanotti, 41, fills a vacancy created by the retirement of Pat Murphy on Aug. 8. In addition to his role as publisher of the newspapers, Zanotti will be executive vice president and chief executive officer of the Arizona Business Gazette and of Phoenix Newspapers Inc., which publishes the three papers, said the spokesman, William Shover. The appointment culminates a seven-month search throughout the United States, said Frank Russell, president of Indianapolis-based Central Newspapers Inc., which owns Phoenix Newspapers Inc. Zanotti was named president and publisher of the Enquirer in 1985, a year after joining Gannett Co. Inc., the owner of the paper.
DOC.HEAD: Watson Named Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Douglas Watson, a veteran of national and international news coverage, has been named managing editor of The Greeneville Sun, the newspaper announced March 5. He replaces Cameron Judd, who left the paper earlier this year to concentrate on writing fiction. Watson, 51, worked for The Washington Post for 12 years, for The Baltimore Sun for six years, and with The San Diego Union, U.S. News and World Report and as senior editor of Emirates News, an English-language daily in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates on the Persian Gulf. He also has worked as a foreign correspondent based in Cairo and later in Jerusalem.
DOC.HEAD: Moyer Named Arkansas Gazette Editor
DOC.TEXT: J. Keith Moyer, executive editor of the News-Press in Fort Myers, Fla., was named editor of the Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock on March 6. He succeeds Walker Lundy, who becomes a general executive at the headquarters of Gannett Co., Inc., in Arlington, Va. Both newspapers are owned by Gannett. Moyer, 37, has been executive editor in Fort Myers since August 1986. A graduate of the University of Florida, he began his newspaper career at the Tampa (Fla.) Times. Lundy, 47, joined Gannett in January 1988 at Little Rock. In his new position, he will work with Philip Currie, vice president-news in the Newspaper Division.
DOC.HEAD: Bowden Named Cedar Rapids Gazette Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Mark Bowden has been named managing editor of The Cedar Rapids Gazette, Editor and Publisher Joe Hladky announced March 7. In his new position, Bowden will manage the day-to-day operation of The Gazette's newsroom and a staff of more than 80 reporters, editors and photographers. He will report to Executive Editor John Robertson. Bowden succeeds Dave Morris, who has been named a senior editor. Bowden joined The Gazette in March 1979 as an assistant state editor and served as state editor and metro-Iowa editor before being promoted to assistant managing editor-news in December 1988. He joined The Gazette after working as news editor for the North Platte, Neb., Telegraph. He also had been managing editor of the Valley City, N.D., Times-Record. Bowden, 37, graduated from Drake University in 1975.
DOC.HEAD: Publisher To Retire at Kauai Paper
DOC.TEXT: John Uyeno, publisher of The Garden Island, says he will retire after almost 50 years at the paper, once a successor is chosen. Uyeno, 63, joined the paper in 1941 as a maintenance man and worked his way up to become publisher about 20 years ago. The Garden Island, oldest newspaper on the island of Kauai, publishes five days a week. It is part of the Scripps League Newspapers, Inc., group.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Clifton Blue
DOC.TEXT: Former newspaper editor and publisher H. Clifton Blue, onetime speaker of the North Carolina House of Representatives, died March 10 at a nursing home. He was 79. Blue served nine terms as a state representative from Moore County and was the House speaker during the 1963 General Assembly session. He began his career in newspapers in 1932 when he established The Captain, a weekly paper in Vass. The paper later consolidated with The Sandhill Citizen. In 1958, he started the weekly Robbins Record in Robbins and continued to publish both papers until he sold them to Park Newspapers in 1982. He is survived by his wife, Gala Nunnery Blue; sons H. Clifton Blue Jr. of Pinebluff and John Blue of Aberdeen; daughters Patsy B. Baily of Derwood, Md., and Elizabeth B. Abrams of Cary; a sister; three brothers, and seven grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: James Coldsmith
DOC.TEXT: James Wesley Coldsmith, former editor and publisher of newspapers in Alexandria, Va., from the 1960s through the 1980s, died March 10 at his home of leukemia. He was 60. Coldsmith expanded an advertising flyer into what became The Journal group of newspapers in the Virginia and Maryland suburbs near Washington. He earlier had been editor and publisher of the Alexandria Port Packet and the Alexandria Gazette. Born in Parsons, Kan., Coldsmith worked for The Associated Press in Tokyo, Denver and Chicago, before moving to Virginia in 1966. Earlier, he served in the Army and was news editor of the Stars and Stripes in Tokyo. Survivors include three children, Janet E. Coldsmith of Alexandria, Va.; Bruce Gordon Coldsmith of Mobile, Ala.; and Jean Anne Coldsmith of Corvallis, Ore.; a sister, Dorothy Matsen of Colorado Springs; a brother, Dr. Donald Coldsmith of Emporia, Kan.; and two grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: Patrick Finnegan
DOC.TEXT: Patrick T. Finnegan, retired budget director of the Scripps Howard Newspapers group, died March 8 of a blood clot. He was 74. He joined the company in 1942 when he was hired by the New York World-Telegram. When the newspaper was merged into the New York World-Journal-Tribune, he worked for the World-Journal-Tribune for its three-year life. He later joined the Scripps Howard corporate office. He served as a vice president of the Scripps Howard Foundation and executive vice president of the James Gordon Bennett Foundation. He retired in 1980. Finnegan is credited with helping introduce computers into the New York newspaper industry. Survivors include a son, six granddaughters and a great-grandson.
DOC.HEAD: Budd Hascall
DOC.TEXT: Frank L. ``Budd'' Hascall, publisher and majority owner of The Goshen News, died of cancer March 8 at his home. He was 75. Hascall had been publisher of Goshen's only daily newspaper for the past 35 years, and had been majority stockholder since 1954. Survivors include his daughter, Jane Gemmer of Goshen, president of the News Printing Co., which publishes the newspaper; a granddaughter, Elizabeth Gemmer; and a sister, Jane Spencer of Woodside, Calif. His son-in-law, John Gemmer, is executive vice president and general manager of News Printing.
DOC.HEAD: Frank Swanson
DOC.TEXT: Frank Swanson, a former war correspondent and publisher of the Calgary Herald, died March 5 after a long illness. He was 72. Swanson also worked for the Edmonton (Alberta) Journal and was editor of The Citizen in Ottawa during 44 years in journalism. All three papers are part of the Southam Newspapers group. Swanson became a war correspondent in World War II for the Southam group. He continued to report from Europe after the war and covered the Nazi war crime trials at Nuremberg. He moved to Ottawa in 1948 and covered politics for Southam for the next decade before becoming associate editor and then editor of the Citizen. Less than a year later, he was named publisher of the Herald, a position he held for 20 years before retiring in 1982. Swanson is survived by his wife, Vera, and a son.
DOC.HEAD: Elsie Wood
DOC.TEXT: Elsie Wood, a longtime member of the Legislative Correspondents Association, died March 5 at an Albany hospital at age 91. ``Newspeople across New York state, and particularly current and past members of the Legislative Correspondents Association, today mourn the loss of a beloved friend and colleague,'' Gov. Mario Cuomo said in a statement. Wood, an Albany resident, worked in journalism at the state Capitol for more than 50 years. She transmitted news as a telegrapher for the Postal Telegraph and Western Union between 1928 and 1956, when she went to work for Cuyler News Service. Wood was one of the first two women to be admitted to the Legislative Correspondents Association when that professional organization began admitting women in 1968. Survivors include a brother, Thomas Grant of Oswego; a sister, Florence Rau of New Jersey; and two grandchildren, Barbara Frank and Allan Frank, both of Albany.
DOC.HEAD: Missing Journalist Wins Award
DOC.TEXT: John McCarthy, a British television reporter abducted in Lebanon, will be awarded the Institute of Journalists' gold medal on the fourth anniversary of his disappearance, the news union announced March 8. The medal recognizes ``journalists who have been prepared to suffer for the freedom of the written word and whose courage and devotion has been eminently inspiring,'' the union said in a statement. No group has claimed responsibility for the abduction of McCarthy on April 17, 1986. The 33-year-old journalist for the London-based Worldwide Television news agency is one of 18 Westerners, including eight Americans, missing in Lebanon. Most are believed held hostage by pro-Iranian Moslem extremists. Longest held is Terry Anderson, the Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, abducted nearly five years ago from a Beirut street. McCarthy's father, Patrick, was expected to receive the medal on his son's behalf April 17 at a special service in St. Bride's Church in London's Fleet Street.
DOC.HEAD: Post Editor to Receive First Amendment Award
DOC.TEXT: New York Post Editor Jerry Nachman has been named winner of the Deadline Club's First Amendment Award, it was announced March 8. The award, to be presented March 28, recognizes longstanding commitment to freedom of the press. In its citation, the Deadline Club noted that Nachman has long supported courtroom access for cameras, which has since been granted on an experimental basis in New York. In 1989 he directed Post reporters to leave any public meeting from which any other member of the press was excluded _ an order that was inspired by the Bronx district attorney's decision to ban a Daily News reporter from a news conference. Nachman also offered legal support to the News. The award is presented annually by the club, which is the New York City chapter of the Society of Professional Journalists.

The Soviets' own Mike Wallace, TV muckraker Alexander Nevzorov, takes just ``600 Seconds,'' as his show is called, to duel with the powerful. One target, the Leningrad Communist boss, is being drummed out of the party because of a Nevzorov report on corruption, The Washington Post says ... Columnist and longtime TV panelist Jack Kilpatrick is moving to Charleston, S.C. As a result, the former Richmond (Va.) News Leader editor will be cutting back his appearances on the syndicated program ``Inside Washington.''

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ In a climate of lawlessness and bloodshed, opposition groups intent on forcing a swift transition to civilian rule called for a general strike today if Haiti's ousted ruler does not leave the country. A coalition of opposition leaders, keeping to a timetable set when Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril relinquished power on Saturday, said it would announce its choice for an interim president today. At least 24 people had been killed in the seven days of protests and clashes that have left this Caribbean nation leaderless and in turmoil. Most of the victims have been civilians slain by soldiers or police. ``The people have shown how much they love democracy by dying for it,'' the Rev. Bertrand Aristide, a Roman Catholic who has been a staunch critic of the government, said in an interview on Radio Antilles.

President Patricio Aylwin called for an end to violence and hate as he took over from long-ruling Gen. Augusto Pinochet, but street disturbances marred the celebration of democracy's rebirth. ``Chile doesn't want more violence, it doesn't want more war,'' Aylwin declared Sunday night from the balcony of the presidential palace after his inauguration earlier in the day. Thousands below him cheered the end of Pinochet's 16-year rule. ``This infant being born, this liberty we are reconquering, we have to take care of it,'' said the 71-year-old Aylwin. He said that would require ``knowing how to respect one another, never again having Chileans divided into enemies.''

New weapons to catch spies _ including rewards for reporting turncoat relatives and greater FBI access to tax records _ are being studied by a panel of private citizens working behind closed doors for the leaders of the Senate Intelligence Committee. Many of the ideas under discussion revolve around money _ now the most common motivation for those who deliver U.S. secrets to foreign governments. Without any public announcement, nine men usually at the beck and call of presidents were recruited last spring by Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., and William Cohen, R-Maine, chairman and vice chairman of the Intelligence Committee, for a unique effort to respond to ``the decade of the spy.'' Most of the nine are former White House, CIA, State or Justice officials who, Cohen said, not only are trusted by the nation's intelligence officers but also can rally political support if controversial new laws seem needed.

Get ready, America. Your ``no tax increase'' federal government is about to start collecting another new tax. As taxes go, this one isn't much. Most of the impact will be on businesses, at least at first. It could raise the price of a telephone by a dime but add $25 or so to the cost of recharging an automobile air conditioner. On April 1, the government will begin collecting this new tax, which is aimed at limiting use of chemicals _ chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs _ that are deemed to damage the ozone layer protecting the Earth. It has the dual task of raising about $4.3 billion for deficit reduction over the next five years.

The Tompkins Square Park band shell is filled each night with piles of ragged blankets. A passerby might hear sneezes and snores and realize there are people underneath, but certainly wouldn't know how many, or their sex, race or age. That is what census workers are being asked to find out _ without waking anyone up _ from 2 a.m. to 4 a.m. March 21 at parks and other outdoor sites where the homeless congregate. The survey is part of an unprecedented nationwide count in shelters, parks, subways, vacant buildings, doorways and bank-machine vestibules.
