In Tokyo, the 225-share Nikkei index, which rose 302.23 points Friday, dropped 624.89 points, or 1.84 percent, today to close at 33,368.23. Rorer surged 3{ to 66] on news that the French chemical company Rhone-Poulenc SA has signed a definitive agreement to merge its pharmaceutical business with Rorer. It ranked second on the Big Board's list of heavily traded stocks on volume of nearly 1.7 million shares. Among the active blue chips, General Motors rose | to 46~, Philip Morris added ~ to 38[, International Business Machines increased ] to 106~, American Telephone & Telegraph was up [ to 41[ and General Electric fell [ to 62{. Navistar topped the actives' list, unchanged at 4] as more than 1.9 million shares changed hands.

DOC.HEAD: Earnings Rise In 3rd-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: H.J. Heinz Co. said Monday its third-quarter profit rose 13.7 percent as its sales rose nearly 3 percent. For the quarter ended Jan. 31, the food maker reported net income of $117.1 million, or 44 cents a share, up from $103 million, or 39 cents a share in the year-ago period. Sales edged up to $1.41 billion from $1.37 billion in the same quarter a year ago. Higher sales came from acquisitions, price increases and volume, the company said. The sales increase was partially reduced by unfavorable exchange rates for some foreign sales, particularly in the United Kingdom and Venezuela, Heinz said. ``We are encouraged by the year-to-date performance and are optimistic that we will achieve a level of full year growth which is consistent with our historical trend,'' said Heinz Chairman Anthony J.F. O'Reilly. The earnings per share figures for the two periods reflect a two-for-one stock split in the form of a distribution of shares effective Sept. 27. For the first nine months of the year, Heinz earned $369 million, or $1.39 per share, up 14.2 percent from $323 million, or $1.23 per share. Sales for the first nine months of the year increased 5.3 percent to $4.39 billion from $4.17 billion mostly because of growth in the company's core products, including ketchup, Ore-Ida Potatoes and Weight Watchers' products and services.

Futures prices for soybeans were lower and grains were mixed at the close Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn rallied after opening lower on news of Friday's disappointing U.S. Agriculture Department supply-demand report, said Susan Leighty, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. She said corn has been supported by good feed demand for hogs and good export demand, especially from Asian countries. But weekend rainfall in U.S. growing areas and a forecast for more showers were depressing the futures market, said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. He said there also has been anxiety among traders over the economic direction the new president of Brazil will take in that important agriculture-exporting country. At the close, wheat was 1} cents to 4\ cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.81} a bushel; corn unchanged to { cent higher, with March at $2.44 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher, with March at $1.47\ a bushel; and soybeans were 4{ cents to 6 cents lower, with March at $5.82 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: EC Raises Aid To Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The European Community decided Monday to boost its aid to Eastern Europe but cut in half proposed increases for other developing countries. The EC's economics and finance ministers agreed on increasing the EC budget over the next three years by 300 million European currency units, or $357 million, to 500 million ECUs, or $595 million, for the benefit of Eastern European countries. The ministers also approved budgeting 820 million ECUs, or $976 million, in 1991 and 970 million ECUs, or $1.1 billion, in 1992 to the Eastern European countries. The European Commission had proposed slightly higher amounts. But the ministers slashed proposals by the Commission to boost aid to Mediterranean, Latin American, Asian and African countries. They approved increases in the EC budget for those countries of 310 million ECUs, or $369 million, for 1991 and 570 million ECUs, or $678 million , for 1992, well below the 800 million and 1 billion ECUs proposed. The revisions must be approved by the European Parliament before they can be formally written into the EC budget.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney Wins Engine Order
DOC.TEXT: Pratt & Whitney has won a $130 million order to supply engines for an Australian aviation firm, the company announced Monday. The engines will power 10 Boeing 757 aircraft on order by Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services. Pratt & Whitney said it will supply 20 engines and three spares. The order comes on the heels of a $900 million award last week tosupply engines to Singapore Airlines, a deal that could grow to $2.2 billion if the airline exercises options to buy more engines. The engines for Singapore Air are PW4000 engines for wide-body aircraft. The engines for Ansett are PW2000s, which are used to power the Air Force's C-17 transport and have captured 59 percent of the market for Boeing 757s, Pratt & Whitney said. William Raabe, a company vice president, said this was Ansett's first order for PW2000 engines and demonstrates a growing acceptance of the engine among Boeing 757 operators. Pratt & Whitney is a division of United Technologies Corp. of Hartford.
The stock market moved modestly higher in late trading today, helped by a recovery in bonds. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 4.96 at 2,688.29 with five minutes left to go.

DOC.HEAD: Pharmaceutical Companies Announce Agreement On Merger
DOC.TEXT: Rorer Group Inc. and France's Rhone-Poulenc SA have signed a $1.7 billion agreement to create one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, the companies jointly announced Monday. The agreement would combine the surbuban Philadelphia-based Rorer with the Paris-based Rhone-Poulenc's human pharmaceutical operations in a new firm called Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. The merger is the latest example of consolidation in the drug industry and is aimed at lowering research costs and gaining global markets. Last year, SmithKline Beckman Corp. of Philadelphia merged with Britain's Beecham Group PLC to form SmithKline Beecham, and Bristol-Myers Co. of New York acquired Squibb Corp. of Princeton, N.J. to form Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. The latest transaction will encompass several stages, with Rhone-Poulenc initially offering $78 per share for 50.1 percent of Rorer's 21.6 million shares, a cost of about $842 million. A tender offer at that price values the entire company at $1.685 billion. Following the tender offer Rhone-Poulenc will transfer its pharmaceuticals business and issue contingent value rights to Rorer, with the number corresponding to non-tendered Rorer shares. In exchange, Rorer will take on $265 million of Rhone-Poulenc debt and acquire the French group's existing U.S. pharmaceutical subsidiary for $20 million. Rorer also will create 24 million new shares, giving Rhone-Poulenc 68 percent of Rorer's share capital comprising some 67.3 million shares. Rhone-Poulenc expects to acquire the 68 percent of Rorer by June 1990. The tender offer will begin Friday, Rhone-Poulenc said. The companies had announced their intentions to merge earlier this year. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Rorer was the most active issue, rising $3 a share to $65.87{ on volume of nearly 2.3 million shares. The agreement does not include other portions of the French company's healh business, such as serums and vaccines, veterinary medicines, animal nutrition and Rhone-Poulenc's interest in Roussel Uclaf SA. ``Through Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, we will achieve our mission of becoming a top 10 research-based pharmaceutical company,'' said Robert E. Cawthorn, chairman, president, and chief executive officer of Rorer. Cawthorn has been named to the same positions in the new company, which will be based in Fort Washington. The company expects to have annual sales exceeding $3 billion, he said. The human pharmaceutical business of Rhone-Poulenc had sales of $1.9 billion in 1989, while Rorer had $1.2 billion, the companies said. Analyst Ron Nordmann of PaineWebber Group Inc. said it is too early to make any judgments on the new company. ``In terms of the details, the company's potential earning power is still up in the air,'' he said. ``We need to get more numbers on the company before we are able to do any earnings assessment.'' Rorer is best known for its Maalox antacid. Rhone-Poulenc is in the top 10 in the European pharmaceutical market but has no direct marketing in the United States or Japan. ``That French company has no presence in the U.S., then overnight, they are in,'' said analyst Michael Martorelli of Janney Montgomery Scott Inc. in Philadelphia. ``And Rorer gets the French company's drugs and adds somebody else's research to it own.'' He said the merger kills any takeover rumors swirling around Rorer. ``Now, with a large partner, they'll no longer be subject to the rumors,'' he said. ``Management can stop worrying about that. It seemed like everytime they turned around there was another takeover rumor or question.''

The stock market drifted to a modestly higher close today in an uneventful session. Stability in the bond market after a selloff Friday benefited stocks. Interest rate worries continued to be a drag on Wall Street while trading was sluggish ahead of potentially market-moving economic reports due later in the week. Michael Metz of Oppenheimer & Co. cited speculation that the Federal Reserve will be forced to tighten its credit policy and push interest rates higher in an effort to ward off inflation as a concern among traders. But he said in his view the fears are unwarranted because economic growth remains weak despite an unexpectedly strong employment report on Friday. ``I think these fears are unjustified. I think we definitely have a slowdown here. Everything points to a very sluggish 1990 and 1991,'' Metz said. Among the statistics to be released this week are the February retail sales report on Tuesday and February reports on wholesale prices, housing starts and industrial production on Friday.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T To Share Key Semiconductor Ingredient Under Sematech
DOC.TEXT: AT&T signed an agreement Monday to share a key ingredient used to make advanced semiconductors under the auspices of Sematech, the consortium of computer chip makers formed to boost U.S. semiconductor competitiveness. Under the agreement, American Telephone & Telegraph Co. will allow a division of Olin Corp. to make and sell a chemical used to etch extremely detailed electronic circuitry on chips. The chemical, called ``deep UV resist,'' allows chip designers to pack a greater number of circuits on chips than current technologies. In making chips, circuitry is etched on silicon wafers using a light-sensitive chemical, or resist, and a ``mask,'' whose function is similar to that of a negative in photography. AT&T Bell Laboratories has invented a version of the chemical that is used with ultraviolet light instead of the visible light currently used. However, Olin will not be the first company to market ultraviolet-based resist. Shipley Co. Inc. of Newton, Mass., has been selling ultraviolet resist for several years, and it is being used by chip makers to test the new technology, said Eric Alling, a marketing manager for the company. ``We're very encouraged AT&T has elected to expand the viabilty of deep UV technology,'' Alling said. The UV resist can produce highly complex computer chips with circuits as thin as 0.3 micrometers, or about 400 times smaller than a human hair, AT&T said. ``Such dimensions are essential for packing more processing power, speed and memory into the chips of the future,'' said Arno Penzias, vice president of research for Bell Labs. Circuitry on most chips today is 1 to 1.2 microns wide, while it reaches 0.8 microns in more advanced chips. AT&T said it also is working on two other advanced technologies for making even more complex computer chips: X-ray lithography and electron-beam techniques. Japanese chip makers are believed to be concentrating on ultraviolet lithography as the next generation of technology, while also studying the X-ray technique. European makers are actively exploring X-rays, industry analysts said. ``Perhaps what this may indicate is that the use of X-ray techniques may be further down the road than the Japanese thought,'' analyst Jay Ritter of Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago said of the AT&T pact. Adopting either technique would require an enormous investment in new chip manufacturing equipment, but the X-ray technology would be more costly than the ultraviolet technique, said Mark FitzGerald, an analyst with Dataquest Inc. of San Jose, Calif. The research firm believes ultraviolet etching will be used for the next generation of semiconductors. Sematech officials hailed the AT&T agreement. ``The deep UV resist is the future in semiconductor manufacturing, and will produce semiconductors that compete in the global market in terms of performance and price,'' said Robert Noyce, president and chief executive of the consortium. Sematech was founded by 14 U.S. semiconductor manufacturers, including AT&T, under the sponsorship of the U.S. government, which splits the cost of the consortium with the companies.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: on Friday.
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 3.38 to 2,686.71. Advancing issues narrowly outnumbered by less than 10 to 9 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 751 up, 703 down and 496 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 114.79 million shares, against 150.41 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index edged up 0.33 to 186.51. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 0.72 to 361.87.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Recalls About 153,000 Large Cars
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. on Monday recalled about 153,000 of its 1989- and 1990-model large cars because of potential problems with their automatic transmissions. The company said the transmissions should be inspected for possible miscalibration, which could result in the loss of overdrive gears. Affected by the recall were about 89,500 1989-model Ford Crown Victoria and Mercury Grand Marquis cars, about 47,700 1989 Lincoln Town Cars, about 13,300 1990 Crown Victorias and Grand Marquis and about 2,500 1990 Town Cars. Owners will be notified by mail and the repair work will be performed free of charge.

DOC.HEAD: National Intergroup Blasts Liquidation Plan
DOC.TEXT: National Intergroup Inc. criticized a dissident investor group's plan to liquidate the company, saying it is ``sketchy, ill-defined and ill-conceived.'' The Pittsburgh-based distribution company sent a strongly worded letter to shareholders over the weekend in response to Centaur Partners' efforts to induce them to change key parts of the company's bylaws. All 12 National Intergroup directors signed the letter. Centaur cannot seek control of the board of directors at July's annual meeting unless shareholders first agree to increase the board's size to 15. It must get 80 percent of the stockholders to agree to the change, according to a Delaware court ruling made last week. Centaur is the company's largest stockholder with 16.5 percent of outstanding shares. It began its efforts to change the bylaws last week, saying it wanted to elect a new board that would liquidate the company for the benefit of shareholders. The Centaur group, National Intergroup says, ``consists of takeover artists who have no proven track record in running public companies.'' It also attacked Centaur's plan as a scheme to enrich the group's investment bankers, who stand to make $2.7 million up front for a three-year contract and the promise of more fees later when assets are sold. Centaur has contended it could fetch $29.34 per share, and perhaps several dollars more, by selling National Intergroup in pieces. The company expressed doubt Centaur could get those proceeds in a ``fire sale.'' In trading Monday on the New York Stock Exchange, National Intergroup rose 25 cents a share to $16.75. Centaur is best known for its unsuccessful hostile takeover bid last year for Pennwalt Corp., a Philadelphia-based chemicals and pharmaceuticals concern.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.HEAD: Stock Market Ends Almost Even in Slow Trading
DOC.TEXT: The stock market meandered to a modestly higher close Monday in the slowest session of the year. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which drifted in a narrow range throughout the session, eked out a gain of 3.38 points to end at 2,686.71. Advancing issues outnumbered declining ones by a slim margin of less than 10 to 9 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 752 up, 697 down and 514 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board eased to 114.79 million shares from 150.41 million on Friday. It was the lowest volume since Dec. 26 when 77.61 million shares changed hands. Previously, the smallest number of shares traded this year had been 118.39 million on Feb. 12. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 139.74 million shares. Strength in the dollar and greater stability in the bond market after a selloff Friday benefited stocks. Interest rate worries, however, continued to be a drag on Wall Street while many investors stayed on the sidelines awaiting potentially market-moving economic reports due later this week. Michael Metz of Oppenheimer & Co. cited speculation that the Federal Reserve will be forced to tighten its credit policy and push interest rates higher in an effort to ward off inflation as a concern among traders. But he said in his view the fears are unfounded because economic growth remains weak despite an unexpectedly strong employment report on Friday. ``I think these fears are unjustified. I think we definitely have a slowdown here. Everything points to a very sluggish 1990 and 1991,'' Metz said. Among the statistics to be released this week are the February retail sales report on Tuesday and February reports on wholesale prices, housing starts and industrial production on Friday. Rorer jumped 3 to 65~ on news that the French chemical company Rhone-Poulenc SA has signed a definitive agreement to merge its pharmaceutical business with Rorer. It led the Big Board's list of heavily traded stocks on turnover of more than 2.27 million shares. Among the active blue chips, International Business Machines increased 1\ to 107}, Philip Morris rose } to 38, General Motors moved ahead by } to 47 and American Telephone & Telegraph added [ to 41[. One loser among the active blue chips was General Electric, which ended \ lower at 62]. Navistar was the second most heavily traded Big Board issue as nearly 2.1 million shares changed hands. It closed unchanged at 4]. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $5.41 billion, or 0.17 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.33 to 186.51. Standard & Poor's industrial index added 0.90 to 391.25, and S&P's 500-stock composite index finished up 0.74 at 338.67. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 0.20 to 436.56. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.87, up 0.72.

DOC.HEAD: Class Action Suit Filed Against Southeast Food Chain
DOC.TEXT: A former Food Lion employee filed a federal class action lawsuit against the fast-growing supermarket chain Monday, alleging the company has illegally denied workers retirement and health benefits. Company officials said the benefit plans are administered according to law and called the suit an attempt by the United Food and Commercial Workers Union to pressure the company into recognizing the union. The company is non-union. ``The union has a history of creating these lawsuits ... and the most mileage they get out of it is in media coverage that they have filed it,'' said Food Lion Inc. spokesman Mike Mozingo in a telephone interview from the company's Salisbury, N.C., headquarters. Food Lion has 675 stores in 10 states from Delaware to Florida, including 81 in South Carolina. The lawsuit, filed by former employee Rickey Bryant of West Columbia, alleges the company used a scheme to terminate employees to prevent them from receiving full or partial profit-sharing benefits _ a program which serves as the company's retirement plan. In addition, it alleges employees are unlawfully discharged on the grounds of ``gross misconduct'' so the company does not have to continue providing health benefits for employees and their families. The suit said those who have the most to gain when a non-vested worker leaves and forfeits profit sharing ``are the longest-serving and highest-paid employees of the company.'' The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Charleston, claims Bryant's termination in 1988 after nine years with the company was a pretext to deny him 55 percent of the approximately $67,000 he had in profit sharing. As of December 1987 the profit-sharing plan had 20,907 active participants and $192 million in assets. But only 81 people were fully vested and only 2,956 were partially vested, the suit said. ``Because of the high turnover rate at Food Lion, there are many thousands of employees who are or have been participants in the plan and who will derive no benefit,'' the suit charges. Among the damages the lawsuit is seeking from Food Lion are Bryant's reinstatement and restoration of back pay and lost health and profit-sharing plan for Bryant and other defendants. Nicholas Clark, the assistant general counsel for the United Food and Commercial Workers International who drafted the lawsuit, said the union came to Bryant's aid even though Food Lion is a non-union company. He said the class action lawsuit could potentially involve thousands of former employees and millions of dollars in benefits. ``The suit has much more significance than just Food Lion,'' Clark added. He said it could affect any employer with a high turnover and who structures profit sharing so workers do not get their benefits. Mozingo said he could not comment on the specifics of the complaint because he had not seen a copy of the lawsuit. More than 21,000 of the chain's 42,000 employees are fully or partially vested in the profit sharing plan. Ten years ago, the chain _ which is opening over 100 stores annually _ employed only 4,849 workers. ``A lot of people working for Food Lion have not been here that long because we simply didn't have that many stores open,'' Mozingo said. He said the union has tried unsuccessfully to organize the chain and ``they have not been able to get to first base with our employees.'' ``They look at our 40,000 employees and see these people aren't sending in dues every month,'' Mozingo said. ``They look to discredit the company and stop our growth.''

DOC.HEAD: MCA Sells Money-Losing Toy Company
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. said Monday it would sell its unprofitable LJN Toys Ltd. unit to Acclaim Entertainment Inc. in a deal giving MCA a stake in Acclaim, a publisher and distributor of home entertainment products. The purchase amount, to be made up of a combination of cash and Acclaim common stock, was not disclosed. MCA, the Universal City-based entertainment company, announced in January it would sell LJN, which MCA acquired for about $66 million in 1985. LJN, which makes video game cartridges, wireless remote controllers and hand-held electronic games, had posted losses for the past three years, MCA said.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Continue Decline
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices fell Monday amid concern over a high OPEC oil production estimate and unseasonably warm weather in Europe and the eastern United States. It was the fifth straight day of declines in the markets for crude oil, heating oil and gasoline. The contract for April delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the key grade of U.S. crude oil, fell 19 cents to $20.24 a 42-gallon barrel after declining $1.05 in the previous four trading sessions. Subsequent contract months fell as much as 32 cents a gallon Monday. Andrew Lebow, an energy market analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said traders were unsettled by a report that production by the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may have soared in February. The report by the Middle East Economic Survey said that OPEC production may have hit 24 million barrels a day last month, 800,000 to 1 million barrels higher than estimated by the International Energy Agency, Lebow said. ``The lack of interest in crude is putting a lot of selling pressure on the market,'' said John Hill of Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. In addition, unseasonably warm temperatures in Europe and the United States weakened demand for home heating oil, analysts said. In addition, gasoline futures prices were down because of supply concerns with a surplus of gasoline in New York harbor. The contract for April delivery of home heating oil fell 0.33 cents to 53.86 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after falling 1.48 cents on Friday. The contract has lost 4.43 cents since last Tuesday. Subsequent contract months also declined Monday, with May down 0.43 cent. The April contract for unleaded regular gasoline fell 0.66 cent to 54.33 cents a gallon after a 1.15 cent loss on Friday and a drop of 4.97 cents since last Tuesday. Later contracts declined by up to 0.95 cent a gallon Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises; Gold Ends Flat to Lower
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major currencies Monday, reaching its highest level in 2{ years against the Japanese yen in Tokyo. Gold prices finished unchanged to slightly lower in New York trading after rising overseas. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $399.25 a troy ounce, down from $399.75 late Friday. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery settled unchanged at $399.80 a troy ounce. The dollar rose despite reported intervention by the Federal Reserve to sell the U.S. currency to stem its advance. Foreign-exchange traders said there was moderate buying of dollars in the wake of Friday's buoyant U.S. employment figures which showed more job growth than had been expected. ``It was just a slow sort of bid to the dollar,'' said Jeff Mondschein, manager of foreign exchange at Continental Illinois National Bank & Trust Co. in Chicago. The dollar would have risen more, dealers said, but for anxiety that the West German central bank would intervene if the exchange rate rose much above 1.71 marks. The dollar closed at 1.7110 West German marks in Europe, up from 1.7040 marks late Friday. By the end of trading in New York, the dollar had edged up to 1.7135 marks from 1.7025 marks late Friday. In Tokyo, where the business days ends as Europe's begins, the dollar climbed to 152.00 yen, its highest level there since it reached 152.35 yen on July 22, 1987. In London, the dollar closed at 152.36 yen, up from 151.32 yen on Friday. In New York trading, the dollar extended its advance to 152.63 yen, up from 151.27 yen late Friday. The U.S. currency also gained against the British pound. The pound fell to $1.6100 in London, down from Friday's $1.6183. That was the pound's lowest close against the dollar since Jan. 3, when it stood at $1.6080. The pound had traded as high as $1.7145 on Feb. 22. Later, in New York, a pound fetched $1.6115, down from $1.6170 late Friday. On Friday, the pound lost nearly 2.5 cents amid anxiety over recent demonstrations against a new tax imposed by city halls across Britain. In addition, opinion polls show the popularity of the Conservative government and of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is at an all-time low as inflation rises and interest rates remain high. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.5258 Swiss francs, up from 1.5095; 5.7915 French francs, up from 5.7560; 1,265.50 Italian lire, up from 1,257.50; and 1.1787 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1804. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Friday, included: 1.5235 Swiss francs, up from 1.5115; 5.7800 French francs, up from 5.7615; 1.9190 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9150; 1,263.75 Italian lire, up from 1,258.75; and 1.1787 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1792. Gold bullion dealers said trading in Europe was quiet. Gold was bid at $400.65 a troy ounce late in London, up from $399.05 on Friday. The late bid in Zurich, Switzerland, was $401.10 an ounce, up from $399.50. Earlier in Hong Kong gold closed at $400.55 an ounce, down from $400.65. Silver bullion traded late in London at a bid of $5.13 a troy ounce, up from $5.11. On New York's Comex, silver for current delivery settled at $5.042 a troy ounce, down from $5.095 late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Pork Bellies Limit Up Again
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices for frozen pork bellies rose sharply Monday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for the fourth time in five sessions. On other markets, grains were mixed, while precious metals and energy products slid lower. ``Bellies are king again,'' said analyst Paul Hare of Linnco Futures Inc. in Chicago. He attributed the rally to a technical adjustment following a slump Friday. Contracts for delivery of pork bellies in March, May, July and August rose the daily limit of 2 cents. Frozen pork bellies settled 1.42 cents to 2.00 cents higher, with March at 52.95 cents a pound. Friday's decline followed three straight higher sessions. Cattle futures were mainly higher, responding to an upward trend in the cash market, said analyst Phil Stanley of ADM Investor Services. Cattle settled .15 cent lower to .40 cent higher, with the contract for delivery in April at 78.02 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent lower to .37 cent higher, with March at 82.47 cents a pound; and live hogs were unchanged to .90 cent higher, with April at 52.82 cents a pound. Futures prices for soybeans were lower and grains mixed at the close Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn rallied after opening lower on news of Friday's disappointing U.S. Agriculture Department supply-demand report, said Susan Leighty, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. She said corn has been supported by good feed demand for hogs and good export demand, especially from Asian countries. But weekend rainfall in U.S. growing areas and a forecast for more showers were depressing the futures market, said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in Chicago. He also said there has been anxiety among traders over the economic direction that will be taken by the new president of Brazil, a major agricultural exporter. Wheat settled 1\ cents lower to { cent higher, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.83{ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents to 3} cents higher, with March at $2.47 a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents higher, with March at $1.47\ a bushel; and soybeans were 2} cents to 5\ cents lower, with March at $5.82} a bushel. Energy futures prices slumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concern over a high OPEC oil production estimate and unseasonably warm weather in Europe and the eastern United States. Andrew Lebow, an energy market analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said traders were unsettled by a report that production by the 13 Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may have soared in February. The report by the Middle East Economic Survey said that OPEC production may have hit 24 million barrels a day last month, 800,000 to 1 million barrels higher than estimated by the International Energy Agency, Lebow said. Markets for heating oil and gasoline also were lower. Crude oil settled 19 cents to 32 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in April at $20.24 a barrel; heating oil was .12 cent to .43 cent lower, with April at 53.53 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was .10 cent to .95 cent lower, with April at 54.33 cents a gallon. Coffee futures recovered from steep declines in early trading on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, but still finished much lower. A brand new contract for delivery in July 1991 dropped 3.37 cents in its first session. Traders said they were still nervous over news that Brazil exporters were asking the government to release its stocks to fill export demands. Coffee settled .60 cent to 3.37 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at 93.25 cents a pound. Precious metals futures were mostly lower on New York's Commodity Exchange. A strengthened U.S. dollar depressed gold, while silver futures fell under the pressure of increased Comex warehouse stocks, according to analysts. Gold settled 10 cents higher to 50 cents lower, with the contract for delivery in March at $399.80 a troy ounce. Silver was 5.3 cents to 6 cents lower, with March at $5.04 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Court Grants Delay in Warner, Schiebel Cases
DOC.TEXT: The Ohio Supreme Court on Monday granted a delay in arguments in the state's appeal from two criminal convictions stemming from the collapse of Home State Savings Bank. The court said oral arguments involving former Home State owner Marvin Warner and a former president of the thrift, David Schiebel, will be rescheduled no later than June 6 if the state and the defendants' lawyers meet a pre-hearing briefing schedule. Arguments had been scheduled for March 27, but special prosecutor Lawrence Kane Jr. of Cincinnati is requesting the delay pending disposition of some other matters in the case, Attorney General Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr. said. Cincinnati-based Home State collapsed on March 8, 1985, four days after ESM Government Securities Inc. of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was declared insolvent. Home State lost $144 million through its securities transactions with ESM. The failure of Home State led to Ohio's savings and loan industry crisis of that year. Warner, Schiebel and another former Home State president, Burton Bongard, were convicted on March 2, 1987 of state charges related to Home State's collapse. Warner was convicted of nine felonies _ six counts of misapplying about $14 million in bank money through unauthorized payments to ESM and three counts of securities violations. He was acquitted of 76 other counts. Schiebel was found guilty of three securities violations, and Bongard was convicted of 82 counts of misapplication and unauthorized transfer of funds. Warner had been sentenced to 3{ years in prison and fined $22 million, and Schiebel was sentenced to six months. Both are free on bond pending their appeals. Bongard later pleaded guilty to loan violations and received a 4{-year prison sentence. He was released from prison in July 1989 on probation. A three-judge panel of the 1st Ohio District Court of Appeals in Cincinnati overturned the convictions of Warner and Schiebel on Nov. 15, 1989. Last week, Celebrezze defended the costs of the special prosecutor _ about $5.9 million so far _ by saying he helped the state recover $135 million it spent to protect depositors and stablize the Ohio thrift industry in the wake of Home State's collaspe.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Introduces Imaging System for Banks
DOC.TEXT: IBM on Monday introduced a computer system for banks that caputures electronic images of checks and electronically ``reads'' and records their amount. The system should greatly reduce the amount of time and money spent by banks in manually entering into computers the amount of checks and in storing and collating the checks, International Business Machines Corp. said. IBM also said banks could improve customer service by providing images of actual checks along with their customers' monthly statements. The system, developed in cooperation with six major banks, employs imaging scanners that can take an electronic picture of checks at up to 2,400 checks per minute. The system employs ``compression'' technology that reduces the amount of data that must be stored to capture an image of a check or other document. Compression technology is needed to allow existing computer equipment to handle the vast amount of data needed to store an image, as opposed to storing data such as figures. The equipment can electronically read the amount of money a check is written for _ either hand printed or typewritten _ in about half the cases, IBM said. When the equipment is unsure of a figure, it will display an image of the check on a screen for a bank employee to verify the figure or manually enter it into the computer. IBM's main competitor in the bank check imaging market is Unisys Corp., said Nick Allen, an analyst with Gartner Group Inc., a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn. He said the market for the equipment should be promising as banks work to limit the labor involved in processing checks. ``We've only recently reached the processing power capability to do this kind of thing,'' he said. ``Check processing of banks already is a major market for IBM,'' he added. ``What this does is stimulate demand for hardware.''

DOC.HEAD: Nortek Says It Has Settled with SEC
DOC.TEXT: Nortek Inc. has reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over a dispute involving a four-day delay in filing a form with the government disclosing its investment in another company. Nortek said it agreed to a consent decree under which it will pay $503,000 into a fund to reimburse any Rexham Corp. stockholders who may have lost money as a result of the delay in notifying the SEC of its investment. The incident occurred more than three years ago. Richard J. Harris, Nortek vice president and treasurer, said his company purchased more than 5 percent of the outstanding shares of Rexham in 1986. The SEC said Nortek delayed by four days filing a form that detailed the purchase, as is required when a company or individual buys more than 5 percent of another company. Nortek filed an ``untimely, false and misleading'' statement of its Rexham investment, said Mary McCue of the SEC. Nortek had purchased 62,000 shares of Rexham stock in 1986 but a form the company filed with the SEC ``did not disclose properly Nortek's position and their intent regarding Rexham,'' Ms. McCue said. Nortek sold its investments in Rexham of Pineville, N.C., in 1987, Harris said. Nortek neither admitted nor denied that it had broken any laws or regulations as a result of its Rexham investment, he said. It agreed to the settlement to close the case and avoid further legal expenses, he said. Under the terms of the judgment, filed in federal court Monday, any Rexham stockholders who sold shares during the four-day period and who lost money can seek repayment through the fund Nortek is establishing. Any money that is not claimed will revert to the U.S. Treasury. ``Nortek filed its consent to a proposed judgment in order to bring an end to the continuous drain on management time and to avoid incurring additional legal fees,'' said Ralph R. Pappito, chairman and chief executive officer. ``We are pleased to put this bit of our history behind us.'' Harris said he did not know how much in interest will be paid by Nortek. Nortek manufactures and markets residential and commercial building products and commercial ventilating and air conditioning systems. Its stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Sweeping Reforms Needed in Stock Markets
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators should give new thought to sweeping changes in U.S. stock markets, including moving trading from action-packed exchange floors to flickering computer screens, a congressional report said Monday. Specifically, the General Accounting Office, Congress' auditing and investigative agency, said the Securities and Exchange Commission should consider a proposal to repeal a New York Stock Exchange rule requiring trades of most listed stocks to be executed on the exchange floor. A rule that forbids after-hours trading of listed stocks, in effect forcing such trading to foreign exchanges, also should be reviewed, the report said. Trading rules were eased in 1979 to permit off-floor trading of newly listed stocks. But, a decade later, most stocks still were initially listed before 1979. Trades of 89 of the New York Stock Exchange's 100 most active shares still must be routed through the exchange floor. The GAO, noting the rapid evolution of computer and communications technology, said it is time for the SEC to reconsider rules banning most off-floor trading. The SEC disagreed, saying its 1979 study of off-floor trading was complex and that it would not dismantle the floor system until market participants determine the resulting new system would be better than the old method. Critics contend that the current structure of the market, including the use of trading floors and ``specialist'' brokers who make a market in the stock, restricts price competition. Supporters of the current system, however, argue that a central location for trading preserves the benefits of an auction market. The SEC agreed that a review of after-hours trading was in order even though, in 1986, the commission rejected a recommendation from it staff that the agency ask the New York Stock Exchange to consider permitting after-hours trading. ``As a result ... exchange member brokers and dealers who wish to trade exchange-listed stocks when U.S. markets are closed must do so in foreign markets,'' the GAO said. The report, dated Monday, was delivered to the Senate Banking Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Says All Its Consumer Packaging Materials Now Biodegradable
DOC.TEXT: AT&T announced Monday that all of its newly manufactured telephones and answering machines will be packed in 100 percent biodegradable material, a move expected to reduce the company's distribution and waste disposal costs. The new packaging, which uses corrugated cardboard in place of bulkier foam to protect the company's line of small consumer products, will make its packaged products about one quarter smaller than their predecessors, said Lee Blitch, AT&T's director of advertising and packaging. He also said the packaging will disintegrate easily in landfills. ``We will save on shipping and (waste) hauling costs because everything will be 25 to 30 percent smaller,'' he said. ``This is also welcome by retailers, who will be able to stock more of the smaller products on their shelves.'' The new packaging standards apply only to AT&T's line of small consumer products and will not affect such large items as personal computers, office switchboard systems and other large components, said AT&T spokeswoman Lynn Newman. Last year, the company announced it had eliminated all sources of chloroflourocarbons, known as CFCs, from its packaging materials. CFCs, contained in such materials as styrofoam and aerosol propellants, are blamed for the deterioration of the earth's protective ozone layer. The New York-based company, which reported $36.1 billion in revenues for 1989, maintains a team of environmental engineers who work with its Bell Laboratories subsidiary to improve packaging techniques, eliminate hazardous materials and encourage recycling, Ms. Newman said. The changes were made, she said, because the old foam inserts that protected cordless and corded telephones and answering machines were difficult to collapse and did not disintegrate in landfills. She said information on specific cost savings expected would not be released because the company did not want to give competitors any hint of the sales performance of their telephone and answering machine lines.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Investment in U.S. Real Estate Down 11 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Japanese purchases of U.S. real estate fell 10.7 percent in 1989, with investment shifting from office buildings to hotels and resort properties, a report Monday said. Japanese spent $14.8 billion on U.S. real estate last year, compared with $16.5 billion in 1988, according to a study by the real estate accounting firm Kenneth Leventhal & Co. Purchases of office properties fell about 60 percent to $3.33 billion in 1989 from $8.31 billion the previous year. Investment in hotel-resort properties rose to $4.16 billion last year from $3.58 billion in 1988, a 16 percent increase. Overall, offices remain the favorite target of Japanese investors, said Jack Barthell, a Leventhal partner. Of the total $57.7 billion that the firm's computer data base shows as invested in U.S. real estate, 44 percent is in offices. Japanese appear to be backing away from purchases of ``trophy properties'' such as Rockefeller Center, the study found. Mitsubishi Estate Co. last year announced it was spending $846 million for a controlling interest in the company that owns Rockefeller Center, the Manhattan office and cultural complex. The study also noted that despite publicity generated by such purchases, Japanese still own just 2 percent of U.S. commercial real estate, far less than European investors. California was the leading state for the second year in a row, with 36 percent of the 1989 investment. Forty percent of the purchases were concentrated in the greater Los Angeles area. Hawaii was second and New York third, but interest among Japanese buyers in properties there appears to be waning. ``Most of the attractive properties have already been acquired, and the cost of acquisitions in Manhattan may cause investors to divert funds to other markets,'' Barthell said. The top three states accounted for 81 percent of the Japanese investment. Among other findings, investment in residential property jumped to 15 percent, triple the amount invested in 1988. Nearly two-thirds of that was in California and 28 percent in Hawaii. Leventhal said the size of Japanese deals is getting smaller as investment moves into smaller American cities, and that Japan's largest institutional investors are turning attention to Europe leading up to economic unification in 1992. Leventhal defines investment as both equity investment and convertible debt secured by U.S. real estate.

DOC.HEAD: Toyota Plans Huge Proving Ground in Arizona
DOC.TEXT: Toyota Motor Corp. plans to put desert heat to work testing the endurance of its cars and trucks, the company said Monday. Toyota, Japan's largest automaker, announced plans for a 12,000-acre proving ground about 45 miles northwest of here. Toyota will be the seventh company to test vehicles on a private test track in Arizona, but it will have the largest facility when construction ends sometime in 1993. The largest test track in the state now is the 5,000-acre General Motors Desert Proving Grounds southeast of Mesa, the Arizona Economic Council said. Nissan, Chrysler, Ford, Jaguar, Volvo and Volkswagen also operate proving grounds in Arizona. Chrysler's track is near Wickenburg and will be closest to the Toyota facility, which will be about 16 miles south of Wickenburg. Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc., the company's California-based U.S. marketing arm, said in a news release it had filed papers with Maricopa County to build the complex. Construction is to begin next year with the complex becoming operational in 1993, if land purchases and permit applications proceed as expected, said Barbara DeMichele, a spokeswoman for B.J. Communications of Phoenix. The complex will include a 10-mile, high-speed oval where vehicles will reach speeds of 160 mph, other shorter tracks with a variety of road conditions, and an airstrip for flying in test cars and trucks, she said in a prepared statement. ``Our requirements call for a site that offers the high temperature conditions we'll need for testing and at the same time provide sufficient space and even terrain to allow for course construction,'' DeMichele said. She said the vehicles would be primarily destined for the U.S. market. Toyota chose the site near Wickenburg from among 10 on a list developed from a national search begun in 1988, said Scott Eubanks of the economic council. Eubanks said the state offered no economic incentives. ``We are especially pleased because we were able to attract Toyota on our merits alone,'' he said. Toyota officials declined to estimate the cost of the track or the land acquisition. The Arizona Republic reported last month that Toyota would pay $47.6 million for 14,000 acres of land. It attributed the report to a source close to the negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Union Accuses Wheeling-Pittsburgh of Stalling Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: United Steelworkers negotiators on Monday accused Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp. of using pressure tactics to convince workers currently engaged in collective bargaining to accept a substandard labor agreement. The union also said the company, which for five years has been under bankruptcy court protection, is stalling contract talks and U.S. Bankruptcy Court proceedings. ``The company's trying to brainwash our members,'' said Andrew ``Lefty'' Palm, chairman of a union committee negotiating with Wheeling-Pittsburgh. In a statement late Monday, Wheeling-Pittsburgh denied the charges and called on the union to back up its allegations in court Thursday. The company said its pay offer of more than $5 an hour over three years is generous. The offer includes a $2-an-hour pay raise, a $3,000 signing bonus and a $4,500 settlement, the company said. At an earlier news conference at union headquarters, Palm said Wheeling-Pittsburgh executives have said they will delay bankruptcy filings until the union agrees to a new contract. ``They have threatened me personally and they have threatened people on this committee that they ... will not file a reorganization plan until they get a labor agreement,'' Palm said. That action defies a court order, he added. Union officials said the company has committed a number of questionable actions in connection with the negotiations, including distributing the company's contract proposal at plants and implying that management might liquidate the company. Also, the union said, company officials have talked with union members one-on-one and in small groups to agitate them and make them angry at the union's leadership. ``They're at them every day,'' Palm said. He said the company is unwilling to give workers a fair pay increase, claiming its financial troubles make it impossible. He challenged that assertion by presenting figures showing that Wheeling-Pittsburgh is making a larger operating profit than another steelmaker in bankruptcy proceedings, LTV Inc. The union data show LTV will pay a $1-an-hour average raise starting next year while Wheeling-Pittsburgh is offering an increase of only 25 cents an hour. Wheeling-Pittsburgh said it and its creditors believe recovery ``would be difficult, if not impossible'' if the union's demands are met. Negotiations with Wheeling-Pittsburgh began in October but broke down several weeks ago, said union negotiator Jim Bowen. Several groups of creditors are vying for control of the company once it comes out of bankruptcy protection but none has emerged as a leader, which complicates the talks, he said. ``It's pretty hard to negotiate with a ghost,'' Bowen said. Wheeling-Pittsburgh employs about 5,500 steelworkers at plants in West Virginia, Ohio and western Pennsylvania. Separately Monday, the steelworkers union announced that its international president, Lynn R. Williams, has asked steel, oil and gas giant USX Corp. to furnish the union with copies of any agreement it has reached with financier Carl Icahn. Icahn and USX last week announced that Icahn's proposal to spin off USX's steel division will be voted on at the company's annual meeting in May. The company said it opposes the idea but will give ``due consideration'' to the outcome of the vote. In a statement, Williams said the spin-off proposal ``raises many questions affecting our members employed by USX, our collective bargaining relationship and the administration of the many collective bargaining agreements between USX and our union.'' Union spokesman Dick Fontana said Williams made his request Friday, a day after USX and Icahn announced the agreement. Fontana said no response had been received from the company.

DOC.HEAD: Sale of Union Pacific Real Estate Unit Canceled
DOC.TEXT: Union Pacific Corp. on Monday said the $532 million sale of its real estate unit for lack of financing. Union Pacific, parent of the Omaha-based Union Pacific Railroad, forged the deal in December with the Koll Co., a real estate development firm based in Newport Beach, Calif. ``They were unable to come up with the financing within the required period of time,'' spokesman Marvin Zim said from Union Pacific's headquarters in Bethlehem, Pa. The financing deadline expired Friday. A spokeswoman for Koll said the company did obtain financing, ``but Union Pacific didn't feel it was satisfactory.'' She declined to elaborate. Koll planned to acquire all of the assets of Union Pacific Realty, a division that managed land holdings for the parent corporation, including about 15,000 acres of property and 30 buildings, mostly in the western United States. Zim said Dallas-based Union Pacific Realty is still for sale. Union Pacific authorized the sale of the real estate division last April, saying it wanted to focus on its transportation operations.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines Adds Flights, Buys Planes
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines Inc. said Monday it would add 39 domestic flights beginning next month, including two cross-country flights from Newark to Los Angeles. American also exercised options to buy seven MD-11 jumbo jets from McDonnell Douglas Corp. The move gives American 15 firm orders for the MD-11s and 251 overall. American has options on an additional 301 jets. The route expansion announced Monday will give American, the nation's No. 1 carrier, 2,300 daily flights. Besides the Newark-Los Angeles flights, the expansion includes the first commercial service at Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and daily non-stop service between Miami and both Newark and New York's Kennedy Airport. ``These are steps that will allow us to enhance our schedules in many important domestic markets and give added strength to several of our hubs,'' said Donald J. Carty, American's executive vice president. Other flights will be added at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, Chicago O'Hare Airport and Raleigh-Durham International Airport. American is based in Fort Worth.

DOC.HEAD: White House: `Room to Talk' on Rostenkowski Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4-6: ``We think,'' with quotes from Darman, Rostenkowski; SUBS 14th graf: ``Rostenkowski proposed,'' to CORRECT that his 33 percent rate is not a new maximum but extends the current ``bubble'' to all upper income taxpayers; on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Monday that there's ``room to talk'' about a far-reaching budget plan by Democrat Rep. Dan Rostenkowski that calls for higher taxes and a one-year Social Security freeze. However, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president's decision to consider the radical proposal by the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee doesn't mean he's abandoning his oft-stated opposition to new taxes or Social Security changes. ``We don't want to pour too much cold water on a plan we may want to swim around in for a while,'' Fitzwater said. ``We think he deserves a lot of credit for a courageous plan, a courageous initiative, a serious initiative,'' White House budget director Richard Darman said on the Public Broadcasting System's ``MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour.'' Appearing on the same program, Rostenkowski acknowledged that his proposal contained ``some political minefields,'' but added that his plan's appeal was that it called for sacrifices from everyone. ``I think you're going to get some positive responses from it if we all get in the water together,'' he said. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., called Rostenkowski's proposal a ``good step'' and said its across-the-board spending freeze ``makes a great deal of sense.'' ``His proposal could be the wake-up call we've been waiting for,'' Dole said in a statement. ``We'll see who answers it.'' On Capitol Hill, Rostenkowski spokesman Jim Jaffe welcomed the plan's unexpectedly warm _ and apparently orchestrated _ reception from the administration and Dole. ``Let's do it,'' he said. Still, Rostenkowksi's proposal, unveiled over the weekend, has generated little support from his own party. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., called Rostenkowski's plan ``a very interesting suggestion,'' but questioned its chances of approval unless the White House supports it. ``I don't see a way we can effectively pass tax legislation raising taxes without the approval of the president,'' Foley told a reporter. ``That remains a problem.'' Rostenkowski proposed chopping the federal deficit through a combination of spending cuts; extending the maximum income tax rate of 33 percent to all upper-income taxpayers instead of reducing to 28 percent above a certain ceiling as is now the case; higher taxes on gasoline, liquor and cigarettes; and a one-year freeze in most federal spending programs including Social Security. The goal is to reduce the annual budget deficit by 1994. It would do away with the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law and its graduated steps for balancing the budget. ``We think there's some room to talk,'' Fitzwater said. ``It weaves a new pattern that needs to be considered at least.'' In the past, the administration has been quick to denounce Democratic plans that advocated either tax increases or a change in the Social Security formula. Rostenkowski's plan would do both. There has been speculation about a grand compromise between the White House and the Democratic-led Congress for reducing the budget deficit, one that would embrace tax increases as well as constraints in the growth of Social Security and other so-called entitlement programs. Fitzwater would not characterize Rostenkowski's plan in such terms, but said: ``We want to consider this plan. The chairman of the Ways and Means Committee is certainly a very important figure. This is the first comprehensive and thoughtful kind of plan we've seen.'' Fitzwater shrugged off a suggestion that the adminstration's posture _ formulated by Budget Director Richard Darman _ was designed to put Democrats on the side of raising taxes and freezing Social Security benefits while allowing President Bush to take credit for deficit reduction. ``Never crossed my mind,'' Fitzwater said. Rostenkowski, Jaffe said, ``is used to playing the role of the bad guy'' and that if takes that to win serious consideration of the plan, then so be it. On the issue of taxes, Fitzwater said: ``Our general attitude is, the less taxation the better.'' Asked if that represented a retreat from Bush's no-new-taxes proclamations of the past, Fitzwater said: ``I'm not signaling any action on our part except to say this gives us a basis for discussion.'' Rostenkowski, of Illinois, contends a 1991 freeze in Social Security benefits and other government programs coupled with new taxes on cigarettes, alcohol, gasoline and the wealthy could reduce the deficit by more than $500 billion over the next five years and produce a balanced budget by 1994. The one-year freeze on Social Security benefits would affect about 39 million Americans. Rostenkowski did not specify how much he would raise gasoline, tobacco and alcohol taxes, other than to say they could provide a total of $100 billion in new revenues over the next five years. But he said in a television interview Sunday that he envisioned the federal tax on gasoline rising from the current 9 cents a gallon to 20 cents or 25 cents. Dole, speaking to the National Association of Federal Credit Unions, said there were parts of Rostenkowski's plan he disliked, but praised the general concept and applauded the one-year-freeze on programs. ``It's got to be everybody. No exceptions. No big interest groups get off the hook,'' Dole said. ``I think it makes a great deal of sense.'' In remarks on the House floor, Rep. Fortney Pete Stark, D-Calif., a member of the Ways and Means panel, offered support. ``It's a challenge to all of us in government,'' Stark said. ``It asks whether we're serious about getting the deficit down, and it asks whether we're ready to abandon the blue smoke and mirrors that have obscured the facts in this debate previously.''

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Offers Reward as Another Bus is Shot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with Currey flying to Miami; SUBS grafs 23, `Currey said...,' to end with 12 grafs to ADD details on Miami visit, New York judge upholding ruling barring Greyhound from hiring non-union workers; no pickup; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Greyhound bus in Connecticut was hit by sniper fire Monday and the chairman of the strike-crippled bus line offered a $25,000 reward for information about a weekend shooting in Florida that injured eight passengers. ``We will not bend or move because of intimidation and violence,'' Greyhound Chairman Fred G. Currey insisted before boarding a Greyhound bus from Jacksonville to Orlando, Fla., then taking a plane to Miami. No one was injured in the Connecticut shooting, which occurred on Interstate 84 shortly before 11 a.m. as a New York-to-Boston Greyhound bus headed into Hartford with 19 passengers. Passengers reported hearing a small pop that some thought was a blown tire. Police recovered a bullet from the baggage compartment on the driver's side, and were trying to determine the caliber and type of gun used, said state police spokesman Adam Berluti. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions disavowed responsibility for the Florida shooting, but a union spokesman in Hartford said he believed the Connecticut shooting was motivated by the strike against the only nationwide bus company. ``I would say it's probably strike-related because I have been driving for 17 years and was never shot at,'' said spokesman Charles True. However, pickets in Hartford denied that union members were responsible. The union, which represents 6,300 drivers and more than 3,000 office and maintenance workers, went on strike March 2. There have been scattered violent incidents since, including a striker crushed to death by a bus operated by a replacement driver in Redding, Calif., and shots fired at buses in Chicago and Phoenix. Currey, Greyhound's chairman and chief executive officer, and Frank Schmeider, its president, flew to Jacksonville early Monday from Dallas after learning of the Florida shooting. The eight passengers were hurt when someone fired a bullet through the front of a Greyhound bus Sunday night in south Jacksonville. The passengers were injured by fiberglass and shrapnel. When asked if he thought the shot had come from a striker, Currey said: ``I pray that it is not true. I hope that it is not true. I do not want to believe that anybody involved in Greyhound would do such as thing.'' The two executives visited the three passengers still hospitalized Monday. Five others were released after hospital treatment. They also visited bus riders who were put up by the company in a Jacksonville hotel overnight. One hospitalized passenger, Michael Rogers of Atlanta, was critical of the company: ``I don't think they should run their lines while they're having a situation like this going on. Or at least warn the general public that a situation like that might occur.'' In Orlando, Currey criticized union leaders for not speaking out against intimidation. ``Their silence is deafening,'' he said. Asked why he rode the bus, he said: ``I took the trip because I thought it was important for Greyhound people not to be intimidated.'' An executive board member of the Jacksonville union local said he didn't believe strikers were behind the shooting. ``As far as I'm concerned it wasn't one of our strikers,'' said Bill Nicholson. ``They've been like choirboys.'' Sheriff's spokesman Steve Weintraub said Monday there have been no arrests in the shooting, and added that the possibility that the shot came from a striker ``is one of the leads we are following.'' The latest violence came as federal mediators in Washington, D.C., met for three hours Monday for ``an exploratory, informal meeting'' with union officials. Jim Power, a spokesman for the Federal Mediation Service, said the union ``agreed to the possibility of additional meetings with the mediation service and management to start the collective bargaining process again.'' Greyhound said executive Vice President P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound's chief negotiator, would meet Wednesday with the head of the mediation service, Bernard DeLury. The company said it expected DeLury to present his recommendations for ending the strike. Negotiations on a three-year contract broke down March 1 and the two sides have had ony sporadic telephone contact since. In Miami, Currey said he was pessimistic about prospects for a settlement of the strike soon. ``We made a very, very fine offer to the Greyhound Amalgamated Council. They shouted it down, just as those men are shouting on the street,'' he said, pointing to pickets outside. ``We will not raise fares to meet the exorbitant demands of the drivers.'' Currey later walked outside the terminal, embraced several pickets and tried to answer questions about the company's position. There was emotional arguing, but the discussion remained peaceful. A picket who didn't give his name said Currey ``had a lot of guts'' for speaking with the strikers. In another development in New York City, a state judge upheld a temporary restraining order barring Greyhound from hiring non-union workers to replace strikers, said Amalgamated Union Local 1202 President Harold Mendlowitz. The judge scheduled a hearing for Thursday to determine whether to issue a permanent injunction. ``New York City is a major hub of operations for Greyhound,'' Mendlowitz said. ``If we can stop them here, it will have a significant impact for our strike nationwide.'' Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale disagreed on the ruling's effect. ``It does not have a major impact nationwide,'' Hale said. ``We're hiring permanent replacements across the country and putting people back to work who return to their jobs.'' Greyhound, which serves 9,600 U.S. communities, said it has restored service to an additional 120 communities that lost regular runs when the strike began. Hale said 48,454 passengers rode 1,876 buses on Sunday. The number of passengers amounted to 35.8 percent of the same day last year while departures were 33.3 percent. The average load was 25.8 percent, 7.4 percent higher than last year.
